TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Knowles (from 19 citizens) and Senator Patterson (from 165 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: ANU and CSIRO: Fellowships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

1.Many Australians agree with the stated aim of the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship, namely to encourage the return of world class expatriate researchers, to support high quality research and to develop research skills fundamental to the nation's national interest with the aim of boosting Australia's research and technology push.
2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship continue to be tenable at the Institute of Advanced Studies of ANU and CSIRO.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: This humble petition is from the undersigned citizens of Australia. Each signatory has read the Holy Scriptures and accepts the authority of God's word as contained therein. Common ground is found in belief on, and submission to the Lord Jesus Christ.

Your petitioners are regular in their prayerful support of government. They are, however, deeply concerned that the Family Law Act does not allow adultery as a ground for divorce. Your petitioners have carried this concern for many years. The Lord Himself in Matthew's Gospel chapter 19 verse 9 said, "Whosoever shall put away his wife except for fornication, and shall marry another, commits adultery and whosoever marrieth her which is put away committeth adultery". The Family Law Act is therefore in direct conflict with the Lord's words.

Your petitioners as in duty bound pray and ask the Honourable House, that Parliament will accept its responsibility before God and cause that adultery be included in the Family Law Act as a ground for divorce.

PETITION.TITLE: Antarctica: Huskies
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is no scientific evidence which shows that huskies are:
1.A threat to Antarctica's fauna including seal and penguin colonies.
2.Linked to disease among other animals in the region.
3.Disease carriers because of a failure in the strict quarantine methods used when introducing a new dog.
4.Inferior to fuel driven vehicles in terms of efficiency of transport and impose greater damage on the environment compared to fuel driven vehicles.
Australia's signature on an international agreement will end a significant Australian tradition of using husky dogs in Antarctica by requiring the removal of all huskies presently in Antarctica.

Recognising that since 1898 huskies have supported Antarctic expeditions, have continued to be of value to scientists carrying out research and are an intrinsic part of the Australian presence in Antarctica your petitioners call upon the Government to reverse its decision concerning the huskies in Antarctica and allow them to remain in Antarctica.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate notices of motion Nos 1 and 2 standing in my name for two sitting days after today for the disallowance of the Export Inspection (Charges Collection) Regulations (Amendment) as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 251, and the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Regulations (Amendment) as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 249. I seek leave to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 October 1992, I reported to the Senate on the Committee's concerns with these regulations, which related to review rights and to the level of fees. The Minister for Resources, Mr Alan Griffiths, has provided the Committee with information which satisfied our concerns. The Committee is grateful for this cooperation from the Minister. As is the usual custom, I seek leave to incorporate the Committee's correspondence in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 17 September 1992
The Hon. Simon Crean, MP
Minister for Primary Industries and Energy
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT
Dear Minister

I refer to Export Inspection (Service Charge) Regulations (Amendment) (Statutory Rules 1992 No. 249) and Export Inspection (Charges Collection) Regulations (Amendment) (Statutory Rules 1992 No. 251), which the Committee considered at its meeting of 17 September 1992.

In respect of Statutory Rules No. 249, the Committee notes the provision in new regulation 6 (inserted by regulation 5.1) for three-level progressive increases in charges for exemption from the requirements of Export Control Orders in a 12 month period. There is no indication whether any of the three levels reflects the actual cost of processing of the applications. If not, the Committee is concerned that the imposition of a graduated scale of charges for exercising what is a right conferred by legislation is in the nature of a penalty and may breach personal rights or impose liabilities.

In respect of Statutory Rules No. 251, the Committee notes firstly that new regulation 2B (inserted by regulation 5.1) provides for the payment of charges. The Explanatory Statement mentions that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service will generally require payment in advance or at the time of the service `for all but regular clients with a good record of payment on time'. This relaxation may be reasonable in business terms, but it is a valuable financial concession and there is no reference in the Explanatory Statement to there being any opportunity to challenge the exercise of this apparent discretion.

Secondly, regulation 6 (see regulation 11.1) is omitted and, as the Explanatory Statement states, `AQIS will not refund charges in the future'. No explanation is offered for this change to the rights of clients.
Thirdly, there is a reference in the Explanatory Statement (under the explanation of regulation 2B) stating that:
`regulation 2B(2) provides that no refund of this charge is to be made regardless of the outcome of the application'.
Regulation 2B(2)is not in the regulations available to the Committee. There appears to be only regulation 2B without any division into subsections.
Finally, the regulation inserted immediately before regulation 2B is numbered regulation 2A(1) even though it, too, has only one subsection.
The Committee would appreciate your comments on the matters raised.
Yours sincerely
Stephen Loosley
Chairman
12 November 1992
Senator Stephen Loosley
Chairman
The Senate Standing Committee,
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Loosley

I refer to your memorandum ac/1/2104 dated 17 September 1992 to the Hon Simon Crean, MP, Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in which you raised a number of queries relating to the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Regulations (Amendment) (Statutory Rules 1992 No. 249) and Export Inspection (Charges Collection) Regulations (Amendment) (Statutory Rules 1992 No. 251). As the matters raised in your letter fall within my responsibilities as Minister for Resources it has been referred to me for reply.

Dealing firstly with Statutory Rules No. 249, the three tier charges imposed under the new regulation 6 reflect, as accurately as is practicable, the actual costs incurred by AQIS in processing such requests from export establishments as follows—

PARA.TAB: i.Generally, infrequent users of the exemption provisions generally require consideration of matters peripheral to the regulation of export products, such as printing errors on labels, broken seals on export containers, etc. Consequently, such matters can generally be processed by relatively junior officers within regional offices. Such checks as are conducted in these cases are minor in nature and are only required in order that should the request be repeated for future consignments, the legitimacy of the application and the wider policy issue can be considered. Consequently, in the costing of this exercise, these latter costs are seen to be more appropriately attributed to regular users of the provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: ii.Where export establishments utilise the exemption provisions more than once in any 12 month period, it becomes necessary to raise the issues as policy matters regarding both the appropriateness of the Order from which exemption is sought, and the bona-fides of the requests being lodged as departures from that regulation. On that basis, reference to AQIS Senior Regional Management, and to Canberra Office (Head Office) subject experts is required, and consequently, the costs to AQIS of processing these requests is correspondingly more per half hour.

iii.In those comparatively rare cases where export establishments routinely utilise the exemption provisions in the production of product for the export market, the highest level of individual scrutiny of the issues raised is necessary, requiring the frequent involvement of Senior Central Office Program Managers on technical and policy implications and of Regional Management in the policing of the determination. In addition, accrued costs incurred by AQIS under (i) above are considered to be entirely attributable to this class of operator, and have been included in the costing accordingly.
On that basis, it can be seen that the graduated scale of charges validly reflects AQIS costs of processing requests for exemption from the provisions of the Export Control Orders.

Furthermore, it needs to be clarified that such exemptions are not a right conferred by legislation. Rather they are a discretion to be exercised by the Secretary in limited and defined circumstances. In the event that the applicant is dissatisfied with the Secretary's exercise of that discretion, recourse to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is available.

Under Statutory Rules No. 251, the new Export Inspection (Charges Collection) regulation 2B was inserted by regulation 5.1 to enable AQIS to progressively develop its systems to emulate commercial practice. In this context you may know that from 1 July 1993 AQIS will be operating on a Group 2 Trust Account. This move will require AQIS to employ full accrual accounting systems, including provisions for bad and doubtful debts. Clearly, the costs of such provision accounts will have to be passed on to AQIS' clients in the form of higher charges. AQIS' current proposal is to minimise such provisions by requiring payment at time of service or in advance if the cost of the service can be calculated. Although consultation with AQIS' clients and industry bodies will be taking place over the next six to eight months on this matter, early indications are that most will be in favour of such an approach. This is not surprising as the alternative would be a provision for bad and doubtful debts in the order of some $4 million per annum to be passed on to industry in higher charges.

Essentially, AQIS is looking to develop systems where payment in advance or at the time of service becomes normal practice, with payments by account only in those cases where payment in advance or at the time of the service cannot be administratively achieved. In the interim, payment by account, with a due date of the twenty-eighth day of the month following the month in which the service is provided (as under the previous provisions of the Collection Act) continues to be the predominant mode of collection.

The development of policy for the equitable administration of debt collection and credit facilities will, as is indicated above, proceed in the closest consultation with industry, and in the recognition that decisions of AQIS management in this connection are subject to review through various mechanisms, but notably under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

In response to your query regarding the omission of Regulation 6, achieved by regulation 11.1, the provision for refunds was eliminated for a number of reasons. AQIS registration charges are predominantly calculated to cover the costs of infrastructure services, including the negotiation of conditions of access to overseas markets for products which are almost without exception seasonal commodities. Consequently, the charge represents a fixed cost for services which are utilised by the industry principally during the operating season, but also throughout the year in the form of advice regarding maintenance, refurbishment and other matters during the `off-season'.

The application of the then Regulation 6(1) resulted in an increasing trend for operators to only maintain registration during the period in which they required inspection services at their establishment, that being the only time when registration is legally obligatory. Notwithstanding their de-registration and associated refund, such operators would continue to call upon AQIS advisory services in various capacities, and re-register immediately before the next season. This trend, and the refund provision generally were diametrically opposed to the nature of these charges as a fixed cost in any financial year and, if allowed to proceed unchecked, would have either eliminated the Registration Charge as a meaningful avenue for meeting AQIS infrastructure costs or, would have required substantial increases to the charge to allow the relevant costs to be covered by revenue generated during the peak season for each of the industries involved.

Regulation 6(2) on the other hand, was considered to be dysfunctional: firstly, if the rate for the following year were to fall, the regulations provided that a refund was payable in respect of those months of registration left to run on the date on which the new charge became effective. No corresponding provision was made for additional amounts to become payable in those cases where the rate for annual registration rose. Secondly, the provision acted as a distinct disincentive to the reduction by AQIS of Registration charges since any reduction must be determined so as to allow not simply for the reduced AQIS costs to be covered, but also the amounts to be refunded to operators of establishments.

The reference to Regulation 2B(2) in the explanatory notes is a regrettable administrative oversight resulting from the progressive development of the explanatory notes as versions of the new regulations were produced by the drafter.

Similarly, the Office of Legislative Drafting in the Attorney-General's Department has advised that the inclusion of the superfluous subregulation number in respect of regulation 2A(1) was an editing error that occurred in that office.

I trust that the above information adequately addresses the Committee's concerns regarding the recent amendments made to the legislation governing the imposition and collection of the various export inspection charges.
Yours sincerely
Alan Griffiths

TALK.START.PARA: —The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1992 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill 1992, which are before the Senate for continuation this morning, cover diverse areas of taxation law. The annual Medicare Levy Amendment Bill continues the usual practice of increasing the income threshold under which taxpayers are exempt from the levy. We support this Bill.

PARA.TAB: The other matters are the proposed reform of the taxation arrangements relating to superannuation, the partial removal of the exemption which applies to car parking fringe benefits, and some amendments to the child support legislation. The fringe benefits tax proposals have caused some debate in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some!

—It depends where one's vested interest is, Senator Watson. Fringe benefits tax is a relatively recent tax which seeks to increase the equity of the tax system by identifying fringe benefits which are provided by employers to their employees, benefits which are not subject to tax in the hands of the employee. Fringe benefits tax is imposed on the employer who provides the benefit, hence it is technically paid by the employer. However, in practice the true incidence falls on the employee because the employer takes into account any fringe benefits tax liability which is generated by the provision of fringe benefits—
—Superannuation.

—and the other areas of the employee's salary package are varied accordingly—just like superannuation, as Senator Kemp says. So it is generally not accurate to say that an increase in FBT slugs employers. It is not accurate to say that, although, of course, in some situations it may. Despite all the protestation from the Opposition benches, fringe benefits tax is a fair tax—I am talking about the tax in principle—because it seeks to ensure that non-cash benefits are taxed in an equivalent manner to cash benefits. There is currently a structural problem which arises because the fringe benefits tax rate is different from the company tax rate, which still means fringe benefits are concessionally taxed relative to cash benefits. There is another Bill before the Senate to correct that problem, and I will deal with that issue more fully during the debate on that legislation.

PARA.TAB: When the fringe benefits tax was introduced and vehemently opposed by the coalition, certain matters were exempted, and one of those was car parking benefits. There are two types of benefits. Firstly, there is the direct provision of a parking space by an employer, and this can be either on site or off site in a commercial parking station. Secondly, the employer can provide an `expense reimbursement fringe benefit' whereby the employer reimburses the employee for the car parking costs, which are first paid by the employee. In both those instances the employee obtains a valuable benefit in a tax advantaged manner relative to employees who have to pay for their own parking out of their after-tax salary or wages. So the Government is arguing that removing the exemption is a matter of tax equity.

I think there is some merit in that argument although, to be totally consistent, the existing exemptions should be completely removed. But that is not what the Government is proposing. The exemption is being removed only when the following conditions apply: where the vehicle is the employee's or the employer's, or is leased by either person and is used by the employee to commute to work; where a permanent commercial car park is available for all-day parking within one kilometre of the employer provided facility; where the parking is for more than four hours between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m.—this is apparently structured to try to exempt some shift workers who may not have reasonable public transport services available and to exempt short stays by employees who subsequently use their vehicles, for example, in the case of couriers; and where the car is parked at or in the vicinity of the employee's workplace. I gather that this final provision is included to ensure that no liability arises when the parking is not connected with commuting to work; for example, if an employee visits another office of the employer or of a client and uses a parking space provided by the employer.

The major complaints from the business and professional community concern the administration of this proposed impost. There are claims that the one kilometre test, in particular, will be very difficult to administer and will lead to anomalies in the incidence of the tax. Those employers who have been forced by planning laws or decisions to provide parking facilities claim that the tax burden will fall on them unfairly. There is also the further question of whether some employers should be specifically exempted because of the possible flow-on consequences to those employers. An example is the impact that may be felt by some schools and some hospitals. These arguments will be further examined in the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

The other relevant point that can be made on this issue and that has not been canvassed by the Opposition is the ecologically sustainable development angle. Honourable senators might be aware that the ESD working groups recommended that the exemption be removed. This was based on the principle that the FBT was unintentionally providing a substantial subsidy to those who commuted to work by private vehicles. If an employer pays an employee's public transport fares for travel to and from work or reimburses the employee in respect of that travel, FBT will be payable on the full amount of the subsidy yet, if parking benefits are provided, no FBT will arise. That is clearly a subsidy structure which will work against sustainable development. So there are both environmental and equity considerations that have to be considered by the Senate.

The major matters in the cognate package of Bills are the changes proposed by the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill, which proposes massive changes to the tax regime that applies to superannuation in this country. The Bill is proposing to legislate the changes announced by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in his `Security in Retirement' statement of 30 June this year. The Bill has been referred to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and will be considered in detail this evening. The most controversial proposal in this package is the immediate termination of the personal deduction provisions for supported employees. Currently an employee who obtains employer superannuation support, because of an industrial award only, is allowed to obtain a tax deduction for personal contributions made to a fund up to a limit of $3,000. The Commonwealth has, quite properly, encouraged people with inadequate levels of employer sponsored superannuation to top up their entitlements.

We can all remember Mr Keating calling on Australians to take up this challenge when he increased the deduction from $1,500 to $3,000 just a few years ago. So many Australians did listen; they did decide to take out top-up policies. They knew that they had not had sufficient capacity to save in previous years and here was a golden opportunity to provide themselves with an adequate retirement income. Where they exercised their option simply to contribute personal contributions to award funds or to employer sponsored funds, this proposal could be justified as the particular employees would not be disadvantaged by ceasing to contribute.

However, there are many tens of thousands of Australians who took out specific personal superannuation policies. These are binding contractual arrangements which obligated people to contribute for many years. The main benefit of the policy is the up-front deduction which is now being terminated. As Senator Watson pointed out last night, unfortunately it was terminated out of the blue with, as I understand it, 24 hours notice. This is one of the matters that will be examined in the Select Committee, as will the aspect of the penalties which apply to fund members who cease making contributions.

I do not think that the Government can justify not only completely reversing a policy which was so important just a few years ago, but also imposing a further cost on policy holders by forcing them to discontinue contributions and hence be slugged with some huge penalties taken from the existing balance in the fund. I understand that we have a compulsory regime now. If there is a legislative compulsory regime obviously people do not need to be given incentives, but in the short term we really do need to give people an incentive to top up. The SGC is important. It will become the dominant retirement income, but the SGC alone will not provide anything like an adequate financial base for retirement for some decades to come.

In the meantime, there must be reasonable top-up provisions. The Government has recognised this by allowing incredibly generous employer contribution limits depending upon the age of the employee concerned. Those over 55 will be entitled to receive $62,000 per annum in employer contributions. So for those with compliant employers there is the option that the employer take over the contributions and the tax benefit will simply be retained by way of a salary sacrifice arrangement. That is now happening; managers and high income earners are in the position to make such arrangements but low income earners who have little industrial muscle will lose their tax deduction, although some may qualify for the revised rebate arrangements.

This measure will have regressive effects in that higher income earners will simply enter salary sacrifice arrangements. That will tend to erode some of the claimed revenue savings of $230m per year that the Government is hoping it will raise. I think the sensible way through this is to have some sort of phase-out arrangements so that the concessions are reduced at the same time as the SGC contributions are increasing. There are many people in their forties and fifties—probably the age group of most people in this chamber at the moment—who should be allowed to save for their retirement under the current law. They should not be targeted and penalised.

The second issue I wish to mention is the reform of the RBLs. It could be argued that this is a politically motivated decision on taxation. We have a virtually unique situation in Australian history where the coalition has committed itself to a radical alteration of the tax regime applicable to superannuation. It proposes to tax all contributions so as to equalise the tax benefit that each dollar of contribution earns. Also a flat rate RBL limit of $300,000 is proposed, and the coalition seeks to increase the tax on earnings from 15 per cent to 20 per cent. We think that the total effect of that package would be quite progressive and it would also raise substantial amounts of revenue.

One would have thought that the Labor Party would have seen that policy as something of a godsend, but instead of being an opportunity to be seen as making the tax system fairer, this has become an opportunity for the Government to, in my view, continue to favour a more regressive tax regime on superannuation. Whilst the broadening of the income tax base achieved by Mr Keating has generally increased equity, this has been more than offset by the failure to increase the exemption threshold and the very large cuts in the higher tax rates and extravagances such as the imputation system.

This RBL decision continues that trend because, whilst the flat rate system is touted as a great reform, the very high lump sum limit of $400,000 and the doubling of that amount where at least half of the benefit is taken as a pension or an annuity in fact mean that the potential tax concession has been greatly increased from the current arrangements. Realistically, what sort of people and how many will be able to accumulate anything like $400,000 for their retirement? Not many average workers will exceed that threshold. How many people will reach $800,000? Very few, I would think. So the net effect of this will be to allow managers and professionals to obtain higher superannuation benefits at the same time as battlers making contributions at the rate of $3,000 a year are being denied any income tax relief. I just do not think that reads like normal Labor Party equity policy.
These and other technical matters will be examined by the Committee this evening and will be further discussed in the remainder of the committee stage of this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—All the participants in this debate have had the complex task of covering a range of legislation dealing with different issues and setting priorities. I will try to reflect that in my comments and, to some extent, recognise that, because some of the most important matters before us will be pursued in another forum, they do not necessitate the same extensive response as the significance of the argument might warrant. I refer particularly to the superannuation matters, to which I will make only brief reference in these remarks to expedite the proceedings and to recognise the fact that we will be dealing this evening with the substance of those matters in the Select Committee on Superannuation.

PARA.TAB: In responding to the second reading debate and in thanking honourable senators for their contributions, I should also indicate formally, although the document has been circulated in the Senate, that the Government will be moving three amendments in the superannuation area and one page of minor amendments in the child support area. Those amendments have now been distributed but I formally indicate to the Senate their intention.

I expected the fringe benefits tax on car parking to generate the most heat, particularly from the Opposition. It has been the subject of a particularly skilled public relations campaign by an industry that has the capacity to pay very high fees to one of the top public relations agencies in Australia to mount the usual campaign for an industry that has a particular tax benefit and therefore knows that a big investment in public relations is worth doing if it means saving the tax benefit. I had a debate on radio with a representative of the car parking association and I said to him, `Tell me the alternative mechanism by which you think your industry should be taxed'. He said, `I do not think it should be taxed at all'. That is the core of the argument.

We are talking about some people who have a significant benefit and an industry that has capitalised that benefit to its profit, and it has mounted a very sophisticated public relations campaign seeking to defend their privilege. Those people have gone for the two classic techniques. Each time we try to amend the tax laws to take away from people, particularly those in privileged positions, that privilege, they have two techniques. The first technique is to conscript a few low paid examples one might find in isolated instances who may conceivably, by some interpretation of the Act, be involved and pretend that it is a debate about them, when we all know that it is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they have been affected, that is legitimate.

—Senator Watson knows that the rich always conscript the poor, and he always falls for it. The second technique is arguing complexity: `This is going to be so complex'. What they really mean is—and the core to it has been exposed by the car parking association—`Do not take away our little perk'. The answer is, `No, we will not fall for that'.

PARA.TAB: This is fundamentally about fairness in the tax system. The core concept of fringe benefits tax, the core concept that underpinned and provided the absolute justification—now accepted by the Opposition—for the fringe benefits tax, applies equally to this. All those people who purport to be defending simplicity when they are actually defending privilege are doing the same again. There are those who are consciously defending privilege and there are those who fall for the arguments every time. Honourable senators opposite may categorise themselves. I do not care which category they put themselves in; they are one or the other. I will bet that, if they ever get into office, they will never repeal this provision—ever. They will take the revenue and they will recognise the fairness. They will not touch it; they will come in here in the hope that some company will send them a big cheque for the election campaign, but they will not do a thing about it. Nor should they.

The core concept is right. It is exactly the same principle as applies to all these fringe benefits. The argument is quite simple. Yesterday I had to put this argument to my own constituents, who wished that they were not being affected. I had to say to them, `You will be and you should be'. That is not the world's most popular argument to put to people who, in the normal course of events, would be my supporters—and who I hope still will be. But the fact of it is this. If two people are paid the same salary for doing the same function and park next to each other in the building, and if one person's car parking is paid by the employer but the other pays it himself out of after-tax income, there is absolutely no argument against the idea that the person who is having that car parking paid for him is getting an enhanced after-tax income and a benefit from the employer as if he were getting higher income, and he should be taxed accordingly. It is the most straightforward of arguments.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the one that has no car park within a kilometre? What about a public hospital?
—If Senator Panizza wants to get excited about public—
—Senator Panizza, you are out of order.

—Thank you for your protection, Mr Deputy President. Senator Panizza is not only out of order, he is also wrong. I ask him to check the fringe benefits tax legislation. He will find that the interjection he makes is absolutely inapplicable to the circumstance. But if he wants to get excited about it, I invite him to do so. The fact of it is that it is fair and we are going to persist with it. I am absolutely confident that the Senate will carry it because it is fair.

PARA.TAB: The most amazing part of this second reading debate was that we had two senators come in here flabbergasted and astounded to find that one of the Government's motivations in introducing this Bill—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is to tax nurses.
—This poor ignoramus is in both the categories I referred to previously. Two people came in stunned to find that the Government has a motivation to raise revenue by this legislation—
—By taxing nurses.

—It does not apply to public hospitals, but the honourable senator should just not worry about it. The fact of the matter is quite simple: yes, it is a tax Bill; yes, it will raise revenue; and yes, that is important. It is absolutely important also that we raise the revenue in the fairest possible manner. We need to fund the services that we provide to the taxpayers in Australia. Notwithstanding the significantly misleading contributions by the Opposition, Australia remains one of the lowest taxed countries in the OECD—in the bottom two or three, depending upon the way you want to measure it. Of the 24 OECD countries, we come in at No. 22 or 23 in terms of the level of tax in Australia. So it is not that Australia is a relatively heavily taxed country. It is important that we continue the process of making our tax system fair. I will not shrink from that. People who get benefit, irrespective of their mode of employment, ought to pay tax on it.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the superannuation matter, as I said, it is the most important of these pieces of legislation, but I will not spend much time on it because we have a committee hearing this afternoon. The legislation implements the security and retirement statement which had the valid principles of providing people with certainty and making a fairer tax regime. It has to be looked at in the context of the package of measures of which it is a part, and particularly in the context of the superannuation guarantee charge. That is the mechanism that drives the fairness of the package as a whole and, particularly, the fairness of the package for low income earners and women. They are the people who are the beneficiaries of the superannuation guarantee charge. People cannot look at one element of a package in isolation. They have to look at the package and say that, taken in context, it is a very important reform.

The most striking criticism was that the Government was not being bold enough in reforming superannuation. That was made by Senator Alston last night. I have to say no-one ever pretends that the reforms they introduce are perfect, but I do not think history will judge this Government as having been weak in failing to address the issues of superannuation. Other people might say that we took the wrong course, and Senator Alston does. It is a legitimate debate that goes to the core question about voluntarism versus compulsion. I do not share his view but he is entitled to that. But to say that we have not been prepared to challenge and face up to the superannuation issue is extraordinary, when we are doing it for the first time after everybody knew for 45 years that it had to be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was Menzies who wrecked it.

—Yes; and a few other things. I welcome the fact that the Opposition is also trying to address the issue. I disagree fundamentally with the way it is trying to do it—at the core question of voluntarism versus compulsion—but at least the argument that we are not facing up to the issue will not stand up to scrutiny.

PARA.TAB: The last point I want to make is in relation to the child support legislation—in many ways, the least significant of the Bills, but one which needs a bit of consideration because we are to go to the committee stage straightaway. I have indicated the amendments that are outlined and I welcome the fact that there is general support for the provisions of the Bill and for the amendments which we have circulated. I understand the concern raised by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats with particular reference to the so-called averment. It is an issue that always causes concern to the Senate when it is raised. If it has the potential in its application to undermine the rights of citizens to fair trial and to reverse the onus of proof in a manner that puts the liberties of citizens at risk, it is very important that we give proper attention to this matter. In the committee stage when we come to deal with those clauses I imagine we will have an opportunity to look at some typical scenarios in which this might apply, so I will not duplicate that.

I do want to take some care to repeat the arguments that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) put in the letter to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee about this Bill. The argument is essentially summarised in the position put by the Treasurer on that occasion when he said he recognised the concern of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee concerning evidence by averment, but, of course, that related to a report on criminal proceedings. He said that the proceedings undertaken by the Agency are, of course, civil rather than criminal and would result in a pecuniary fine and not a gaol sentence. That does not totally do away with any concern but I think it changes the context within which it might be seen. Notwithstanding that, the intention behind the proposal to insert a provision in the child support legislation is one to allow the prosecution to aver fact only, and so assist the court and both parties in the carriage of any prosecution where the fact is or should not be disputed.

One of the problems we have had in the Child Support Agency is the delay in the effective discharge by the Agency through the courts of the prosecutions. Sometimes that delay is caused by errors at the administrative end, sometimes by the very nature of the case or the way it is handled by the courts, but sometimes it is caused by the complexity of the process—the complexity of the level of proof required for mundane matters of fact. This is ultimately connected to the ability of the Agency to collect support for children in single parent families which is, after all, what is driving the legislation.

The correspondence that I and, I am sure, other senators get is often to do with delays in the prosecution process—the frustration experienced when it is established or at least agreed, and is clearly the view of the Agency and the custodial parent, that there is an entitlement which is effectively not able to be enforced because of the delays in the court processes. This is one measure by which we can deal with that. We have always to balance the issues before us.

The explanatory memorandum states that the Agency, through the averment provision, does not wish to deny a person natural justice, nor can it. Nor does it want to do more under the proposed provisions than to state in the information that a particular matter is a fact—for example, a notice to obtain information was issued on a certain date or a final notice was issued on a certain date or a summons was issued on a certain date—because sometimes the requirements of the courts to prove that those things took place actually lead to significant delays. That is not because anyone is doing anything wrong; it is what the law currently requires. But those delays are not just technical matters; those delays have a profound effect on the living standard of children and custodial parents and frustrate the proper purpose of the Bill.

These types of matters are procedural and factual and they do not infer any type of conduct or intention by a defendant. It would be abnormal to mix matters of law and fact in an averment, in a child support prosecution, but the proposed provision states that, in the event that they were to be mixed, the averment is prima facie evidence of the fact only. Moreover, if the matter that is averred is challenged by the defendant—for example, if the defendant were to argue that a notice was not received—then the court must consider any evidence provided on its merits. It becomes a matter for the defendant and the prosecution to attempt to tip the scales in their favour. The evidence submitted will determine the outcome, and the value of that evidence is not affected by the averment provision. What we are seeking to do is simplify for the court the process of establishing fact in a prosecution when that fact should not be in question. To the extent that it is not challenged, the averment provisions will do that. But if a fact is challenged, normal processes will apply.

I went to some length about that matter, which is at its heart a minor issue compared with all the other matters before us, because, first of all, we are going to have to deal with it in a moment and, secondly, it is a minor issue with significant consequences for a number of people in need in our country. I hope, therefore, that we will be able in the committee stage to persuade the Committee that it should accept the proposals which have been put forward. I thank the Senate for supporting those elements of the package which it has supported and look forward to the speedy passage of the remainder after due debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. In answering an interjection of mine, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is at the table, claimed that I did not understand the Bill on car parking. I said that it was inequitable for someone working in a private hospital to be treated differently from someone working in a public hospital, even though that public hospital is within one kilometre of a public parking space. If the Secretary thinks that is equitable, I would like him to explain it.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to the order of the Senate of 12 November 1992, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill 1992 stands referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Admnistration for consideration and report by 14 December 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: CHILD SUPPORT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Clauses 1 to 37—by leave—taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 11, page 7, proposed Example 2, Step 3, omit "Mary owes Peter $1,831", substitute "Mary owes Peter $1,600".
(2)After clause 12, page 8, insert the following new clause:

PARA.TAB: "12A. Section 59 of the Principal Act is amended in the definition of `income amount order' by omitting from subparagraphs (a)(i) and (b)(i) `being an order' and substituting `or a determination under Part 6A (Departure from administrative assessment of child support), being an order or determination'.".

SPEECH.PARA: (3)Clause 18, page 10, proposed subsection 63A(1), line 15, omit "1 July 1993", substitute "30 June 1993".
(4)Clause 19, page 11, proposed paragraph 64A(1)(b), line 10, after "exceeds", insert ", by 10% or more,".
(5)Clause 31, page 15, after paragraph (a), insert the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(aa)in the definition of `appealable refusal decision' in subsection (1), by inserting in paragraph (c) `or 71A' after `71';".

SPEECH.PARA: (6)Clause 33, page 16, lines 3 and 4, omit "amended by omitting subsection (4)", substitute:

PARA.TAB: "amended:
(a) by omitting from subsection (3) `Subject to subsection (4), the' and substituting `The';
(b) by omitting subsection (4)".

SPEECH.PARA: (7)Clause 37, page 16, proposed paragraph 84A(1)(a), line 29, after "71", insert "or 71A".

The Government wishes to make a number of minor amendments to the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. There is a need to reflect the intention stated in the second reading speech to allow a 10 per cent tolerance between an estimate of income that has been used in a child support assessment and the actual taxable income assessed by the Commissioner of Taxation after lodgment of the income tax return before a penalty is imposed. The tolerance is consistent with the imposition of penalty in provisional tax cases under the income tax legislation where a 10 per cent tolerance also applies. This amendment will ensure that the tolerance applies at law rather than by administrative arrangement.

PARA.TAB: The Government wishes to include in the Bill another minor matter which has only just come to notice. Clients of the Child Support Agency may not elect to use an estimate of current year income in the assessment if there is an income amount order made by a court. This is to avoid the possibility of one party negating the outcome of a court order by simply electing to use an estimate of current income when the other party has taken the trouble to have a court review the assessment and an order changing an income amount in the assessment has been made.

Income amount determinations may also be made by child support review officers under part 6A of the Act. They have the same result as income amount orders made by a court and for consistency should be treated the same. The amendment will include income amount determinations and the definition of income amount orders.

There are five other minor corrections, including two consequential amendments, in the supplementary amendments. Details are in the supplementary explanatory memorandum. I commend the new inclusions and the other amendments in the Bill to the Committee. I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting these amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Clauses, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 38.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I outlined in my speech at the second reading stage, we have some major problems with clause 38. This involves averments. We argue that the Government simply has not given us a reason as to why it needs this provision, other than apparently it is going to be slightly easier to administer. Also, as I noted previously with regard to clause 38, there is no provision here to in any way restrict the use of the averment. It does not make here any reference to limiting the proposed averment to matters particularly within the knowledge of the defendant, and it does not restrict it to formalities or to the specific ingredients of the charge. Therefore, the Democrats will be opposing clause 38.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to say much more than I did in the debate on the second reading. I understand the concerns that honourable senators have. Every senator in the chamber has from time to time had concerns about these sorts of issues; essentially I made them the thrust of the argument in summing up the second reading debate. The only argument I would put in supplement is this: although the wording is capable of the interpretation Senator Lees puts on it, the Child Support Act and the nature of the prosecutions that might be taken under it actually do not raise the sorts of issues that potentially arise and cause the concerns that, for example, first motivated the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee when it started to raise the issue of averment. These issues have led to its being a consistent feature of Senate concerns since that time.

PARA.TAB: If one looks at the prosecutable offences under the Child Support Act, one would see that we are not really dealing here with the sorts of issues that might cause the concerns Senator Alston raised last night and which Senator Lees raised today and last night. I said in private conversation to Senator Alston last night that, if I thought the Bill meant the things which he raised and was consistent with those which Senator Lees raised, I would not support that clause either. It would not be in the Bill. That does not mean that I am right and others are wrong. They are entitled to their view and, if the Committee also has that view, I do not want to pretend that the legislation will collapse from want of this clause; it will not. What will happen is that some prosecutions, which through their successful conclusion might expedite payments to children and custodial parents with rights to that money, will take longer and sometimes may not be concluded at all.

Let us look at the nature of the offences. They include failure to provide information, or failure of an employer to deduct or remit or to provide information or to advise an employee or to keep appropriate records. They are summaries; they are not full descriptions of the offences, but those are the offences to which we are referring. People cannot be prosecuted under this for the sorts of serious offences that, for example, arise under the Crimes Act or the Income Tax Assessment Act where the concerns of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee that prompted this continuing concern might reasonably arise. This provision will only facilitate child support prosecutions, and it assists the court when the fact is beyond doubt.

The other point is that, where the facts are challenged, the amendment makes it clear that the averment does not have any special impact. For example, in the most common case, which is failure to provide information as requested, if there is an averment that a notice issued and it is challenged by the person, who says, `I did not receive it', the averment does not become the basis of establishing the argument. The Agency would have the normal obligations that apply at the moment to prove to the satisfaction of the court that that document did issue and it could reasonably be argued that it was received. So that is the circumstance in which this might be applied.

I do not want to take up the time of the Committee with undue debate. Everybody here understands the principles. It is an issue of some concern but not of earth-shattering importance. I accept that. I understand the concerns of Senator Alston and Senator Lees; they are proper concerns. We have them, but we think that, on balance, this is an appropriate circumstance for the facilitation of these relatively minor—but nevertheless significant to the individuals affected—offences where this averment provision should apply to facilitate child support prosecutions. I leave it in the hands of the Committee.
Clause negatived.
Remainder of Bill—by leave—taken as a whole, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition supports the Antarctic (Environment Protection) Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. The Bill amends the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980 to meet Australia's obligations under the Madrid Protocol prior to ratification. It makes provision for environmental assessment in the Antarctic, a new system of protected areas in the Antarctic, greater protection for Antarctic fauna and flora and their habitat, and the making of regulations providing for environmental impact procedures and for waste management and waste disposal. It also incorporates the provisions of the Antarctic Mining Prohibition Act 1991, with some amendments consistent with the Madrid Protocol, into the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly), in her second reading speech in the other place, repeated here, was discourteous enough to urge members of the Opposition to be equally as firm as the Government in their support of the legislation. That is the usual arrogant nonsense we expect from the Minister. There is no need for her to urge us to support this legislation. We initiated this move. That is why I must say that the prattlings of the Minister, which indicate that she considers herself to be the only political protector of the environment, are just so much phoney nonsense. I am glad to see Senator Bourne nodding her head in agreement.

For example, there is no acknowledgment in the Minister's press release of 15 October 1992 that the Opposition had any role whatsoever in supporting from the very beginning what this legislation is all about. That is typical and unfortunate. This is an area where there is bipartisan support, so there is no need for her condescendingly to urge members of the Opposition to be equally firm in our support of it, and I reject the general atmospheric from the Minister that the coalition has no interest in or concern for this area.

On the contrary: apart from the fact that we initiated this particular matter in opposition, when in government we have taken a consistently strong role in protecting the Antarctic. For over 30 years Australia has been one of 40 parties to the Antarctic Treaty, which has governed the activities of countries with claims on the Antarctic Territory or conducting activities there. The Treaty, by the way, had its origins in the Cold War and, with both the United States and the USSR as signatories, it played an important role in keeping Cold War tensions out of the area. In fact, the Antarctic Treaty of 1959 was a very important measure in which the Menzies Government was involved. It was a great milestone internationally and it was something that the Menzies Government was, quite properly, very proud of.

Following six years of negotiations with a regime that would have permitted mining in the Antarctic, in 1991 the Treaty parties signed a document known as the Madrid Protocol, which prohibits mining altogether. I repeat: this approach to prohibit mining was initiated by the Opposition, by the coalition in Australia, particularly by former Senator Chris Puplick. If anyone wants to go back to the record, they can see that, while Mrs Kelly was still flapping around about the Canberra Raiders, Senator Puplick was actively and effectively promoting the proposition that mining should be prohibited in Antarctica. I notice, however, that history has been rewritten and Mr Hawke is now the hero of this matter, although apparently a fairly fallen hero at the moment. Following the coalition's initiation, the Government decided in May 1989 not to sign the proposed minerals convention. Australia, supported initially by France, eventually persuaded the other Treaty parties to agree to the Madrid Protocol.

Since initiating the moves leading to the signing of the Madrid Protocol, the coalition has supported the Government's actions, with one exception, namely, the decision to summarily remove the huskies from the Mawson base this month. This Bill provides for their removal by 1 April 1994, in accordance with the provision in annexe 2 of the Protocol. The British have decided that their obligations will be met simply by stopping the further breeding of huskies in Antarctica and letting the existing dogs live out their natural lives there, in an environment they have known all their lives. We, in opposition, have urged the Government to follow the same procedure, but without success. I understand that the huskies are now in Minnesota.

This problem reflects the typical arrogance of the Government and this Minister because there is no clear, obvious need for these huskies to have been removed this month except for the Government's claimed commercial opportunity. According to the Government's chosen interpretation of the Protocol, there were 18 months to go before the huskies should be removed. As evidenced, the British have taken the view that they are meeting the requirements without having to send the huskies away from Antarctica. But is it not interesting the way the Minister uses words in a mischievous and misleading way? In her press release, Mrs Kelly interprets as appalling our proposal that they should stay there and follow the British position of, if necessary, not being allowed to breed and so on. She refers to statements by the shadow Minister for the environment, Mr Carlton, that Australia's huskies should be left in Antarctica to die. That is simply dishonest. They are to be left in Antarctica to live until they die.

I am, frankly, sick and tired of the politicising of this sort of issue by the Minister. It is a disgrace to use words in that phoney, crooked way. She says, `We have given the opportunity to let them live', as if our proposal were to kill them off—which is simply false and dishonest. So what is new from this Minister? According to her press release, Mrs Kelly said, `Given that the dogs must be removed'. If they `must' be removed, how come the British are not doing so? We find not only what she is doing but the manner in which she has done it to be unacceptable and unreasonable. It was for that reason that, when this matter was in the House of Representatives, we sought to amend the motion for the second reading of the Bill. We cannot do that now because it is a fait accompli. In the House of Representatives we moved:

That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House expresses its grave concern over the decision of the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories to remove the Mawson Bay huskies from their long term environment and to give them to a resort operator in the USA, and calls on the Minister to reverse this decision and follow the British example of allowing the dogs to live out their lives in the Antarctic".

SPEECH.PARA: That motion was defeated in the House of Representatives. I just want the Australian public to recognise that, despite the best endeavours by the coalition, the Government's normal authoritarian, dictatorial approach, as expressed through this Minister, was carried on.

PARA.TAB: The extent to which this sort of behaviour is unacceptable is evident from what the friends of the huskies have been conveying. As a community that describes itself as the Friends of the Polar Sledge Dogs, they have been making a strong case about this. For example, Mr Patrick Moonie, in a recent article saying that there is no sound environmental reason to remove huskies from Antarctica, says:

The Mawson huskies have been isolated in the pristine Antarctic working environment for 41 years and, with no record of acquiring, carrying or transmitting disease, it is ludicrous to suggest that they could start now. Similarly, there is no evidence that they have been a threat to wildlife and, with more stringent controls recently introduced, the incidence of threat is even more remote.

SPEECH.PARA: He states that, in 1988, a nationwide campaign for retention of the huskies in Antarctica—and I quote:

. . . resulted in an investigation by the then Minister, Senator Graham Richardson, who issued a statement that the huskies were not a threat to the environment and that there were no plans for their removal.
It is magic, is it not, the way that suddenly changed. He continues:
The Antarctic Division director, Rex Moncur, also stated that they were far better for the environment than any mechanical vehicle.
In his article, Mr Moonie states also:

PARA.TAB: More importantly, huskies are unquestionably the safest means of transport over the unpredictable and sometimes treacherous sea ice and heavily crevassed glaciers. During our Antarctic operations a large number of vehicles of all types have fallen through the sea ice . . . Other Antarctic nations have lost not only vehicles but men's lives also. To this day, we have not lost a dog team or attendant sledges.

SPEECH.PARA: On this matter, the Friends of the Polar Sledge Dogs give an outline of what the coalition has done to try to assist them. Regarding the time when the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) was the shadow spokesman for the environment, they say:
Mr Chaney wrote to Mrs Kelly and put this matter to her:

"Would you please provide me with any material produced either by Australia or by any other parties to the Protocol which may have been used as a factual base for the pressure to remove the dogs? If there is no such material and if the decision was taken purely on a subjective judgement it seems to me to weaken considerably the case for their removal.

Mrs Kelly's answer was a bureaucratic "Yes Minister" classic, claiming that the Protocol working papers were not available for public distribution! It now seems certain that there is no factual basis, either environmental or operational, to substantiate the removal of the huskies and that is probably the reason why the Minister has been so evasive in refusing to respond to correspondence on this issue.
The Friends continue:

Mr Chaney also questioned Mrs Kelly on whether any difficulties had been experienced by vehicles travelling over the Antarctic seaice, noting the exemplary comparative safety record of the huskies over the same terrain for the last 37 years. In reply, Mrs Kelly highlighted the amphibious function of Hagglunds vehicles and that they had experienced but "few difficulties". This blithely ignored the two Hagglunds (replacement cost $200,000 each) that sank through the seaice off Davis Station, one of which was subsequently salvaged and rebuilt at a cost of $90,000.

The Federal Opposition has serious reservations on the decision by the Government to remove the huskies and Senator Michael Baume (Liberal NSW) recently put a series of related questions to DASET and Antarctic Division at a Senate Estimates Committee hearing. There were some interesting concessions and admissions contained in the evidence, including the fact that no study has been done that would enable a comparative analysis of the viability of the huskies as a means of transport in the Mawson Station environment in Antarctica. The Secretary of the Department attempted to link the European seal virus with the Antarctic huskies. This hoary old chestnut was first thrown up in 1988 by fringe elements of the environmental movement and has since been thoroughly debunked by the scientific community. In 1988 the North Atlantic European Grey seals suffered a virus attack that killed several hundred. It was suggested that a canine virus was the cause and, by an amazing extrapolation, that canines (ie huskies) in the Antarctic might therefore wreak havoc with the Antarctic wildlife. An investigation by reputable scientific bodies established that the Grey seal deaths were due to a livestock virus causing rinderpest (cattle plague) and had no relation to any canine virus. . .
With the Government becoming increasingly intransigent and resorting to disinformation on the huskie issue it would appear that a review of the situation is only possible with a change of Government.
I must say it was very sensible of the Friends to recognise what sort of improvements one would get with a change of government. The Friends reported:

The Opposition is in favour of undertaking an Environmental Assessment Study on the Mawson huskies, using the procedures outlined in the Protocol specifically designed for such a purpose, in order to establish a position based on factual evidence and consistent with our international treaty obligations.
Of course, it is now all too late for that because, 18 months earlier than the Government claimed they had to go, they have been evacuated to Minnesota. As the Friends asked:
Is it an attempt to pre-empt a review by the Opposition, should they win government in the autumn of 1993?
I must say that, yes, I believe it was. I believe it was a deliberate attempt to prevent the Opposition reviewing this arrogant determination. As the Friends conclude:

The principal aim of our campaign is to retain the huskies in Antarctica, where they rightly belong because of the overwhelming evidence of their environmental compatibility, their better safety record than vehicles over particular terrain and the fact that they represent, more than anything else, the intrinsic ethos of our polar endeavours, their removal would thus constitute an act of gross historical vandalism. If the huskies must be removed from Antarctica then they must be retained as working teams in Australia, for to do otherwise would be an appalling indictment on the Government and an abrogation of our national heritage.

I conclude by saying that I should make it clear that the Bill as a whole is in line with the policy which the coalition suggested originally and which was taken up by the Government. It is in line with the actions of coalition governments in the past—for example, the Menzies Government in 1959 in entering into the Treaty, and the Fraser Government in 1980 in bringing down the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Bill. As a result, I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also welcome the Antarctic (Environment Protection) Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, which will enable Australia to be the second country in the world to ratify the Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty, known as the Madrid Protocol. It is gratifying indeed to be able to speak to a Bill on the environment which so clearly accords with Democrats policy and, indeed, with the policies of all parties in this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Madrid Protocol stands out as a shining example of what countries can achieve through international environmental diplomacy. It recognises the unparalleled wilderness and aesthetic qualities of Antarctica and its immense value as an area for the conduct of scientific research. It sets up procedures to ensure proper protection of the whole continent and prohibits mining in the Antarctic Territory. It recognises that the human impact must be contained and minimised in order to ensure that the earth's last pristine wilderness is preserved, not just for the benefit of all future generations but for its intrinsic value as an area of great beauty and its own worth.

Australia has taken a leading role in the preparation of the Madrid Protocol, reflecting the prominent role played by Australia in the history of Antarctica and in the development of the Antarctic Treaty. Australia is one of the currently 26 consultative parties to the Treaty, which came into force in 1961. The impetus for the Treaty is thought to be the International Geophysical Year, which involved scientists from many countries in research programs on that continent. The IGY was so successful that countries claiming sovereignty over parts of Antarctica were encouraged to settle their differences and develop a more cooperative approach to the use of that continent. The outcome of their efforts was the Antarctic Treaty, which included a stipulation that Antarctica should be used exclusively for peaceful purposes and not become the scene or object of international discord.

Since the development of the initial Treaty, a number of agreements have been reached which further the protection of the Antarctic environment and its biological diversity. These include the agreed measures for the conservation of Antarctic fauna and flora; the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Seals; a code of conduct for Antarctic expeditions and station activities; the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources; guidelines to evaluate the environmental impact of proposed scientific research programs; and sites of special scientific interest, which protects specified areas of research.

Despite these measures, the record of environmental protection in Antarctica has been poor. The International Whaling Commission has reported serious depletions in the populations of whales in Antarctic waters. The Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources was signed in 1977. However, by 1983 overfishing had caused dramatic reductions in a number of fish stocks. A number of Antarctic bases have failed to implement appropriate waste management plans, simply disposing of wastes into the surrounding environment; and in some cases severe localised damage has ensued.

Although the measures I have just outlined were important first steps, they failed to incorporate a whole systems approach to environmental protection. The Madrid Protocol reflects such an approach by seeking comprehensive protection for the environment. Australia's role in the development of the Protocol was absolutely pivotal, and it is something of which every Australian can feel very proud. For many years certain countries had harboured an interest in Antarctic mineral resources. In June 1988 the Antarctic Minerals Convention was adopted by a special Antarctic Treaty consultative committee in Wellington. The underlying assumption of the Treaty was that mining and environmental protection were compatible. The Exxon Valdez disaster proved that such an assumption is totally false. One cannot ensure, no matter what precautions are taken, that accidents will not happen. The risk of environmental damage is simply too high to allow mining activity to proceed in such a fragile environment as Antarctica.

To the relief of many Australians concerned about the prospect of mining, after considerable pressure from all sides of this Parliament, the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, announced on 22 May 1989 that Australia was opposed to mining in Antarctica and would not sign the Minerals Convention. He confirmed that Australia would pursue the concept of Antarctica as a wilderness park and would seek an extension of the moratorium on mining. France joined Australia's initiative. Other countries saw merit in the proposal, with the US finally falling into line in July 1991. The Protocol was finally signed in June last year.

The story of Australia's role in the development of the Protocol reveals how effective Australia can be on the international stage, provided the Australian Government is willing to take a strong and proactive role in international environmental negotiations. It is extremely disappointing to hear repeatedly these days how Australia's stature as an international leader in environmental affairs has diminished considerably. This is particularly obvious in ozone and climate change negotiations. Australia took a leading position at the 1990 London review of the Montreal Protocol. The Australian Government allowed a youth delegation to attend, which made an enormous impact on the tenor of the conference.

The next review is to occur later this month in Copenhagen, and I understand that Australia's policy position will simply reflect the UNEP line on so-called transitional substances, or HCFCs. Earlier this year the Government rejected amendments which the Democrats moved concerning the Ozone Protection Amendment Bill which could have ensured that Australia again took a leading role in the protection of the ozone layer.

The Government's weakening of its environmental resolve is also apparent on the domestic front. Most Australians now realise that the Government's commitment to the Toronto target was a political sweetener intended to win over concerned individuals and environment groups. The national greenhouse response strategy has been hijacked by bureaucrats and bears almost no resemblance to the consensus recommendations that arose from last year's ESD process. Incredibly, the bureaucracy believes that only cosmetic changes need to be made to the extremely weak draft that was released a few months ago.

However, I will not focus on the Government's failings in this regard. Along with the Opposition, I am delighted that the Government is seeing through a commitment to the comprehensive protection of Antarctica. The Protocol not only prevents mining for 50 years, whereupon the ban may be lifted with the agreement of at least three-quarters of the current consultative parties, but also sets out a list of procedures for environmental impact assessment, for the conservation of Antarctic flora and fauna, for waste disposal and waste management, and for area protection and management.
I should say a few words on the huskies in Antarctica. Article 4 of annex II to the Protocol states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dogs shall not be introduced onto land or ice shelves and dogs currently in those areas shall be removed by April 1, 1994.

The huskies are an exotic species in Antarctica. Although they provide friendship to many of the people living on the bases, they nevertheless pose a risk to the environment and to indigenous animals such as penguins and baby seals. Australia's strong position on environmental protection would have been compromised by allowing the huskies to remain there until they died from natural causes.

PARA.TAB: The only other countries to have huskies in Antarctica are the United Kingdom and Argentina. We understand that the UK is resisting the removal of the dogs and this may impede its ratification of the Treaty. This would in turn become an obstacle for the entry into force of the Protocol. It would be intolerable for Australia to adopt such a position, and it is to be hoped that the UK can be persuaded to alter its position. I understand that the huskies have now gone to a new home in Minnesota, where they will be kept together as working dog teams.

In conclusion, the Australian Democrats fully support this Bill to prohibit mining in Antarctica and to establish a comprehensive protection regime for the Antarctic environment. The Protocol is a landmark in international efforts to protect the global environment and Australia's speedy ratification will help to bring it into force. In taking the steps that we have, Australians have ensured that our children and our grandchildren will have the same opportunity as we have had to know that the earth's coldest, driest, windiest, highest continent still remains a wilderness, even if only a privileged few actually visit there. Just knowing that the integrity of Antarctica will be protected is a cause of deep satisfaction for all of us. The Democrats support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, support the Antarctic (Environment Protection) Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 but, in particular, I want to talk about the premature removal of the huskies from the Australian Antarctic Territory. My office is situated 100 to 200 metres away from where the Aurora Australis berths in Hobart, so I have a fair amount to do with the Antarctic activities of Australia. I have been very interested in this subject.

PARA.TAB: As has been stated by my colleague Senator Michael Baume, the Madrid Protocol on environmental protection of the Antarctic required that all huskies be removed from Antarctica by 1 April—April Fools Day, in other words—1994. We all know that the huskies have been an integral part of the Australian activity in the Antarctic. They were first used in Sir Douglas Mawson's Antarctic expedition of 1911-14 and they have been at the Mawson base since 1954. It seems that now, because Australia along with the other Antarctic Treaty nations has signed a document which panders to the radical elements in the environment movements, the huskies have had to go. They have gone, apart from a few that are too old to travel.

The irony is that the effect of the Protocol, which claims to protect the Antarctic environment, will be to place the pristine Antarctic environment under greater risk by increasing significantly the use of mechanical vehicles by expeditioners. As we are speaking here today, the Mawson huskies are on the move. In fact, 19 working dogs and three young pups left Antarctica on 4 November this year. They were moved very quickly, with not a lot of publicity. There was a fair amount of publicity in the local press in Hobart but not much anywhere else. They have headed off to Minnesota. The other six dogs that are still at Mawson were considered too old to travel. I guess most of us in this place will be feeling that way by the end of the session. I am led to believe that a decision on their future will be made at the end of 1993-94, if they are still alive. I mean the huskies, not us.

The huskies arrived in Hobart on Monday of this week. They were flown to Melbourne on Tuesday. I think they arrived in Los Angeles this morning. From there they will spend 3 1/2 days on a truck, travelling 3,500 kilometres to their new home. They are going to outward bound schools near Ely in Minnesota, which is about 35 kilometres south of the Canadian border, where dog sled teams are still used. That will be a long and totally unnecessary journey.

The decision to remove the huskies from Antarctica was based on two primary concerns. The first was that the huskies may introduce disease to Antarctica. The second was that the huskies may break free and attack penguin colonies. So what? Both of these concerns have been proved to be unfounded. Firstly, there has been no recorded instance of a Mawson husky acquiring, carrying or transmitting disease. They might have bitten a few of the handlers but they certainly have not done those sorts of things. In fact, after spending the past 40 years isolated in a virtual quarantine situation, it is practically impossible for the huskies to be infected with disease. They are more likely to be infected from the humans than to infect anybody else.

Secondly, there is no evidence that Antarctica's wildlife is threatened by the presence of the huskies. Reports of huskies breaking free from their leashes and attacking penguin colonies are very rare indeed, not only in regard to Australia but in regard to other Antarctic Treaty nations.
