In fact, the huskies are trained not to disturb wildlife, let alone to attack it. I read a very good article by a devoted former expeditioner to Antarctica, Mr Patrick Moonie, who was on television a couple of nights ago, pointing out the errors of the Government in making this decision. I think he made quite a good point when he said that, here we are, getting into bed with the French and saying that we have to do all the right things when, at the same time, the French are exploding nuclear devices in the Pacific and are actually bulldozing penguin colonies at their Antarctic station at Dumont d'Urville.

We are the only ones, we are the trendsetters, forced by other well-meaning nations, including France, to get our huskies out of Antarctica. In fact we are the only ones who have done so. I am sure that the decision to remove the huskies pleased the radical environmentalists, or the vociferous ill-informed lobby group, as Mr Moonie called them. These zealots, if they had their way, would have us all living in caves again. The decision angered most people, but the ones who were affected most by it were Australia's Antarctic expeditioners themselves. The dogs have been an integral part of the working of the Mawson base for the last 40 years. Their very presence has a very beneficial effect on the morale of the expeditioners, who are separated from their loved ones by a very great distance and who are living in an isolated and remote region.

If anybody should know it is Patrick Moonie, who was a member of five expeditions to Antarctica. He quite rightly pointed out the psychological factors of the huskies at Mawson. The huskies are of very great importance. They are the only objects upon which the personnel at this isolated outpost can lavish their affection. That may change now, of course, if we are to send troops down to Antarctica. I am sure that the decisions that have been made recently by the Government as far as homosexuals are concerned would mean that our expeditioners could lavish their affections on things other than dogs.

Nevertheless, I think most of us can understand how these expeditioners feel about losing these dogs. Only recently our family dog went missing. One of Duncan Kerr's staff found it for me and brought it back; I thought that was quite good of her. I was talking to Senator Brownhill only yesterday. His family dog drowned in the swimming pool, and I know the effect that has had on his family. I think we can all understand how the expeditioners feel about the premature departure from Antarctica of these wonderful animals. What I cannot understand is the rationale behind the decision to remove the huskies. They are the most efficient means of transport on the continent and they pose no threat to Antarctica's pristine environment.

When our colleague Senator Richardson was Minister for the environment, he issued a statement that the huskies were no threat to the environment and there were no plans for their removal. What has changed since then? Of course, what has changed since then is the Minister. The huskies are still the same but the Minister has changed. We now know that Mrs Kelly, the Minister, is one of the few Ministers in the history of this Parliament who, when it comes to a dispute, is able to upset every party in the dispute. The recent

SPEECH.PARA: Benders Quarry issue in Tasmania is one such example. It should be no surprise that she has made another poor decision in an attempt to canvass the green vote for the next election. However, what is surprising is the utter contempt shown by Mrs Kelly and her office to the supporters of the huskies in their attempts to discuss the issue with her. I note this article written by Patrick Moonie, where he says:

PARA.TAB: I am told that the Minister, Ros Kelly, has received more mail on the husky issue than any other matter, but she has resolutely remained mute to any entreaties and has refused to respond to, let alone acknowledge, correspondence, phone calls or our requests to meet a delegation to discuss the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously this is a political move—nothing more, nothing less. The removal of the huskies will downgrade the effectiveness of Australia's Antarctic operations. This is because their function will now be taken over by machines, which will be far more harmful to the environment. Rex Moncur, the Director of the Australian Antarctic Division, has stated in the past that the huskies are a lot less of a threat to the environment in Antarctica than any mechanical vehicle. But the same Rex Moncur, when he went to the meeting in Madrid, was obviously pressured by the Minister to agree to remove the huskies, and I am sure he would privately say that was a very grievous decision he had to make.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that the huskies have by far the best transport safety record in Antarctica. We know that many machines have been lost by Australia and other Antarctic nations and also that some men's lives have been lost, but Australia has never lost either a dog or any of its attendants. I do not think there is any doubt that this is due to the keen senses of the huskies, which can sense danger in a manner that people in vehicles are not able to. In fact, there have been several reported instances of huskies refusing to travel across icefields which have been found, upon further investigation, to be dangerously thin. If anyone saw the TV documentary the other night, the person being interviewed—and I think it was Patrick Moonie—actually quoted a case where the huskies refused to go on. After a lot of coaxing they still would not go on, and when people went forward and had a look they found that the ice was dangerously thin. It would have been a disaster if they had gone on. What is going to happen now when these teams go out with mechanical devices? They will not have the advantage of man's best friend there to help and save them.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been sledged into history.

—Senator Crichton-Browne is quite right: they have been sledged into history. The fact is that they have been taken away from Antarctica—and where have they ended up? In America. Why is that so? Is there not somewhere in Australia where we could keep these animals that have been so faithful not only to the Antarctic expeditioners but to our country? We should have some pride in the fact that those animals are the descendants of the animals that have been there for 40-odd years. But they were rushed off, bundled onto a truck, travelled 3,500 kilometres in 3 1/2 days—and they are going to end up in Minnesota. Surely something could have been done to put them to work, even in the Snowy Mountains near Canberra. I am sure that all who have been part of our Antarctic expeditions over the years would have loved to have known that the animals that they became so attached to were still residents of Australia.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I would have to say most strongly that the decision to withdraw the Mawson huskies from Antarctica is short-sighted, is based upon unsustainable premises and will be definitely to the detriment of Australia's Antarctic program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the observations that have been made by Senator Michael Baume and Senator Paul Calvert. Much of that which I would have said has been said by them, so I shall be ever so brief. I formally move:

PARA.TAB: At end of motion, add ``, while not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the Senate expresses its grave concern over the decision of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories to remove the Mawson Base huskies from their long-term environment and give them to a resort operator in the United States of America''.

SPEECH.PARA: This decision really epitomises the absolutely absurd nonsense which Mrs Kelly goes on with. There is no scientific, practical or logical reason why these dogs are required to be moved from the Antarctic. I asked Senator Collins, the Minister representing Mrs Kelly, whether there was any scientific evidence as to the impact that the husky dogs were having on the ecology of the Antarctic, and Senator Collins responded by saying:

While there is no scientific evidence available on the impact of the Mawson husky dogs on the Antarctic environment and the ecology, there have been numerous incidents of huskies killing penguins which have strayed too close to them or of the dogs breaking free and killing the wildlife.

That is absolute nonsense. We know that there is no risk of the dogs introducing disease because they have been born and bred and lived their entire lives in the pristine environment of the Antarctic, and there is no history of any Antarctic dogs being infected by disease or conveying disease. To suggest that they are in some way a hazard to the environment is an absolute nonsense. To talk about eating a few penguins that are dopey enough to waddle onto the dog line, as an explanation for removing the dogs, is absurd. Anyone who has been to the Antarctic would know that the penguin is not exactly an endangered species. There are literally millions of them in the Antarctic.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are bulldozing their nests at the French bases.

—As Senator Calvert reminds me, they are bulldozing their nests in the French bases, yet we have Mrs Kelly telling us that the whole Protocol would collapse if Australia refused to remove its dogs. It is interesting that the British have said they have no intention of removing their dogs and their dogs can live the rest of their lives in the Antarctic in the only environment that they know; the world actually will not come to an end and there will be no consequential collapse of humanity as we know it. The British have made it quite clear to the Australians that we can whistle.

PARA.TAB: The very reason that this particular aspect is incorporated in the Protocol is because of this lunatic fringe group of environmentalists who, as far back as the middle and late 1980s when there was no protocol, were insisting that the dogs be removed. I seem to remember reading that one of the Greenpeace women went to the Antarctic and from the bow of the ship she observed the scattered remains of a penguin that had ventured too close to the husky dogs. All she could see were a few feathers and lots of blood—the inevitable consequence of getting near one of these healthy and hungry dogs. From that day forward we have had a campaign being waged by these lunatics to remove man's best friend from the Antarctic.

History records the wonderful contribution that they have made. I think they were first used in the Antarctic in 1898; they were certainly used by Mawson in 1911. So they have been down there for well over 90 years and I think these particular dogs have been there since the mid-1950s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since 1954.

—It was 1954. So they have been down there for 40 years without being a danger to man, animals, the environment or the ecology; and they have made a magnificent contribution to science and scientific research. They are used every year for an excursion across the ice of some 300 kilometres to allow the expeditioners down there to undertake their scientific work. Mrs Kelly well knows that even under this Protocol the dogs were not required to leave, as Senator Calvert says, until 1 April 1994.
—April Fools Day.
—Yes; but we have moved the dogs. Mrs Kelly has moved the dogs out already and they are now winging their way at enormous expense to the taxpayers via Qantas to Minnesota.
—They are actually on a truck at the moment.

—On a truck, are they? There are two reasons for that. The first reason is that Mrs Kelly knows that the next Government, which will be elected in the first half of next year, will reverse the present decision. The other reason, I understand, is that the people who are taking the huskies have said that they will not take them any later than the end of this year, so that was the reason for the great rush to get rid of them.

PARA.TAB: As I say, there is no sensible, logical or scientific reason why the dogs should be removed. The Director of the Antarctic Division, Rex Moncur, is on record as saying that he has no wish to see them removed. There is no scientific evidence being proffered as to why they should be removed, but we have got this nonsense provision in the Protocol that insists that they be moved and so they have been. It is not sentimental to recall the close intrinsic relationship there is between the expeditioners—and there has been for 40 years—and the Antarctic dogs, and the fabulous contribution they have made to science. As far as I am concerned they are part of our living heritage in the Antarctic. I take it that the next step will be that Greenpeace will be moving to have it made a wilderness and all the expeditioners will be asked to leave the Antarctic as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I deal with the proposed second reading amendment to the Antarctic (Environment Protection) Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and with the issue of contention in this debate, I thank all senators for their resounding support for the fundamental principles, the big issues, that are involved. I do not denigrate the issue that is in contention, but quite clearly it is less significant than the major questions we are dealing with. It is a very strong plus for Australia that we have unanimity on it. I do not want to enter into controversy with Senator Michael Baume about its initiation. There is no doubt that the Opposition has taken a strong role on this question, as has the Government. I cannot remember the sequence, but I know that the Australian Democrats have always taken a similar position.
—Mr Keating rolled Mr Hawke in Cabinet.
—It is kind of Senator Crichton-Browne to undermine any attempt to have a positive role in this place, but it is not helpful.
—It is factual, though.

—That the honourable senator has wonderful knowledge of what goes on in Cabinet is often something which he asserts but very rarely something which he can establish. The fact of the matter is simply this.
—Would you like to disagree with me?
—I am bored out of my wits by Senator Crichton-Browne's tedious attempts to lower the standard of everything which he enters.
—You don't make it very difficult.

—No, it is always very high to start with. That is correct. The fact is this: the Opposition raised this issue; that is to its credit. The Democrats supported it; that is to their credit. The Government decided to pursue at an international level what seemed, when it was initiated, a fruitless course which many people thought was potentially even counterproductive. Many people thought it might undermine the reasonably good agreement toward which we were heading. That was a very significant debate and I can remember being involved in it inside the Party. The people who took the opposite view, who said, `Of course there shouldn't be mining but taking an extreme position will undermine the reasonable objective', were arguing a sensible proposition from good motives. I did not share their view and I greatly welcomed the decision that then Prime Minister Hawke took.

PARA.TAB: Others had a different view. In the debates in which I was involved—the person to whom Senator Crichton-Browne referred was not involved, but it is irrelevant—there were significant people of good will on environmental issues who took a different view and said that the Australian Government should take a different position. They also were seeking to do their best to protect the Antarctic environment. It was a tactical disagreement, not a disagreement about objectives. But I welcome the fact that, notwithstanding the controversy about the huskies and notwithstanding Senator Crichton-Browne's more recent interjections, we have had very proper support, including from Senator Crichton-Browne, for the fundamental principles of this important legislation.

Let us go briefly to the question in contention. I do not think Mrs Kelly is sitting in her office cowering, hoping that I will come forcefully to her defence so she can emerge in public again from these scathing attacks upon her. I suspect that she feels reasonably comfortable. Nevertheless, it is important that we put the position on the record.

It is true that there are arguments of some force that the element of the Treaty which we are seeking to give effect to here, which requires the huskies to be removed, is unnecessary. There are a number of people who would share that view and it is no secret that Australia initially argued against the inclusion of the proposition up to the signing of the Madrid Protocol. But it is in the Treaty and it is a great part of a great reform. It is an element. In the big picture, it is a very small element; to achieve the big picture it was not possible for us to win on every point.

Are we now saying that Australia should not comply with its international obligations? As a matter of international citizenship, are we saying that we should not comply with our obligations? If we do say that, how are we going to urge others to comply with the bits that we think are important? We cannot have it both ways. It is a very comfortable position to be in to say, `Everybody should agree with the bits we agree with but we claim the right not to comply with the bits with which we disagree'. So, first of all, it is a question of good international citizenship. Secondly, it is a question of maintaining maximum support for the implementation of the Madrid Protocol, which is fundamentally important to the advancement and enhancement of the international environment. That is why we are complying. It is why we should comply. It is why, in my view, we must comply.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is going to happen to the UK?

—Two things. One is that we have contacted the UK Foreign and Commonwealth Office and sought clarification of the UK position. We were advised that the UK is committed fully to the implementation of the Madrid Protocol and that the UK does not want to be inflexible on the matter of its dogs in Antarctica and will review its position before the 1994 deadline. The other one involved, Argentina, has commenced removing its dogs in accordance with the Protocol and advises that all its dogs will be removed this summer. So, of the three involved, two—ourselves and Argentina—have taken a position that quite directly implements the Protocol. The UK has not at this stage, but will review its position before 1994. We made the decision, first of all—which I think we should have done; which we did; which I think we were obliged to do and should have done—that the dogs had to be removed according to the timetable set down in the Protocol.

PARA.TAB: Senator Calvert and others will know that, whilst I was involved in the early part of this debate in the party room, I have not been as centrally involved as Minister Kelly, but my advice is that the judgment made by advisers and ultimately by the Minister on their advice was that, if they were to be removed—that was the first decision and I think that was made for the reasons I have outlined—then the best location for those dogs, in their interests, was the Minnesota location; that was where they should go, in their interests; and therefore, if we did not take up the opportunity, it would not recur. It was not a question of saying, `We do not want to send them to Minnesota until a bit later. We would like them to stay where they are a bit longer'. That option was not, and is not, available.

For that reason, once the first decision was made—with which Senator Calvert and others disagree, I understand—then the best way of implementing it was that which has been taken. It was in the interests of the animals concerned and therefore the most appropriate decision to make. I understand that people have an alternative view. I think they are wrong as to what the Australian Government was obliged to do and should have done and they are wrong, as a matter following on from that, as to the most effective way of implementing that decision, once made. It is a legitimate disagreement. It should not impair the recognition of the significance of the fundamental achievement that is reflected in this legislation and of the role of Australia in that—an achievement for which all Australians can be proud.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Crichton-Browne's) be agreed to:
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I would like to say that I regret the decision of the Australian Democrats to vote with the Government on our amendment. I put on record that, by so doing, they have supported the removal of the huskies from their environment. I suppose there is only one thing we should be grateful for: as there is a Chinese station in Antarctica, I am glad that Senator Evans was not involved in this matter, or the huskies may well have met a more different fate.

—I do not want to be seen to be lacking grace in this debate, but Senator McMullan raised this question, following Senator Michael Baume's observations that Mrs Kelly has given the impression that the Antarctic Treaty is a creature of the Government's and that we are being beseeched to give it proper and due support. Let the record clearly show that Senator Gareth Evans was vigorous in his support of the minerals regime and opposed the Treaty.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister at the time gave every indication that the minerals regime would be set in place and there would be no treaty of this nature. It was following a decision of the Opposition, articulated by former Senator Chris Puplick, followed subsequently by the Democrats, that the overwhelming political expediency of the environment drove the Government into agreeing. The only voice of dissent from the Government was heard in a paper prepared in Mr Keating's office which criticised the regime. That was the only indication by the Government that it opposed the minerals regime and supported this Treaty. I just put it as a matter of record, not to be ungracious and not to be cheap or smart, but at least to show the record as it really is.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator McMullan) read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—The Minister may proceed.

—This morning's Melbourne Age, amongst other newspapers, made some reference to my citizenship—of course, in the context of yesterday's High Court ruling. The article I want to address is the article by Margo Kingston on page 15 of this morning's Melbourne Age where she says—in brackets—that Senator Bolkus was an orphan. Before that she said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Senator Nick Bolkus, born here, thinks his father was Greek but is not sure.

I just want to place on the public record that I am not an orphan; I never have been, and was not born an orphan. I know both my natural parents and they are both still alive. I was born in Adelaide in 1950. Both parents came to Australia as children more than 70 years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —You look much older.

—I feel much older after a few days in here. Both parents were not born in Greece. My mother was born in South America and, by a quirk of history, her parents had been chased off a Greek island by either Turkish, French or Italian invaders. My father also was not born in a place which was Greek at the time of his birth.

PARA.TAB: To reinforce that, I am informed that my sister inquired a few years ago as to whether we were entitled to dual citizenship and was told quite clearly by the Greek Government that we were not born of people who were born in Greece and, as a consequence, we were not entitled to it. But the main point I wanted to correct was that I am not an orphan and my parents are pleased to verify that.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus, on behalf of Senator Tate) agreed to:
That this Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to change the Corporations Law.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill implements an enhanced disclosure system for corporations and other entities in which members of the public invest. It requires a new form of ongoing or continuous disclosure of information of interest to investors, as well as improving the present system for periodic reporting, in particular by requiring a half yearly financial report. In light of this enhanced level of disclosure of information in relation to investment entities, the Bill introduces a number of reforms to facilitate the issue of prospectuses by these entities.

Provision has been made for the additional costs which will be incurred by the Australian Securities Commission in administering the enhanced disclosure system. The Attorney-General announced in August that the necessary additional expenditure of $3.2m over the next 4 years had been approved in the context of the Budget. This will cover upgrading of the Commission's computer system, as well as ongoing administrative costs for this period. However, the Commission expects that the running costs included in this figure will be substantially offset by revenue raised through charges for additional access to its national database.

Further details and an assessment of the financial impact of the Bill on business is contained in the Explanatory Memorandum. In essence, some additional costs can be expected for business, although these should not be significant for entities which are listed on the Australian Stock Exchange or which, consistent with good governance practices, already have internal reporting systems in place. Furthermore, the reforms to the prospectus provisions will result in savings for these entities when they engage in fundraising.

Mr President, the Government considers it is essential that there be timely disclosure of relevant information about the financial position and prospects of entities in which Australians invest. It is essential to enable informed judgments on investment decisions, whether made by individual Australians or by large institutional investors. In every case the principle is the same—disclosure of relevant information about an investment and access to such information, either directly or through advisers, is necessary to ensure an equitable and efficient investment system.

It seems likely that the 1990s will see an increase in activity on the part of shareholders in monitoring, and in taking direct action concerning, the governance of their companies. Effective and soundly based action by shareholders is enhanced if they have access to all material information about their companies.

However, the importance of adequate disclosure goes beyond this. An effective disclosure system will often be a significant inhibition on questionable corporate conduct. Knowledge that such conduct will be quickly exposed to the glare of publicity, as well as criticism by shareholders and the financial press, makes it less likely to occur in the first place.
In essence, a well informed market leads to greater investor confidence and in turn to a greater willingness to invest in Australian business.

It is commonly acknowledged that the frequent lack of disclosure of significant information was a major shortcoming of our corporate regulatory system in the 1980s. Failure to address this shortcoming would be an abdication of our responsibility to Australian investors. It is not sufficient to say, as some have, that the problem of adequate disclosure is not as great today. Our regulatory framework must be capable of meeting the challenges which will emerge with the next period of major stock market activity—at which point there is a risk that the cautionary experiences of the past will be put to one side. Furthermore, there are concerns about the present level of corporate disclosure which a legislative regime will address.

Against this background, the Attorney-General asked the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee in June last year to report, as a matter of high priority, on the need for a statutory system of ongoing reporting by listed companies.

In welcoming the Committee's report in October last year, the Attorney-General noted the wide ranging nature of the Committee's recommendations, as well as its impact on the business community, and asked his Department to consult with interested parties, especially business, in relation to its implementation.

There followed a process of detailed consultation with business and professional groups, both through written submissions and also numerous meetings with representatives of these groups and individual experts. It is fair to say that considerable criticism was made of the Advisory Committee's proposal for legislation—both as to the need for legislation at all, and as to the scope and potentially onerous nature of the recommended disclosure system.

In light of the consultative process undertaken by the Attorney-General and his Department, the legislative outline announced by the Government in July this year differed in a number of significant respects from the scheme recommended by the Committee. The changes involved a substantial narrowing of the range of entities to be subject to the statutory system so that it will now only apply to those entities in which investors have a direct interest because their securities are traded or offered for sale in the marketplace. In addition, the scheme put forward by the Government involved a reformulation of the ongoing disclosure obligations to ensure a less onerous and more cost effective system. In announcing the scheme, it was emphasised that these obligations would be framed so as not to involve the imposition of `due diligence' obligations applicable to the issue of a one-off prospectus for raising funds.

Since July, the Attorney-General's Department has again engaged in a very intensive process of consultation with business and professional organisations in developing the draft legislation. Four detailed issues papers prepared by the Department provided a basis for a series of meetings with representatives of these organisations and a number of individuals. The constructive approach adopted during this consultation process was most valuable from the Government's perspective and has contributed significantly to the draft Bill. The consultation process has been welcomed also by the business sector, especially because of the opportunity provided for their input at a stage prior to the adoption of firm policy positions by the Government.
Before dealing with the Bill in more detail, I want to stress three points.

First, the Government is committed to a legislative scheme for enhanced disclosure. It does not believe that this is a matter which can satisfactorily be left to the discretion of the entities themselves or to the Stock Exchange in respect of listed entities. With the enhanced role envisaged for the Australian Securities Commission, legislative requirements will have greater force and effect than stock exchange rules. And it is appropriate that obligations with civil and criminal consequences of the kind involved here be contained in legislation—rather than in stock exchange rules which are, in essence, a private contract between the exchange and listed entities.

The second point I need to emphasize is the Government's ongoing commitment to consultation on the detail of the legislative requirements, prior to the Bill's enactment. It is intended that debate on this Bill be deferred for a period of 3 months to enable public comment and consultation. At each of the previous two stages of consultation undertaken by the Government, significant changes have been made to meet the justifiable concerns of business. If any further justifiable concerns are identified, these too will be met. The Government will be looking for constructive input and suggestions from business and professional experts in order to ensure that, once enacted, the legislation will be effective in achieving the objective of enhanced disclosure, in a cost efficient and commercially practicable manner.

Finally, I draw attention to the fact that the Bill provides for the disclosure provisions in Part 2 of the Bill to commence on 31 December 1993. This will give affected entities ample time to put in place any new procedures and reporting systems necessary to enable compliance with the new periodic reporting and continuous disclosure requirements.

I now want to outline a few of the most important features of the Bill. I will deal first with the reforms arising from the enhanced disclosure scheme. A more detailed outline of this scheme is set out in the Explanatory Memorandum.
(a) Entities to be covered

The major application of the enhanced disclosure scheme will be to entities listed on the Australian Stock Exchange and to other entities which raise funds in circumstances in which a prospectus is required to be lodged. Entities subject to the new system are referred to as disclosing entities. Applying the disclosure scheme to those entities which have to prepare a prospectus or which are listed provides a direct connection with investors who have an interest in timely disclosure of material information. An exception is provided where, for example, the number of shareholders or the number of unitholders in a trust falls below 50—in which case an entity will cease to be a disclosing entity. Flexibility is provided to enable a complete or partial exemption from the enhanced disclosure system for particular entities, through the making of regulations or by way of an Australian Securities Commission order. These exemptions may be made subject to conditions. In particular, consideration will be given to the desirability of an exemption for those foreign entities whose special position is already recognised by the Australian Securities Commission and the Stock Exchange.

It should be noted that the entities covered by the scheme include those referred to in the Corporations Law as `prescribed interests'. This category of investment is presently being examined by the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee and the Australian Law Reform Commission as part of their review of `Collective Investments'. The approach adopted in the Bill on disclosure in relation to these investments is along the lines of that foreshadowed by these bodies in their review.
(b) Enhanced periodic reporting

The major change to the Corporations Law for periodic reporting is the new requirement for a statutory half yearly report. The purpose of this report will be to provide financial details and a review of half yearly operations, in a manner which corresponds to existing annual reports. However, the reporting will not be as detailed as for annual reports.
The Australian Accounting Standards Board will, as a result of the Bill, have power to make accounting standards for the purposes of the half yearly reports.

The reports will be subject to review by a qualified auditor to give an additional level of assurance as to their compliance with the requirements of the Law. The review will not, however, require the level of enquiry or the expense involved with the audit undertaken for annual reports.
Additional annual reporting requirements, analogous to those applicable at present to companies, will be introduced for disclosing entities which are not now subject to them.
(c) Continuous Disclosure

The single most important reform contained in the Bill is the requirement for disclosing entities to report to the Australian Securities Commission, on an ongoing or continuous basis, matters of significance concerning these entities.

Disclosure will be required to the Australian Securities Commission of material information as soon as practicable, but in any event within 3 days of an event or a change in circumstances. The overriding requirement is that disclosure be made as soon as practicable within this timeframe.

In view of its extensive investigation and enforcement powers, the Australian Securities Commission is well placed to take action designed to ensure a high level of compliance. In addition, significant new civil remedies will be provided to enable an investor who suffers loss as a result of non-disclosure to recover that loss from the disclosing entity. Where an individual, such as a director, a senior company officer or an outside expert, is knowingly involved in a contravention of the disclosure requirements, that person will also be liable. In addition, a company officer whose action exposes the company to liability for breach of the continuous disclosure provisions may well be liable to the company for not discharging the usual duty of care and diligence owed to the company. Adoption of this form of personal liability for directors and professional advisers addresses a concern raised by business interests regarding the liability attaching to the scheme, whilst at the same time providing an appropriate incentive for compliance.

The criteria to be used in determining whether disclosure of a matter is required will be based, in essence, on what a reasonable investor would expect to be disclosed. It adopts the tests presently used by the Corporations Law in determining the information to be included in a prospectus and by the Australian Stock Exchange in its Listing Rule dealing with ongoing disclosure by listed entities.

Consistency with these tests is an important element of the new scheme. It will thus be possible for the disclosure test to be applied in a commercially sensible manner, with a level of familiarity on the part of many users and advisers. However, there is an important difference from its use in relation to prospectuses. A number of features of the continuous disclosure scheme are designed to ensure that `due diligence', in the sense this term is used in respect of prospectuses, is not a part of continuous disclosure. Thus, the element of `reasonable enquiries' in the prospectus provisions is not incorporated for continuous disclosure. There is a defence for an entity which establishes a reasonable disclosure system designed to enable compliance with the legislation. Such systems are already common in major entities and are regarded as an essential part of corporate governance. Their existence should in many cases enable compliance without additional cost. For entities without such a system, it will be a defence to show that disclosure would not have been achieved had there been a reasonable system in operation.

These features, together with the approach taken in respect of criminal and civil liability, reflect the Government's desire to have a scheme which, while having statutory force, is capable of being administered by entities in a commercially reasonable manner.

A defence is also provided where an entity does not wish to disclose confidential information. This issue raises difficult considerations. On the one hand, entities in certain circumstances may be justified in withholding information, the release of which would prejudice the entity. On the other hand, it is necessary to ensure that excessive and improper use of a `confidentiality' exception does not undermine the success of the disclosure scheme as a whole. In this regard, it is worth noting that one of the criticisms of the present level of disclosure relates to the reliance on claims of confidentiality to justify non-disclosure.

The exception which has been included in the Bill reflects both the commercial need for confidential information to be withheld and the desire to avoid potential abuse. It establishes an objective test which enables non-disclosure where a disclosing entity can establish that disclosure would result in an unreasonable prejudice to the entity. This test reflects the fact that the confidentiality of particular information and the consequences of its disclosure is a matter which the entity itself is in the best position to establish.

The continuous disclosure obligations are contained in approximately two pages in the Bill and result from the use of general principles in the drafting. This approach has the major benefit of enabling reliance on tests of what is reasonable in the circumstances. These tests are thus objective in nature and provide appropriate guidance, in easily understood language, for disclosing entities, officers and professional advisers. Furthermore, it can be expected, consistent with the usual approach of the courts in these matters, that judges will not seek to second guess, with the benefit of hindsight, judgments by company officers which were reasonable at the time and in the circumstances of their making.

The role of the Australian Stock Exchange in supervising listed entities is an important one and care has been taken in drafting the legislation to enable this role to be preserved and enhanced. The enhancement of the Australian Stock Exchange's role is achieved in part by a provision which will make it clear that the Exchange is protected by qualified privilege in carrying out its disclosure and supervisory functions.

The enactment of legislation requiring ongoing disclosure should not be seen as a criticism of the Stock Exchange. It has been generally recognized that the level of disclosure by listed entities achieved by the Stock Exchange has improved significantly in recent times. However, the Government believes that legislation will ensure that these gains are maintained and improved upon. In addition, the legislation will, of course, apply to a significant number of unlisted entities. It would not be appropriate to have a legislative framework for these unlisted entities, while applying a different system, based only on contractual obligations in Listing Rules, to listed entities in which there is a major investor interest.

It is to be hoped that the Stock Exchange Rules and the legislation can complement one another. From the Government's perspective, close co-operation between the Australian Stock Exchange and the Australian Securities Commission would be expected to significantly enhance the overall level of corporate disclosure.
(d) Prospectus Reforms

As has been indicated previously, the introduction of a statutory disclosure scheme provides scope for streamlining the existing prospectus requirements. The enhanced level of information available to investors on an ongoing basis in respect of disclosing entities means that in many circumstances adequate investor protection can be achieved without requiring information about the disclosing entity to be repeated in a prospectus.

Reform in this area is based in part on a report in March 1992 by a Sub-Committee of the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, which was convened specifically to review the prospectus provisions.

The Sub-Committee's report noted its support for the concept of continuous disclosure. This Bill deals with the major recommendation relating to rights issues by the Sub-Committee, as well as some other reforms, which relate directly to the introduction of an enhanced disclosure scheme. Some additional reforms to the prospectus provisions, including the remainder of those in the Sub-Committee report, will be dealt with at a later stage during 1993.
For disclosing entities which meet certain criteria related to the level of information available about the entity, there will be four significant reforms:

First, for primary offers of quoted securities (in particular, rights issues) by qualifying disclosing entities, the requirement to lodge a prospectus will be satisfied by lodgment of a limited prospectus which provides information relating to the offer. The approach adopted in this regard is based on that recommended by the Sub-Committee, although the precise test has been derived from the present prospectus test in the Corporations Law. The essential aim is to obtain the inclusion of information relating to the offer of securities which would be required to be included in a prospectus, while not requiring information about the entity which should already be available through the enhanced disclosure system.

The second change will significantly streamline the present requirements for a secondary prospectus where an offer of securities is made by a seller other than the corporation which issued the securities. Whether such a document should continue to be dealt with as a prospectus is a matter which will be examined during the second stage of reforms, in the context of proposals that have been made for the adoption of a narrower definition of the term `prospectus'.

The third prospectus reform will enable the incorporation by reference into a prospectus of material in documents lodged with the Australian Securities Commission by a disclosing entity, subject to certain safeguards.

The fourth reform will extend the life of prospectuses in certain cases from 6 to 12 months. This reform is justified also by the requirement for a supplementary prospectus to be lodged where there is a significant change in circumstances.

The entities which will qualify for relief from the current prospectus requirements under these reforms will be those which meet certain criteria designed to provide a level of assurance as to the information available in the market place about the entity. For this reason those entities which are subject to an exemption of one kind or another from the disclosure provisions will not automatically be entitled to operate under this streamlined system. To ensure that the system operates in a reasonable and flexible manner, in cases where an exemption results in no material adverse effects for the level of information available to investors, the ASC will be empowered to specify that an entity may nevertheless have the benefit of the proposed prospectus relief.
The present exemption from the accounts provisions in the Corporations Law for certain banks and life insurance companies requires special mention.

The relevant provisions take account of the overlapping requirements in the Banking and Life Insurance legislation dealing with the provision of financial information by banks and life insurance companies and are designed to avoid duplication. The Bill extends the present provisions in respect of the periodic disclosure requirements, where applicable. However, the justification for the continued operation of these provisions may be questionable, having regard to the `investor protection' rationale for the enhanced disclosure scheme and the new prospectus provisions. The Attorney-General therefore proposes to establish, in consultation with the Treasurer, a working group of officials to review the current exemption and make recommendations on any changes that are required. It is envisaged that the Reserve Bank of Australia, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, the Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Accounting Standards Board would be involved in this review.

An important reform will be made to the Corporations Law to clarify and relax the present prohibition on a company's ability to insure and indemnify its officers (including directors) and its auditors.

The existing prohibition has long been criticised, both for its uncertain scope and its lack of consistency with appropriate commercial practice. Reports have been made by both the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee and its predecessor, the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee, recommending that the prohibition be relaxed. In formulating the reforms, regard has been had to the somewhat different recommendations in the two reports, as well as to the position in several common law jurisdictions overseas.
In essence, the reforms proposed will operate as follows:

A company or a related company will not be prohibited from indemnifying an officer or auditor of the company against liability incurred by the person in that capacity provided the liability arises to a third party and does not involve a lack of good faith. Existing provisions allowing indemnities in respect of costs incurred in legal actions will be preserved.

A company or a related company will not be prohibited from taking out insurance to benefit an officer or auditor of the company provided the liability does not involve a wilful breach of duty to the company or the gaining of an improper advantage, as defined in the Corporations Law. Insurance will also be possible to cover the costs of legal actions brought against officer and auditors.

In other circumstances, restrictions will remain on companies indemnifying, exempting or insuring their officers or auditors. It should be noted, however, that the definition of officer will be narrowed to exclude any restrictions on payments for the benefit of employees.

A number of important safeguards are designed to ensure that these provisions will not be subject to abuse. In particular, disclosure will be required in a company's annual report of indemnities and insurance policies taken out for the benefit of company officers and auditors.

Furthermore, the usual principles requiring a company officer to act in the best interests of the company will apply to decisions to indemnify (or agree to do so) and to take out insurance for officers. Similarly, the provisions to be inserted in the Corporations Law by the Corporate Law Reform Bill which was introduced earlier this month and which dealt with remuneration of officers of public companies, will apply to payments of insurance premiums and indemnities.

In summary, this provision is designed to achieve a reasonable balance between providing flexibility for companies to act in an appropriate, commercial manner and the need to ensure that shareholders' funds are not used improperly to benefit directors and officers.

I note that the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Institute of Company Directors were closely involved in, and indeed contributed significantly to, the development of the policy reflected in the proposed amendments. These two organisations have welcomed the approach reflected in the revised provisions.

The other reform contained in the Bill will overcome a problem encountered with the use of documents from the Australian Securities Commission's national database as evidence in court proceedings. The proposed amendment follows discussion of this issue with the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission and the Ministerial Council for Corporations. It will enable a document from the database to be admissible in a court proceeding as prima facie evidence of the matters stated, without the need for certification of the document.

Mr President, this is the second major Corporate Law Reform Bill introduced in the Senate this month. As was indicated in introducing the first Bill, the enactment of these two Bills will complete a major stage in the Government's ongoing corporate law reform program.

An important part of the next stage, which will involve simplification and modernisation of corporate law, will be a review of the rules applicable to companies operated by small business. This review will be carried out in light of the recommendations of the report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Corporations and Securities, which is expected to table its report on the Close Corporations Act 1989 next month.

As indicated earlier, it is proposed that debate on the present Bill be deferred for 3 months to enable public consultation on its content. In accordance with the Heads of Agreement between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory on corporate regulation, the Ministerial Council for Corporations has approved the introduction of the Bill into Parliament on this basis, subject to the usual consultation and approval process taking place with the Council prior to the debate on the Bill.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Bjelke-Petersen) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 6) 1992MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION BILL 1992ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity, very briefly, on the first reading of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) to raise a matter generally about taxation and the continuing taxation that this Government imposts upon business particularly in Australia. The Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill has already been dealt with in this Parliament, but because I had some other parliamentary duties last night when this matter was raised I did not get the opportunity to mention some matters about the difficulties which the fringe benefits tax on car parking facilities will impose upon various people.

PARA.TAB: On 4 November 1992 I raised in the adjournment debate how this particular fringe benefits tax would impost on local authorities around Australia, and I particularly mentioned the Melbourne City Council, which had very strong reservations about the Bill. I indicated that in that instance and in the instance of many other capital cities and major provincial cities the effect of this Bill would be to move many businesses away from the central business area and would leave underutilised much of the infrastructure that has already been put in place. It is something that local authorities around Australia are very concerned about and very strongly oppose because of the impact it will have on them and, as well, because of the additional revenue they will have to find, in many cases, to pay this tax. I will not repeat the things I said in that speech but I do make reference to it.

I also want to mention some letters that I and many of my colleagues have received. I make specific reference to a letter I received from the Brisbane Parking Industry Association which provides quite a deal of information. Very briefly, I indicate some of the points raised by that association in opposing this Bill. The central business district employees are already penalised and they are disadvantaged because they must pay parking costs. Employers are already heavily taxed through sales tax, income tax, capital gains taxes and other State taxes, including payroll tax, and they have been hit with other additional costs—training levies and superannuation costs—all of which will be removed under the next Hewson Government.

The letter goes on to say that many employers have been hit by staggering State land taxes. They are paying double and triple the amounts they were paying just a few years ago. The tax payable on parking would have a significant effect on employers in labour intensive industries. It is a sectional tax. A financial burden of major proportions for many employers would result and it would create enormous administrative costs. It would also, the Association points out, jeopardise the Better Cities program by forcing development out of the cities. Of course, that is a program that this Government is interested in. It would force employers to cut costs and jobs and the tax would get higher and higher.

In addition, I want to make reference to a letter on the same subject that was sent to me by the Townsville Chamber of Commerce and to quote from that letter. The Townsville Chamber of Commerce points out that the proposed legislation imposes yet another unnecessary tax impost on business. It points out that any business within approximately two kilometres of the Townsville Post Office, including manufacturers, wholesalers and businesses in the south Townsville area, will be charged at least $200 per annum for each car parking space provided to most employees, including employees using their own cars. It points out that the tax is inequitable. It is even charged where the employee is required to use his or her own car for business purposes during the day. It further points out that the tax is discriminatory, that businesses located near the city heart which provide employee parking will have to pay the tax, while those located elsewhere providing exactly the same facilities will not.

The Townsville Chamber of Commerce rightly points out that in relation to Townsville—and this would apply in many other provincial cities as well—this tax ignores the fact that provincial cities such as Townsville lack adequate public transport as an alternative to driving to work. That is something that I do not think the Government has taken into account seriously enough. The Chamber rightly points out that it will impose considerably more paperwork on business. The legislation provides for exemption on any day the employee does not park his vehicle for four hours overall—not continuously, that is. The exemption does not, however, go far enough. There will be many situations where an employee will be required to use his or her vehicle at times during the day and still be parked for more than four hours. In practice, the cost of maintaining time records to monitor this will outweigh any potential benefit, meaning employees will have to pay unnecessarily to save money.

If the car parking FBT has to be imposed, an option should be allowed of basing it on the percentage non-business use of the vehicle where a log book has been kept. The rationale for the tax—if one applies at all—certainly does not apply in provincial cities. I ask the Government very seriously to consider that. Employers will be unnecessarily penalised for the trouble and cost of providing parking for employees who do not have the extensive public transport system available to their counterparts in the capital cities. I understand that the Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill, which I am not talking to but simply referring very obliquely to, has been referred to a committee for further consideration. I hope the Committee will take into account the matters I have just raised.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

DEBATE.TITLE: ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION BILL 1992ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION BILL 1992

Over the past few years this Government has publicly shown a strong commitment to the protection of endangered species. A vital component of this position has been a public commitment to the consideration of the enactment of Commonwealth endangered species legislation. This Bill is the result of that commitment, and will form the legislative component of the Government's ongoing action to protect endangered species.
The Bill is also in response to the widespread view expressed by the Australian public that endangered species are a national problem that requires Commonwealth Government involvement.
Extinction of species is, of course, a natural part of the evolutionary process. However, in the 200 years since European settlement the rate of extinction in Australia has accelerated dramatically.

This increase is not, as some believe, an event associated only with the early days of settlement when our scientific knowledge of the Australian environment and our impacts on it were far more limited than they are today. Extinctions and endangered species are very much a current problem. Half of all our animal extinctions have occurred this century.

Scientists agree that Australia has right now 226 species and sub-species of plants and 73 of animals which are endangered, that is, they are in immediate danger of extinction. A further 661 species and sub-species of plants and 66 of animals are vulnerable: that is, they are likely to become endangered if present threats continue.
On the international level also, the Bill will demonstrate that Australia is taking action to address endangered species conservation.

We are not alone in our efforts to save endangered species. Many other countries, including Japan and the United States, have already taken legislative action to protect endangered species, with the need already reflected within the recently concluded Convention on Biological Diversity and Agenda 21 of the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development.
Within Australia, a number of States and Territories have introduced, or are in the process of introducing endangered species legislation.
All of this action only makes it more important for the Commonwealth Government to proceed with the enactment of its own endangered species legislation.

Endangered species do not recognise State boundaries. What is needed for their proper protection and management is a national perspective. We need nationally agreed lists of what species are endangered and vulnerable, and a national approach to plans for their recovery.

Of course, it is essential that the lists are prepared on a scientific basis and that the scientists advising the Minister are free to make their decisions without the pressure of other influences on their decision making.
The development of the legislation has been subject to extensive consultation over a long period.

The legislation was first mooted by the Government in March 1990. The Endangered Species Advisory Committee provided the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories with an options paper on endangered species legislation in April 1991. A public consultation process was begun in early 1992 with the release of a paper: "Commonwealth Endangered Species Legislation—The Proposal".

Extensive consultation with all relevant interest groups including industry, conservation organisations and the States and Territories followed during the development of the Bill. The legislation was adjusted to take into account the legitimate concerns of industry and conservation groups, while still maintaining its integrity.
The Bill addresses such fundamental issues as the scientific process for listing endangered and vulnerable species and the development of recovery and threat abatement plans for their protection.
The major focus of the legislation is its positive and proactive approach to endangered species and their long term survival in Australia.
Some critics, having focused on the regulatory aspects, which are in reality of limited extent, appear to have overlooked its predominantly positive approach.
The legislation has the following key features:

.National lists of endangered and vulnerable species and endangered ecological communities. These lists will be determined on purely scientific grounds. Key threatening processes will also be listed. The initial lists are schedules to the Bill.

.Recovery and threat abatement plans, which must be developed for listed species on Commonwealth lands and waters, and which can be developed co-operatively between the States and Commonwealth for State areas to enable the recovery process to be coordinated on a national basis. Development of recovery and threat abatement plans will include public consultation and the Environment Minister will also consult with other Ministers where the plans concern matters for which they are responsible.

.An advisory committee will be established to provide the Environment Minister with advice on the administration of the legislation, including the times within which and priorities for the preparation of recovery and threat abatement plans.

.A scientific subcommittee will also be established (in consultation with relevant Ministers) to advise the Environment Minister on amendments to the lists established under the legislation, and to advise the Minister of the criteria that should be used in deciding whether a list should be amended.

.The Bill contains provisions for the establishment of voluntary conservation agreements between the Commonwealth and persons having interests in Commonwealth areas. These will assist in ensuring the implementation of the recovery and threat abatement plans and the objects of the Bill.

.The Bill also makes provision for the Environment Minister, in an emergency situation, to place interim conservation orders on activities threatening a listed species or community on Commonwealth lands and waters. In cases where an interim conservation order is to be applied to an act carried out primarily for a commercial purpose, the legislation provides for other relevant Ministers to take emergency action where this is possible using their own powers rather than the Environment Minister having to act.

.Permanent conservation orders can also be applied on Commonwealth lands and waters. These will be made with the approval of Cabinet as will the extension of any interim conservation order applying to activities carried out primarily for commercial purposes.

.There is also provision for impact assessment conservation orders which the Environment Minister can apply in order to ensure the protection of species where projects are undergoing environmental impact assessment. These orders will only apply for the duration of the impact assessment process.
.Enforcement and permit provisions are included to control the taking of listed species in Commonwealth areas, and also to ensure conservation orders are complied with.

.The legislation enables interested persons to apply to the Federal Court for an injunction in respect of conduct by the Minister for the Environment or the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service that contravenes the Act (other than matters concerning the listing process and the making of permanent conservation orders).

The Bill has been developed in the context of Ecologically Sustainable Development (ESD) and it accords with the basic principles of ESD. It is obvious that the extinction of species through human intervention is inconsistent with the principles of ESD.
The principles of ESD have been mentioned specifically in provisions for the preparation and implementation of recovery and threat abatement plans and the making of conservation orders.

We all must remember that once a species is lost, it is lost forever. But there is much we can do to prevent that. Recovery plans which are such a key element of this legislation have a vital role to play but so too do the provisions for control of listed key threats such as fox predation and the die back fungus Phytophthora.
These matters need to be tackled on a national scale, and this legislation will provide us with a framework that will help us get on with the job.

Mr President, the Government believes that the Bill demonstrates that Australia can conserve endangered species and have development as well. Australians want their environment, and the economy too. This legislation does that.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992
This Bill is associated with the Endangered Species Protection Bill 1992.

The Bill clarifies the circumstances in which endangered species considerations trigger environment assessment under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. There are also amendments to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 to enable the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to carry out duties specified in the Endangered Species Protection Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate, and present the Explanatory Memorandum for both Bills.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 6) 1992MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That these Bills be now read a second time.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 6) 1992
The Bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects.
It includes measures to implement changes announced in the 1992-93 Budget, as well as changes to the Prescribed Payments System announced by the Treasurer in July.

Budget announcements to be given effect by this Bill are changes to tax deduction arrangements for occupational clothing, changes to dividend streaming arrangements, and new arrangements to treat limited partnerships as companies for tax purposes.
Other minor amendments proposed by the Bill relate to the gifts provisions and consequential amendments following the introduction of the family payment advance.
I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.

The Bill will give effect to the Budget decision to deny a tax deduction for expenses incurred in relation to certain corporate uniforms or wardrobes. This measure will ensure that the taxation laws do not confer an unfair advantage on some employees by permitting tax deductions for clothing which may not be essentially different from that worn to work by other employees for which no deductions are allowed.

The effect of the amendment is that employees will only be able to claim tax deductions for expenses incurred in purchasing, cleaning and repairing items that comprise a uniform or corporate wardrobe where the wearing of such clothing is expressly required by the employer as a condition of employment.

The Government has decided to target more closely the areas of potential abuse in this area. The Government will not prevent non-compulsory uniforms or wardrobes from being deductible in cases where the clothing is clearly identifiable as a corporate wardrobe. The Treasurer will develop strict guidelines to establish whether noncompulsory uniforms or wardrobes, as sets of clothing, are eligible for taxation deduction. These guidelines, which will be published as soon as possible after this Bill receives Royal Assent, will prevent the clear cases of abuse of the existing requirements that have come to the Government's attention.
The Government proposes to amend the Bill in Committee stage of its passage to give effect to this proposal.
It is important to note that the new rules will not operate to deny a deduction for clothing worn to protect employees from injury, or their normal clothing from damage.
The savings cannot be estimated at this stage.
Because of the changes to the Budget announcements the Government has decided to postpone the implementation of these measures until 1 July 1993.

The Bill gives effect to the announcement in this year's Budget that the income tax law is to be amended to ensure that the dividend streaming provisions work as intended when applied to international dividend streaming arrangements.
The changes affect only those companies that are a party to international dividend streaming arrangements. The vast majority of companies will not be affected.

The amendments will result in a resident company being able to preserve a portion of its available franking credits to be offset against the franking debit that arises under the dividend streaming provisions when a non-resident associate pays a related dividend under the streaming arrangement.
This change will apply to franked dividends paid by resident companies on or after the date the Bill receives Royal Assent and will have an insignificant impact on revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Taxation of limited partnerships as companies

SPEECH.PARA: As announced in the 1992-93 Budget, limited partnerships formed on or after 19 August 1992 will be subject to the same taxation provisions as companies.

The proposal is consistent with the Government's equity objectives for the taxation system. The Government has taken measures before to ensure business structures comparable to companies are accorded comparable tax treatment. In 1985, provisions were introduced to ensure public trading trusts were taxed as companies. The previous Government had introduced similar measures in relation to corporate unit trusts.

A limited partnership has more in common with a company than with a conventional partnership. Where partners in a conventional partnership are individually and collectively liable to meet partnership debt and make good partnership losses, the liability of limited partners is limited (generally to their investment).
Limited partnerships formed prior to 19 August 1992 will be subject to the same taxation provisions as companies from the 1995-96 year of income.

Limited partnerships formed prior to 19 August 1992 may continue to be treated as partnerships for taxation purposes until the 1995-96 year of income. If they do not continue to carry on the same business, or if their ownership changes beyond a limited extent, they will be treated as companies for the year of income in which they change and all later years.
Limited partnerships that are subject to the new arrangements will be known as corporate limited partnerships.

The new arrangements are likely to have a revenue benefit; however, a reliable estimate cannot be made. This is because in some States legislation authorising the formation of limited partnerships has been enacted only recently.

The Bill also contains the amendments to the Prescribed Payments System which were announced by the Treasurer on 1 July 1992. The amendments are designed to reduce the administrative burden on payers, payees and the ATO.
The amendments, which will not directly affect the revenue, replace the current monthly reporting arrangements for payers with annual reporting.
The amendments proposed will also modify the current arrangements for deduction variation and exemption certificates and approvals to quote reporting exemption numbers.

The gift provisions of the income tax law are being amended to reflect a change in name of the College of Pathologists of Australia to the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia. The change will have no impact on revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Exemption for income tax of family payment advance

SPEECH.PARA: From 1 January 1993 the recipients of family payment will be able to have the payment made in a lump sum up to six months in advance. This Bill will amend the income tax law to exempt the family payment advance from income tax. As the regular instalments of family payment are already exempt from income tax there is no cost to revenue.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992
The Bill will amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to increase the rate of Medicare levy as announced in the Budget Statement.
For 1993-94 the rate of Medicare levy will be increased by 0.15 percentage point to 1.4 per cent of taxable income.

It is proposed to amend the PAYE schedules to take account of the increase in the levy from 1 July 1993. All taxpayers who are liable to pay the levy and who have it deducted in PAYE instalments will be affected from that date. Other taxpayers will be affected on assessment.
The benefit to revenue of the increase in the levy is estimated to be $300m in 1993-94. The increase will fund outlay measures for health and aged care announced in the Budget.
The Bill will also make a minor technical amendment to the Medicare Levy Act.
The explanatory Memorandum accompanying this Bill contains more detailed explanation of the provisions of this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX (DIVIDENDS AND INTEREST WITHHOLDING TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 9 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a first time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill, together with Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1992, will also give effect to the Budget announcement to introduce a final withholding tax on royalties paid or credited to non-residents.

The Bill will amend the Income Tax (Dividends and Interest Withholding Tax) Act 1974 to apply to the provisions of that Act to royalties and will formally impose a final withholding tax of 30 per cent on royalties derived by non-residents.

Where, however, the recipient is resident in a country with which Australia has concluded a double tax agreement, the rate of withholding tax will be limited to that specified in the agreement—generally 10 per cent.
The new arrangements are to apply to royalties paid or credited from the commencement of the recipient's 1993-94 year income. For most recipients this will be 1 July 1993.
The introduction of a withholding tax is estimated to yield additional revenue of $50 million a year.
The Explanatory Memorandum accompanying this Bill contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1992TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 6) 1992MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992INCOME TAX (DIVIDENDS AND INTEREST WITHHOLDING TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it once again a package of taxation Bills. I intend to confine my remarks to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) and the Income Tax (Dividends and Interest Withholding Tax) Amendment Bill, which is complementary to Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) as it legislates for the 30 per cent tax.

PARA.TAB: Taxation Laws Amendment Bills (No. 5) and (No. 6) cover a series of taxation measures, many of which have been announced in the Budget. As with many other tax Bills being debated under this guillotine organised with the Australian Democrats, however, I would like to register my protest against the guillotine in operation. The 20 minutes allotted to me to speak today is barely enough to cover the details of one aspect of these Bills, let alone 18 different significant changes in Bill No. 5 and six significant changes in No. 6.

Australian taxpayers were exhorted by the Federal Government, in the Budget, to ensure that their work and management practices maximised the productivity of existing resources and to embrace new technologies and management philosophies. Everybody applauded this. In particular, companies were encouraged to adopt international benchmarking to identify the areas in which their work and management practices could be improved as compared with world best practice.

Unfortunately for the Australian taxpayer, the cost of pursuing the aforementioned objectives has been made all the more expensive in many cases by another Budget measure. The introduction of a final withholding tax of 30 per cent on royalty payments to non-residents—reduced to 10 per cent in the case of most tax treaty partners—will force many Australian taxpayers to pay at least that much more for the know-how, technology and equipment which they require to achieve world best practice.
