The definition of a royalty in the Income Tax Assessment Act is broad enough to encompass payments for the use of all of these items. For this purpose I seek leave to have this definition of royalty incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The existing definition of a royalty in section 6 of the Income Tax Assessment Act "includes any amount paid or credited, however described or computed, and whether the payment or credit is periodical or not, to the extent to which it is paid or credited, as the case may be, as consideration for:

PARA.TAB: "(a)the use of, or the right to use, any copyright, patent, design or model, plan, secret formula or process, trade-mark or other like property or right;
"(b)the use of, or the right to use, any industrial, commercial or scientific equipment;
"(c)the supply of scientific, technical, industrial or commercial knowledge or information;

"(d)the supply of any assistance that is ancillary and subsidiary to, and is furnished as a means of enabling the application or enjoyment of, any such property or right as is mentioned in paragraph (a), any such equipment as is mentioned in paragraph (b) or any such knowledge or information as is mentioned in paragraph (c);
"(e)the use of, or the right to use:

TAB.TAB: (i)motion picture films;
(ii)films or video tapes for use in connection with television; or
(iii)tapes for use in connection with radio broadcasting; or

PARA.TAB: "(f) a total or partial forbearance in respect of:

TAB.TAB: (i)the use of, or the granting of the right to use any such property or right as is mentioned in paragraph (a) or any such equipment as is mentioned in paragraph (b);
(ii)the supply of any such knowledge or information as is mentioned in paragraph (c) or of any such assistance as is mentioned in paragraph (d); or
(iii)the use of, or the granting of the right to use, any such property as is mentioned in paragraph (e)".

TALK.START.PARA: —The new tax is meant to fall on non-resident companies, but most technology transfer agreements stipulate that the purchaser pay for any tax liability. As Australia represents only 2 per cent of world science and technology activity, it is inevitable that we have to import most of our technology. Peter Roberts, writing in the Australian Financial Review, notes that there must be something wrong with a country that relies on its imports of overseas technology and then introduces a draconian tax on that technology.

PARA.TAB: The Government has indicated to me that it will be moving an amendment to clarify the position for payments of royalties to residents of tax treaty countries who have a permanent establishment in Australia. Considering the comments written by noted tax experts in the industry concerning this section of the Bill, this is necessary.

A recent article in Butterworths Weekly Tax Bulletin No. 56, written by a Sydney barrister, Robert Gordon, summarised these comments exactly. I seek leave—and I sought approval previously from the Minister—to have that incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: by Robert Gordon BA LLB ASA Barrister, Sydney

PARA.TAB: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.5) 1992, introduced into Parliament on 15 October 1992, gives effect to a number of proposals announced by the Treasurer in the August 1992 Budget, including the introduction of a withholding tax on royalties paid to non-residents: see 1992 Bulletin [785].

In relation to royalties paid to a resident of a country with which Australia has a double tax agreement where the royalty is derived in carrying on business in Australia through a permanent establishment, the explanatory memorandum to the Bill specifies that such royalties would be treated as "business income" such that the tax liability would continue to be determined by assessment at normal rates of tax, rather than pursuant to the withholding tax system.

The amendments to apply from the commencement of the 1993-94 income year are to be effected by the extension of the current machinery provisions for the collection of interest and dividend withholding tax—Div 4 of Pt VI of the ITAA.

That interest derived by a permanent establishment of a non-resident is subject to tax by assessment, and not by the withholding tax mechanism, is a result of it being specifically exempted from withholding tax under s128B(3)(h)(ii) and that it is not made exempt income by s128D.

On the other hand, unfranked dividends derived through the permanent establishment of a non-resident (other than in relation to dividends derived from the assets included in the insurance funds of a non-resident life assurance company), continue to be subject to withholding tax as there is no specific exemption for them under s128B(3), and as such they are otherwise exempt by s128D.

The drafter of the explanatory memorandum must have assumed that royalties derived by the permanent establishment of a treaty partner resident, by falling out of the royalties article and into the "business profits" article, would thereby not be subject to Australian withholding tax, since to achieve that result under the domestic law it would have been necessary to introduce a provision such as s128B(3)(h)(ii) as applies to interest derived by the permanent establishment of a non-resident.

The "business profits" articles of Australia's double tax agreements are inconsistent with the denial of deductions to permanent establishments that flow under the domestic law, by unfranked dividends and from 1993-94, royalties (both subject to withholding tax), being exempt income by s128D.

Such a treaty partner resident will be able to assert pursuant to s4(2) of the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act, that the "business profits" article is inconsistent with the domestic law, so as to allow the relevant deductions by assessment. But this would not appear to relieve the payer of the royalty from the obligation to withhold tax and remit it to the Tax Office within the prescribed time according to the withholding tax provisions. Any excess tax withheld should be refunded after assessment of an annual tax return.

It is difficult to understand why the drafter of these provisions thought it was satisfactory to rely on the overriding provision of a relevant double tax agreement, when in relation to interest income derived by the permanent establishment in Australia of a non-resident (whether from a treaty country or not), s128B(3)(h)(ii) takes such interest income out of the withholding tax net.

The explanatory memorandum fails to acknowledge that in a vast majority of royalty contracts with non-residents, there is a "gross up" arrangement whereby the non-resident's withholding tax liability is, in effect, met by the Australian resident payer. That the increased tax liability under these measures will largely be met by Australian users of foreign technology, defies logic, at a time when Australia is seeking to become more internationally competitive.

To the extent that non-treaty country residents are to be denied all deductions in relation to Australian source royalty income, and treaty country residents will be disadvantaged as to the timing of their obtaining the benefit of deductions, there is considerable risk that either the cost of the technology on offer will be outside the reach of Australian licensees or the non-resident provider will potentially not wish to continue to licence Australian users.

It is also considered unfortunate that at the same time as the Bill extends the s73B deduction for 150% of certain research and development expenditure, there is no proposal to extend the s73A deduction for other research and development expenditure (which is available to non-residents), beyond the 30 June 1995 cut-off date. This is particularly so in the light of the fact that s73B deductions are only available to Australian incorporated companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the Government has signalled that it intends to clarify the situation with regard to royalty withholding tax, the industry has indicated to me that this still does not rectify the disparity that exists for similar payments to non-treaty countries which also have an existing permanent establishment in Australia. I know of one company which will have to pay this tax of 30 per cent on gross revenue. This is absolutely outrageous. It already pays tax on exactly the same basis as if it were an Australian company. Note that I said that the tax is 30 per cent of gross revenue. Our normal company tax rate is 30 per cent on revenue less expenses, or net expenses. This company will fold with the imposition of this withholding tax. Further problems with this stage of tax will be pursued at the committee stage, but I think it is atrocious to bring in such a heinous rate of tax that it will actually close companies in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) also extends the availability of tax deductions and depreciation to a wider field of environmental expenditure than is currently available. In particular, a deduction is allowed for this expenditure if incurred after 19 August 1992 and if incurred for the sole or dominant purpose of preventing, combating or rectifying pollution or treating, cleaning up, storing or removing waste. These amendments have generated considerable criticism from sectors of the industry. It is felt that the legislation has implications far beyond those even contemplated or intended by the IR&D Board.
Maria Lui, senior tax consultant with KPMG Peat Marwick, Melbourne, and Rodger Fernandez, a solicitor and lecturer in law, in Butterworths, edition No. 54 state:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislature should ensure that special care is taken to draft legislation from a global perspective rather than ad hoc amendments which have the detrimental result for greater uncertainty in tax legislation.

Presently, under the provisions of this Bill, a new section, 73CB, will be inserted in the Income Tax Assessment Act. This will deny deductions under section 73B if an eligible company incurs expenditure to a government body in connection with research and development activities carried out on behalf of the company if the Commissioner is satisfied that, when an expenditure was incurred, the company was not at risk in respect of the whole or part of the expenditure. It is this new section that has created all the comment.

PARA.TAB: Section 73CB has been described as not being in conformity with the Budget announcement which stated that deductions would be denied to participants in syndicates involving tax exempt bodies. The proposed legislation appears to have changed direction from tax exempt bodies to government bodies. This will be further pursued when the Bill is referred to the committee stage. Deductible losses on the disposal of traditional securities are also dealt with in this Bill. Section 70B is therefore being amended to prevent the deduction of losses incurred on the disposal or redemption of traditional securities after 30 June 1992, if the securities are essentially of a capital nature.

The amendment will also apply to losses from the waiver or release of debts. The new rules will prevent a deduction from being allowed under section 70B if the traditional security is one that is regularly traded on a stock exchange or other securities markets and the disposal takes place in the ordinary course of trading on the market. This change has been described as perpetuating a gross tax inequity against taxpayers. As a result of this amendment there will be a lack of symmetry in the treatment of traditional securities in that gains will be assessable under section 26BB, yet losses of a capital nature will be quarantined losses. For example, a superannuation fund investing solely in fixed interest securities will be fully assessable on the gains yet will have a quarantined capital loss which will never be utilised. This is in direct contravention of sections 303 and 304 which are intended to stop this operation. There is a real mismatch in the tax legislation which we are introducing for the first time which is a major concern because of the lack of symmetry.

Further, it is of concern to taxpayers generally that section 70B has been amended to transfer the loss on disposal or redemption of a traditional security to a capital gains tax area. That is, should a section 70B loss be treated as capital gains tax loss, that loss cannot be offset against revenue and profits. Provisional tax arrangements have also been affected by this Bill with the uplift factor for 1992-93 being reduced from 10 per cent to 8 per cent, whilst the margin for error when estimating taxable income when varying provisional tax is to be increased from 10 to 15 per cent, which we welcome.

Considering the low inflation rate of approximately 1.7 per cent and the low economic growth being experienced, the uplift factor could have been dropped even further. In addition, for the years after 1993-94 the rate is to revert to 10 per cent. Apparently the Government does not believe all its economic advisers, who unanimously appear to be predicting a very slow climb out of this `recession we had to have' under the present economic policies.

Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) also covers several other important issues. The write-down valuation arrangements for horse breeding stock have been amended, and I note that the Australian Bloodhorse Breeders Association has submitted that these changes will affect the now lucrative export trade in bloodstock. This trade was expected to reach $50m by 1994. Significantly, the changes will affect the present relationship in this country with New Zealand. Presently the New Zealand bloodhorse breeding industry is in decline and is failing to attract new international buyers because of the positive dollar impact of the original 1985 write-downs which this amendment is now reversing. The overall effect of this proposed amendment will be to give this sort of advantage back to New Zealand.

The Bill also proposes to allow to become tax deductible gifts to certain environmental organisations. While not decrying the need for the tax deductibility of gifts, I do wonder whether this proposal is merely a political sop to the conservation element in our land.

I also note that this Bill has once again incorporated another one of Fightback's policies, that is, increasing the zone and related rebates by 12.5 per cent of assessments in respect of the 1992-93 year of income and by 25 per cent for assessments in respect of the 1993-94 year of income and subsequent years of income. Generally, the coalition, of course, welcomes these sorts of changes, and we note that the Government virtually has pinched this straight out of Fightback, a policy which it generally is trying to fight against.

I now turn my attention to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6). This Bill contains measures to implement changes announced in the August 1992 Budget, as well as changes to the prescribed payments system announced by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in July. The Bill gives effect to the Budget decision to deny a tax deduction for expenses incurred in relation to certain corporate wardrobes or uniforms. Employees will generally only be able to claim tax deductions for expenses incurred in purchasing, cleaning and repairing items that comprise a uniform or corporate wardrobe when the wearing of such clothing is expressly required by the employer as a condition for that employment. Fortunately, the Government has now backed down from its original Budget intention and will now not prevent the cost of non-compulsory uniforms from being deductible.

It was also announced that the Treasurer will develop strict guidelines to establish whether non-compulsory uniforms or wardrobes, as sets of clothing, are eligible for taxation purposes. Such guidelines are to be published as soon as possible after royal assent to the Bill. I think it is unfortunate that the clothing manufacturers and others involved in this trade are facing this period of instability and uncertainty. These guidelines should be available, should have been ready and should have been on the desk while this Bill was being debated.

Further, I understand that the Government amendments to be moved at the committee stage will provide for the establishment of a register of approved occupational clothing to be kept by the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority—more expense, more administrative cost and more complexity put on business.

The coalition at this point registers its strong disapproval of this sort of legislation on the run. Far too many questions have been left unanswered. If the industry itself is unclear, how does that place us as legislators who are supposedly passing this sort of legislation? There is a clarification that urgently needs to be made, and I call upon the advisers to see that that is expedited.

At the same time, if the actual wording of the Bill is examined, the Taxation Institute of Australia has noted, there will be real practical difficulties for employers and employees alike in determining at any particular time when there is a relevant policy preventing an employee from substituting items of uniform or corporate wardrobe, `except in special circumstances'. For example, since clothing is defined to include accessories such as ties, belts, scarves, et cetera, must the policies be set out in advance as to what special circumstances should exist for ties to be worn or not worn on a given day? This indicates the degree of stupidity that tax auditors can indulge in to impose penalties on so-called defaulting companies.

Moreover, there will be practical difficulties in establishing whether an employer has, in fact, enforced such a priority. I think it is an absolutely ridiculous imposition on employers. When one considers that, in the corporate wardrobe industry, designs and orders for materials are made up two years in advance, one realises that this method of legislating on the run is just not good enough, particularly in an environment in which this industry is facing such severe tariff reductions.

Another proposal in the Bill that has attracted volumes of criticism is the amendment to make limited partnerships subject to the same tax provisions as companies. This measure is to apply immediately to limited partnerships formed after 19 August 1992 and to those existing prior to that from 1995-96. The effect of this measure presumably will be the elimination of some alleged taxation advantages which limited partnerships can have over companies, particularly the opportunity to pass off losses directly to investors and the ability of investors, including non-residents, to receive tax-free distributions.

However, many facets of the business world and taxation academia have strongly opposed this piece of legislation. It is moving against international trends, when limited partnerships are the accepted vehicle for major infrastructure development in Australia—development that we need and employment opportunities that we need. The Government is putting the nail in the coffin. The proposal to treat limited partnerships as companies for taxation purposes is based on the view that taxation advantages offered by limited partnerships have the potential to erode the revenue base. However, in reality, the exact opposite will be the case.

The Taxation Institute notes that these limited partnership proposals will be counterproductive to encouraging investment. The Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants notes that this proposal will limit the entities available for the carrying on of a business within Australia; that it will have a substantial effect on investment, especially in relation to new projects that incur losses and bear substantial risks in the early years; and that any loss to the revenue base in the early years will be more than offset by the increase to revenue from the gains made in the later years. Then there is all the revenue that will be gained as a result of the employment consequences and the accelerated impact on other industries.

Any scope for tax avoidance can easily be catered for through the general anti-avoidance provision of part IVA which is available to deny the benefit of blatant, artificial or contrived tax avoidance schemes. Butterworths Weekly Tax Bulletin, No. 42, in an article by Terence and Deborah Dwyer and Jeff Mann, taxation experts, notes that `the mere fact that losses flow through to partners does not constitute tax avoidance'. That is an important point that is made by those tax experts.

For a government that promotes the use of a level playing field, this taxation proposal is contrary to that philosophy. Dwyer's article notes that `treasury is tilting the playing field against higher risk investment in new technology "niche" industries', in addition to the bias towards encouraging a monopoly on the sale of new technology to larger companies with the income necessary to absorb start-up costs. Limited partnerships were introduced originally as a convenient and flexible method for investment purposes and have also been regarded as the ideal investment vehicle for projects subject to substantial risks in the early years. Current legislation exists in the States of New South Wales, Western Australia and Queensland for limited partnerships.

Much concern has been expressed at the high-handed manner in which the Federal bureaucracy is seeking to eliminate limited partnerships. This proposal will frustrate recent State sponsored initiatives for business growth and development. Limited partnerships offer real benefits for States seeking private capital for infrastructure. One can only wonder whether the Government wishes to encourage investment or whether it wishes to continue along the path of the `recession we had to have'.

To conclude, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) also contains measures to implement the amendments to the prescribed payments system which are designed to reduce the administrative burden on payers, payees and the ATO. We welcome this move. Dividend streaming arrangements have also been refined so that they will marginally improve the international dividend streaming arrangements. The amendments will result in a resident company being able to preserve a portion of its available franking credits to be offset against the franking debit that arises under the dividend streaming provisions where a non-resident associate pays a related dividend under the streaming arrangement.

The coalition welcomes this move but has severe reservations about aspects within both Bills Nos 5 and 6 and the implications they are going to have on the Australian economy. We have reservations and, to that end, we have referred the Bills to a committee for further scrutiny on Friday, 11 December. We welcome the participation of interested parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak specifically on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. This Bill provides for an increase in the Medicare levy from 1.25 per cent to 1.4 per cent of taxable income from 1 July 1993. In the 1992 Budget it is estimated that this initiative will raise $300m in 1993-94. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Baldwin) in his second reading speech stated that this revenue will fund outlay measures for health and aged care announced in the Budget. Thankfully, long-suffering Australians may never be burdened with this latest taxation impost of the Keating Government. The coalition's health policy, which was released as part of the Fightback package in November 1991, states that under a coalition government the Medicare levy will remain at 1.25 per cent of taxable income and will not be increased. Since the Budget announcement increasing the Medicare levy, the shadow Minister for health, Dr Woods, has stated that a Liberal-National Party government will return the Medicare levy to 1.25 per cent.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt about it, Australia's health system is in crisis. Public waiting lists have increased to between 70,000 and 100,000. Private hospitals remain underutilised, with a 55 to 60 per cent occupancy rate. Hospital costs have risen by 163 per cent over the last 10 years. Between 1982-83 and 1991-92 expenditure on medical services and benefits grew at a rate of 19.5 per cent per year. Since Medicare commenced in 1984, the proportion of the population privately insured has dropped from above 60 per cent to about 40 per cent. One of the effects of this has been an increase in the cost of private health insurance, which has risen over the past five years by 130 per cent. These are just some of the symptoms of Australia's current health care crisis. It is a crisis that just will not go away. It is a crisis which will not be solved—in the short or the long term—by tinkering at the edges while ignoring the fundamental problems inherent in Medicare.

The initiative in this Bill is basically a fraud. Funds obtained from the Medicare levy currently provide only 8 per cent of the total health care costs. Any Australians who are tricked into believing that their Medicare levy covers the costs of health in Australia are being fooled. It covers, currently, 8 per cent of the health care costs. Yet the Government through its publicity continues to inculcate into the minds of members of the Australian public the false perception that the Medicare levy guarantees that all Australians will have access to free and timely health care.

The increase in the Medicare levy to 1.4 per cent in this Bill shows that this Government does not have the courage to tackle Australia's health care problems. It is unwilling to correct the imbalance between the private and public hospital systems. It lacks the political willpower to introduce a price signal or co-payment in order to reduce overservicing and the overuse of medical services. It does not have the ability to reduce the escalating out of pocket medical expenses faced by health care consumers.

The question has to be asked: why does this Government continue to ignore the fundamental problems in our health care system to the point where three State health Ministers and one Territory health Minister have called on the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to scrap the proposed Medicare agreement? In fact, one Minister, a Labor Minister, has resigned over the issue. The answer is simple, and it has nothing to do with the health care needs of Australian citizens. The Government's inaction is based on a belief that the majority of the voting public who do not require regular medical attention still cling to the false perception that Medicare is a free and universal health care system to which they will have ready access.

I do not believe that the Government's intransigence in the face of the State health Ministers' current revolt is even ideologically based. Maybe some of it is. For purely political reasons, the Government has ducked the much needed reforms of our health care system such as introducing a patient co-payment and encouraging a system of tax credits for taking out private health insurance.

In order to continue to perpetrate this fraudulent perception of free health care, this Government has ignored the advice of its own Minister, the advice of the public servants, the advice of the States, the advice of the medical professions, the advice of the health insurance sector, and the advice of the private hospital sector and the public hospital sector. Who else has to give it advice?

Not only has this Government ignored the advice from all and sundry but, worse still, this decision to increase the Medicare levy is a culmination of this Government's back-flip on one of the very few decent health care related decisions it has made during the last 10 years. In the 1991 Budget the Government announced the introduction of a $2.50 co-payment for Medicare services, and Senator Tate—the Minister sitting here—was the person who had to defend that. He put up all the arguments why it was so wonderful. And we agreed with him—for once. It was a positive attempt to reduce the health care costs so that there was a price signal to let people know that it cost something to go to the doctor, that there was a cost involved to the taxpayer. It was a good idea. But shortly after the Budget announcement the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) said:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that to produce the same fiscal result as our GP package (Medicare co-payment) would require a lift in the Medicare levy from 1.25 per cent of income to 1.53 per cent and because this would not stem the growth in service use, further increases in the levy would be required in later years.

He foreshadowed that it needed to be 1.53 per cent without the co-payment, that the overservicing would not be stemmed and that the levy would be required to be increased. We were told that by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. And what happened? The Government back-flipped on it. Mr Howe continued:

The fact is that it is neither equitable nor efficient to pump more money into a system which is oversupplied with practitioners and delivering unnecessary services. It would be inequitable to increase the compulsory contribution of working people to finance unnecessary services and services of marginal clinical value brought about by too many doctors.
What did he say again? He said:
It would be inequitable to increase the compulsory contribution of working people to finance unnecessary services and services of marginal clinical value. . .

That is what he said this time last year. He said that it would be inequitable for working people, the people that those in the Party on the opposite side say they represent. They have been represented badly for 10 years. Now what is going to happen to the few that are still working? They are going to pay 1.4 per cent in increased tax, which Mr Howe himself said was inequitable. Those on the other side ought to be squirming.

PARA.TAB: At the time, the Government estimated that the co-payment would result in savings of $1.6 billion over four years. As I said earlier, this current initiative is estimated to result in increased annual revenue of $300m. Given the ongoing recessed state of the economy and the fact that the Government's estimate of revenue from the Medicare levy was not realised last financial year, there must be some doubt and some question cast on whether this revenue estimate will even be realised. As more people join the dole queues, that revenue raised from the Medicare levy will decrease.

However, I guess that the sixty-four dollar question we ought to be asking is whether the Government, if the Australian public foolishly re-elected it, will increase the levy again next year and again the year after and so on. Mr Howe has said that that is the likely outcome of not having a Medicare co-payment. Prior to the chairs being shifted on the Titanic last December, when Mr Howe and his representative in this chamber were fighting and telling us about the importance of the Medicare co-payment, Mr Howe claimed that if there was no co-payment further increases in the levy would be required in later years. I have said that before and I will say it again.

Three or four surveys have been carried out with taxpayers' money—the few people left in the work force. The interesting thing is that those surveys have shown that a significant proportion of Australians—something like 70 per cent or more; I would like 70 per cent to approve of something I was suggesting—thought we should have a co-payment as a price signal. If the Minister is telling the Government that this is what it should have, if the surveys are telling us that the public accept it, if it is going to bring in revenue, and if it would mean that the Medicare levy does not have to be increased, I would have thought the Government would have kept it. But no, there is no co-payment now. Why? It was done away with as an integral part of the Keating leadership coup.

About this time last year, around the corridors of Parliament House people were negotiating. They were changing their vote. Members of the Left were shifting over. They were about to shift Mr Hawke right out of the Lodge. One part of shifting him out of the Lodge involved getting rid of the Medicare co-payment because that was going to buy one or two votes. Some people might shake their heads, but that is the truth. That is what happened: he was bought out, sold for a shekel. A few Judases kissed Mr Hawke on the cheek or on the ear, supped with him, and then tossed him out. That is what they did, but they bought that. They did not want that co-payment. That has cost Australia enormously. It has cost every working Australian an increase in the Medicare levy, to start with. No doubt it has cost an increase in the hospital queues as well.

The fundamental problems in Medicare have not been tackled. There is no price signal in the system to stem overuse and overservicing, for the patient to question the doctor about why he or she should return to the surgery for a result. There is no signal at all. The public hospital system remains undercapitalised. I had a phone call the other day from a person I used to be associated with as a colleague and he said, `Come up to the hospital now and have a look at the people who have been lying on trolleys in casualty for days because we cannot get them into wards. I have just treated somebody on the floor'.

The private hospital system is underutilised. With an election looming, Labor is even less inclined to encourage those who can afford it to take greater responsibility for their own health care. Expenditure on medical services continues to rise at a rapid rate. It is little wonder that, when Mr Howe was asked on ABC radio the day after the Budget whether there would be any future increase in the Medicare levy beyond 1.4 per cent, he was reluctant to comment, saying that it would not be useful to do so. It was very difficult for him to comment, I suppose, because he had already said that to cover what would be lost if we did not have a Medicare co-payment the levy would have to go up to 1.53 per cent, I think it was, and that there would be increases in future years. It must have been very difficult for him to go back on what he had said but particularly difficult to say there would not be an increase.

This decision to raise the Medicare levy to 1.4 per cent and impose a further taxation burden on Australians, regardless of whether they choose to take out private health care insurance, must be seen in its true light. Even with the Government's proposed waiting list reforms and the allocation of more funds to the bonus pool, it is really nothing but a bandaid approach taken in the interests of political expediency rather than improved public health care. Thankfully, an incoming coalition government will mean that the Australian public will not have to wait as long for the needed reforms to our ailing health care system as many of them have had to wait on the long hospital queues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and to make four points about that wide-ranging tax measure and the other Bills that are being taken together. Those four small points, which will have a big impact on a lot of industry in rural and remote areas, are the provisional tax uplift factor; the measure to give credit for tax deducted from investment income when varying down provisional tax; increased margins for error allowed when varying down provisional tax; and the zone rebate increase.

PARA.TAB: The Government has decided to drop the provisional tax uplift from 10 per cent to 8 per cent. I am sure that people will correct me if I am wrong, but I thought that this measure was introduced by the Government to take into consideration one's supposed increase in profits each year as one's business is supposed to expand. I have been saying ever since I came to this place that this is an unfair measure because people do not really know whether their business will increase next year or not. Even in these depressed times—I am sure that everyone knows that this is the worst depression we have had for the last 60 years—the Government is still presuming an increase in profit of 8 per cent. Anyone here would know that that is a totally ridiculous situation.

The 8 per cent supposed increase in profit comes at a time when inflation is supposed to be somewhere near zero. It comes during the worst depression for 60 years. It also comes when interest rates on invested savings, which have a lot to do with provisional tax, are almost at an all-time low. Before the Government claims too much credit for interest rates being at an all-time low, let me say that that is mainly because the Government is the only one borrowing money these days, to overcome its shortfall, especially in the One Nation package. Private enterprise, or business, is not borrowing. When the economy does improve, I am sure that interest rates will go back to somewhere near normal again.

We are always told by Senator McMullan and others that people can vary provisional tax if they do not think they will be making an increased profit of 8 per cent or so. But, of course, they incur a penalty if they are wrong, even though there is something in this Bill to address that matter. I believe that, under section 221YDB of the Income Tax Assessment Act, there are fairly severe penalties if one is more than 10 per cent out. That is what it used to be. Now it is going to be increased to 15 per cent. Of course, to vary provisional tax also costs quite a lot in increased accountancy fees.

In this measure, the dropping of that uplift factor from 10 per cent to 8 per cent is only for this year. I presume that the Government thinks there is going to be a big upswing in the economy the year after that, in 1993. I can tell honourable senators that the only way there will be increased activity in Australia is if we have a Hewson government by that time.

I move to the next point I wish to address—that of giving credit for tax deducted from investment income when varying provisional tax. I welcome this move, of course, but I believe that it has not come about for the reason that the Government is supposedly giving—because of those who do not supply their tax file number and are then taxed at the rate of 49 per cent plus the Medicare levy. I believe that it was in the legislation in the first place to cover the Government's proposal that was later defeated by public pressure regarding a withholding tax on bank interest. I believe it was included for that purpose.

If the Government has decided to forget the idea of a withholding tax on bank interest, I believe it will only be for a very short time because Senator Button, in answering a question from me yesterday or the day before, did not rule it out in the life of the Parliament. So I believe that is why it was included there, not necessarily because of those who do not supply tax file numbers. All the same, I do welcome the measure. I made the point when the Government was thinking—and I believe it still is, of course—of having a withholding tax on bank interest that it would have been covered by provisional tax anyhow, so there would be no real necessity to have it.

The third point that I would like to address in the limited time available to me is the increase in the margin for error in varying provisional tax from 10 per cent to 15 per cent. Of course, anyone as old as I am would remember—and even Senator Crichton-Browne might remember—when that margin was 20 per cent—not 10 per cent, not 15 per cent, but 20 per cent. That gave a reasonable margin for error.

Many Government members think that it is quite easy to vary provisional tax and get it spot on. One can get it fairly spot on, but it all depends on what sort of business one is in. When it comes to rural industries, it is not nearly as predictable as in the case of a big supermarket, a corner store or something like that, where one gets a trend for the year—it all depends on what the mood of the country is—and that trend will generally continue from the end of February to the end of June.

Rural industries are vastly different. In the wheat industry or the wool industry, the end of the harvest may occur on 28 February and those are the figures that are used to do one's variation of provisional tax. Of course, what is always up in the air regarding payments from the Wheat Board is whether it will drop one in on 28 June or on 5 July. That makes a big difference. A reasonable payment coming in then will blow the 10 per cent variation, the 15 per cent variation and it can easily blow the 20 per cent variation as well. So it can work in some industries and commercial activities, but it certainly does not work in the rural industry. I welcome the 15 per cent variation proposal, but I condemn the Government for not allowing a 20 per cent variation and I also condemn it for putting it in only for one year.

The final point I would like to address relates to the zone rebates that this Government has decided to increase by 25 per cent, starting fairly well down the track. Being from a remote area, I welcome this measure, but I say that the Government is only fiddling at the edges, because those zone rebates should have increased a long time ago by far more than they have now.Of course, we flagged this in the Fightback package and the Government has copied it, but it has decided not to bring it in until way down the track, and we will have brought in the Fightback measures by then, anyhow. Correct me if I am wrong, but it will be bringing them in only six months before we will introduce them under the Fightback package. Of course, this Government is not going to be in power to implement them at that time.

I will show how much the Government is fiddling at the edges with regard to zone rebates. It will have a financial impact on revenue of $5m in 1992-93, increasing to $19m in 1993-94. So if it will only have a financial impact of $19m by that time, it shows that the Government is fiddling at the edges.

Of course, under the Fightback measures, we will be doing far more for our rural and remote areas. Mr Hulls from the House of Representatives—I think he represents the seat of Kennedy—claimed fame for having these measures put into place, but I believe they were copied out of the Fightback package. He was telling us how good they were for Kennedy—and probably it would be the same for the seat of Kalgoorlie, which I live in—but they are certainly nowhere near enough. We will be far better off with the Fightback package, under which we are taking off 26c a litre on fuel and taking off sales tax and all those other measures. In conclusion, I welcome some of the measures but condemn the Government for not going far enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to take this opportunity in this cognate debate to refer very quickly to the matter of the taxing of limited partnerships as companies, which my colleague Senator Watson has referred to in his brief contribution to the debate. It is a great shame that the Government, helped by the Democrats, has ensured that these complicated matters which affect the lives of so many Australians can be debated for only such a short time.

PARA.TAB: The limited partnerships taxation decision announced in the Budget is not a matter which is very sexy when it comes to politics, but it is something that will hurt this nation at a time when its infrastructure has run down—and this is on the admission of both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). The expenditure decisions in the One Nation statement were to a great extent designed to pump some money into our rapidly running down infrastructure. That was public money, borrowed money, money which would force up interest rates. Most people in Australia know—or do not know, but should know—that Australia still suffers some of the highest real interest rates in the world. This makes the cost of money which should go into infrastructure or any other development project higher than it should be.

It was proposed to use the limited partnership structure in the very fast train project. It has been used in a number of major infrastructure and development projects—for example, Mr Acting Deputy President, tourism developments in our own State of Western Australia. It is a structure that is tax effective in that people can make an investment through a limited partnership structure and can use the losses suffered in the early years of these major projects to offset against income from other sources.

The Government's proposal is clearly designed to ensure that it reaps income in the current year; it has clearly signalled that it does not want to wait around for the income from limited partnership structures, particularly in infrastructure projects. As we know, by their very nature infrastructure projects involve a massive investment of funds up front and low and limited returns many years down the track. That applies whether one is building a major road, a tunnel, a bridge or a railway, and it also occurs when one is building a major tourism development where masses of funds need to be invested up front. Australia is now in a position where it needs infrastructure development. It needs tourism development; it needs major development, and this one measure—

TALK.START.PARA: —It needs a new government.

—It certainly needs a new government, but it needs investment in these major projects to ensure that it stays competitive in the world. I think the decision the Government has taken here is a short term one. I am quite sure that Senator Button would not have supported this decision in Cabinet. I know that he is privately disturbed about the decision to tax limited partnerships as companies. He was personally responsible for encouraging the Victorian Government to introduce legislation to ensure that it had a limited partnership structure in place so that it could be used to fund major infrastructure projects and to allow private investment infrastructure.

PARA.TAB: The decision announced in the Budget by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) to tax limited partnerships as though they were companies will ensure that many projects that we will not even be aware of will not get to the drawing board stage. It is a short term decision. It will cost Australia jobs. It will cost Australia infrastructure. It is a Budget announcement which the Government should be roundly condemned for. In the short time I have available, I want to say that the Government stands condemned for this very short term decision which will cost Australia jobs, cost Australia investment and cost Australia a place in a competitive world environment.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring to the attention of the Senate yet another appalling decision by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin. He has recently announced that he will not permit Australian research fellowships and senior research fellowships to be tenable at Commonwealth research organisations and at the Institute of Advanced Studies at the ANU.This decision is completely unjustified and is contrary to the objectives of the fellowship scheme, which were to encourage the return of world class expatriate researchers, to support high quality research and to develop research skills fundamental to the national interest with the aim of boosting Australia's research and technology push. This move by the Minister focuses on the potential contribution of the fellowship holder to the host institution rather than to the contribution of the productivity of Australia's research effort overall.

PARA.TAB: The Minister's decision is contrary to the real national interest. As stated by the shadow Minister for education, Dr Kemp, if there is a public interest in facilitating career paths and research then this public interest also requires that those career paths be able to be developed in the most appropriate institution, whatever that may prove to be. If an institution has successfully established itself with a reputation for world class research, this is not a reason to provide incentives for outstanding researchers to go elsewhere in order to give other institutions similar reputations at the expense of established institutions.

The Minister's decision was made in a very sneaky way, with no press release, a selective leak to the media and a letter to the heads of institutions concerned. If such a dramatic change in policy towards Australian research fellowships had to be announced in such a low key way, the Minister is obviously ashamed of what he is doing and it is clearly the wrong decision.

The Australian Research Council has for a long time declared that there is a clear policy to support research excellence and research concentration. It is damaging to both training and the research requirements of fellows to deny them the opportunity to work in certain institutions. In the current arrangement fellowships are awarded to individuals, not to institutions, and that is the way it should stay.

The Minister's decision is damaging not only to research but to the ambitions of a clever country. It represents a waste of resources by bureaucratic edict. Most of all, it is bad for the fellows and for the fellowship scheme because it limits the prospects and opportunities, and on average it reduces the incentive for the best researchers to return to Australia. The needs of research are paramount, not the needs of the host institution.

The Minister's decision is harmful to the people who are most concerned, the fellows who are so rigorously selected as the best researchers available. It is extremely harmful to the conduct of Australian research. The awards should be made on the basis of excellence and the `awardee' should be able to go to the best places for research. To debar the ANU and the CSIRO from these awards contradicts the primary aims of the awards as stated, and that is to reward excellence.

Because of the high profile of the ANU and the CSIRO internationally, the new policy will strongly compromise Australia's ability to attract back high quality people from overseas. The concept of a clever country is universally agreed upon and applauded. But how can the clever country become a reality unless excellence is the overriding criterion? For the sake of the clever country and the continuing success of Australia's research, the Minister must reverse this poorly thought out decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to discuss the current funding crisis afflicting universities across this country. In particular, I wish to draw attention to the chronic funding shortage in New South Wales higher education institutions, specifically the University of Technology and the University of Sydney. The Sydney Morning Herald has highlighted this problem recently in its series `Campus crisis', which detailed the extent of the cutbacks and the effects on course size and quality and staffing.

PARA.TAB: It does not give me any pleasure to relate the problems facing these institutions—each symbolising the oldest and the newest aspects of higher education in this country. Sydney University is the oldest tertiary institution in Australia. For many years it has enjoyed a wonderful reputation based on the outstanding quality of its teaching and research, for its beautiful campus, its classical architecture and broad extracurricular activities. Today Sydney University is suffering due to funding shortfalls and the increased pressures brought about by the Dawkins led reforms of 1987 and the amalgamation process.

Sydney University is now host to five satellite campuses: the Cumberland College of Health Sciences, the Faculty of Nursing campus, the College of the Arts campus, the Conservatorium of Music campus and the Faculty of Education campus. Like many other institutions, Sydney University faced insurmountable government pressure to amalgamate—pressure that at times was tantamount to blackmail.

University administrations, student organisations, staff and students all over the country have had to adapt to the stress of an increased student load and, with it, a need for greater services, transport hassles and greater education requirements. To cope with these new responsibilities, little government funding or assistance was forthcoming. Instead, in the interests of `rationalisation' and `streamlining', students and staff dealt as best they could with the mega-institutions that had been created. Today our oldest university is contemplating massive cutbacks to staff and courses and, consequently, education quality. The University of Sydney is not alone.

The University of Technology, Sydney, formerly the Sydney Institute of Technology, merged with campuses from the college sector to create a new university. Almost overnight, it was expected, this institution would transform from a technology driven place of learning to adopt a more classical mode of teaching and research. Similarly, the colleges with which it merged were products of a different education sector again, one that had a more liberal educational influence. These vastly different education institutions, each serving different education purposes and responding to different community and personal needs, were thrown into the Dawkins hotpot, which almost halved the number of tertiary institutions in Australia.

This dramatic transformation of the higher education system took place at a rate and to an extent that was unprecedented. In some cases, the short term consequences of the merger process proved too much for some institutions, such as the University of New England and the Maritime College in Tasmania. Many institutions are only beginning to witness the long term consequences of amalgamations.

This leads me to the articles in last week's Sydney Morning Herald entitled `Campus crisis'. They exposed the severe funding shortfall in New South Wales higher education institutions. The articles revealed the level of expected funding cuts to UTS and Sydney University and proclaimed that this represents a national funding crisis for education. It is obvious that subsistence funding levels at these institutions will severely diminish the quality of courses, and the hardest hit are the humanities faculties.

I have received petitions from Sydney University students and I strongly support their protests against the economic rationalist approach of the university administration and the diminution of the level and quality of their courses that will occur as a result of funding cuts.

Staffing cutbacks, by as many as 40 people in 1994 in Sydney University's Arts Faculty, will result in reduced access to teaching staff for students, less supervision in specialist areas of study and undue pressure on all-important staff-student relationships. Plans to privatise security and cleaning services, and cuts to staff entitlements such as sick leave at Sydney University, greatly concern me, as do reports that the Science and Engineering faculties at UTS use computer simulation for experiments, that field trips have been reduced and that teacher training has been halved.

UTS has a greater number of part time students—49 per cent—than any other university, and thus suffers under the Government's relative funding model, where two part time students are funded to the equivalent of one full time student. The university will enjoy only a 2.5 per cent increase in funding next year, most of which will be spent on salary increases. In the meantime, teacher numbers are declining, class sizes are increasing and scientific equipment necessary to science and media courses is obsolete.

Similar reports have come from the University of New South Wales. Professor John Milfull, Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences at the University of New South Wales, has reported on findings that show this faculty was underfunded by 10 to 15 per cent last year. Chronic underfunding of our universities threatens the atmosphere and the environment of institutions that are the lifeblood of our intellectual progression as a society. Funding levels per full time student in higher education have been slashed by almost 10 per cent in the five years between 1984-85 and 1989-90.

This Government has failed to match increased places with funding for infrastructure, staffing and capital works. Students have had to tolerate substandard facilities, with overcrowded tutorials and lectures, inadequate laboratory equipment, insufficient course materials and library books, which contravene occupation health and safety regulations and have a detrimental effect on teaching standards. Students are rightly suggesting that the education they pay for must be of an excellent standard if this country is to emerge from recession and if we are to become the clever country. This crisis signals an erosion of the historical role of a university in providing a centre for learning, research and progress and suggests that the Government's priority areas are those mostly commercially viable areas and do not stress other areas such as the humanities.

I have outlined examples of tertiary institutions that are feeling the pinch in my home State of New South Wales. Unfortunately, there are many more examples I could discuss as well. I stress the importance of this matter and urge the Government, with its economic rationalist view of education, to reconsider the role of education in society. Education is not a revenue raising measure that produces graduates in the same way as products come off a conveyor belt; it is a guiding light that leads to a more democratic and inspired society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate a matter of grave concern for members of the Australian Defence Force concerning restrictions that the Government, through the Public Service Commissioner, has placed on ADF members who take redundancy and then wish to gain employment in the Australian Public Service. The restriction means that redundant Australian Defence Force members are excluded from joining the Public Service for a period of time equal to the length of their severance benefit. The maximum exclusion period equals the maximum redundancy payment of 48 weeks.

PARA.TAB: This policy was conveyed to the Department of Defence by the Public Service Commissioner, Mr Denis Ives, in a letter dated 11 September 1992. But the final date for Army personnel to nominate themselves for redundancy was 8 July 1992. There is no doubt that the 510 members who nominated themselves and were subsequently accepted for redundancy did not know on 8 July that there was a restriction on their ability to join the Australian Public Service. The only restriction members were aware of on 8 July was that contained in the ministerial determination No. 211 of 1989 made under section 58B of the Defence Act. Paragraph 11 of that determination is quite clear. If an Australian Defence Force member who is made redundant subsequently rejoins the Australian Defence Force within 12 months of leaving, without ministerial approval, in a full time uniformed position, he must repay the redundancy payment in full. There is absolutely no mention of any restriction on, or penalty for, joining the Australian Public Service.

The facts are that 49 Army personnel left the Australian Defence Force on the redundancy program before learning of the receipt of Mr Ives's letter and the policy contained therein. Yet during debate on the report of Estimates Committee B on 10 November, in response to a question from Senator Newman, the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) said:

SPEECH.PARA: If 50 in the Army did leave under a misapprehension—I would like Senator Newman to get all 50 to say that they did—we will assist them; we will approach the Public Service Commission and say, `These people have been disadvantaged. We do not believe the rules should apply to them. They should be helped'. Sure we are willing to help them.

The help to which the Minister refers is this: the 49 members who left the ADF without knowledge of the Public Service Commissioner's policy will be allowed to take up a position with the Public Service only if they repay their redundancy payment on a pro rata basis up to the maximum of 48 weeks.

PARA.TAB: The 461 who left, or will leave, after 30 September are now prevented from joining the Public Service for a period equal to that of their redundancy payment, up to the maximum of 48 weeks. The letter from the Public Service Commissioner, dated 11 September, states that this policy is in line with the restrictions placed on employees of the Australian Public Service and non-Australian Public Service Commonwealth agencies. In fact, Mr Ives said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I confirmed these arrangements apply to former APS staff and to staff retrenched by non-APS Commonwealth agencies. For this purpose the ADF is regarded as a non-APS Commonwealth agency.

This is in direct opposition to previous practice, which has recognised that Australian Defence Force members, despite being paid by the Commonwealth, do not enjoy Public Service conditions and pay. In fact, under section 87 of the Public Service Act 1922, ADF members are not classified as people employed by a Commonwealth authority, and no ADF member can take benefits under the Australian Public Service Redeployment and Retirement Award 1987. This means that redundant ADF members cannot be redeployed within the ADF, nor within the Australian Public Service or any other Commonwealth agency.

PARA.TAB: In addition, and I feel that this is the most important point, Australian Defence Force members do not enjoy any special rights over the general public in applying for Public Service jobs. The effect of the Public Service Commissioner's policy is only to stop ADF members applying for Australian Public Service jobs advertised externally which they must win on merit over all comers. This is a right which any member of the public has, including those who have taken a redundancy package from the private sector.

This issue is not new. Senator Newman raised it in this chamber on 10 November and Mr Rocher, the shadow Minister for defence science and personnel, raised it in the House of Representatives on 7 October. Both my colleagues have raised doubts about the legal basis of this policy. Indeed, I think this is the crux of the issue: the correctness and legality of the policy decision. Given that the advice given to the ADF about these new restrictions does not appear to be based on ministerial determination No. 211, I am interested to know on what basis and authority this decision has been made.

In reply to another question from Senator Newman during the debate on the report of Estimates Committee B on 10 November, the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, stated, and I quote from Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: I am saying that in terms of our having a policy on this matter, they being voluntary redundancies, it is open to us, I believe, to determine the conditions of those redundancies.
Yet during the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1992-93 in the House of Representatives on 7 October, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Bilney, said:

I need to point out very clearly that the Public Service Commissioner is an independent statutory position. There is no way in which a government can possibly interfere with his statutory role so I need to make it clear that, when he does come to a final decision on this matter, we are obliged, as Ministers in this Government, to accept the verdict that he hands down.

So I would like to ask: who exactly made that decision? Was it the Government and its Ministers, was it the independent Public Service Commissioner, or was it generated from within the Department of Defence; and, whoever made this policy decision, was it correct and legal?

PARA.TAB: I have made some inquiries as to the answers to these two questions and I am not really happy about the information that I have received. So I would ask the Minister for Defence whether I am correct in believing that: under section 33 of the Public Service Act 1922, the Public Service Commissioner does not have the power to extend the restriction which currently applies to Australian public servants to members of the Australian Defence Force; only a Minister can impose such a restriction by amending ministerial determination No. 211 of 1989, and any such restriction cannot be retrospective; alternatively, a Minister can impose such a restriction by introducing and passing a Bill to amend the Public Service Act 1922; and a Minister of this Government has made no such amendment to ministerial determination No. 211, nor has a Bill to amend the Public Service Act been introduced.

I believe that, if I am correct, it is entirely possible and even highly likely that members of the Australian Defence Force would be entitled to take legal action. Given the potential seriousness of this situation, I would also make the following inquiries of the Minister. Firstly, has the Minister or his Department sought, or are they seeking, legal advice on this matter, and what is that legal advice? Secondly, is the Minister aware of any other Government Minister or department, the Public Service Commission or any other interested body seeking such legal advice, and what is that legal advice? Thirdly, is the Minister aware of any member of the Australian Defence Force who is affected by this policy decision considering taking legal action through the courts? Fourthly, what correspondence have Government Ministers received from the headquarters of the Australian Defence Force, and does it contain advice, legal or otherwise, about the validity of the policy stated by the Public Service Commissioner?

I ask the Minister also whether, if I am correct in thinking that only a Minister can impose such a restriction by amending ministerial determination No. 211 or the Public Service Act 1922, and that this has not been done, the Minister will take the following actions as a matter of urgency: firstly, to instruct the Public Service Commissioner to withdraw his advice to the Department of Defence; secondly, to notify members of the Australian Defence Force who are about to leave that they are once again able to apply for Australian Public Service positions advertised externally on merit without restriction; thirdly, to ensure that any Australian Defence Force member who has already left and joined the Australian Public Service will not have to pay back to the Commonwealth part or all of the redundancy payment as previously advised; and, fourthly, to undertake to discover how many members left the ADF and won Australian Public Service positions on merit but were subsequently denied those positions, and re-offer them the position, offer them a similar position or, if that is not possible, compensate them adequately for being unjustly denied a position they were entitled to all along.

Finally, I am sure the Minister is fully aware that the 510 Army personnel caught up in this confusion were compelled to make a decision between two superannuation schemes—DFRDB and MSBS—by 30 September this year, a decision which the Minister knows cannot be changed. There can be no doubt that the major influence on their choice between the schemes was their impending redundancy. The importance of this choice should not be underestimated. There are vast differences between the two schemes. MSBS is almost identical to the Public Sector Superannuation scheme, providing benefits no matter when the Australian Defence Force member decides to leave, but DFRDB provides a lifelong pension only after the member has served 20 years. Under DFRDB, members who serve less than 20 years get back their own contributions only, not even interest on their contributions, and therefore lose considerable money. Surely it must be obvious that Army personnel on this redundancy program who had not yet served 20 years had no choice but MSBS.

I believe this goes a long way to explain why only three of the 461 members who were given the opportunity to withdraw from the redundancy program did so. I would suggest that, if they had been given the opportunity to reconsider their choice between DFRDB and MSBS, the number of withdrawals would be significantly higher. I look forward to a response from the Minister as to the legality of the policy stated by the Public Service Commissioner and to answers to the related matters I have raised today on behalf of hundreds of concerned Defence Force members.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Campbell, who indicated to me that if I wished to respond at this stage he would cede the call for three or four minutes. Secondly, I would like to make the point that, when debates on matters of public interest were first established through the committee dealing with Standing Orders, it was not envisaged that they would be used as an opportunity to have Ministers come in and reply. The fact that I do so today should not create an expectation that constantly on Thursdays various Ministers will come in to reply.

PARA.TAB: When senators such as Senator Ferguson show great courtesy by notifying Ministers that they want to raise something, there is an expectation that Ministers will come down on the adjournments when they are notified in advance, and if they do not it will be at their own peril because whatever is said is not answered. You will know that occasionally Ministers have a reason why they cannot come down on adjournments, but generally they try. I make that point because Senator Ferguson in his address did indicate he would like me to answer some questions.

Not being a shorthand note taker I did not take down all the questions, but the matter was raised by Senator Newman during Estimates committee hearings and I indicated to her at that stage the position we were at. I say across the chamber to Senator Newman, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I regret that the day after Senator Newman raised the matter one piece of advice arrived which would have been very useful to her the previous day, and I am critical of those who did not get it to me at the time.

The background to this is that in April this year the Army approached me with a proposal for a limited redundancy to assist it with `downsizing', that wonderful word that has got into the modern lexicon, to meet four structure objectives, in order to meet what I think we all recognise as greatly reduced separation rates over the last year and a half.

After consideration of a range of issues relating to the proposal, I approved a redundancy program of 350 in June of this year. The number of personnel who volunteered to take up the redundancy ended up being far in excess of the 350 I had authorised. Therefore, in August I approved an additional 160 redundancies, taking the total to 510, for 480 of which the equivalent positions would be abolished behind those leaving. I did leave scope for 30 promotions in the system because that again slows down in a time of poor attrition rates.

It was during discussions with the Department regarding these additional redundancies that the issue of what conditions would apply in terms of re-employment, in the public sector or elsewhere, first arose. At that time I indicated that normal Public Service conditions would apply. The Department then sought clarification from the Public Service Commissioner regarding the status of ADF members. The Public Service Commissioner wrote to the Department on 11 September 1992 making it clear that the ADF is regarded as a non-APS Commonwealth agency. As such, ADF members who accepted redundancy should not be employed in the APS, either immediately after or within a reasonable period of their separation from employment with the ADF.

We did receive inquiries from ADF members which prompted the three Service chiefs on 24 September 1992 to get advice on the Public Service Commission's policy. Neither the Government nor the Department wishes to see individual members disadvantaged by accepting a redundancy package without full knowledge of all the conditions that apply. This is a critical factor, I believe. If anyone has accepted a package without the full knowledge of what that package entails, then that disadvantage must be remedied, again stressing that this is a voluntary package and that, once all the conditions are known and people make the voluntary decision, that is their decision to make.

We had discussions with the Public Service Commissioner which produced an agreement that those Army members who had already accepted redundancy benefits and who separated before 30 September 1992 may apply for Public Service positions and be considered for employment without the required break in service. There was the condition that I think Senator Ferguson mentioned, that they must pay back to the Commonwealth the notional unexpired portion of their severance benefit, and all that comes back to why people pay redundancy benefits and the advantages that accrue therein. I might say that a 20-year veteran usually gets an equivalent of one year's pay, the tax benefit of which doubles its value. I think no-one in the Senate would challenge that particular point. All other members who accept the redundancy offer will be ineligible for Public Service employment during the term of the redundancy payment.

In addition, those members who have accepted redundancy but have not yet separated, who feel that this policy seriously affects their original acceptance, may elect to withdraw from the program. In other words, if they were offered a redundancy and they now believe, because they cannot get a job in the Public Service, that they do not want to proceed with the redundancy, they may return to the service.

Senator Ferguson raised the question of what is the overall legality of this particular situation. It is a question that I have also thought of. Recently, we sought and received advice from a QC, and that is under Government consideration. I am happy to release that QC's opinion when Government has considered the matter. I do not believe that it is general practice to do that before Government has considered the matter. But I must say that Mr Finnane, QC, in a very impressive opinion, has raised some of the questions that Senator Ferguson has raised here today, so that will impel me to give those considerations within Government.

The Department has just written to the Public Service Commissioner and requested that the policy be withdrawn until the matter is resolved by Cabinet. I do not believe we have had a response yet on that issue. The Government has separately asked the Public Service Commissioner to report on the options to deal with employment of people who have accepted voluntary retrenchment from government employment. In other words, the Government as a whole—I am not sure where it was initiated—has written to the Public Service Commissioner on this matter. We in Defence, raising specific defence issues, have written to the Commissioner and passed on Mr Finnane's legal opinion. I hope that this matter can shortly come to Cabinet and be resolved because there are issues of conflicting principle involved. I do not want to see any serviceman disadvantaged.

In conclusion, I have to say that redundancy, on the other hand, is a specific tool with which to assist people who are projected to be unemployed for some time. That is why it is treated so generously from a tax point of view. I stress again that this was voluntary. I stress again that those who took a voluntary redundancy, knowing all the conditions, made that personal decision themselves. If there were any—and I think I mentioned a figure to Senator Newman of up to 30—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; I stand corrected. With the up to 50 who may have accepted a redundancy not in full knowledge, we will assist in all ways to make sure they are not disadvantaged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to the discussion of matters of public interest today relates to the proposed World Heritage listing of the Nullarbor, a matter on which I have been campaigning for some year and a half now. Honourable senators will probably be aware that this World Heritage listing of the Nullarbor was proposed by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, 18 months or so ago with the support of the State Ministers for environment in South Australia and Western Australia. The Minister at that time in Western Australia was Mr Bob Pearce, who has since decided to resign as Minister for the environment for reasons that are well known in Western Australia, and the new Minister is Mr Jim McGinty, the member for Fremantle.

PARA.TAB: I wanted today to share with the Senate another piece of world heritage in the embodiment of a Mr Thomas Dimer who, like yourself, Mr Acting Deputy President, had the great honour to have been born out in the wild outback of Western Australia. He is 89 years old and I had the pleasure of meeting him last Friday. Thomas Dimer has spent most of his 89 years living on the Nullarbor and working out in the bush. He probably knows—and perhaps someone like Harry Butler could either support or contradict me in this—more about the flora and fauna of the Nullarbor region than any living person on this earth.

Thomas contacted me after I had made a number of public statements in relation to the proposed World Heritage listing of the Nullarbor, which I oppose, and asked to meet with me and share some of his knowledge. One of the great benefits of the meeting I had with him last Friday morning was that Thomas was able to show to me a book which he has written—or had transcribed for him. I think it is a series of interviews with some people from the Battye Library.

It is a fantastic tale of his life, which I was able to skim over in a short time. It started 89 years ago. There are stories about the pioneering days out on the Nullarbor and in the outback regions of Western Australia. It is a book which Thomas seeks to publish. I gave an undertaking to him last Friday that I would seek to find someone to help fund the publication of this story. It is a unique part of Australia's history and something which has led me to call Tom Dimer a person who should actually be listed as World Heritage, far more so than the Nullarbor region itself.

Tom Dimer is an interesting character. He knows and loves the Nullarbor probably more than just about any living person on this earth, and yet he is vehemently opposed to the World Heritage listing. He sets out his reasons in a letter he wrote to the West Australian newspaper, which in its great wisdom it decided not to publish. I call on it to publish the letter because, firstly, Tom Dimer is a great old character who has a story to tell, and, secondly, he adds some important facts to the debate about whether the Nullarbor region would be protected or enhanced by having a boundary drawn around it which would be posted off to World Heritage headquarters. I think the headquarters is in Geneva or Paris or some other city of great relevance to the Nullarbor.
