With the indulgence of the Senate, I shall read parts of his letter. Mr Dimer sets out some of the problems that have faced the Nullarbor over the last 100 years, mostly relating to feral and vermin animals. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed World Heritage Listing for the Nullarbor Region is intended to protect native plants and animals. However, it may be counter-productive.

The station owners and farmers there have taken an interest in the well-being of their surrounding properties for a number of years. Feral or vermin animals (especially cats, foxes and dogs) have been controlled whenever possible. The local people have been trying to redress the damage done by early introductions. By curtailing the efforts of these people the Environment Minister would create an uncontrolled breeding ground where native species stand little chance of survival as the vermin would be out of control as they can increase very fast left to their own survival.

I have spent many of my 89 years on the Nullarbor. My experience has spanned many decades as I have worked for the Agricultural Protection Board, local Councils and the Police Department on many occasions.
To list this area as World Heritage or an A Class Reserve is only creating a haven for the vermin. The vermin (especially the introduced kind)—
I guess he might be referring to politicians when he says that—
is eradicating all the native species such as an example:-

The 5 different kinds of lizards, goannas, snakes and such like. The hopping creatures such as the ring tailed possums, tree kangaroos (which there are at least 4 other kinds of species). They wiped out the curlews, plovers and all birds that nest close to the ground. The cats especially, which were introduced early in the century, are endangering a lot of creatures because of their ability to survive on the small native creatures.
All these species were in plentiful numbers especially on the Nullarbor Plains. I have noticed this more so from the early twenties as I was around that area for quite some years.

During the 80 odd years of my experience with the bush—I studied the wildlife and flora and quite often would open up the different kinds of vermin and discover particles of native animals inside them that hadn't been digested. I would at any time be prepared to debate with the environmental ministers over this issue as I feel that he is doing great damage to native wildlife.

The point that Tom makes in a long letter—probably too long for the West Australian—reinforces my own experiences on the Nullarbor, having crossed the Nullarbor on road and rail about 17 or 18 times in the last 15 years. His point is that the station owners, the motel operators and the highway operators all have a very strong vested interest in controlling vermin and in protecting their environment. To a man, woman and child on the Nullarbor—almost all of whom have signed the petitions that I have been tabling in the Senate virtually every day for the last year—they are opposed to World Heritage listing.

PARA.TAB: They are scared of World Heritage listing, particularly the pastoralists, who fear that, even with the best intentions of the current Ministers for the environment and the best assurances given them by the Western Australian Labor Government, the South Australian Labor Government and the Federal Labor Government, the security of their tenure on their leases would not be affected by World Heritage listing, the listing is a threat to their tenure and therefore a direct threat to their investment in things such as fencing, which is used to control vermin, and water conservation, which is designed and implemented to preserve the natural vegetation. This investment costs millions and millions of dollars every year and this investment, which specifically helps the environment on the Nullarbor, is put at threat—not only by World Heritage listing but also by the very threat of World Heritage listing.

Honourable senators may or may not know that the World Heritage listing was intended to proceed this year and that the State Government in Western Australia, probably for political reasons, allowed that date for nomination to pass without the nomination going forward. The governments responsible, the Federal Government and the two State governments I have referred to, spent just over $100,000 this year having three studies done into the heritage values of the Nullarbor. None of those studies involved any consultation whatsoever with the local people—a matter which I have raised many times. People like Tom Dimer who really do know about the Nullarbor were not spoken to. The pastoralists and graziers who spend every day of their lives working on the Nullarbor, who understand the flora and the fauna better than any bureaucrat in Canberra or particularly any politician in Canberra or Perth, were not consulted.

I have called on the Ministers, firstly, to release those studies which the taxpayer has paid for and, secondly, to end the uncertainty that the people on the Nullarbor live under, and that is this threat of World Heritage listing. Until we have a definitive statement either from the Federal Minister or the State Minister, Mr McGinty, that World Heritage listing will not be proceeded with, their lives will be under doubt and the investment that they would seek to put into the Nullarbor in terms of fencing and water conservation will be reduced. Of course, the long term impact of that is that the very objective of World Heritage listing, which is to preserve and protect the native species of flora and fauna on the Nullarbor, will be jeopardised.

So I take the opportunity of this debate to call on those Ministers, firstly, to release those reports, and, secondly, to make a joint statement before Christmas—because it would be a very good Christmas present for those hard working, long suffering people who earn their livings from the Nullarbor Plain—that World Heritage listing will not be proceeded with.

They have the reports before them. They have had all the studies done. They have not done any consulting. They do not need to; I have done that for them. My colleague in the other place, Graeme Campbell, Julian Grill, a member of the State Parliament, Richard Court and I consulted with more than 55 people out at Cocklebiddy earlier this year—

TALK.START.PARA: —What a quartet!

—A powerful group of people, Senator Ray. We met with 55 people out at Cocklebiddy earlier this year. They are all opposed to it. The locals do not want it; the local councils do not want it; the thousands of people who have signed my petitions do not want it; and I would venture to suggest that if the native animals could talk out on the Nullarbor, they would not want it either because they are well looked after and preserved by the people who have a vested interest in preserving the environment from which they make their living.

PARA.TAB: Because I can see that people are falling asleep around me, I will conclude by recording my thanks to Tom Dimer for coming forward—indeed, coming into my life, to put it emotionally. He is a part of living history. I encourage anyone who wants to understand more about the history of the outback to come forward and help Tom Dimer publish his fascinating story of life in the outback. Tom Dimer is a classic old Australian and there are not many of them left. Even when saying that he needs to find $2,000 or $3,000 to publish his story, he said, `I don't really want anyone to give me the money; I just want them to lend it to me. I'll pay it back because the book will sell'.

He is only a pensioner but he wants to pay it back. He was not looking for a handout. He is an old digger who has worked very hard all of his life, out in some very tough country. I hope that people will come forward and find a way to make sure that Tom Dimer's story is shared with future generations of Australians, and that his wish be fulfilled that his country, the Nullarbor Plain—which is so close to his heart—not be World Heritage listed and not be controlled by politicians and bureaucrats who have no affinity whatsoever with that part of the world.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1) That discussion of matters of public interest be not further proceeded with this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE 1991-92ADVANCE TO THE PRESIDENT FOR 1991-92JOINT ADVANCE TO THE PRESIDENT AND THE SPEAKER FOR 1991-92

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 20 August and 8 September.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) proposed:

That the committee approves the statements on the Advances to the Minister for Finance and the President of the Senate, and notes the statement on the Joint Advance to the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, for the year 1991-92, of the Heads of Expenditure and the amounts charged thereto, pursuant to section 36A of the Audit Act 1901.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make one brief observation to the extent that the Advance to the President is partly a global amount of the appropriations for the Department of the Senate. I noted in the discussion in the Committee of the Whole on the appropriations for the Department of the Senate that there is some difficulty in the Department of the Senate managing on its appropriations, to the point where juggling—of a not particularly sophisticated kind—has to take place with the various aspects of the funding so as to allow the place to continue to function.

PARA.TAB: Getting printing done outside of the building comes under administration. We can continue to have our printing done but we cannot have it done in-house because it comes under the category of wages, and when the wages budget is running 20 per cent ahead of schedule we have to manipulate the books. I do not mind enlightened accounting practices, but it goes past that point. We clearly have problems in relation to the funding of committees, and to the general functioning of the Parliament. If I thought there was a concerted effort by the Government, in terms of its own distinct functioning, to cut back—I am not talking about Government departments; I am talking about the process of government to cut back equally—I would not mind. However, when we choke off funding to the Senate, we are choking off the only avenue available for scrutiny of government and legislation.

As we see the legislation being introduced into the Parliament growing in both number and sophistication, as is inevitable in the more sophisticated society in which we all now live, the committee system of the Senate will have to continue to grow, to be upgraded and to become more sophisticated and more diligent and more capable in the discharge of its responsibilities and duties. That can only take place provided there is adequate funding. It has been an ongoing battle for the last three or four years when I have been involved to get levels of funding for the Senate which allow it just to carry on in a very ordinary way. We now have the new process of efficiency credits and so on, so that virtually we are getting less each year.

To the extent that we are still developing proper systems in this new building and it is difficult to draw a baseline, we are struggling to some continuing degree. I hope that future governments will think more carefully before they put upon budgets of Houses of the Parliament constraints of the type that we are presently having visited upon us, which inhibit their proper functioning.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to respond fully to Senator Crichton-Browne. It is some time since I looked at the financing of the Department of the Senate. I still think it is slightly ridiculous that there are about 18 government departments yet this building contains an additional five. As to his almost rhetorical question of whether the squeeze is being put on the Senate for some political reason, I do not think that is true. I think it is the overall type of fiscal situation.
—When you have the Prime Minister describing us as irrelevant and unrepresentative swill, you have to wonder whether he extends that view to funding.

—Senator Crichton-Browne can wonder what he likes, but the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was not involved in the particular specific process and allocation of funds to the Department this year. That process was chaired by Mr Dawkins and basically supported by Mr Willis; neither of them has strong or, probably, any views about the Senate at all. This building has added to the expense of the running of everything. The increased legislation program must create pressure. The tendency, if one is an Australian Democrat, is to try to solve difficult political situations by setting up a committee. That adds to the pressures. The pressures on the time of senators mean that more and more staff are needed to write the reports, and that is a bad trend. Indeed, a couple of joint committees, at least, bring consultants in to write reports.
—They have to table them.

—This is the problem. I think the committee system can work very well, provided senators run it. I do not see much point in setting up committees if staff run them and consultants come in and write the report. We need a rationalisation of the committee system in this chamber. Even on the other side of the chamber, where there are more potential candidates than on this—we have Ministers who cannot serve, neither can Presiding Officers—the pressure is being felt to find people to go on committees. I do not know what the answer is long term. We looked at combining standing committees with Estimates committees to get overall expertise, and whether we should set a limit on the number of select committees we set up, but that creates enormous problems of timing. When the first two or three get their select committees in, no-one else can have a go. We looked also at whether we should head for more joint committees with the House of Representatives. That brings party-political considerations far more into the deliberations than under the Senate committees.

PARA.TAB: The reason I am saying this is that it has to be recognised that there are more committees, there is a heavier work load, et cetera, and there are not abundant resources anywhere within government expenditure to be devoted to that. I feel the same pressures in my portfolio as probably the people that have to run the finances of the Senate Department, probably magnified on a scale of 1,000 times. But I have not detected recently the sort of aggro that the honourable senator may suggest, as an intention to fix the Senate up by cutting its funding. It would be true to say that three or four years ago a certain Finance Minister had those views.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the consideration of this motion a moment longer except to say that I am sure Senator Ray understands that a democracy is not the most perfect system of government in the world but, of course, it is one of the most fragile and one which brings with it all sorts of inherent costs. To ensure that it is preserved there is an inordinate price to be paid, in the same way as people look at the costs of running this building and try to make some value judgments as to whether they are getting value for their money. Provided democracy is working and is seen to be working and is not some indulgence and extravagance, it is primarily, fundamentally, and certainly notionally, a good investment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ray made the observation about the number of departments of the Parliament. I remember a proposal once by the Government to create one super department. Of course, when the costings were done for that it was demonstrably obvious to anybody who had read the consultant's work that while it might have centralised everything in Leo McLeay's office, it certainly was not doing anything for efficiency, competence or cost cutting. If anybody on this side could be satisfied that the amalgamations of departments would not in any way dilute the quality of the performance and would create efficiencies, nobody would be disagreeing with them, but simply amalgamating because big seems to be beautiful and best is presumably not the best way to go, particularly when one is trying to run a department.

As for the system of committees, as I say, I think there are dilemmas. One is that the more committees there are, the more strain there is on those able to serve. The obvious point is made in respect of the Government that it has fewer people to go around, but as long as we are dealing with the sort of legislation that we are dealing with and its complexities, it is inevitable that if we are to have proper consideration and deliberation and even contemplation of legislation, the committee system is needed.

I do not know how my colleagues get on, but I have never had one person on my staff who has ever helped me on a committee, either to write a minority report or to contribute to a majority report or even to do research for me. Some might argue that is the function of the committee secretariat, but I do not necessarily see it that way if we are all bringing to that committee our own quaint notions of wisdom. The answer might be to provide additional staff to members of parliament. I think the last addition we got might have been at a time when—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are going to cut all that by 10 per cent.

—No, we have not said we will cut the number of staff; what we have said is we will reduce it by a global figure of 10 per cent by way of efficiencies. The answer seems to me to be to have additional staff—
—So the Senate is not inefficient.

—There are some aspects of the Senate which are inefficient. I read in today's paper that there is supposed to be a strike by employees—staff members of Labor members and senators—because they are dissatisfied with their salaries and conditions. I have got to use that terrible expression Reg Withers used: `If you want to pay peanuts, you will inevitably get monkeys and nothing better'. To have the quality of research that is necessary, the right sort of money has to be paid. The sort of money that is paid now is not based on qualifications or skills; it is just across a flat band. A retired party hack can be working in an office doing nothing except servicing constituents—for whom he is not intended to be there—and getting exactly the same money as somebody who has got two degrees and an honours degree and is doing sophisticated research. Sometimes, perhaps, it is a measure of the capacity of the member or the senator to understand the level of research that is being undertaken that determines the sort of staff they put on. In my view there is a compelling argument—
—The party hacks can do better research than people with PhDs.

—That is true in some cases when they are just trying to bring to bear the question of commonsense, nothing more sophisticated than that. I agree. It is always important to have somebody on the staff who can count, for a whole range of reasons.
—Not as good as you can.

—I do not seem to get it right too often. There is something to be said for paying staff members depending on their skills so that senators and members are able to go out there and get quality people and put them on their staff and get the sort of research that is necessary. Of course, if the senators and members are so dopey that they cannot utilise somebody of that capacity, I am sure it will soon manifest itself one way or another.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the House of Representatives amendments to the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very simply, this is yet another add-on, a tacked on amendment to an omnibus Bill which was dealt with a little while ago. The Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 came into the Parliament in its original form without any mention of an amendment to the Australian Institute of Marine Science Act. It also came in without any mention of proposed amendment to the Trade Marks Act. The Trade Marks Act amendments were added on to the Bill after debate had commenced. These amendments were added on when the amendments that the Senate effected to the part of the Bill dealing with the National Measurement Act had been carried. So again we are seeing an example of poor Government management.

PARA.TAB: What this amendment does, however, in this case is quite useful. It is a pity that attention cannot sometimes be drawn to the first-class work that the Institute of Marine Science does. In moving these amendments, the Government is giving formal legislative recognition to the role of commercial programs within the charter of the Institute. In effect, these are similar to the amendments that were moved previously to the ANSTO Act that aimed at legitimising that organisation's commercial operations.

When the Institute of Marine Science comes before Estimates committees it always gives straightforward, informative answers and it always keeps the Parliament apprised of what commercial work it is involved in. Indeed, it is quite a shame that a lot of its work, particularly at the forefront of investigation of historical temperature analysis, is not given more prominence than is given some of the more trendy research which has less factual foundation than the work that the Institute does.

I join with Mr McGauran, in the other place, to pay tribute to the work of the retiring Director of the Institute, Dr Joe Baker, as his seven-year term comes to an end this month, and place on the record the fact that at all times Dr Baker has shown a great willingness to share the information and the research that his Institute has done with the Parliament. I repeat that that work has been first-class.

It is a shame that I cannot say good words about the National Standards Commission, which operates under the National Measurements Act. I refer to the amendments which we passed in this chamber and which have been accepted in the other place. Subsequent to the amendments in this place, which were very significant because they deleted from the Act a power that was to be given, sought by the Commission—draconian powers of search and seizure which the Australian Democrats joined with us in denying the Commission—far from accepting the will of the Parliament and the debate that caused that decision to be made, Mr Birch and his Commission flouted the intention of the Parliament by sending around a survey that was blatantly contemptuous of the decision that the Parliament had made. It was put in rather innocuous terms, and asked whether people believed the Commission should have the power to ensure patent compliance and whether they would support an amendment to the Act to give the Commission similar powers to those of weights and measures inspectors.

That was the very issue that the Parliament had debated in great depth and here he was, in absolute contempt of that debate, trying to get those draconian powers restored to him. I suggest that Mr Birch take a look at the debate in the Hansard. He will see that there was grave concern about the powers that he was seeking, and that the reasons that he and his Commission were denied them were based on sound argument.

I believe the way in which the Government is using omnibus Bills to bring together disparate matters that bear no relationship to one another, and tacking bits on after the Bill has been introduced as a method of dealing with something that somebody may have forgotten earlier, is poor legislative form. When we dealt with the trademark legislation we looked at the prospect of putting a person in gaol for turning out a T-shirt with somebody else's logo on the front of it. I think that is pretty serious stuff and it is something which I, as I expressed at the time, was opposed to. I think the manner in which that serious matter was introduced into the Parliament was an insult and an indictment of poor management. I stress that I do not in any way or shape disagree with the substance of the legislation that has been introduced—dealing with the Institute of Marine Science—but I do disagree with the way in which it was done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add the support of the Australian Democrats for these amendments to the Australian Institute of Marine Science Act. I agree with Senator Bishop's concern about the way that these amendments have been tacked on to what was a very long and complex omnibus Bill. I was not made aware that these amendments would be made to the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill until 5 November. That was some time after we had dealt with the primary Act in this Senate. I had a letter from Minister Free which informed me that these amendments would be made and that there was some urgency in these amendments being accepted, as the commercial potential of a number of current AIMS proposals were dependent on the timeliness of their release into the market. If these amendments were so urgent, why were they not made in the principal Bill, when we considered the issue some weeks earlier?

PARA.TAB: I wrote back to the Minister and offered our support for these amendments, contingent upon assurances being given to us that the capacity for AIMS to commercialise its research would not result in real funding cuts to its budget. I am pleased to say that the Minister has given me those assurances. We will certainly be looking at the budget line item for the Australian Institute of Marine Science in the future, to ensure that the Minister's assurances to us about its budget will be maintained. I offer our support for these amendments. However, it is with the rider that the Committee is concerned that we are now dealing with these amendments some time after the previous Act has been passed by the Senate, and that the Minister has given us an assurance that the capacity for commercialisation will not result in budget cuts to the Australian Institute of Marine Science.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. A couple of weeks ago, I had a phone call from a local newsagent who was very concerned about one of his elderly customers of many years. He told me that she needs a hip replacement and, according to him, she has been on a public hospital waiting list for two years. He rang in desperation to find out whether there was any way he could help to get her further up the waiting list. He said he could not bear to see her struggling into his shop week after week in more and more pain and becoming frailer and frailer. How can the Prime Minister claim that Medicare provides an equitable, efficient and fair system of health care for all Australians when between 70,000 and 100,000 people are forced to wait, as has this lady, for months and even years, often in considerable pain, for access to a public hospital bed?

—There is no doubt that Senator Patterson's compassion for this particular constituent is very real, and I know it will be shared by all honourable senators. The question is what practical steps can be taken within our health care system in Australia to ensure that those who are suffering from some illness or the effect of some traumatic accident are given the best medical and hospital care. The answer by the Government is to strengthen the public hospital system in a way which enables waiting lists to be reduced.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Patterson knows, a considerable amount of money has been promised to the States for a program over the next two years to reduce waiting lists but, more specifically of course, to ensure that those who want to avail themselves of the public hospital system will find a strengthened system because, over the next six years, we intend to put $1.6 billion into that system under the Medicare agreement that is presently being negotiated. That agreement looks to total health care, not just a financing proposition such as comes out of the Fightback package.

What comes out of the Fightback package is a proposition that, in addition to paying tax and the Medicare levy, persons should be compulsorily required to take out private health insurance, without any regard to their income capacity, except for very low income pensioners, for example, where money will be taken to subsidise them but taken away from the public hospital system. Nothing the Opposition is suggesting will produce more bed days availability within the public hospital system.

I believe that what we are putting forward from this side of the Government in the renegotiations is a recognition that, for example, there is a place for private health insurance. That is recognised in the preamble to the Medicare principles which are being incorporated in the Bill and being put forward by Mr Howe in the Medicare negotiations.

Principally, there needs to be a recognition that Australians continue to support Medicare and its general philosophy of ensuring that all eligible Australians are entitled to receive proper health care through our public hospital system. I believe that that strengthened system gives a better hope to Australians for the relief of the sort of suffering of which the honourable senator spoke, rather than requiring them compulsorily, household after household, to take out private health insurance premiums.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister said that this year the Government will give money to reduce waiting lists, and I think the figure this year will be $50m. From 1987 to 1989, the Government gave $50m, matched dollar for dollar by the States. That did nothing to reduce the waiting queues in hospitals. What will the Government do? The Australian public wants to know when the Government will have a plan that brings the Australian health system back into some array, makes it fair and equitable and reduces those waiting lists, especially for that lady about whom I am talking, and all the others who are waiting in queues.

—Our policy is very clear and is being negotiated at the moment by the Minister for Health with the various health Ministers from around Australia who, of course, are trying to sabotage it for ideological-political reasons at the moment. But I can tell honourable senators that as they look at the very remote prospect of ever being subjected to the Hewson formula of health care, they will come to the negotiating table before the next Federal election and they will sign that agreement because they are very fearful of what those opposite have in prospect for them.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Would the Government ever contemplate introducing an Office of the Employee Advocate to hear complaints by workers about their individual employment contracts instead of the current protection provided by the award system? Would the Government ever contemplate using the Commonwealth Employment Service to field complaints by workers, as advocated by Mr Howard earlier this week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Howard has made a major gaffe. He has also driven yet another hole of great defect through his own industrial relations policy. That policy is now transparently false, one that does not contain guarantees. The Office of the Employee Advocate in that policy is now clearly a flawed proposition. Let me quote Mr Howard who, on the twenty-third of this month on radio 2BL, said, `In country areas workers will go either to the local CES or to the Social Security office to lodge a complaint'—

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The question was whether the Minister would contemplate setting up an employee advocate and various other things. He is now quoting Mr Howard, which is not relevant to any answer to the question that was asked. I ask that you require him to answer the question that was asked, rather than engage in what is obviously a debate.

—On the point of order, Mr President: the Office of the Employee Advocate is a matter of common debate in the field of public debate on industrial relations. That is an established current fact. Mr Howard is an advocate of that office. What Mr Howard says about it is relevant to why the Government will not introduce it, and my answer should be allowed to proceed unimpeded by this sort of vexatious point of order.

—Order! The Minister was asked a question about industrial relations. He was asked about various things and whether the Government would implement them. I think it might be better if he dealt with that part of the question.
—On public radio Mr Howard said, `People can queue at the CES or at the Department of Social Security to have access to the Office of the Employee Advocate'. There is a fatal flaw in this.
—Abide by the President's ruling.

—I have the radio transcript; that is what Mr Howard said. The fatal flaw is this: under its Fightback proposals the Opposition intends to abolish the CES. The CES is to be abolished and the activities of the Commonwealth Employment Service are to be privatised. So if complainants who want to get access to the employee advocate are to queue at the CES, under the Opposition's policies they clearly would not have anywhere to go in order to raise their complaints.

—Mr President, I take the point of order again. This is not a time for debating our policies. We are more than happy to debate our industrial relations policy as against the Government's policy, which has resulted in a million people being unemployed. But now is not the time for that. So I ask you to bring him to order and remind him of his responsibilities in Question Time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robert Ray

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Senator Hill says that this is not the time. It was obviously the time on 26 October 1982, when Senator Hill asked a question of Senator Sir John Carrick, part of which said, `Is such a statement consistent with the announced Federal Labor Party's policy on uranium mining?' He later went on to ask other questions on Labor Party policy. On 26 February 1980 Senator Walters asked a question of Senator Sir John Carrick:

INTERJECT.PARA: Is this not a contradiction of Labor's previously announced policy to cut petrol prices? Further, how could the ALP justify its broken promise to the Australian motorist, given that it did not admit that import parity pricing encourages conservation. . . ?

Mr President, I will table this material if necessary. There were questions from Senator Young on Labor Party policy. There was another question from Senator Walters on 10 November 1981 on Labor Party policy when we were in opposition. There was one from Senator Teague on 8 December 1982, one from Senator Crichton-Browne on 21 September 1982 and from Senator Bonner on 16 February—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your point of order?
—The point of order is that you are absolute hypocrites to object to the answering of questions relating to Opposition policy when you old recidivists did it time and time again.
—Point of order, Mr President—

—I am on my feet on a point of order; Senator Patterson can follow. Your junior woodchucks here have not been told that you used to do this in government more blatantly than we ever did and then you start shouting out and interrupting Senator Cook today. Here is the record of you doing it. If it is good enough for you, it is good enough for us.

—On the point of order: I listened very carefully to Senator Cook. I think he was using arguments as to why the Government would not implement a certain policy. However, I ask him to be relevant to that and not to Opposition policies.
—Mr President, may I—
—Is this a point of order?

—Yes—or I am asking for clarification of your ruling on Senator Ray's point of order. He is standing up in this place talking about fictitious points of order, and he has raised one today that has no relevance at all.
—Order! He responded to a point of order.

—Thank you, Mr President. We would not, of course, introduce an Office of the Employee Advocate. It is a cruel hoax on any wage earner or employer who finds a contract has been breached to suggest that such an office would be of any comfort or protection to him. It clearly would not because, under the Opposition's proposal, it would be operating on the common law, where the relationship between an employer and an employee is that of a master and a servant and where the rights of the employee are virtually non-existent. But the proposal by Mr Howard to send them along to the CES when he proposes to abolish the CES is an even greater hoax.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I refer to standing order 73(4), which relates to a Minister not debating a question. It is quite clear that, despite your clear ruling, Senator Cook is now going back to debating Opposition policies. Mr President, I ask you once and for all to bring this totally recalcitrant Minister into line.
—Order! I asked Senator Cook to be relevant. I assume that he is.

—Thank you, Mr President. I do understand the sensitivity of honourable senators opposite, being caught out in misleading the Australian public about their policy. They obviously do not want their misleadings to be exposed. Mr Howard has clearly forgotten what his Fightback policy is or he is deliberately now misleading people about it.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is clear that the Minister continues to reject your ruling and to go on as though you had made no ruling at all. Mr President, if your rulings have any meaning whatsoever, the Minister is clearly out of order, and I ask you to sit him down.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robert Ray

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Mr President: the question asked of Senator Cook raised questions of Opposition policy but then asked whether the Government was going to adopt it. It was exactly the same sort of question that Senator Walters raised on 10 November 1981. It is a very brief one. She directed a question to Senator Carrick, saying:

INTERJECT.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Has the Minister noted that the Australian Labor Party's new defence policy is based on Australia's need for self-reliance? Can the Minister say whether this now represents endorsement of the Government's defence planning policy?
That is exactly the same as the question that was asked of Senator Cook.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask Senator Cook, however, not to debate Opposition policies but to give reasons why the Government will not introduce certain policies.

—We have a perfectly good service—the awards management service—whereby ordinary Australians can ring up and find out what their rights are under an award. Under the Opposition's policy, of course, there would be individual employment contracts and not only would one have to queue at the CES or the Department of Social Security—which would have its funding cut quite significantly; the queues would be longer—but also each individual contract would have to be examined and the rights of ordinary Australians would be undermined. The Opposition should bring forth its industrial relations Bill so that we can actually see the draconian nature of its proposals.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. I was especially interested in the answer he gave to Senator Patterson recently. I refer the Minister to the fact that 832,000 low income earning Australians over the age of 65 are so afraid of those long queues that Senator Patterson referred to—the queues for so-called elective surgery, for such things as hip replacements, cataract and prostate procedures, all caused by the Labor Party's mismanagement of the health system—that they have remained in health insurance funds despite a considerable financial sacrifice to do so. For many of them it is a choice between necessary house repairs and health insurance. Does not the Labor Party recognise that these poor, elderly Australians are making these financial sacrifices? Why does not the Labor Party, after 10 years of government, have a policy to abolish these queues?

—In the course of her question, Senator Newman made the point that people take out private health insurance—some Australians do, and they are perfectly free to do so—at what she termed `considerable financial sacrifice'. Those opposite are going to make it compulsory for Australians and households to take out private health insurance which will cause considerable financial hardship to many millions of Australians, in addition to the tax and the Medicare levy they have to pay.

PARA.TAB: The only difference will be that, for example, in relation to very low income pensioners, a tax credit subsidy will be offered. In order to create that tax subsidy or credit situation, those opposite will be taking money from the public hospital system and helping to fund those private health insurance premiums. The very interesting fact about those private health insurance premiums is that Dr John Deeble, senior research fellow at the Australian National University, has had a look at those particular proposals and has come to the conclusion that the additional medical and hospital costs of an Opposition policy—if we were to adopt it—would be at least $1.42 billion. According to Dr Deeble, more than $1 billion would go to doctors. That is the hidden agenda of the Opposition.

Using the private health insurance premiums which those opposite will make compulsory for all Australians at considerable sacrifice, they will find that they will be transferring money into the pockets of doctors, rather than into the provision of good public hospital health and medical care, which is what we believe ought to be the case. That is where the money should go—in support of the public hospital system—and that is exactly what we are proposing to do. I am quite sure that the 70 per cent of Australians who support Medicare and who have done so for a decade will continue to support this Government because of its support for Medicare.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister is obviously so scared about Fightback that he has to tell lies about our policy to this chamber and to the Australian people. He is misleading the Parliament. When will the Labor Party introduce a policy that will help older Australians?
—And when will he go to confession?

—As my colleague says, when will he go to confession? When will he help these people to have private insurance by using measures such as the private health insurance rebate that they will get under Fightback? It contains protection for people on low incomes. When will his Government introduce a policy such as that, which will prevent the pain and suffering that his Government has been causing for 10 long, long years?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Since it was ruled that I could not debate Opposition policy in my answer, it ought to be a consistent ruling and Opposition questioners who wish to debate policy in framing their questions should also be ruled out of order.
—Order! There is no point of order, but it is not parliamentary to accuse Ministers of lying.
—Oh, Mr President!
—Order! Senator Walters, it is no use appealing to me. I am not the judge of whether a Minister's statement is correct, and I will enforce that ruling.
—It is your job to tell him that he must not mislead the Senate.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Standing order 73(1)(i) states that questions shall not ask for a statement of the Government's policy. That is exactly what Senator Newman's question did. It is therefore absolutely out of order.
—Order! I will allow the supplementary question because it is the sort of supplementary question that has been used in this place for a long time.

—In the supplementary question, which I can barely remember, Senator Newman spoke about relieving people of the costs of the provision of health care. But in fact, of course, it is Opposition policy, which we will not adopt, that 80 per cent of Australians who presently are able to get bulkbilling from their doctors will not be able to get bulkbilling. I ask Senator Newman: how does that help households and Australians who are bearing the costs of health care?
—Answer the question.
—Order! Senator Newman, you have asked the question.

—In relation to the rebates which the Opposition is speaking about, they will have to be financed by ordinary taxpayers paying into Consolidated Revenue out of which those opposite will pay those rebates. In that situation, what those opposite will be doing is using the money that would otherwise go to public hospitals.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Given the decision of the High Court in Sykes v. Cleary and Others, will the Government give consideration to facilitating the adoption of the recommendations made by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its report on the constitutional qualifications of members of parliament, dated 2 June 1981? To bring the Minister's mind to who was on that Committee at the time, there was Senator Alan Missen, Senator Gareth Evans, Senator David Hamer, Senator Christopher Puplick, Senator Michael Tate himself and Senator John Wheeldon—a Committee which approaches the quality of the present Committee, may I say.
—I do recall the Senate Committee which Senator Cooney has referred to producing a report called Constitutional qualifications of members of parliament.
—You just happen to have it in front of you.

—I do happen to have it. It was a very eminent and distinguished Committee, as has been pointed out. I believe that the Committee perhaps had a premonition about what occurred yesterday and, of course, with our former colleague the not-Senator Wood. In so far as that particular report spoke of dual nationality and the problems that might be occasioned, I seem to recall its conclusion was that candidates ought to go to the electorate making a declaration as to whether, in fact, they have dual nationality and indicating that they have taken reasonable steps to renounce it.

PARA.TAB: Under yesterday's ruling, the High Court requires that reasonable steps be taken to renounce foreign nationality. But I believe that what the Committee had in mind was, rather than High Court judges—an unelected bench of judges—making that particular determination, the electorate itself, provided with that information by way of a declaration, would make its own judgment on the loyalty of the candidate to Australia. I think that is something worth considering.

As to the question of employment in what is called an office of profit under the Crown—generally speaking, Public Service type employment—I seem to recall that the Committee indicated that we might have to have a deeming provision in the Constitution which would allow the person to be deemed not to be employed in the Public Service from a certain date. That might have to be varied in accordance with the decision.

I believe that the deliberations by that Committee over some many months some time ago—I think it was 1981, some 11 years ago—do provide a very sound foundation for consideration of the issues which flow from the decision by the High Court yesterday.

I think we obviously need to ensure that those who are Australian citizens and wish to stand for election, wish to present themselves to the electors in their particular electorate and wish to serve in this Commonwealth Parliament, ought to have the opportunity to do so as Australian citizens, and we ought to take every step possible to ensure that that can be brought about.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I would like to take his answer to Senator Cooney a little further. I ask the Minister: does the Government agree with the literalist approach to the issues of office of profit under the Crown and dual nationality? Does the Minister agree that the decision severely limits the rights and opportunities for people to be elected to this Parliament on the basis of the type of job they have, where they live and where they were born? When will this Government take action to ensure that what happened to Phil Cleary yesterday will not happen to other Australians in the future? When will that action be taken and what type of action will it be?

—I think it would be true to say that most Australians would have been surprised at the decision. That is not to say that the decision does not accord with the terminology of a Constitution that was drafted back in the 1890s. But it would surprise Australians to learn that those who serve in the police forces, or as clerks or engineers in public service, or as teachers might be in jeopardy of not being able to stand for election to the Parliament without having to resign and, therefore, take a very real risk with their employment opportunities and the income which they and their families are entitled to expect during the period of being a candidate for an election.

PARA.TAB: That seems to me to be very probably a hindrance or an impediment and the sort of consideration that might lead people in those situations not to resign and therefore offer themselves for election. It would be a very grave disservice to the Australian community if those persons felt that they were disabled from even offering themselves for election, let alone taking a seat if elected. I know that Senator Kernot has herself been considering a Bill of a type to deal with this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have introduced it.

—The honourable senator has introduced it. That would be a tradition that began with Senator Mal Colston, the distinguished Chairman of Committees, who some years ago introduced a Bill to deal with this sort of matter.

PARA.TAB: We are now in a position where quite clearly the Government needs to take account of what bipartisan support we can get for some propositions which would enable us to deal with this matter in a way which was fair and which enabled those who are in particular types of employment to take reasonable steps. By this means the electorate could be assured of the fact that, first of all, they are Australian citizens whose loyalty is to Australia and its democratic values and, secondly, that, if elected, they cannot be influenced in their candidacy or prospects by the sort of employment they were involved in.

These things have to be looked at. As I said, they have been looked at by the Senate Committee. Senator Kernot's Bill and other suggestions will be taken into account by the Government in determining what it might suggest to the Parliament as a remedial course of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Attorney-General considering holding a referendum? The Minister might expect bipartisan support because the Opposition's citizenship policy supports the holding of dual nationality.

—The Government is in no position at the moment to determine whether there will be a referendum, having considered this matter only over the last 24 hours. I do not believe that is in prospect at the moment. Quite clearly, we will have to deliberate on the matter.

PARA.TAB: As to the honourable senator's question about citizenship, of course it is important and this is a factor which has growing bipartisan support. I believe there has to be another look at the Australian Citizenship Act to ensure that when people obtain citizenship and go through the ceremony with which all senators are familiar, it is made very clear they are pledging their loyalty to Australia and its democratic values, institutions and laws and to their fellow Australians. In that way we can make even clearer that their primary and exclusive allegiance is to the country whose citizenship they have adopted and not to some citizenship from their ancestral homeland, which many of them under the laws of their former homeland find very difficult to renounce.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware of recent concerns being expressed by the general aviation industry over the introduction of a goods and services tax? Does the Government have any plans to introduce a goods and services tax on general and regional aviation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of these concerns. Indeed, they follow hot on the heels of the concerns expressed by regional airline operators, of which Senator Short is aware, about the destruction that would be caused to their industry by the imposition of a 15 per cent goods and services tax. In a recent editorial in the magazine of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, Mr Peter Patroni made the following statement:

ANSWER.PARA: There are approximately 7,000 private aircraft in Australia whose owners could be slightly better off under GST, but I believe the remaining 23,000 active private pilots who have to hire aircraft will be disadvantaged.

I would add that if the analysis that was contained in that editorial had gone on to consider what else was contained in the Fightback proposals which have been put up recently by the Opposition, it would be even worse news for general aviation—that is, the commitment that has been given to attempt to get full cost recovery forthwith from the light aircraft industry.

PARA.TAB: Interestingly enough, in the Fightback document, the coalition not only is proud of this particular boast but also has costed it at a saving to the Budget of $20m. To add to the folly of this proposal, the coalition has now been forced into agreeing to fund from the Budget the cost of CAA services which are currently funded from Avgas excise. The coalition discovered—it took them many months to do so—that this Avgas revenue, which collects around $23m per year, was in fact directly paid to the CAA for providing services to the aviation industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This could not be interpreted as other than a debate on Opposition policy, or what the Minister claims to be Opposition policy. It is therefore out of order. The fact that Senator Ray has been contemplating for 10 years whether he should have taken a point of order against me in 1982 or against Senator Walters since 1981 is more a reflection upon him than anything else, but it is certainly not relevant to the issue of whether Ministers should be answering questions in this place rather than debating policy. I therefore ask that you bring this Minister to order.

—Mr President, on the point of order: Senator Ray, of course, has told us today what any person serving in any parliament for any length of time knows; that is, that in fact Question Times in every parliament around Australia are conducted in this way. Senator Hill is asserting in this point of order that it is not proper to ask questions which relate to coalition policy in Question Time in the Senate. I distinctly recall a number of questions being asked by coalition backbenchers to coalition frontbenchers—the last one I heard was to Senator Short—directly about coalition policy. I would like to know whether it is in order for the coalition in the chamber, the Opposition, to ask questions relating to Opposition policy. I might add that not a single point of order was taken by anyone on this side to the question asked of Senator Short. I do recall that he went on to speak for eight minutes. Does Senator Bell recall that?
—Yes.

—Senator Bell does recall that. Senator Short went on to speak for eight minutes in response to that question. Is it in order for the Opposition to ask questions about coalition policy but not for the Government to do so?

—Order! Senator Collins was asked a question about concerns in the aviation industry about a certain policy. He was also asked whether the Government would implement that policy. He is entitled to use arguments, but I think he should get back to the theme of whether or not the Government would implement the policy.
—We will not, for the reasons that I am enunciating to the Senate. One of the problems Dr Strangelove and his Fightback proposals are causing—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask that you ask the Minister to address the Leader of the Opposition appropriately.
—Yes. Proper names should be used. I constantly remind all senators about that.

—I do apologise, Mr President. I withdraw the allusion to Dr Strangelove. Of course, I was referring to Dr Hewson. The difficulty the coalition has with these proposals is that we are funding the regulatory proposals that govern the general aviation industry from the Avgas excise. The coalition in its Fightback document, having proposed and stated that this industry will move to full cost recovery, has stated in a letter from Mr Jull to Mr Patroni that it will fund the cost of these proposals now from general revenue, that is, from the Budget.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. The Minister would be aware that the Government is presently spending $3.5m worth of taxpayers' money, instead of Labor Party funds, on a propaganda campaign to promote Medicare in the Government's Budget health announcements. Can the Minister tell me how many patients with the very severe hip replacement needs that Senator Patterson referred to this $3.5m would enable to be done and so taken off the waiting list, relieving the pain and suffering of this type of patient that Senator Patterson so graphically referred to?

—If the money being spent on informing people about their entitlements under Medicare were simply an isolated exercise, there might be some basis for Senator Walters's question. But the fact is that it is not. It is in harmony with, and in the context of, a package announced in the Budget that provides considerable funds for the reduction of waiting lists in all jurisdictions throughout Australia over the next two years and which holds out the prospect of an extra $1.6 billion being put into the public hospitals of Australia over the next six years, if the various States come to the Medicare agreement, all of which will enable the sorts of surgery and medical and hospital treatment which Senator Walters is concerned about to be undertaken to a much greater extent than is the case at the moment.

PARA.TAB: It is in that context that the program of informing people about their entitlements under Medicare has to be seen. It is part of the sort of advertising that takes place for MBF, HCF, St Lukes Health Insurance fund or Medicare. These are all ongoing programs which are quite common to those in this field who inform either their members or prospective members—in this case, all eligible Australian citizens—of their entitlements and rights. I believe that in that situation the sort of money that is being spent is in proportion to the operation of such a massive Medicare program that supports the health care of all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How many operations would the $3.5m propaganda campaign cover?

—I have already explained that this is not a propaganda campaign. It is a campaign which enables people to understand their entitlements under Medicare better. It is in the context of the devotion of $71m over the next two years simply to the question of the reduction of waiting lists and $1.6 billion extra into public hospitals over the next six years to enable precisely those sorts of operations to be undertaken by those elderly people, as Australian citizens, not depending on private health insurance premium payments, which they would otherwise have to undertake.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Why does the Federal Government support a policy which in a number of States would mean the lowering of the age of consent for homosexual acts? Is it not a fact that this would remove such protection as the law provides to 16- and 17-year-olds against attempted homosexual seduction at the very time when the homosexual lobby group is soliciting recruits amongst youth through its coming out campaign? Why will the Government in its AIDS campaign not tell teenagers that it would be a deadly risk for them to engage in those predominantly homosexual acts which in Australia are the principal causes of the spread of AIDS?

—I want to make it absolutely and utterly clear that the Federal Government has no policy or program whatsoever relating to reducing the age of consent for young males in our community to engage in certain sexual practices. In so far as Senator Harradine purports in his question to imply that that is a policy of the Federal Government, he is wrong and he knows that he is wrong.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine may be referring to a report that was compiled in all jurisdictions—the Federal, State and Territory governments—by officials, endorsed by the heads of department of all health departments around Australia, and published a week or so ago. That does not represent in any way the policy of this Federal Government. It is not part of our combating AIDS strategy that the age of consent provision, which is probably in most criminal codes around Australia, should be lowered. It is an utterly incorrect assertion by Senator Harradine and it does not form part of our policy. I simply wish to refute it and make that clear.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. First, I have in my hands a document written by Mr Howe and addressed to the States of Australia saying:

QUESTION.PARA: I urge these governments to continue with this commitment in giving serious consideration to these unique recommendations and taking the necessary steps towards implementation.

That is the recommendation. Is Minister Howe expressing Government policy or is he not? He has said to the States that they should take action to implement that recommendation. Secondly, the Minister did not answer my question as to why the Government, in its AIDS campaign, will not tell teenagers that it is a deadly risk to engage in those predominantly homosexual acts which have proven to be the principal spread of AIDS in Australia. Why does the Government not do that?

TALK.START.PARA: —That report had 90, 100 or more recommendations. All the Minister for Health has done is forward it for serious consideration by the jurisdictions concerned. There is no endorsement or adoption by the Federal Government of those recommendations. It has not considered them and has not endorsed, supported or adopted them. I am telling the Senate that now.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, in regard to the question that indulgence in certain homosexual acts can raise the risk of contracting AIDS—not only AIDS but also other sexually transmitted diseases; it is AIDS that Senator Harradine is concerned about—of course governments, voluntary organisations and community groups are trying to ensure that the message gets through to young people that they should either refrain from such actions or, if they must indulge in them, take some protective measure. Unfortunately, that message needs reinforcing time and again because it is neglected by so many youngsters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Earlier in Question Time the Minister said that some Ministers of health refused to sign the Medicare agreement because they were creating some sort of political stunt. One of those Ministers was Mr Keith Wilson, who has resigned as Labor Health Minister in Western Australia. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: Australia has the most inefficient and ramshackle hospital funding system one could imagine.
Why does the Medicare agreement for 1993-94 provide no increase in Medicare funds to the two Liberal States of New South Wales and Victoria while the other States receive an increase?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite confident that the Western Australian Health Minister resigned for a number of reasons which he has not fully expressed. The Premier of Western Australia has indicated her full support for the renegotiation of the Medicare agreement and the principles upon which it is based. She heads the Government of Western Australia. It is the Western Australian Cabinet that will make the decision in relation to Medicare. I am quite sure that that concurrence with the renegotiation will take place. What was Senator Herron's second question?
—It was in relation to New South Wales and Victoria.

—This suggestion that there is any political endeavour by the Federal Government to deal with this in a way other than to serve the interests of those millions of citizens in New South Wales and Victoria who would benefit from a strengthened public hospital system is absolutely absurd. To suggest that the funding arrangements that have been offered to New South Wales and Victoria depend on the political complexion of the governments there would probably need to be tested against the question: was the offer made before the change of government in Victoria? If it were, Senator Herron would be found to be completely misleading the general public and this Senate chamber in suggesting that whatever offer has been made to Victoria depended on the political complexion of the government there.

PARA.TAB: I believe that what is being offered is a strengthening of the public hospital system with the addition of $1.6 billion of extra moneys over the next six years and in many other ways strengthening the general practice system throughout Australia—the rural and remote areas—and provision of primary health care for all Australians. In so many ways what have emerged as the principles and the program of the Federal Government as it renegotiates the Medicare agreement will advance the interests of residents of Victoria and New South Wales alongside those of Australians elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The health Ministers of both those States have stated that there is no increase in funds. Mr President, you ruled out of order that I could call the Minister a liar. I would hesitate to do so. But I think you should point out to him that he should be honest in his replies. My supplementary question is: when is the Minister going to announce his plan to fix `the most inefficient and ramshackle hospital system one could imagine'?

—Mr President, when my first response to Senator Herron is looked at in the Hansard you will find that there is no basis whatsoever for the accusation that has been levelled at me. In relation to what does the Federal Government intend to do with what has been described by Mr Wilson as a ramshackle health system, that is being addressed by this whole renegotiation of the Medicare agreement. This will be done on the basis of not simply looking at a health financing system, which the Opposition seems to be obsessed with, but looking at a total health care system for all Australians—not in relation to their hospital and primary health care but whether they are from urban, remote, rural or provincial areas of Australia. It will cover particularly the relationship with aged health care, which is an important element of the total health care of all Australians.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the Minister aware that the Tasmanian Government has imposed a State-wide blanket classification of Tasmanian waters as bonamia affected? Was the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy consulted prior to this action being taken by the Tasmanian Government and, if so, what was the basis for imposing the classification? Is the Minister aware that other internationally recognised methods of containing the spread of bonamia, such as restriction notices on affected areas, movement restrictions and bonamia free zone classifications, are available? Has the United States been notified of this change in status and what is the effect of this action on the memorandum of understanding between Australia and the United States? What effects has the Tasmanian action had on the oyster industry within Australia and what effect will it have on Australia's export earnings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the honourable senator was talking about oysters and not lobsters. Mr President, if I appear more erudite than normal on this matter it is because I have a brief in front of me which enables me to talk about exotic diseases which afflict oysters and other things.

PARA.TAB: In regard to the first question, I assume that the honourable senator's reference to a State-wide blanket classification concerns the issue of whether Tasmanian authorities have classified all oyster growing waters in the State as infested with the disease bonamiosis. I can provide a number of details on the disease and the Tasmanian situation. The disease is one which, as far as is known, affects only the native flat oyster in Australia and it causes mortality. It is also known widely overseas.

I am advised that following surveys conducted by the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries on the disease status of flat oysters in Tasmanian waters, the Tasmanian Aquaculture Cooperative Society has been advised by the Department that bonamiosis is endemic in Tasmanian flat oysters—I can give the Senate the botanical name—and that there is no prospect of complete eradication of this disease from Tasmanian flat oysters. I understand that the full extent of the distribution of bonamia in Tasmania is not yet known.

As to the second question, the matter at issue is primarily a State responsibility except in so far as it concerns obligations under the US shellfish memorandum of understanding and Organisation des Epizooties, the French named international organisation on quarantine. I am advised that discussions on this matter were held at officer level between AQIS and the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries.

As to the third question, any action decided is primarily a matter for the Tasmanian authorities. As to the fourth question, AQIS has advised the United States Food and Drug Administration that the disease has been identified in flat oysters growing in Australia. This advice was provided to comply with AQIS's responsibilities under the MOU.

As to the fifth question, during the initial outbreak of disease the Tasmanian Government placed restrictions on flat oyster farmers, with some production being destroyed. Compensation was offered to three oyster growers. However, since bonamiosis affects only native flat oysters, the impact on Australian production and exports of oysters should be minimal. Exports of Pacific oysters to the United States should not be affected. Exports of flat oysters have recently been made to Holland to test the market. I am not aware of any problem with the shipments. Bonamiosis is present in many countries and further export markets could be developed. I am advised that the disease is not of human health significance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. The Minister has been asked four questions today that he has either refused to answer or cannot answer. I plainly ask him when he will announce the Labor Party's policies on dealing with over 100,000 people who are on public hospital waiting lists. When will he announce the Government's policy on dealing with the influx of people whom the Minister, the Prime Minister and Mr Howe want to go onto the public system once they encourage them all to go off the private system? When will the Government announce its policy on what effect this will have on low income earners, many of whom have no choice of going public or private? Finally, how will the Government ensure that the private hospitals continue to offer high quality care when it plans to cut their funding? I ask these questions seeking the Minister's answers on what the Government plans to do in the future.

—Senator Knowles cannot have been listening to the variety of ways in which I have put the Government's Budget propositions and proposals for the renegotiation of the Medicare agreements which is being conducted right now. For example, the Budget indicates that we are providing some $70m over two years to help reduce the waiting lists and to ensure that those who get treatment do so on the basis of a clinical assessment. The Budget also indicates how $1.6 billion over six years is to be pumped into the public hospital system.

PARA.TAB: Senator Knowles professes concern about low income earners. Why, then, in relation to those who are not pensioners or cardholders, would the Opposition refuse their GPs the possibility of offering them bulkbilling? If those opposite are so concerned about low income earners, I do not see why they would say to doctors, `You have no choice in this matter. You must levy a price to be paid for that visit to the GP without the benefit of bulkbilling'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell the truth.

—That is true, apart from pensioners and cardholders, and Senator Knowles knows it. As to the private hospital system, Senator Knowles would know that this Government provides very considerable funding to help with private health insurance, which has an impact on the provision of health care in private hospitals.
—Why was Keith Wilson wrong?

—I have already indicated why I think that he was wrong. In relation to the provision of health care in private hospitals, Medicare pays 75 per cent of the recommended or schedule fee for in-patient medical services, which costs the taxpayer about $700m. There is a subsidy of some $800m for private patients that stay in public hospitals. There is a considerable way in which the Government assists those who are private patients assisted by private health insurance, whether they go to public hospitals or private hospitals for their hospital treatment. I believe that in all of these ways there is a considerable indication by the Government that it values the place of private health insurance within the overall health care system of Australia, but not to the point of obsession, which seems to be the case with the Opposition.

—I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Australian Government's attitude towards the current political unrest in Pakistan, particularly with regard to the safety of Benazir Bhutto?

—Our basic attitude is one of very real concern that the current political unrest in Pakistan will lead to a chronic polarisation of political life in that country with the potential for over-reaction or excessive use of force either by the Government or by the Opposition in Pakistan. Honourable senators will be well aware of reports of the Pakistani security authorities intervening on 18 November to prevent a march led by former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto from entering Islamabad. The aim of that march was to urge the Government to call new elections.

PARA.TAB: While Pakistan authorities appear to have used very considerable force, there have been no reports of widespread serious casualties, and that at least is something to be grateful for. According to the Pakistan Government's spokesman, the security authorities took Ms Bhutto into temporary protective custody, sent her to a home in Karachi, forbade her to return to Islamabad, Rawalpindi or Peshawar for 30 days and arrested around 3,000 of her supporters, although Ms Bhutto claims that up to 25,000 of her supporters have been arrested. Protest rallies and arrests continue. Ms Bhutto is pursuing the protest, travelling by train towards Islamabad. She is presently in Lahore.

The Australian Government regards peaceful demonstrations as a legitimate vehicle for the expression of political views in a democratic society. We abhor the use of violence against peaceful demonstrations. A properly operating parliamentary system ought to provide an appropriate vehicle for the expression of dissatisfaction with the Government. We hope that the present political tension will not jeopardise the cause of democracy in Pakistan. We certainly call upon all sides to defend and to strengthen Pakistan's democratic process.

May I also take this opportunity to call on the Pakistan Government to ensure that Benazir Bhutto is not subjected to harassment or harm from any source and to release the very substantial number of Opposition supporters detained in connection with the current political unrest. We hope and trust that all sides will respect the universal standards of human rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that response. Will the Australian Government continue closely to monitor events in Pakistan?
—I think the honourable senator can take that for granted; yes, we will.
