—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Given that the coalition health finance policy is to give a tax break to low income earners to help them with the cost of private health insurance, should they choose to take it out, and to impose a tax penalty on the high income earners who continue to ride on the taxpayer by choosing not to take it out, why did the Minister mislead this chamber and the Australian public by asserting earlier today that under a coalition government private health insurance will be compulsory? Did he do so because the Government has no plan to fix the ramshackle mess that our health administration in Australia suffers from?

—I thought that the sort of language I used would have been well understood by a party which is driven only by financial and commercial considerations, because it is quite clear, for example, in relation to the high income earners that the honourable senator spoke of, that they will be under coercion and compulsion because honourable senators opposite would levy a financial penalty on them if they did not take out private health insurance. That is the sort of coercion and compulsion that they would be subjected to.

PARA.TAB: I believe that we do have a policy. I have outlined it several times in this chamber. It is a policy which has to do with strengthening the access of those eligible Australians to our public hospital system primarily, but also, of course, to help with those private patients who attend our public hospitals—by a massive subsidy; I mentioned some $800m with respect to that. There are many elements of the Government's health care policy which make it much more than the health financing policy with which the Opposition is obsessed. In relation to primary health care given by GPs, whether in an urban or a rural setting, in relation to a reduction of waiting lists and in relation to a whole host of matters—particularly aged care, for example—we believe there is a need for a comprehensive health policy which provides for fair health and hospital access for all Australians who qualify on a strictly clinical basis.

In that regard we believe that the Medicare enterprise was launched so successfully by this Labor Government and is endorsed by seven out of 10 Australians, and will continue to have the support of most Australians—principally, of course, that part of it that has to do with bulkbilling. Except for pensioners and card holders, the Opposition would strip that away as a possibility to be offered by GPs when they are visited by ordinary low income Australians.

So, in all these ways, it is quite evident that the Government has to build on and strengthen the foundations of Medicare. It will not dismantle it as the Opposition would wish, and it certainly will not become obsessed with private health insurance premiums as the way in which the health care system is to be further financed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps the Minister could have another go at answering the question. What was put to him is: why did he say in Question Time today that under a coalition government private health insurance will be compulsory when it is manifestly obvious from his answer that he knows that not to be true? The Minister knows that the proper answer to the question of whether or not it will be compulsory is no. He knows that there is a tax incentive to help low income earners in, and a tax penalty to push high income earners in. On that basis, why did the Minister assert today, broadly and without qualification, that under a coalition government private health insurance will be compulsory? Why did he mislead the Senate and the Australian public as to the coalition's policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time on Tuesday, Senator Watson asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer relating to the implementation of the new sales tax legislation. I have an answer to that question and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Treasurer on 24 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: Can the Minister representing the Treasurer confirm that the new streamlined sales tax legislation recently passed by the Parliament will be able to be fully implemented as designated in the legislation by 1 January? Can the Minister also confirm that the Australian Taxation Office will meet all its commitments under the legislation in issuing the registration numbers necessary to be in place by 1 January? Does the suggestion from the Tax Office that an ad hoc arrangement of using some old exemption certificates along with the new registration numbers meets the requirement of the legislation?

ANSWER.PARA: I can confirm that the new sales tax legislation will commence on 1 January 1993.

PARA.TAB: Information booklets containing registration application forms have been mailed to eligible persons. When these eligible persons have returned the completed application forms the ATO will issue them with a registration number which they will be able to quote to obtain goods free of sales tax. Eligible persons are primary producers, miners and manufacturers of exempt goods.

Given the number of applications received to date the ATO now anticipates that some eligible persons may not return the forms and receive their registration numbers before 1 January. As an interim measure, a person who has lodged their registration application by that date will be able to use the new exemption declaration for purchases until they receive their registration number. The ATO's response places no additional burden on these people. The exemption declarations replace the existing exemption certificates that eligible persons are required to quote under existing administrative arrangements.

The Commissioner has the power to authorise an exempt person to quote an exemption declaration in special circumstances by virtue of section 84 of the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992. Facilitating the commencement of the new arrangements is considered to be a special circumstance.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Spindler)—as amended by leave—proposed:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)That the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities review the scope and effectiveness of the Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Stock Exchange inquiries into the trading of shares in Jupiters Ltd since 1 January 1992, with particular reference to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the identity of the buyers and sellers of shares during relevant times;
(b)whether any of the shares traded in that period were traded, and are now held by third parties;
(c)whether any benefits were derived on the basis of access to information about the casino tendering process.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (2)That the Committee report on or before 31 March 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler's motion, in the final form in which it has emerged for consideration by the Senate, is certainly an improvement on the one circulated earlier today. The Government commends it as an improvement, particularly as it seems to recognise that the true role of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities is a supervisory one. It is quite right that it should act as inquisitor of the Australian Securities Commission in relation to the effectiveness of the undertaking by it of its duties under the Australian corporations and securities legislation.

PARA.TAB: It still seems to me to be perhaps going beyond the proper role of the parliamentary Joint Committee. That role is defined in section 243 of the Australian Securities Commission Act which relevantly speaks of the parliamentary Committee's duties being to inquire into and report to both Houses on activities of the Commission which the Parliament's attention should be directed to. That is a paraphrase of its role, but basically it is to report on the activities of the Commission.

In so far as this motion attempts to have the Joint Committee examine the identity of the buyers and sellers of shares during relevant times, inquire into the question as to whether any of the shares traded in that period were traded and are now held by third parties and whether any benefits were derived on the basis of access to information about the casino tendering process, it may well be that there is a trespassing on the division which the Parliament saw fit to make between the role of the Australian Securities Commission and the Joint Committee.

I believe that we are really on the edge of confusion of the role of both of them, somewhat akin to what we have already been through in relation to the National Crime Authority. I believe it has to be clearly understood that the role of the joint parliamentary committee is to carry out investigations into allegations of insider trading and that the parliamentary committee cannot substitute itself for the Australian Securities Commission in that regard. So I believe that this is perhaps on the borderline

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense.

—It is not nonsense. It is a very good point that I am making. I believe for a cautious and prudent interpretation of these terms of reference when it gets before the committee. Primarily, as I say, the terms of reference speak of the proper supervisory role of the joint parliamentary committee. I am just concerned that it does not itself get into the task and role of the Australian Securities Commission itself into conducting an inquiry into insider trading. It will be a fine line. I am quite confident that the committee will have the capacity to understand where, from time to time, that line ought to be drawn and I therefore have given leave for Senator Spindler to move this particular motion. I believe, as I understand it, that the Opposition will be supporting it.

—I believe this motion should be supported. Further material has come to the attention of the State Parliament in Queensland and was tabled there this morning relevant to this matter; I think it is important that this motion be supported.

—in reply—I agree with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that there is a fine line of distinction to be drawn; however, it is certainly within the purview of the committee to examine the reviews that were made and the reports that were issued as a result of those reports and to examine any shortcomings of those reports and to put any material on record that has not been elicited by those reviews.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: QUESTION ON NOTICE
(Question No. 2408)

Senator Michael Tate—The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The question set out in the Notice Paper of 4 November 1992 referred to the date 9 April 1991. It is my belief that this was not the honourable senator's intention and that she intended to refer to 9 April 1992. The answer is accordingly given in reference to 9 April 1992. I am advised that:

(1) Despite preliminary inquiries, the ASC is not in possession of sufficient evidence or information which would afford a reason to suspect a contravention of a national scheme law or a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory, as is required by Section 13(1) of the Australian Securities Commission Law in order to initiate a formal investigation into share trading relating to Jupiters Limited. Therefore, the ASC has not formally investigated the purchase of shares of Jupiters Ltd shares on 9 April 1992 as the purchase of shares at that time did not represent an extraordinary trading pattern when viewed against Jupiters Limited's issued share capital of 192.4 million shares. However, if Senator Chamarette has any evidence or

SPEECH.PARA: information relevant to this matter, I would be pleased to pass it on to the ASC.

PARA.TAB: (2)The ASC has not investigated this matter.
(3)The ASC has not investigated this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Treasurer (Senator Button) this day, in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Watson on 24 November 1992, relating to Australian Tax Office administration of Sales Tax exemptions.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer relates to certain disarray in the Tax Office as a result of the unreal commencing date of 1 January for the so-called streamlined sales tax legislation. As the Senate is aware, the Tax Office has had difficulty in getting the required booklets out to the various eligible taxpayers. Consequently, the Tax Office is anticipating that a very significant number of taxpayers will not have their registration by the due date, 1 January 1993.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration inquiry into the simplified sales tax Bills was told that it would be impossible for the Tax Office to effect the necessary administrative arrangements by that date. Despite these warnings, the Government went ahead with an unrealistic commencement date and will cause many problems for taxpayers who will not have received their registration number under the new streamlining arrangements by 1 January.

The Tax Commissioner has issued a press statement which indicates that taxpayers will not be inconvenienced. But I am told that this somewhat contradicts what is outlined on page 1 of Streamline sales tax: how it affects you and on page 4 of an accompanying booklet for primary producers. The implication is that those who do not register will have to quote an exemption declaration—which is the one that has been referred to in Senator Button's answer—when buying certain goods used in their business. It goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: This procedure is much more consuming than using a sales tax number as you must give details to your supplier regarding the circumstances in which the goods will be used and in which exemption item applies. If you are registered, you do not have to supply these details,—
obviously—
you just have to quote your sales tax number.

But the problem is: how will ordinary, everyday taxpayers know the number? Furthermore, these taxpayers who have not received their registration number cannot get the declaration certificate from the merchants; they have to apply to get the forms from the Australian Taxation Office. In the case of primary producers, this will be in the middle of harvest time and it will cause a great deal of problems.

PARA.TAB: There is another problem. People will need to give details on the exemption certificate of their exemption declaration; their name, address, and telephone number; what goods they are buying; how they will use those goods; why they are making a claim; and under what exemption item they are claiming the exemption. They will be asked to sign the form and give it to their supplier.

It will cause further problems to individual taxpayers because not only will they have to get this declaration from the merchant, according to the Tax Office, but also they will have to apply for it. These forms are only available in the regional and the city offices. Furthermore, people cannot apply for just one form, because if buying fencing fittings and other items they have to lodge a separate form for each eligible item. So it is quite wrong to indicate that taxpayers will not be inconvenienced if they do not have their certificate registration number by 1 January.

I also remind the Minister to tell the Tax Office that there is some confusion about the messages given on the hot lines because they are confusing exemption certificates and exemption declarations. They have different applications. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Knowles proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The health of thousands of Australians being put at risk by the Prime Minister advocating `that Australians don't need private health insurance'.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the future of health under this Labor Government and what the alternatives are under a coalition government.

PARA.TAB: There will be five Opposition speakers on this matter of public importance. I will be talking briefly about the Medicare agreements; Senator Patterson will talk about the private and public hospital system; Senator Walters will talk about the Government's attempts to destroy the private hospital system and private health insurance funds; Senator Newman will elaborate on the plight of women and the problems of access for the aged; and Senator Herron, who is a very well-respected surgeon and knows the area extremely well, will talk about the poor quality of health care delivery that has developed under this Government over the past 10 years.

We are debating this matter of public importance as a result of the blind refusal of this Labor Government, further demonstrated today at Question Time by Senator Tate, the Minister representing in this chamber the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe), to recognise the role of the private sector in health care—a refusal that will cause the collapse of the private hospital system in this country.

Today the Australian Private Hospitals Association took a very unusual step of launching a national campaign throughout Australia to demonstrate its vital role in Australia's health system. That campaign will conduct an audit of its patients, the staff and the operations performed today. That will be an invaluable audit because it will demonstrate the problems that this country would have if the association undertook the course that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is advocating when he says, `Many people are privately insured and they don't have to be'. If that is the case and that is the cause that this Prime Minister, Mr Howe and Senator Tate want to take on to ensure that people move away from private health insurance, they must be aware of the consequences.

More than 100,000 people cannot gain access to hospitals for operations today. Senator Walters asked a question today about the $3.5m that this Government is spending on its self-promotion, as opposed to spending its own Labor Party money during a campaign to promote its policies, which are yet to be announced. Senator Walters simply asked: how many operations would that $3.5m cover if put towards hip operations? Senator Tate refused to answer the question. Yet it took Senator Panizza to tell the Senate that it would save the pain and suffering of 350 patients.

This country has a right to a better health service than that which it has today. This same Labor Government is raising the Medicare levy from 1.25 per cent to 1.4 per cent. This is the Labor Government that has said, `We will not increase the Medicare levy'. This is the same Labor Government that has said that there will be no capital gains tax. This is the same Labor Government that has said that there would be no child living in poverty by 1990. However, it was smart enough not to talk about the parents living in poverty by 1990. The fact remains that this Government cannot do a thing about the financing of health.

Ten years ago this Government said that the Medicare levy would be self-financing for health. Let me tell honourable senators where we are at with that. In 1989-90, the levy covered only 21.3 per cent of health costs. It was nowhere near 100 per cent. By 1990-91, it covered 19.2 per cent. Last year it was down to 17.2 per cent. The projection for 1992-93 shows that it will be down to 17 per cent.

This is the Government that tries to pretend that someone's levy—the levy that it is now in the throes of increasing—is miraculously going to pay for the total cost of health. The levy is now covering 17 per cent of it. How does the Government fund the rest of it? It does so by increasing general taxes—by increasing the tax take right across-the-board.

Of course, the rise in the levy will not make any difference at all in 1993-94, after which the same trend obviously will continue if the people of Australia are unlucky enough to have this Government continue in office. But there will not be a problem because there will be a change of government. So the 1993-94 prospect will not become a reality. This Labor Government is in the process of dragooning the States into a new Medicare agreement that supposedly assists public hospitals. All that the States must do is undertake to somehow increase their proportion of public patients in public hospitals. It is just extraordinary! How on earth can they start increasing the number of patients when the beds are not available?

A couple of weeks ago in the Senate I gave example after example of people who are experiencing serious complications as a result of being locked out of the public hospital system. Yet their access to the private hospital system is going to be further restricted when this Government implements a policy to remove more and more people from the private health insurance system. It is typical of this Government's blind and stubborn approach that it refuses to contemplate the fact that some public patients may be perfectly able to afford private cover and it is taking beds away from those public patients who cannot.

Many patients in public hospitals are locking out low income people. We plan to free up that system. The proposals in the publication, the so-called Charters for public patients, are an exercise in futility when the root cause of the problem of waiting lists is simply and deliberately ignored.
The former Labor Minister for Health in Western Australia, Keith Wilson, who resigned his office on 13 November, commented on the approach of the Federal Minister. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It's a very unintelligent addressing of the issue and it shows that he is ideologically hung up in a way which prevents a commonsense approach.

They are the words of a Labor State Minister who has seen fit to resign over this Labor Government's mismanagement of the area of health. Over the last decade we have seen sufficient mismanagement by this Labor Government. It is about time the Labor Party put forward its policy on health. The situation is getting worse and worse.

PARA.TAB: It is inadequate for the Minister, Senator Tate, to stand up here in Question Time today and say, `You know our policy'. If all the Government's policy means is a lengthening of the queues and a further locking out of people from the private system then that is not the policy the people are wanting to know.

There is no point in telling us that the Government has spent hundreds upon thousands of dollars trying to shorten the waiting lists. The Government has done that, but all to no avail. For the last 10 years the Government has been trying to shorten the waiting lists. What has happened to the waiting lists? They have grown and grown. So there is no point in trying to tell us that the situation is being resolved. It is being exacerbated by the Government's policies.

The former Western Australian Minister dared to point out that the emperor had no clothes by criticising this Labor Government for failing to recognise the importance of private health insurance as a source of hospital funding and claiming that `We have the most inefficient and ramshackle hospital funding system one can imagine'. This Labor Minister was so concerned about this Federal Labor Government's health policy that on his last visit to Canberra he sought a meeting with the shadow Minister for health, Dr Bob Woods. He realised that Dr Woods and the Liberal and National parties have a policy that will solve the problems for this country.

We want to know when the Labor Party will release its policy so that people can judge one policy against the other. There is no point in this Minister continuing to tell the untruths that he told in a litany of untruths during Question Time today about the Liberal-National Party coalition policies. Let the public compare one with the other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the Senate concerns what is put by the Opposition in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The health of thousands of Australian being put at risk by the Prime Minister advocating `that Australians don't need private health insurance.'

Australians need a continuation of Medicare—the very firm foundation which seven out of 10 Australians still believe provides the best health care system in the world and which I certainly support and which those on this side of the chamber wish to strengthen. We will do so in full recognition of the primary Medicare principles which concern the access of all eligible persons in Australia to medical and hospital care.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you privately insured?
—Why don't you shut up and let me have a go!

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! The previous speaker was heard in relative silence and I would ask that the Minister be accorded the same respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: Madam Acting Deputy President, we have a gallery full of children hearing the Minister for Justice telling me to shut up. It is a disgraceful thing to do!
—There is no point of order.

—Looking at the question of the provision of health care for all Australians, I agree that there is a role for private health insurance. That has to be said right from the start because there has been a total distortion, as though the Federal Government ignores and does not put into any sort of proper role within the provision of health care for Australians that which is played by health insurance.

PARA.TAB: It is important to note that in the Medicare principles which are being negotiated by the Government at the moment with the various State and Territory jurisdictions, the very first paragraph states:
The Commonwealth and the States are committed to the following principles in the provision of public hospital services.

SPEECH.PARA: There then follows immediately a preambular note to the whole section:

PARA.TAB: The principles focus on the provision of public hospital services to eligible persons but operate in an environment where eligible persons have the right to choose private health care in public and private hospitals supported by private health insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: So right at the beginning is the proper recognition of the role of private health insurance in the ability of Australians to choose to take out private health insurance should they wish to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why isn't it part of the Medicare agreement?

—It will be part of that preamble to the Medicare agreement; that is the whole point. The Medicare agreement itself is principally concerned with the access to public hospital services of those who are eligible to receive the treatment that is provided. That is what Medicare is principally about. But there is a role for private health insurance and it is recognised right at the beginning of the statement of the principles which are presently being negotiated.
—Only for public hospitals.

—No, not just for public hospitals. We do not have any ideological blinkers. We say that private health insurance has a role. The Opposition is saying that the further financing of the health system, which is required, really depends solely on ensuring that a good premium income is coming in to the private health insurance funds. We do not believe that that is the case. We do not believe that tax credits and penalties is the way to go to ensure that that money flows through to those who practise within the health system through the private health insurance mechanism, because that is what principally would happen.

PARA.TAB: The Government's policy emphasises that there is a need to strengthen Australia's public hospital system. Our primary concern is for all those Australians who need some medical attention or hospitalisation and depend on our public hospitals in order to receive that service at a time when they have suffered some acute malady, the consequence of a chronic illness or the effects of a traumatic accident on the road or in an industrial situation, whatever it might be. We believe they are entitled to that service and that our great public hospitals definitely need to be strengthened. That is why we are proposing to spend another $1.6 billion in supporting those public hospitals.

We believe that that is the best way in which to use taxpayer support for the provision of health care for Australians. We do not believe that it should be used by diverting taxpayers' moneys away from that particular type of funding of public hospitals to providing a tax credit for low income persons whom the Opposition wishes to encourage to take out private insurance. That is not the way to spend those hundreds of millions of dollars. The money should go directly into the public hospital system, with some private health insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some.

—Yes. About 11 per cent of the whole health care costs of Australians comes out of funding through private health insurance. The great bulk comes through taxpayer supported initiatives of Commonwealth and State governments. That is where Australians derive the greatest benefit in relation to the provision of their health care. The tax system and the Medicare levy, based as it is on a progressive tax system, means that those who can afford to make a contribution to the health care of Australians will make it in proportion to their income rather than by private health insurance premiums, which do not differentiate between the income of those who are paying it for a particular provision against the prospect of payments because of a visit to a doctor or the need to be hospitalised or to receive some other treatment.

PARA.TAB: We clearly have a priority in favour of strengthening the public hospital system. I believe that that has to be completely reiterated and understood.

In relation to the whole question of the provision of health care, it has to be emphasised that one is not simply speaking of a funding mechanism. One is speaking of what one wishes to achieve. We are all concerned with the cases which we are all aware of, of those who have the treatment of an illness or a condition which is causing them pain delayed or deferred because of a difficulty in getting a bed at a time which would give them relief earlier than otherwise. That is why this Government has provided some $70m over the next two years specifically to deal with the waiting list problem. But that is only a portion of the way to remedy the problem.

The bigger effort in that regard will come from the extra moneys flowing into the public hospital system under the general agreement to put in an extra $1.6 billion over six years. But, by specifically tackling the question of the queuing of people for treatment and in ensuring that those who are in the queue get treated according to an assessment that is based on clear clinical need, we will emphasise and help in that assessment so that we have a true listing in priority of those who require and deserve the treatment.

In these ways we are addressing the question of the health care of Australians and not simply concentrating obsessively on the private health insurance mechanism to pump money into, it is said, the provision of health care, but it may be simply into the pockets of those who provide health care.

It is also important that we recall that within the Budget provisions of the Federal Government in the whole question of the provision of health care for Australians a very real effort is made to strengthen the provision of health care by those who most people see most of the time, that is, their GPs. In Tasmania this is well appreciated and coincides with the establishment of a chair in community medicine and rural health matters at the University of Tasmania out of Launceston. As a matter of social equity and social justice there is a real requirement that those who live outside the major urban areas of Australia have access to good health care from their GPs.

We are certainly strengthening that network of rural doctors and those in the smaller towns of Australia who can be persuaded to stay in, or move to, those areas to provide that sort of care. That is the sort of practical step that we are taking to provide better health care for all Australians. It is one that I am quite sure is held in very high regard.

There are many ways in which the Government is concerned to take steps to help in this regard. If one is talking about access to primary health care and general practitioners, one has to keep in mind that bulkbilling is an important part of the experience of many Australians as they approach their doctor for advice as to a problem that is bedevilling them and causing some ill effect, either physical or mental.

They go to their GP and the GP, under the Government's Medicare scheme, can make a choice as to whether to bulkbill that person, whether to make a bulkbilling arrangement. We believe that that is proper and part of the freedom of choice which is characteristic of Australian society and ought to be encouraged. We find to our horror that, under the Fightback alternative which is being paraded today, in relation to those who are not pensioners or cardholders—I refer to the remaining 80 per cent of the Australian population—GPs will not be allowed to bulkbill.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can if they want to.
—They will not be able to get the arrangement under Medicare that they can get now, as the honourable senator well knows. That is the truth of the matter.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I refuse to have our policy misrepresented. Under our policy, the amount is entirely up to the doctor. It is a misrepresentation to say that these people are excluded from bulkbilling.
—Order! There is no point of order. I believe that you are speaking later, Senator Herron. You can make your point then.

—It is extremely important for Australians to understand that if they wish to retain a system of health care which has provided the greatest certainty and equity that the Australian community has seen in relation to the provision of health care over the last decade, they must support the strengthening of Medicare. The alternative being proposed by the Opposition will do away with the provision of health care in a way which I believe probably will be unmatched in the world.

PARA.TAB: Of course, there are those cases which we are all concerned about and which have been put to the Senate during Question Time. But we know what the alternatives are around the world. We know the desperate plight of those who are so dependent on a private health insurance system, as occurs in the United States. One is terribly fearful of either oneself or a member of one's family falling ill because of the need to pay very high health insurance premiums. Or they find that when they go to the hospital, the hospital asks whether they have a health insurance card, and if they do not have a health insurance card they do not get treated.

As Senator Herron himself has said in debate here, the United States has the best health system in the world—for those who can afford it. It is not the same here. One can get very good health care in Australia without the need to be wealthy. That is a result of the Medicare program which has been instituted by this Government. I know that for a fact through personal experience of the health care system here.

There is a place for private health insurance within the Australian health care system. It is only a proportionate place. The major place lives within the role of the Australian, State and Territory governments to help, through the taxation system, to strengthen the public hospital system. That is our primary obligation and duty to the Australian people. We continue to press for that in the negotiations that are taking place. Over the next few weeks those negotiations will come to a conclusion which will verify the fears that are held by all States as to what would happen to their public hospital system under the Fightback proposals. Quite clearly, with a reduction of 5 per cent in the funds paid to the States under the Fightback proposals, there would be much less money available to the States for them to spend on various public services, which must include their hospital services.It follows absolutely certainly.

The Opposition would strip away $31m to $32m from Tasmania through the reduction in the general grants made available. That would have to flow through to the provision of services for the Tasmanian people, including the provision of hospital services through our public hospitals, such as the Royal Hobart Hospital and others. That is a prospect which, when understood right around Australia, will fill not only the general citizenry but State and Territory Health Ministers with foreboding. I am quite sure that before the election day they will sign this agreement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Looking at the matter we have before us, the emphasis today on hospitals, and in particular private hospitals, is understandable because it is the day the Private Hospitals Association is launching its campaign. It is a campaign with which the Democrats have some sympathy. We understand some of the problems that are being faced in our health care system today. But it is not just today that we see this emphasis on hospitals, hospital funding and waiting lists. The impression one gets from listening to debates in this chamber is that health is all about hospitals and the ongoing philosophical debate about whether hospitals are publicly or privately funded, about whether we need waiting lists, how many waiting lists, how many people are on them, should we have them at all, should we try to clear them, and so on and so forth.

PARA.TAB: Before looking more deeply at the issue, I do not want to gloss over the problems that certainly are evident in some hospitals with some long waiting lists. But there are far more problems in hospitals than waiting lists. The Government should start acknowledging that it has responsibility for those who are moved out of hospitals early, whether because of day surgery or whether because it is simply now the practice to move people home fairly rapidly. The Government must accept its responsibility for their ongoing care and monitoring, and not somehow try to push that into hospital funding as it now stands.

I will argue that in Australia we do, indeed, have a good health care system once one is sick. But what I want to argue today is that our health care system should be more than an illness abatement program or a sickness management program. In particular, I want to look at the document entitled Enough to make you sick: How income and environment affect health. It is put out by the national health strategy team. It is research paper No. 1, September 1992. I quote from the executive summary:

SPEECH.PARA: There are overwhelming inequities in the health of Australians.

PARA.TAB: Again and again, similar themes emerge when the inequalities for the most disadvantaged groups are examined:

SPEECH.PARA: They have the poorest health
They make the most use of primary and secondary health services, but they are the lowest users of preventative health services
Their poorer health status largely explains their greater use of primary and secondary health services.

So who are these Australians? I do not think anyone in this chamber has any doubt that they would include the unemployed and under-employed, hundreds of thousands of children, many people in rural communities, particularly farming families, single parents, the homeless and the tens of thousands of Australians who now rely on welfare agencies for basic food, clothing and other essentials. I go on to look at what this research tells us. I quote again:

PARA.TAB: Overall standardised death rates are highest for those from areas experiencing the worst socioeconomic disadvantage. Compared with people from advantaged areas, these people have standardised death rates which range from 46 per cent higher (for girls) to 67 per cent higher (for men). They also have higher death rates from certain causes of death—

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with that later. It goes on:

PARA.TAB: Of all people in the community, those of low socio-economic status are:
most likely to suffer disability
most likely to have serious chronic illness
most likely to suffer recent illnesses

most likely to report being only in fair or poor health as opposed to good/excellent health. (for example, low income men are 167 per cent more likely than high income men to view their health in this way, and similarly, low income women are 148 per cent more likely to do so).

SPEECH.PARA: It continues:
In addition to having poorer health status according to these illness indicators, people of low socioeconomic status are more susceptible to certain chronic conditions . . .

PARA.TAB: Many of the disorders which affect those of low socioeconomic status disproportionately are associated with certain behavioural risks which are more prevalent in those of low socioeconomic status. For adults these include:

SPEECH.PARA: . smoking . . .
. being overweight . . .
. being inactive . . .
Having read that, I can only ask: when are we really seriously going to start to look at prevention, instead of spending all our time in this chamber and so much of our resources on cure?

PARA.TAB: The States are doing this in bits and pieces. I note that in my State of South Australia, unfortunately, we now have an extensive program of food provision for children—not just primary school children but also secondary school children. And it is not just breakfast; sometimes it is lunch and in some schools it also extends to after-school additional supplements. If for no other reason, surely we should be concerned about the fact that they cannot concentrate and often do not behave themselves if they are hungry. Indeed, with regard to South Australia, I do not know of the need ever having been greater than it is now.

I suggest that, on a national level, we need to look at a truly national food nutrition program—and I am not talking about just food supplements. We need a federally funded and coordinated program that involves making sure kids understand what is good food and the importance of a good healthy diet versus continuing the intake of what we may best describe as junk food. By senior primary, and certainly into secondary school, we should have classes—and I am sure many of us can remember them—that actually show students how to prepare nutritious meals, looking to the future when these individuals will actually be caring for themselves. This information could then be taken back and shared with the family.

People may believe that this is happening in schools. Unfortunately, as we see the pressure for subjects in other areas, this is not now happening universally; far from it. Our school systems are going backwards. Cuts to education in almost every State have meant a reduction in the number of teachers, additional pressure on teachers and a change in priorities—away from learning for life and life skills to education for employment and virtually nothing else. We have seen in many schools the virtual demolition of what used to be known as home economics, certainly for anybody after year 8, and then it is done only in a very passing and cursory manner.

If we look at a document entitled `Common and agreed national goals for schooling in Australia'—and these goals are supposed to provide a framework for cooperation between schools, States and Territories and the Commonwealth—we see that goal No. 9 says:

SPEECH.PARA: To provide for the physical development and personal health and fitness of students and for the creative use of leisure time.

That is so full of holes, so inadequate and so vague that one could probably have an annual walkathon to fulfil that basic goal in terms of fitness for students. As for personal health, handing out a few pamphlets would probably be enough. As for the creative use of leisure time, other subjects such as music and art are falling by the wayside as well as physical education and home economics.

PARA.TAB: Physical education programs are constantly under pressure in our schools and the pressure is getting greater. The pressure is to reduce time, so kids are finding that, if there is any physical education available, it may be for only one lesson a week; there certainly is not daily physical education in most schools. Students are being counselled out of activities; told that it is far more important in year 8 to do academic subjects. Indeed, one of my daughters was in this situation. By year 9 no physical education is available for many students. In many schools now, as teacher cuts go on and on, the teacher is not trained in physical education, and so often what the students are learning and doing is not appropriate and tends to turn off as many students as it benefits.

As well as that, for those schools that are still running physical education programs, finances are becoming so tight that many kids have to sit on the sidelines. This is not just the old problem that always existed with students moving into senior years and attending recreational activities such as ten-pin bowling; it is now happening for gymnastics and dances in the junior schools. Schools are no longer either upgrading their gym equipment or even maintaining it so it can be used. Instead, they are bussing kids to the local gym and employing an outside teacher and $1, $2 or $3 has to be handed over. Kids from low socioeconomic backgrounds simply cannot afford it, and they sit and watch. Surely a healthy life is as important, if not more important, than a purely wealthy one. We really need to look at what our schools are doing and what our kids are being told.

Returning to these national goals, the use of leisure time is an essential issue not just for those who are employed—or those who want to drop off at the gym on the way to work, jog in their lunch hour or perhaps go to squash on the way home. It is essential for all Australians, and that includes those who are unemployed and underemployed and those who have not had these opportunities at school. People need to understand the importance of maintaining a reasonable level of fitness and people need to be confident when they want to undertake activities. For example, people need to be confident enough to actually take the kids to the beach, knowing that they can supervise because they themselves can swim; or be confident enough to go for a fun run or perhaps bush walking. If these people have not had this experience either in their days at school or with their families, there is very little opportunity for their children unless they get these experiences at school. Many families simply do not do a lot of what we would consider to be the ordinary, everyday recreational activities because they have less opportunity and because they lack finances.

In regard to finances, the demise of our physical education programs in most schools is not such a problem for parents who have high or moderately high incomes. They can perhaps even send their kids off to a private school and, as most private schools are able to maintain programs, the problem is solved. But, where their children attend public schools, they can afford to send their kids to swimming coaching or tennis coaching after hours; they can take their kids ten-pin bowling or skating on the weekend. It is the kids from backgrounds where there is not sufficient finance and where parents have not had the experience who are suffering the most. Hence I look back at this document and see it as simply reinforcing what the national health strategy has found. Very briefly, I would argue that our physical education programs really are a national disgrace.

I do not see any sign, despite all the research that has been done—and this is only one document that has shown it—that we are about to divert one dollar to schools to ensure that we have a healthier and fitter population. Indeed, it may be health dollars that are really needed in our schools to ensure that some of these basic programs are up and running.
Returning to the matter of death rates, this document, Enough to make you sick, says:

SPEECH.PARA: Compared with children of high socioeconomic status, disadvantaged children have higher death rates from the following causes:
. hypoxia
. sudden infant death syndrome
. accidental drowning (in boys)
. disorders related to short gestation (in girls)
. motor vehicle traffic accidents (in girls).
Compared with adults of high socioeconomic status, disadvantaged adults have higher death rates from the following causes:
. pneumonia/influenza
. bronchitis/emphysema/asthma
. lung cancer
. ischaemic heart disease
. cerebrovascular disease
. motor vehicle traffic accidents
. suicide
. diabetes

PARA.TAB: Often the magnitude of these differences is enormous.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not go on to read the rest of that section at the moment. Very quickly looking beyond these death rates, the document says:
Compared to adults of high socioeconomic status, adults of low socioeconomic status are more susceptible to:
. bronchitis/emphysema
. asthma
. back problems
. arthritis
. ulcer
. hypertension
. varicose veins (in men)

What does all this bring us back to? Let us go back and look at the issue we are discussing today—`The health of thousands of Australians being put at risk by the Prime Minister advocating "that Australians do not need private health insurance"'. I would say it is being put at risk by our ignorance of what really is the underlying problem, our total ignoring of the preventive side of what we should be looking at in terms of our health policy. I would argue very strongly that just talking about hospitals and where the money is coming from is not the real issue. Harping on how we are going to fund health is important, and I think we need to sort some of that out. No doubt speakers after me today will look further into the hospital system. But what we really need to look at is whether or not in this country we should start really trying to prevent illness.

PARA.TAB: I have looked at only two ways of doing that and they both fall within the education system. I have not mentioned the basic need to share resources more equitably in this country. The important debate is how we can solve the problems highlighted in this document before they become too obvious, before any more Australians are condemned to a life of poor health because of lack of prevention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating in this matter of public importance the issue:

PARA.TAB: The health of thousands of Australians being put at risk by the Prime Minister advocating `that Australians don't need private health insurance'.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no argument at all with Senator Lees about the fact that we need to emphasise preventive medicine and public health promotion, but that is not the issue we are debating today. The issue we are debating today is private health insurance and whether there is a need for it. We can have a debate about preventative public health at some other time. We are talking about people taking out private health insurance and their access to hospitals.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees said, `We have a very good health system once you are sick'. I can take her to person after person who is sick and they can testify that we do not have a very good health system, especially if one does not have private health insurance. It is not a very good health system. Senator Lees heard me ask Senator Tate this afternoon a question about a lady who needs a hip replacement operation. I was rung by the owner of the local newsagency who has nothing to do with health and nothing to do with this lady, except that she is a customer in the shop; she comes into the shop regularly. Over a period of two years she has deteriorated because she has been waiting for a hip replacement. The newsagent rang me up in desperation, saying, `What can I do? Can anything be done to get her further up the waiting list?', because he was appalled at the condition this lady was in.

If Senator Lees wants to talk about public health and illness prevention, I would suggest that it would have been much better if that lady had been in hospital very soon after she had been diagnosed as needing a hip replacement so that she did not lose her mobility and then develop other illnesses as a result. Getting that lady into hospital and getting her a hip replacement is an aspect of preventive medicine. Had she been able to afford private health insurance—or had it been after the next election when she gets a rebate for having taken out private health insurance—she might have been able to get a hip replacement without having to wait two years. Senator Lees should not come into this chamber—now she is leaving—and tell me, `We have a very good health system once you are sick'. It might be very good if one has an acute illness, but if one has a chronic illness it is awful.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has said that Australians do not need private health insurance. That is a big fib. He can go and tell the lady who struggles into my local newsagent every week that she does not need private health insurance. She would have had that hip replacement by now had she had private health insurance. I ask the Minister whether he takes out private health insurance.

A week ago my mother and stepfather came back to Australia after living in the United States for 25 years. They are shocked by the cost of private health insurance here; they had top private health insurance in the United States. What did I do in the first week they were back? I made sure they had private health insurance cover. That is how sick I think our system is. The Prime Minister says that they do not need it. I said, `Don't believe Mr Keating, Mum, because you know he is wrong'. She rushed off with me down to the local pharmacist and enrolled in private health insurance. I know that if she needs a hip replacement she will get it. She is not really in a position to pay the health insurance premiums she is paying, but she said, `I will give up other things because I need that cover; I want that insurance'. Mr Keating is wrong. People do need private health insurance. After 10 years, the time the Government has had to get it right or to do something, the health system is in the depths of the blackest crisis ever.

Earlier today, when I was speaking on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, I said that a doctor, with whom I was associated in my previous profession, rang me recently and said, `Come to the casualty section of my hospital right now. There are people lying on trolleys who have been here for days and I have just treated someone on the floor'. I thought I was talking to someone in a Third World country. No, it was a young fellow who, after some years in general practice, has gone back to train as a surgeon. He was working in casualty and he could not believe what had happened to our hospitals since the time he had left when he was a resident doctor in training after completing his medical education at university. He is not a Liberal voter. He has joked with me about being a Labor supporter. He is not a Labor supporter any more. He cannot believe what Labor has done to our hospital system. The hard reality for Australia is that Labor's so-called free and universal health system has led to a grossly inefficient, expensive, not so universal and definitely unstable health delivery system; and it cannot be sustained.

Every day we see the gross failings of the Government's health care system. Every day we are reminded of our health care crisis. We now have a health care system where public hospitals are underfunded and overcrowded, and the number of Australians waiting for elective surgery has increased to between 70,000 and 100,000 in just 10 years. This means that thousands of Australians are currently waiting, many of them in considerable pain, for routine operations such as hip replacements, prostate operations, cataract operations and other things, which would enable them to have a better quality of life, especially those in their latter years. We are talking about them having a quality of life in their last 10 years. Some of them will have been so disabled by the waiting period that they will not ever again have a quality of life. This Labor Government has subjected those people to spending the rest of their lives with a disability which resulted from the failure to get into hospital when they really needed treatment.

We now have a health care system where private hospitals are underutilised with a 55 to 60 per cent occupancy rate. That means that just over half of the beds in private hospitals are being used. It is not surprising, because we have a million unemployed people who cannot afford to take out private health insurance and a lot of people who would if they could take out private health insurance. They cannot afford it, and there is no incentive for them to do so.

It has been estimated that 20 to 25 per cent of those earning $40,000 or more a year fail to take out private health insurance. What happens when they get sick, especially if they get an acute illness? They take up a bed in a public hospital that should have gone to someone who really could not afford to have private health insurance and who really should be in that public health system. That is what those people do. Those people who can afford private health insurance and who can afford to take a greater responsibility for their health care deprive pensioners and low income earners from gaining access to the very limited number of public hospital beds.

We now have a health care system where the cost of private health insurance has risen by 135 per cent in the last five years. I do not need to tell pensioners about this. Many of them still keep their private health insurance at the expense of other things, sometimes even food. They turn their heaters off and do all sorts of things to try to save enough money to get basic hospital cover.

Twenty per cent of the Australian public have jettisoned their private health insurance since the inception of Medicare in 1984. More than two million more Australians rely solely on the Medicare system than was the case some five years ago. If the proportion of Australians who take out private health insurance continues to fall at the rate of 3 per cent a year, it is anticipated it will cost the public hospitals an extra $150m per year to operate. I ask the Government where it is going to find that money. That is another hole.

We now have a health care system where the number of Australians aged above 65 who have taken out private health insurance has increased from 755,000 in 1989 to 824,000 in 1991. I am talking about old people—many of whom are on pensions and cannot really find their way clear to take out private health insurance, yet they struggle to do so. It is hardly surprising that they do, given the parlous state of the public hospital system. Since those who maintain health insurance are more likely to be elderly and therefore use more hospital services, premiums will continue to rise at an alarming rate. That will drive more people out of the private health insurance system and it will drive the costs up again.

I want to know—and perhaps Senator Crowley, Senator Loosley or somebody else will tell me—where are those opposite going to find the money for that purpose? I would also like to know the answer to that question because Mr Howe said that if the Government did not have a Medicare co-payment—and Senator Crowley, when she bothers to come into this debate, will tell me because she was one who opposed the Medicare co-payment last year and now it is being raised to 1.4 per cent—it would need a levy of 1.53 per cent. Where will it get the money? There is a gap there and there is a gap here as people move out of the private health insurance system into the public system. Where is it going to get the money?

We now have a health care system which is heralded as being free, but in reality funds obtained from the Medicare levy provide only 8 per cent of the total health care costs. As Senator Knowles said, members of the Australian public are being hoodwinked if they believe this 1.4 per cent Medicare levy will cover their health costs. No, they have been told an untruth again. Labor propaganda—that is what it is.

The injection of funds that we have had in this Budget for waiting lists will not bring about the kinds of structural reforms that are necessary to address the balance. What has happened is that we are seeing today the private hospital system protesting, as happened a few months ago with the public hospital system in an unprecedented show of strength, and telling us that the hospitals system is almost now no longer viable.

Today we are asking the Government: where are its policies? The Australian public wants to know; the hundred thousand on the waiting list want to know: where are the Government's policies that will get us out of this mess and heal our sick health system?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —So far, all the speakers in this debate on the matter of public importance have been talking about the Government's ideology. Both Senator Knowles and Senator Patterson pointed out clearly how injustices have resulted from the Government's unbridled adherence to that ideology—an ideology that is crippling Australia not only economically but also because of its lack of fairness and equity.

PARA.TAB: The Government has made it very clear that it wants to get rid of private health funds and it will go to any lengths to do so. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) was asked questions this afternoon requesting information on the Government's policy to overcome the enormous number of patients on hospital waiting lists. He had no answers to our questions and only proceeded to tell untruths about the Opposition's Fightback package.
Everyone knows that the Australian health system is in crisis. We have had the Minister for Health in Western Australian, Mr Keith Wilson, resigning. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the area of the hospital funding we have been left with a situation which I described at the hospital survival conference in Melbourne last May as the most inefficient and ramshackle hospital funding system one could imagine. It includes continuing the myth that the Medicare levy provides the funds.
We all know that is what the Government tries to push. We all know that it is an untruth. He went on:

This has meant that hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians, including the 42 per cent of people over 65 who choose to be privately insured as a measure of securing ready access to hospital treatment without an undue wait for needed care, have been ignored. Ignored also is the majority of Labor supporters with private health insurance and the need to encourage people who could afford it to see the membership of private health funds as a means of supplementing scarce public funds needed to maintain high quality public hospital services.
He ended up saying:
Federal Health Minister, Brian Howe, has failed to recognise the role of private health insurers.
That is about the only thing I would disagree with him on. I think Mr Howe does recognise the role of private health insurers and will make sure he dumps them.

PARA.TAB: We have tens of thousands of people on waiting lists at public hospitals who are unable to gain access for urgent treatment. Some, indeed—and it is not too emotional to say so—die before getting that treatment. Yet the Government is so ideologically bound to destroy the private funds that it has spent $3.5m of taxpayers' money, instead of Labor Party funds, in the lead-up to the election for a propaganda campaign to try to sell Medicare and soften up the electorate.

How far will the Government go in its efforts to destroy the private health system? Let us look at the blatant methods it uses. It has to be first understood that the Government's own Act requires that all health funds be registered in each State—that is, to stop funds shifting money from one State to another in an attempt to undercut the contribution rates of the competing funds. This would be so easy to do if it were permitted. However, the Minister and he alone may give permission for the shifting of that money if he chooses, but not—and I stress `not'—if he believes the moving of that money would allow this undercutting to occur.

Let us look at what has occurred. Medibank Private, the Government's own fund, as far back as 1983-84 transferred out of the Victorian branch $22.3m. That money was given to its branches in New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania. This was done to enable the branches of Medibank Private in those States to meet their legal requirement to hold two months reserves of their contributions. Why were the branches in these States so short of money? Because they were busy undercutting their competitors in their States, thus giving them a greater market share.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely outrageous.

—It certainly is. But, at the same time as those branches were getting this bigger market share and undercutting others, they were running down their reserves. Yet the Minister turned a blind eye to this blatant predatory pricing exercise and gave the Victorian branch of Medibank Private permission to transfer its money. What happened? The Victorian branch, of course, had to have its turn to be rescued.

PARA.TAB: So in 1989-90 Medibank Private in Victoria lost $21.8m, and as stated in the last annual general report of the Health Insurance Commission 1990-91 it lost $41.7m. So—surprise, surprise—Medibank Private's branches in New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia came to the party and transferred money back into Victoria to rescue that branch so it could maintain its legal reserves with, of course, the Minister's permission.

Why did Victoria suffer this big loss? Because it was its turn to undercut its competitors in Victoria. This is how it did it. I will cite the family insurance cover in Victoria. Medibank Private's top cover in Victoria costs $24.70 with the basic cover being $17.47; MBF is well above, $33.90, with the basic cover being $21; HBA is $30 with the basic cover being $19.60; ANA is $38.60 with the basic cover being $21.40.

So in that year, with a loss of $41m, the Victorian branch of Medicare Private undercut all the other major health funds in that State. Yet the Minister, with this sort of evidence, this blatant predatory pricing, this blatant evidence of deliberate undercutting, gave Medibank Private permission in the New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australian branches to transfer money to shore up the Victoria funds.

This is how the Government works; this is the Government's ideology—and, unless the Labor Party is thrown out of government, this will finally succeed in bringing down the health system. This explains the lengths to which the Government will go to get rid of the private health funds.

We are aware that the Government has set up an inquiry into hospital services chaired by Jenny Macklin. The Government always chooses the chairman if it wants a certain outcome and recommendations. One of the options she suggested for the Government to adopt was to extend the choice of doctor and hospital to all through a single national insurer. Is that Medibank Private? Let us have a look at what the Government's mates, the health insurance unions, say. A newspaper article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Three major health unions have united to condemn Australia's public and private hospitals for promoting private health insurance.
They said this should involve extending the rights of Medicare patients to use private facilities under one national insurance system.
We have the unions and Jenny Macklin; and, of course, we have Mr Keating himself who says:
You just don't need to cover yourself with private insurance.

For heaven's sake, the Minister should not tell me that the Government's ideology is not blinkered and that it is not the Government's plan to get rid of the private health funds. The Government's plan is to put everyone into one national health fund, and that comes across to all of us very blatantly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I am here to argue against this extraordinary matter of public importance put forward by the Opposition under Senator Susan Knowles's signature. The matter of public importance reads:

PARA.TAB: The health of thousands of Australians being put at risk by the Prime Minister advocating `that Australians don't need private health insurance'.

SPEECH.PARA: One would have to say, listening to the debate in here, that the Opposition thinks its policy is different. Members of the Opposition spent a lot of time interjecting, howling and carrying on during Question Time pointing out that that is precisely what the Opposition's policy says. It is the biggest piece of nonsense that I have heard in a long time to come in here and put forward a matter of public importance opposing the Opposition's own policy. Boy, that takes class! It takes a really dumb Opposition to put forward a matter of public importance opposing its own policy as proposed under Fightback. It is absolutely extraordinary.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition maintains that the health of Australians is being put at risk by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) saying that Australians do not need private health insurance. That is what Fightback says. Senator Vanstone asked in response to Senator Tate whether he was saying that we are being compelled to join or whether there is a choice. Fightback says that Australians do not need health insurance. The reason the Opposition says that Australians do not need health insurance is that it is keeping Medicare. This is the second great fraud of the Opposition's health policy: it is keeping Medicare.

Those opposite do not want to go around telling Australians that, but they are keeping Medicare for three reasons. First, they want the money. They have never come clean on which actual levy they will keep, but they want to keep Medicare because they want the money. Secondly, they want the goodwill. It has taken the Australian Labor Government to create the goodwill that goes with Medicare; a huge popularity in the community, over 70 per cent, want it.
An opposition senator interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I refute that. Over 70 per cent of people like Medicare and want it. Those opposite want to keep the goodwill that goes with it.
—Let them fight an election on it.

—Any time. Senator Loosley says, `Let them fight an election on Medicare'. To the barricades, troops! I cannot wait to get out there and put the nonsense those opposite are proposing to the people. First, they want Medicare because of the levy; secondly, because of the goodwill; and, thirdly, because they know that this time at least they got one thing right. They would not dare go back to the Australian people and say, `Two million of you can be ignored and dropped on the scrap heap', as they did before we came into government. Two million Australians without insurance: they want Medicare as a safety net at ground level to prevent any Australian from requiring to buy private health insurance. Medicare offers all of those things—and that is why they are keeping it. The policy of those opposite says, `They don't need private health insurance'. They are keeping Medicare, yet they come in here and propose a matter of public importance condemning their own policy. What a bunch of idiots they are! What a mob of nonsense idiots! They are really off their faces!
—You can do better than that.
—I can do much better than that, but it is not parliamentary. This Opposition wants to go to the people of Australia. It is keeping Medicare and saying, `You don't need private health insurance'.

PARA.TAB: I have a great problem with the claim made by Senator Susan Knowles, which I happened to hear on the television while I was in my room. Senator Knowles needs to come in here quite often and get things wrong, because then a Labor senator like me can help her get it right. She and Senator Bishop arrived in this place a few weeks ago and said there was a 30 per cent luxury tax on tampons and women's sanitary products. Senators Bishop and Knowles are wrong; and Senator Knowles is wrong in what she was claiming today. She is absolutely wrong about waiting lists. She tells me—fortunately, we are not broadcasting so the listeners' ears are not being dented—

TALK.START.PARA: —Calm down.

—I do not need to calm down. I actually have a passion and an understanding of this. Senator Knowles is wrong about waiting lists. Once again, as with tampons and sanitary pads, Senator Knowles is wrong about waiting lists.
—I know what I would do with one of those at the moment, just to keep you quiet!

—I think that is particularly unkind and unladylike of Senator Patterson, but if she wishes to sink to that kind of vulgarity, she can go ahead. I want to remind people, particularly honourable senators in this place, that the number of people on waiting lists, as claimed by Mr Peter Shack when he last presented the Opposition health policy in a debate with Dr Blewett before the last election, was put at 100,000 by the Opposition. What does the Opposition's own Fightback package say? It says 60,000. It is down and Senator Knowles had better get it right. It is down for some of the reasons that Senator Knowles has no idea about.

PARA.TAB: If anyone is listening, I welcome Senator Knowles back into the chamber. She has come back to get it right, has she? I am delighted to help her. The number of people on waiting lists was wrong. Senator Knowles said that before the last election there were 100,000 and that in Fightback it is 60,000. The reason it is down is that the Government, in collaboration with the States, put $50m over three years into reducing waiting lists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Liar.
—Senator Knowles has called me a liar across the chamber, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I ask you to ask her to withdraw that.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! Senator Knowles, your comment is unparliamentary and I wonder whether you would be kind enough to withdraw it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the fact that Senator Crowley is consistently calling me a liar, I would ask her to withdraw, and I will consequently withdraw. I withdraw, and I now take a point of order and ask that Senator Crowley, who has consistently today and on previous occasions called me a liar, be asked to withdraw unqualifiedly.
—Senator Knowles, I have not heard Senator Crowley call you a liar today, but if she has she will know it and I am sure that she will withdraw.
—I am not quite sure where that leaves me, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I support your first claim that you have not heard me say it because I do not say it, knowing that it is unparliamentary.

PARA.TAB: The point is that the waiting lists have been reduced from 100,000 to 60,000, according to Fightback's own figures. One of the reasons for that reduction is the specifically targeted $50m in collaboration with the States over three years to reduce those waiting lists. Senator Herron would know these figures because he has seen the graphs. Recognising that that is the case with targeted money to reduce waiting lists, the Government has ordered it to be done again: $70m will be provided over this year and next year to reduce waiting lists.

Some of the Liberal State Ministers—I believe Mr Phillips in New South Wales and Mrs Tehan in Victoria—are so clear about their preferred political position that they will not even take that money. They are prepared to make a political point about waiting lists rather than take the money to reduce them. Anybody in Victoria could simply stand up and say, `Minister Tehan, you could reduce your waiting lists immediately'. Minister Tehan could be challenged by any Victorian about the fact that she is refusing to sign the Medicare agreement and take the money that the Commonwealth is waiting to pass over to her to reduce the waiting lists in the hospitals in Victoria. She would rather force Victorians to wait, and force the pain and anguish that I heard honourable senators talking about earlier today, because she wants to stand on the cheap political principle of promoting private insurance, and so does the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the only answer.

—It is very interesting that Senator Herron says, `It is the only answer'. That is not the case at all. Let me give the Senate a few illustrative examples. In South Australia a few years ago the Minister for Health, Mr Cornwall, arranged with the private hospitals to take public patients into those beds. The private hospitals were delighted to cooperate and they did, until the specialist medicos withdrew their labour.
—Rubbish!

—Does Senator Walters want to know the facts? They are the facts. The specialist medicos withdrew their labour. The private hospitals wanted their beds to be used—they wanted to offer their grossly excessive spare capacity to public patients—and the specialist medicos refused to allow it to happen.
—Absolute rubbish!

—Senator Walters can say, `Absolute rubbish', but that is about all she can ever say, even when she is saying something else. The other example is that exactly that arrangement happens right now for veterans in this country. There is an agreement to assist public patients and public hospitals in providing care for veterans around this country between the private hospitals and the specialist medicos who already know that it can be done but refuse to go on doing it in South Australia. In other States—I believe in New South Wales—it has been very successfully done to help reduce waiting times for pensioner patients' eye operations. It can be done. Every now and again it has been done, but the specialists in this country are refusing to cooperate.

PARA.TAB: This is an interesting point to make because it recognises two things. There is spare capacity in the private hospitals. They know that. They would like to make better use of their beds. They are more than honest. In the Select Committee that I chaired, that is what they came and told us—they have spare capacity, they want patients, but the private specialists will not allow public patients to use those beds. Why? Because it pegs specialists' salaries. That is what it is about. Those opposite should go out and say to Australians, `If you buy private insurance, what it gets you is not assurance, not comfort, not guarantees, but a licence for doctors to charge like wounded bulls'. If those opposite do not want to know about that, then they had better realise that wherever they go, I am coming after them and I am going to tell people.
