The Opposition is going to increase the AMA schedule of fees under Fightback by 25 to 30 per cent for each visit to the doctor—$25 to $31—and patients will get only a reduced rebate. What a good lot those opposite are. They are making it really tough for any individual to see the doctor. They have at least a $5 co-payment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you let them insure?

—They cannot insure; even Senator Herron should know that. They can only insure for the gap between 75 and 85 per cent. They will have to pay $316, according to the Opposition's figures, to do this—about $6 a week. They will get their 75 per cent reduced rebate for seeing the doctor. If they buy gap insurance, they will be able to get up to the 85 per cent, then they will have to pay $5 per head per time anyhow.

PARA.TAB: Also, under this Fightback package those opposite are moving all the schedule fees for a hospital visit to the AMA schedule. Both of these things will hurt and cost individuals who are sick. They will certainly hurt and cost the community of Australia in terms of pushing the price of health care right up—going the American way, where those figures are appalling now and will not be restrained by the Opposition. They will add to inflation. The Opposition only has the courage to introduce this policy now by sneaking it in by stealth under cover of the GST. When the GST impact is washed out, to the extent that it will wash out, the impact of inflation under the Fightback health package will still be there, still hurting Australians, still making their purchasing power less.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! Nonsense!

—It is in the Opposition's own document. Senator Patterson should not tell me `Rubbish' when 0.7 per cent inflation is the figure the Opposition has in its document. That will stay there, on and on, increasing the push for wage increases, increasing the price of goods and services, increasing the whole cost of health to this nation. It is an absolutely hopeless health policy.

PARA.TAB: But the point those opposite asked us to debate today is `that Australians don't need private health insurance'. That is what the Opposition's policy says. It is carrot and stick, if I listen to Senator Vanstone. Those opposite are saying, `We will encourage people who earn below $30,000 with a rebate that is graded. We will punish those who earn above $30,000 by a penalty that is only graded up to $50,000'. Those opposite are saying to the Australian people that they do not need health insurance.

To have the gall to come in here and move a motion that condemns their own policy I think takes the cake. But it would take an opposition to do it, an opposition that does not understand its own health policy, does not know that its own figures say that waiting lists are reduced, and does not want to acknowledge the inflationary impact and the cost to Australians—to individuals and to the nation as a whole. It is a hopeless policy, a pathetic policy and a pathetic example of the Opposition by this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am so glad that has come to an end. It is incredible to believe that the previous speaker once practised as a medical practitioner.
—She didn't practise.
—Oh, she did not actually practise; she just got through university. That is a relief because I cannot believe she could satisfy a literacy test.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not think my professional status really ought to occupy members of the Opposition much, but if they are going to use it, could they please get it right. Senator Walters is incorrect there. She is wrong and I would be happy if she would withdraw that.
—There is no point of order.

—We have heard a lot of noise and it has been a lot of fun, but it is the usual Labor scare tactics coming from Senator Crowley. It is a pity she cannot read. If she could read she would know that a lot of the stuff she has been giving us is inaccurate and the rest of it is a lot of hot air and no substance.

PARA.TAB: It is a bit like the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Senator Tate) at Question Time today. He was so cornered by the questions of the Opposition that he only wanted to lash out as well. He did not have much that he could say of substance to defend the Government's policy, and the reason is that the Government is so vulnerable on health policy. It is a total and utter failure; it is grasping at straws. At every election it tries to shuffle the deckchairs around on the Titanic; at every election it makes promises and soothing noises about health care; but the fact is that the health system is failing and it is coming into utter disrepute.

The only reason Medicare stands at all is that the Government is now rationing resources. Unfortunately, the people who suffer from rationing of resources are the poor—those on low incomes and the self-funded retirees. I am particularly thinking of the women in this community who are the low income earners. If you are a pensioner you may be okay, but God help the rest of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even the pensioners can't get in.

—Of course, because the pensioners have to fight with the rich to get their place in the hospital queue. Under this Government it is very interesting to see that we now have something like 20 per cent of low income earners who are in desperate financial difficulties, but are still finding the money somehow to pay for private health insurance because they are so worried of those hospital queues where they have to compete with people who may have an income of $100,000 and who choose not to pay for health insurance and who rely on the safety net.

PARA.TAB: Only 70 per cent of those on higher incomes in Australia are still paying for private health insurance. So it is some social equity policy that this Labor Government is presiding over, when it is the rich who are using the beds in the public hospitals and the poor who are having increasingly to buy private health insurance that they cannot afford simply to be sure that they will get a bed when they need one.

In Question Time today I asked a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services about the 832,000 older Australians who are so afraid of the queues for elective surgery—they fear that they may have a cataract, a hip replacement or prostate surgery problem in the future—that they pay for health insurance they cannot afford at the expense of other things they need simply to get the peace of mind of knowing that, if the need arises, they will not have to fight with the rich for a bed in a public hospital in Australia.

After 10 years of the Labor Government, we have these queues that will not go away. As I said, every election time the Government shuffles the money around trying to make it look as if it is getting rid of the queues and, in fact, it is just like shuffling the deckchairs.

Let us not forget that of those who are designated low income earners in Australia—and 3.5 million earn less than $20,700—nearly two million are women. I would have thought that Senator Crowley might have had some concern about Australian women on low incomes who cannot get access to decent health care.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't charge a levy, Senator.
—People earning under $20,700 are paying for a levy. Senator Crowley is leaving the chamber. Come July next year, all Australians will be paying an increased Medicare levy. God help them.

PARA.TAB: Self-funded retirees in this country get no help with their health insurance that they are struggling to pay, and they get no pharmaceutical benefits card from this Government. They will end up paying 1.4 per cent of their taxable income on a Medicare levy come July next year—safely after the election, we notice. The goodies are announced to come in prior to Mr Keating's next election—or his first election, because, let us face it, he has not been elected yet—while the nasties, such as the Medicare levy, come in afterwards. That is something for Australians to remember. People will be paying for this Government in many ways for many years to come.

It is interesting to recognise also that lately the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been trying to associate himself with the deep, meaningful and caring issues in this country, one of which is violence, particularly against women. I support him in any concern that he might express. The interesting thing is that this issue has a health aspect as well. The deliberately inflicted injuries that are caused in this country each year cost Australia a very great deal of money. In the national strategy on violence against women, it was estimated that, annually, there are about $286m worth of intentionally inflicted injuries identified in the hospital system. No wonder the Prime Minister is concerned about violence. He should be very concerned about it from a Budget point of view, quite apart from a humane point of view.

We are not too sure whether that figure is accurate, because a New South Wales Government document suggests that, as far as women right around the country are concerned, the figure may be closer to $40m. If that is doubled and a bit more is added, it still does not get anywhere near the Commonwealth's figures, but perhaps that is a quibble.

We must not forget that only today the Director of the Institute of Family Studies said on national radio that there is a direct correlation between increasing unemployment and increasing violence in Australian homes. We are getting figures on the cost of violence to our health system, but all we are getting from the Prime Minister is concern with no action whatsoever to deal with the underlying cause, which is the unemployment in our country. It is a national disgrace. The Prime Minister should certainly be concerned, but concern is not enough; we need action.

As I said before, health care is being rationed not only by the hospital queues but also by the restriction of pharmaceuticals and the failure of the Government to accept procedures for rebates. I have been particularly concerned about the question of densitometry, which is a test for osteoporosis. Mr Acting Deputy President, I draw to your attention that in December 1989 my colleague Senator Patterson asked Senator Reynolds, who was then a Minister, about densitometry and Medicare rebates. Senator Reynolds told the Senate that the matter was then under consideration. That was in December 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like them waiting on the hospital queues.
—That is exactly what it is. It is another form of rationing. That was in December 1989 when Senator Patterson asked the question.
—How long ago? 1989?

—December 1989. In March this year I asked Senator Tate, who represents the Minister for Health, when the Government was going to get on with making densitometry a Medicare rebatable item. His answer was:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government aims to develop a comprehensive strategy . . .
It is a strategy now. Everything is a strategy. It means that there does not have to be any action—just put it on paper. Senator Tate continued:
. . . to address not just diagnosis of osteoporosis but also prevention and effective treatment.

That is all very nice. This Government is simply looking into things. It is a looking glass government. It thinks that if it has put something on paper and said that it has an intention, the intention is as good as the action. Of course, we all know that it is not. It is but yet another example of the rationing of health resources.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tate told us that we had a great health system, yet women in this country cannot get a low risk—

TALK.START.PARA: —And Senator Lees.

—Yes, Senator Lees said it too. What did they say about women getting a low dose, low risk contraceptive pill? `You can't get that in this country', yet it has been around for 10 years in the rest of the world.

PARA.TAB: Older people who have become reliant on a particular drug can no longer get that drug. Retirees cannot get equality of treatment in the health system with pensioners. Rural women have trouble getting quality diagnostic services in country areas. Women and other low income earners are compelled to jostle in queues with the rich. Our elderly are waiting far too long in queues or, alternatively, they are struggling to pay health insurance because of their fear of those queues.

This Government has no policy. It has no policy to give everybody a choice of doctor and hospital, as we do in Fightback. It has no policy to enable our health system to be expanded, as we provide for in Fightback. It has no policy to end unemployment and reduce violence and health costs as a consequence. It has no policy to give a fair go to self-funded retirees in any area, especially health. It has no policy to give a fair go to those on low incomes, of whom nearly two-thirds are women. Therefore, any Australians who take any notice of the Prime Minister's advice that Australians do not need private health insurance need a psychiatrist because they jolly well need their heads read.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this matter of public importance on health insurance. As a consultant surgeon, I made a considerable sacrifice to come into this chamber. I made that sacrifice because I got angry at what I saw occurring with the health care of this wonderful nation of ours. I have become angrier since I have been here because I have come to realise there is abysmal ignorance not only on the part of the Government but also in the bureaucracy that advises it. The Government has now reached the stage of telling us that everything is all right, that we will have more of the same and that it will put a bit more money into the system.

PARA.TAB: I am angrier still because I have seen what has occurred in relation to the quality of health care in this country. I am angry on behalf of the people who are sitting in the gallery and the patients who are away from this abysmal whoopeeland of Canberra and the people who inhabit the centre of government here who are totally ignorant of the deterioration in the quality of health care that the average individual experiences.

Mr Acting Deputy President, if you get ill, what do you want? You want a doctor who listens to your concerns. You want a doctor who has the time to listen to your concerns. You want a doctor whom you can trust, who is competent and who will act in your best interests, irrespective of any financial inducements to do otherwise.

From its earliest origins, the profession of medicine has steadfastly held that physicians' responsibilities are to their patients and that that takes precedence over their own economic interests. Thus, the oath of Hippocrates enjoins physicians to serve only for the benefit of the sick. The oft recited prayer attributed to Moses Maimonides, a revered physician of the twelfth century, asks God not to allow thirst for profit or ambition for renown to interfere with the physician's practice of his profession.

In modern times this theme has figured prominently in many medical codes of ethics. For example, the international code of the World Medical Association says that a doctor must practise his or her profession uninfluenced by motives of profit. In 1957, in its newly revised principles of medical ethics, the American Medical Association declared that the principal objective of the medical profession is to render service to humanity. It went on to say that in the practice of medicine a physician should limit the source of his professional income to medical services actually rendered by him or her or under his or her supervision to his or her patients.

Since the introduction of Medicare, we have witnessed the constant denigration of doctors and doctor bashing by the Government. We heard it this afternoon. Minister Tate said that the Opposition's health policy would put more money into doctors' pockets. I wish it would so that their income might rise to the extent of what politicians get in their pockets. At present the average income of a general practitioner out in the suburbs is half that of a politician. Senator Tate has the gall to say that it might put some more money in their pockets.

The medical profession has been in constant conflict with the Government since the introduction of Medicare because it is representing the patients and standing between government and bureaucracy and its patients. There has been a low economic return for practising a professional ethic. The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners went cap in hand and negotiated with the Government to get a higher rebate for its patients. It came out with a bureaucratised system called vocational registration whereby a general practitioner gets $2.55 more per patient providing he or she goes through the system of vocational registration, as opposed to a doctor who does not go through that vocational system.

Where are we today, three years after that system was introduced? Has there been any improvement in the quality of health care of patients because of the introduction of the bureaucratised system of vocational registration? The answer is no.

TALK.START.PARA: —None at all.

—Yes, none at all. My colleague Senator Walters asked during the Estimates Committee what parameters the Health Department was using to determine how the quality of health care had improved. It could not answer. We know that there has been no improvement in the quality of health care. The implication is that there would be a better quality of health care if that were to be done.

PARA.TAB: Now the Government is talking about accreditation of general practice—in other words, bureaucrats determining whether or not a general practitioner is giving good service. If the quality of the advice that is given to the Minister at the moment or the actions of the Government are any indication, God help the doctors when they are overseen by the bureaucrats in relation to that. We are following the Canadian example. Because of the waiting lists that are occurring in Canada, the bureaucrats in Montreal are telling the cardiac surgeons which patients should go on the waiting lists to be operated on.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're joking!

—I am not joking. It is reported in the latest journal of the American Medical Association. That is the direction in which we are going. We will have Canberra bureaucrats determining which patients should move up the waiting lists. We heard Senator Tate this afternoon saying that the Government's policy was to give clinical precedence to the people who are on waiting lists. I tried to tell him that that has been occurring since Hippocrates' day. The doctor is the triage who determines the emergency need of treatment. Senator Tate tells us that the Government intends to improve the clinical performance of doctors. God help us when we reach the stage of the Canadian system!

PARA.TAB: Senator Tate talked about bulkbilling and said what a great thing it is. I am sorry that neither Senator Crowley nor Senator Zakharov is here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Zakharov is in the chair!

—My apologies, Madam Acting Deputy President. That happened while I was eruditely giving my exposition on Medicare. Madam Acting Deputy President, you of all people should be aware of the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs into radiological services in relation to Medicare benefits, set up by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services and the College of Radiologists because the Medicare system was getting ripped off because of bulkbilling. We got a fatuous response from the Minister in reply to our inquiry which is still being pursued. So much for bulkbilling! It allows the private entrepreneurs to enter into the system and rip it off. We have government inquiries looking into it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley made a big point of the two million people who are uninsured when she was talking about private insurance. She did not mention that Queensland already had a public hospital system which was available to everybody free of charge, nor did she mention that in that area doctors were treating many people for nothing out of the goodness of their hearts—

TALK.START.PARA: —All pensioners.

—All pensioners were treated similarly. I almost fell out of my chair with laughter when Senator Crowley talked about the $50m that was allocated to South Australia to shorten the waiting lists. Do honourable senators know what happened when that money was allocated to South Australia? The waiting lists went up. I have a graph in my hand demonstrating that.
—You're joking!

—Yes, the waiting lists for elective surgery in South Australia increased with the allocation of $50m. I suppose it increased for many reasons, but perhaps people realised that there was an opportunity to seek their much-awaited treatment and the queues may have become longer.

PARA.TAB: This afternoon Senator Tate talked about the $1.6 billion that will be spent in the next six years. That is the figure out of the One Nation statement. We know what happened to that One Nation statement. This amount will be spent by a country which will have a Federal Budget deficit of between $13 billion and $20 billion. We can add another $1.6 billion dollars, I presume, if the Government is in power—and it will not be in power. Another throw-away line out of the One Nation statement is `We'll print the $1.6 billion if we are in government'. That is where it will have to come from. There is no magic cake. We are already talking about Budget deficits of $17 billion next year. Where will that $1.6 billion come from? The printing presses? Senator Tate also said that $57m would be spent in the next two years. How much of that is being spent in Queensland? Three million dollars will be spent to plan where the money should be spent.

A survey has been carried out at the Royal Brisbane Hospital to find out how much money would need to be spent on the hospital to bring it up to modern standards. Honourable senators should have a guess as to how much is needed. One thousand million dollars is needed to bring the Royal Brisbane Hospital up to modern day standards. Senator Tate says that $57m will be spent, with $3m going to Queensland to try to plan how to spend it. I can tell the Government how to spend it. The State Government has already determined that.

We also heard about the possibility that there will be more money in doctors' pockets because of the Opposition's health policy. Senator Crowley and Senator Tate said that this will cause a surge in expenditure on health care. The total proportion of money spent on doctors' incomes of the total health care bill is 18 per cent. We could increase their income by 25 per cent and maybe bring them up to half of what a politician earns and we would increase the health expenditure by 4 1/2 per cent, or for that matter we could decrease it and bring it down because that is what the Government has been doing.

Since Medicare was introduced the rebates given by governments for procedures have progressively dropped behind the consumer price index time after time. There have been decreases. The poor old radiologists went along trusting the Government because they wanted to get rid of the shonky operators. The Government said, `We'll go along with that providing you take $20m a year off the refunds for radiology'. The poor old radiologists went along with the Government and look what happened to them.

Medicare is spinning out of control—and this is not recognised. That is what makes me so angry. We get this response from the Minister and from Senator Crowley, who practised perhaps 20 years ago. She ought to go back because she would do a lot more good out there than she would do here, hopefully.

TALK.START.PARA: —She would do a lot more damage.
—She may well do that too, Senator Knowles. I would not know. But I do get angry because there seems to be—
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. If Senator Knowles wants to interject, she should at least conform with Standing Orders and do it from her proper place.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—I did not hear an interjection made by Senator Knowles.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was just talking to Senator Patterson, if you want to know, stickybeak.
—Order! Senator Herron, please proceed.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I can hardly constrain my anger when we get responses from the Government such as `All in the garden is rosy; just go along with us; we are going to print a bit more money to throw at the system; do not worry about the quality of health care that is given; do not worry about the people who are on the waiting lists'. As I instanced yesterday, a man in Western Australia was told that he would have to wait five months for an urgent coronary procedure. This was documented in the Western Australian newspapers. But we are told, `Don't worry about that. We are going to go along as we have in the past'. Is it any wonder that I get angry when I hear this unbelievable inability to comprehend what is occurring out there in the real world?

PARA.TAB: What the Government is proposing to us is not a response. What it is saying is, `We will contain health care costs. We will ration services'. Yet, the Government pretends that this is not occurring. The Government is about cost constraint. It talks very lovingly about the way in which the percentage of money spent on health care has been kept at 8 per cent of gross domestic product for the last 16 years. It talks lovingly about this great achievement. Little does the Government realise that at the same time we have had a rapidly ageing population and an explosion in technology.

The Liberal Party and the coalition have a plan that allows doctors to negotiate with insurance companies in relation to fees. It gives freedom of choice to patients to go to the public hospital system or the private hospital system. It is an answer. We do have a plan which has flexibility for the future in respect of the ageing population and the cost of technology. I commend the matter of public importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the matter of public importance proposed by Senator Knowles. It is significant that the proposition originates from a senator from Western Australia. Madam Acting Deputy President, if you cast your mind back a relatively short while to late 1989, I am sure that you will recall the observations made by the then coalition health spokesman, Mr Peter Shack, who is also a member of the Liberal Party from Western Australia. Mr Shack conceded on the eve of the then Federal election that the coalition did not have much of a track record in the area of health policy. That remains true to this very day.
—We have now.

—I will be delighted if the Opposition makes health an issue at the next Federal election and in particular focuses on Medicare. The simple fact of recent Australian history is this: since the inception of Medicare in 1984 there have been three Federal elections fought either principally or in secondary terms on the issue of health care and the Medicare universal health insurance system. Those three elections were won convincingly by the Labor Party. If the Opposition is keen to go down that road again in 1993, the result will be another defeat.

PARA.TAB: There has been some recent electoral experience in the United States on this issue—and I will say a little more about the American health system later on in my observations. I am referring not only to the presidential election in which Governor Clinton and Senator Gore focused on American health policy but also to a casual vacancy earlier this year in the United States Senate for the State of Pennsylvania.

The Democratic candidate—a man by the name of Harris Wofford—campaigned primarily on health care. He focused upon some realities in the United States, including the fact that not only are there 40 million Americans without any form of health cover whatever, but also 60 million Americans are chronically underinsured. That means that in the overwhelming majority of cases people who fall sick or whose families encounter ill health are virtually assigned to a charity system.

Mr Wofford was elected to the United States Senate. For the first time in 30 years a Democrat had won a Senate seat for the State of Pennsylvania. A person by the name of James Carville took an interest in that campaign. He went on to become Governor Clinton's campaign director and was pivotal in Mr Clinton's election to the United States presidency.

The coalition does not have a good record in the area of health care. There is no question about that. That is not my judgment—that has been the judgment of the Australian people time and again. It is true at a Federal level. We heard from Senator Tate this afternoon that the objective is to oblige people to take out private health insurance.

It is also true at a State level. One only has to look at the New South Wales experience where the ideological cataracts have come into play with the rush to privatisation. It is true in Victoria with the obsession with downgrading conditions of working people, particularly nurses, in the health care system. As Senator Cook knows better than I, in recent times we have seen this happen under the Kennett Government. We have seen it at State level and we have seen it at a Federal level. The greatest risk to the health care of Australians is a coalition victory at a general election in 1993. This has been the case on the three preceding occasions.

Let us look at Medicare. After some eight years, Medicare is still supported by over 70 per cent of Australians. Seven in 10 Australians still rate the system either satisfactory, good, or very good. That is an impressive record by world standards when we are talking about health insurance, health care and health cover.

There is no risk contained in the observation of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), as Senator Knowles would have the Senate believe. The observation is true. But it is also true that the Government does not have ideological cataracts in place. The Government does not have a problem with people taking private health insurance. The Government does not have a difficulty in seeing private health insurance balance out the public commitment to health care.

Of course, Medicare is built principally upon the original Medibank system of the Whitlam Government. I recall vividly the promise in November 1975 of one Malcolm Fraser, as the unelected Prime Minister, when he said, `Medibank will be retained and strengthened under a Liberal government'. What was the result after the general election of December 1975? That promise, like so many others of Fraser's and the coalition's since, was torn up.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the following June.
—In the following June. There is no question but that from that time the coalition has lacked any effective health policy at all. In 1993 it will be equally true.

PARA.TAB: The Labor Government pursues policies that are inclusive rather than exclusive, not only in the area of health care but also in the constellation of issues upon which a general election will be fought. It is true that the economy, matters of tax policy—principally the GST—and matters of industrial relations will be the core issues on which the election will be fought early in the new year. But it is also true that there is a subset of very important questions surrounding those basic economic concerns. I refer to the areas of education, social security, the environment and health. So there is no doubt that we are focused on the different policy options. Senator Herron's American policy alternative can be tested and judged by the Australian people. Our policy alternative of continuing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would ask Senator Loosley to withdraw that statement, `Senator Herron's American policy'. The policy that the coalition is proposing has no relationship nor any similarity at all to an American policy.
—There is no point of order.
—From the Senate Hansard of 25 February 1992 I quote an exchange where Senator Collins asked rhetorically:

SPEECH.PARA: Have you seen the health system in the United States lately?
Senator Herron replied:
It is one of the best in the world for those who can afford it.

The problem is, of course, that 100 million Americans cannot afford their health care system. So there is no question that the coalition wants to take us down the road of the American health care policy. It is a policy dominated by the American Medical Association and their political action committee in Washington, DC. That is a statement of fact. One does not have to read Hedrick Smith or William Greider to see that for their own eyes. I have seen it when I have been in Washington; that is the alternative for the Australian people. In terms of the manner in which this Government works its health policy—

TALK.START.PARA: —Sounds like Crowley giving a speech.

—Senator Crowley is a fine GP. I have personal experience with just how well qualified Senator Crowley is to deal with an injury. I pay the same remark about Senator Herron for advice he has given me on occasions. There would be a number of other senators in this chamber who have cause to thank Senator Crowley for her advice on occasions.

PARA.TAB: The circumstances that exist in Australia at the moment are that, as a consequence of the 1992-93 Federal Budget, what the Government is about doing is building upon an already impressive record of achievement in the area of health. I have just a few points to make in the short period that remains to me. For example, the Government has implemented one of the most successful AIDS management programs in the world; there is no question about that on a comparative scale or an absolute scale.

The Government has fully embraced the recommendations of the Baume report into drug evaluation and is implementing the report's recommendations. That was a first class evaluation; the recommendations were first class and the response has been first class. The Government is paying particular attention to women's health programs through a $34m national women's health project, the $64m national program for the early detection of breast cancer, the $32m organised approach to preventing cervical cancer and the $6.5m alternative birthing services program. Those are facts. We are not talking here in terms of hyperbole about an alternative system that might or might not exist in the US—in the way the coalition wants us to believe it does. We are talking about the factual basis upon which Australian health care is built.

The Government has also established the national Aboriginal health strategy and is spending $232m on a range of public health measures in Aboriginal communities. That is entirely appropriate. Senator Jones will be aware that the need is obvious and evident, particularly in Queensland. The Government has committed $8.5m over three years to providing training and support to rural health workers, another very worthwhile initiative taken by this Government.

I take the point that Senator Lees made earlier about preventive health care. It was a very useful observation that she made and it is one with which in large measure I agree. But we ought to recognise also that the Government is working towards a healthier population through the $6.1m national health advancement program and the $40m national campaign against drug abuse. The Government has also launched a national food and nutrition policy and is developing expanded national health goals and targets. The Government has also committed $9m to developing and providing health services for at risk and homeless youth to help them take care of their own health.

There is no question about the programs being in place; there is no question about the programs being worthwhile. It is also of value to look at the community response to the 1992-93 Budget. In an endorsement from the Australian Council of Social Service, ACOSS stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Health initiatives in the Budget reflect a theme of strengthening Medicare as the centrepiece of our public health system.
There is a further endorsement by the Doctors Reform Society which states:
This Budget backs our popular and efficient public health system. The money will be well spent because Medicare is working well.
The Consumers Health Forum of Australia stated:
The substantial increase in hospital funding will be useful in addressing the access and equity issues which consumers have regarding public patient access to public hospitals.

These statements are not invented by the Government. These are not the kind of fabrications that we hear emerging from those opposite. These are simple statements of fact. The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners stated in relation to the 1992-93 Budget:
The Budget demonstrates that the long and intensive negotiation process undertaken by the RACGP, AMA and the Government has delivered the framework needed to revitalise general practice.

That is an observation made by people who are not normally associated with the policies of the Labor Government. It will be interesting to hear statements of denial from those opposite in contradiction of what the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners had to say about health care in the 1992-93 Budget.

PARA.TAB: Fightback cannot deliver any of its promises. It cannot, and it will not. First of all, the Australian electorate will not endorse it, and people opposite are now beginning to realise that. If the Opposition fights a general election on the basis of its policy, we will win it, just as we have won the four preceding general elections.

The consequences of Fightback would be to place public hospitals under increasing pressure by slicing at least $1.25 billion of government funding from their budgets. It would guarantee access to high quality health care for only the wealthy. Again, the American alternative comes into vogue. Fightback would abolish bulkbilling for all but four million pensioners and welfare recipients while encouraging doctors to charge whatever the market would bear. Again, this is the American health system in practice and offered to Australians.

Fightback would also make 1 1/4 million families up to $1,140 a year worse off, and up to a quarter of a million singles up to $510 a year worse off. There is no question about those circumstances. Fightback, when analysed, falls down just about everywhere.

We have seen the alternative in Victoria under Mr Kennett—the attack upon health workers, particularly upon the nursing profession—while the Federal Government ploughs an extra $1.6 billion over six years into the public health care system for its refurbishment and its reconstruction. The basis of health care in this country is universal health insurance—fairness, equity, inclusive policies—a balanced approach supported and endorsed by the Australian electorate in the three preceding general elections, and it will be again next year. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Loosley showed great support for his Government's success in health policy by spending most of his contribution talking about system in the United States. I know that Senator Loosley knows a lot about the US political system, but clearly from what he said he knows very little about the US health system. Obviously it was a lot easier for Senator Loosley to concentrate on the situation in the United States than the situation in Australia at the moment. The reality of what happened in the United States last month was that the American people voted overwhelmingly for change, and that is exactly what Australians will do here next year.

PARA.TAB: We are very happy to fight the election on health issues. Indeed, it was my honour and privilege to invite Senator Herron to come to the electorate of Canning currently held by George Gear—not for much longer, not even with the generous help of Senator Cook sending out pamphlets for him—to campaign on health in that electorate. We are happy to meet the honourable member for Canning, George Gear, anywhere—on any street, in any shopping centre—to debate health any day of the week because he will lose. We are prepared to fight the health issue at the election.

In the very short time that is available to me in this debate, let me stress the matter that is so important for people on hospital queues in Australia, particularly in Western Australia. All of the talk about whether $1m will be spent here, or $3m there or $50m somewhere else is totally irrelevant if a member of one's family is waiting for a bypass operation or some other important operation.

So many people in Australia now suffer because the health system ensures that people who can afford a crucial operation like a bypass will get it but that people like Mr Sanqvist of Coolbellup in Western Australia, who died last month because he was uninsured and had to wait for a bypass operation, cannot get that operation. All of this debate, all of this discussion, by politicians and bureaucrats who have nothing better to do, does not help poor Mrs Sanqvist, whose husband died a month ago on this Government's hospital waiting list. I ask the Government to come clean and tell Australia how many people have died on these hospital waiting lists. The Government stands condemned. (Time expired)
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! The time for the debate on the matter of public importance has expired.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Operation of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to part 7 of the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Act 1991, I present the report on the operation of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987 and seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, relating to petroleum resource rent tax and the document I have just tabled, to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to move to take note of the statement and document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, pursuant to Part 7 of the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Act 1991, I present the report on the operation of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987.

The introduction of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax (PRRT), and the enhancements to PRRT introduced in the August 1990 Budget, were integral components of what has become a decade of micro-economic reform undertaken by the Government in the petroleum industry.
Taking office in 1983, Labor found a petroleum industry subject to heavy Government control, and where uncertainty was undermining an industry already possessing a high degree of natural risk.
Moreover, in 1983, the outlook for Australia continuing to supply a high proportion of its oil needs from its own production was uncertain to poor.

In the early 1980s, the then Bureau of Mineral Resources indicated that the domestic production of crude oil, condensate and naturally occurring LPG from existing and planned new developments would increase to 1985, but then decline. In the absence of substantial new discoveries, the reports indicated that Australia's level of self sufficiency would fall to somewhere about 30 per cent by the mid 1990s. These reports emphasised that new discoveries and developments would be essential in the forecast period if Australia's level of self sufficiency was to be maintained at the level then prevailing, some 66 per cent.

The Government addressed this challenge through a comprehensive program of fundamental reforms, designed to encourage a vigorous, dynamic and competitive petroleum industry. The Government's program of reform has included
.deregulation of the oil and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) markets;
.implementation of an Offshore Exploration Strategy to facilitate the development of Australia's petroleum resources;
.fundamental change to secondary taxation; and
.the development of a National Gas Strategy.

As a consequence of the Government's policy reform agenda the gloomy picture foreseen by earlier forecasters has not emerged. The policy environment in which the industry operates has been changed beyond recognition; the industry has been re-vitalised.

Real oil prices today are lower than they were following the first oil shock in 1974. Despite this, Australia has fared well in terms of investment in exploration and development in our offshore waters. Self-sufficiency currently stands at around 85 per cent. Furthermore, we can be optimistic about future prospects.

ABARE, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, in its latest forecasts, noted that there was an excellent chance that oil production could be maintained at current levels or even increased, up to and beyond the year 2000.
The Government has overhauled the industry, and the results are there to be seen. The PRRT is an integral part of that reform program.

The requirement to report on the operation of the PRRT Act arose out of the legislation that implemented the 1990 Budget reforms to PRRT. These reforms extended the PRRT to Bass Strait. They also introduced company-wide deductibility for exploration expenditure in all PRRT areas.
The PRRT is an efficient tax. Unlike other secondary taxes, it is levied only on the net income of a profitable project. It does not adversely affect production in times of changing prices and costs.

Moreover, the PRRT provides a reasonable balance between providing the private sector with adequate returns for the risks it takes in investing in petroleum exploration and development, and providing the community with a fair return on the use of its non renewable resources.
The decision in 1990 to extend the PRRT to the Bass Strait project was the outcome of an intensive review brought forward by the Government in the light of industry concerns evident at the time.

The excise and royalty regime, which the PRRT replaced, had become too inflexible to adapt to changing market conditions. Frequent variations had become necessary with the result that the regime was complicated, and distorted investment and production decisions. The Bass Strait producers argued that they could invest a further $1 to $1.5 billion to extract an additional 200 to 300 million barrels of oil if the petroleum taxation arrangements were reformed.
The impact of the tax changes is clear—the Bass Strait project has been rejuvenated.

New developments currently under consideration include the construction of two new platforms at a combined cost of $650 million to extract a further 85 million barrels of oil. Two other fields, containing a combined total of 16 million barrels, are also expected to become viable under the PRRT.

Major infill drilling and workover programs on existing platforms are currently estimated to add 150 million barrels of economically recoverable oil. Exploration activity has also surged, with big increases in both seismic surveying and exploration wells.

It is clear that the fundamental impediments to further development identified by the Bass Strait producers have been removed. Furthermore, it is clear that the move to PRRT has avoided the situation where some production was stopped at low oil prices, because of the distorting tax regime.

The wider impact of the PRRT reforms also needs to be considered. Australia's offshore areas are only lightly explored. To ensure that the full potential of our resources is realised, we must create an environment that facilitates efficient exploration. The introduction in 1990 of company-wide deductibility for exploration expenditures against the PRRT removed a significant impediment to efficient offshore petroleum exploration.
The reforms mean that new exploration decisions are driven by prospectivity and technical factors rather than by distortions in the taxation arrangements.
While it is too soon to fully assess the impact of this amendment to the PRRT, the signs are all positive.

The Australian Petroleum Exploration Association has reported that wider deductibility appears to be diversifying exploration activity among its members. Increased holdings of offshore acreage by local and international companies indicate that funds that may once have gone to areas abroad have been redirected to Australia. And activity in offshore frontier areas has remained very encouraging.

Some industry submissions to the report raised concerns about the effect of the 1990 reforms on natural gas developments. One concern was the reduction in the premium on the carry forward rate for general project expenditure from 15 to 5 percentage points above the Commonwealth long term bond rate. It was argued that the reduced premium would impede the development of commercial gas projects.

The reduction in the premium reflected the significant benefits to industry that derived from the introduction of company-wide deductibility for exploration, and the relative risks of the different stages of a petroleum project.

The carry forward rates and the tax rate for the PRRT are part of a balanced and integrated package that includes wider deductibility for exploration expenditures. To preserve the community return, any adjustment in the carry forward rate for general expenditure would require a corresponding adjustment elsewhere.

The issue raised has been carefully examined and there is no evidence that the current provisions are impacting adversely on developments. Therefore, changes will not be made to the carry forward provisions.

I will now turn to the concerns raised in connection with the impact of the PRRT on gas prices. Some submissions argued that the PRRT will directly impact on Victorian gas and ethane users with a consequential adverse impact on industry and employment. Requests for change were made in submissions by both the producers and their gas and ethane customers.
The Bass Strait producers asked that gas and ethane revenues from the Bass Strait project be singled out for a specially reduced rate of taxation.

The Government is not prepared to accept this suggestion. The PRRT is a project tax, not a product tax. A change of this kind would reintroduce the type of taxation distortions on investment that characterised the former excise and royalty regime. The producers' request also ignores the windfall reduction in secondary tax that they received in the early years of the PRRT. It would undermine the legitimate community return from the project.
Users of natural gas and ethane asked the Government to regulate in some way the price of gas products from Bass Strait to ensure that the producers were not including a PRRT component.
In this regard, it is worth highlighting that a number of factors intervene to determine gas prices to the consumer.

First, I want to reiterate that the PRRT is a project tax, not a product tax and again note the windfall gain in reduced secondary taxation in the early years of the PRRT received by the Bass Strait producers.

Second, prices for gas and ethane are negotiated by the parties involved consistent with normal commercial practice. Whether PRRT falls under the definition of costs that can be passed on, is currently being decided by legal interpretation of the existing contracts and by arbitration.

Consistent with normal commercial practice, the Government would expect that once the legal standing of the contracts has been decided, negotiations will commence in regard to what amount, if any, of the PRRT will be passed on. These matters are best determined by the parties concerned and are currently being resolved by contractual arbitration and negotiation.

A further factor relevant to natural gas prices in Victoria is the Victorian Government's Public Authority Contribution charge on the Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria. In the 1990/91 financial year the Contribution amounted to $242 million. In 1991/92 it was $265 million.
The Victorian Government has the option of varying this charge which is three to four times the figures being discussed in relation to the PRRT.

One can observe that, in the absence of these charges, Victoria would have by far the cheapest gas in Australia, with an indicative city gate price for 1990-91 at Melbourne of 87 cents per gigajoule, compared with $2.40 per GJ in Adelaide, and $2.85 in Sydney, based on figures from the Australian Gas Association. One can also observe that the Kennett Government has shown no compunction in raising Victoria's domestic gas prices by some 10 per cent since assuming office.

In the light of these factors, the argument that the application of PRRT will be disruptive to end users of natural gas and ethane cannot be sustained. It is clear that there is no direct link between the PRRT and the price of natural gas and ethane to the consumer.

Nevertheless, the Government recognised that there were special circumstances affecting the prices for natural gas in Victoria. When the Government implemented the 1990 reforms to the PRRT it sought to minimise any potential transitional impacts on the Victorian natural gas market.

The Commonwealth therefore provided the Victorian Government with a special grant of $60 million for the first two years of the application of the PRRT in Bass Strait. Following the grant, the then Victorian Government stated in the Victorian Parliament in May 1991 that it would become its responsibility to ensure that the application of the PRRT was not passed on. I am not aware of any change in this position following the change of Government in Victoria.

It is clear that the PRRT provides the certainty and stability needed to attract long term investment in our petroleum exploration and production industry. The Government indicated at the time of the 1990 reforms that it would not be considering any further concessional changes to the arrangements for petroleum production taxation. Nevertheless in preparing this report I have given careful consideration to industry arguments.
I can advise that the Government will further examine the restrictions on the transferability of expenditures on disposal of a partial interest in a project.

We will consider issues such as whether a transfer of expenditures should be proportional to the interest in the project, whether each project category of expenditure should be transferred proportionally or whether it should be optional.

We will also examine further the legislative provisions affecting the end of year transfer of exploration expenditures under farm-in arrangements that are commenced part-way through the financial year.

In this context we need to ensure that the policy objectives of company-wide deductibility are in fact being met, while ensuring that the PRRT does not inhibit risk sharing and management that are normal aspects of oil industry activity.
I expect that an announcement on these matters will be made in the first quarter of 1993.
The Government gave an undertaking to the Senate in June 1991 to include in this report details of the time taken to administer applications for project production licences.

Since 1985, the Commonwealth has received 14 applications for a production licence of which 13 have been awarded. In considering applications the Government needs to examine a number of resource management issues. Details of the processing of applications are included in the report.

In conclusion, Australia has a regulatory and taxation regime for petroleum exploration and development that makes us internationally competitive. This has been recognised internationally by respected, authoritative sources.

The report I table today shows that the Government's package of reforms for the industry are working. New investments are going ahead in Bass Strait under the PRRT. The report also indicates that exploration activities in our offshore areas are no longer being affected by taxation that distinguishes between project and frontier areas.

When the Government assumed office in 1983, it found a hopelessly over regulated petroleum industry, contemplating a declining role in meeting Australia's vital crude oil needs. The Government set about systematically freeing up the energies of the industry, with bold reform policies.
Petroleum Resource Rent Tax is a key element of those reforms, providing a strong stimulus to the industry, while safeguarding the community's return for the use of its non-renewable resources.

The PRRT is an excellent example of micro-economic reform introduced by this Government in the area of energy, and indeed the economy as a whole. It demonstrates the Government commitment to policies that will ensure a strong, competitive petroleum industry into the 21st century.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement and document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report tabled in this chamber on behalf of the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, on the operation of the petroleum resource rent tax will be eagerly read by the major gas producers and consumers in my home State of Victoria.
—They are taking off excise.

—I thank Senator Walters for that comment. I shall return to that very relevant issue in the course of my remarks. This report which the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, has tabled and the accompanying statement are the result of the coalition's concerns about the impact of the resource rent tax, particularly on Victorian gas and ethane producers and users. Evidence before the Senate inquiry on the legislation, which was conducted in May and June 1991, indicated to those of us on the Senate Standing Committee that the Minister's assessment and that of his Department on the impact of this legislation was hotly contested by those who produced and consumed gas and ethane.

PARA.TAB: I suggest to the Minister that this report will not lay to rest the significant criticisms that have been made regarding the impact of the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Act of 1991. The shadow Minister for resources and energy, Mr Tim Fischer, in the other place, has given the coalition's response to this report, but I would like to add some comments of my own. First, I want to make two general comments. I have expressed concern in this chamber on a number of occasions regarding how the Federal Government's actions have damaged Victoria. Madam Acting Deputy President, I know that you, as a senator from Victoria, will also share the concerns that I have about this matter.

For example, there is no doubt that the politically driven mergers of Qantas and Australian Airlines, and Telecom and OTC certainly could have a serious effect on Victoria, where Australian Airlines and Telecom were once headquartered. The Defence Force restructuring, announced by Senator Ray, as I have said elsewhere, has also had a major adverse effect on Victoria. Naturally, I do think that defence policy must take account of wider issues. Nonetheless, we have to recognise that the impact of those decisions which were taken by Senator Ray and the Government have been particularly harmful to Victoria and, in particular, to employment in Victoria.

The Keating-driven merger of the State Bank with the Commonwealth Bank will also have the effect of further major job losses in Victoria. Madam Acting Deputy President, you will be aware that Minister Griffiths appears from time to time in the press suggesting how particular actions that he has taken, given his various responsibilities, have benefited his home State. I suggest to you that moving the headquarters of CSIRO to Melbourne, welcome as it is, hardly compensates for the loss of Australian Airlines and the likely consequences flowing from the loss of the split headquarters which exist now of AOTC. The Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, is now in the chamber. He will be aware of the concerns which I have expressed in that area. One only has to read the recent submissions made to the Minister's Department, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, on the resources rent tax to get the feeling that Victoria continues to strike out as far as this Government is concerned.

The second general point I wish to make is that the Minister refers to the resource rent tax as `an excellent example of micro-economic reform'. The reality is that this Keating Government and, before it, the Hawke Government wimped out on most areas of micro-economic reform and, in particular, taxation reform. If the Government were truly concerned about encouraging industry in Victoria and elsewhere in Australia, it would support and, indeed, initiate the removal of job destroying taxes such as the payroll tax and the fuel excise tax. Madam Acting Deputy President, you will recall, as a member of the Labor Party, that Mr Keating himself said some years ago that the removal of the payroll tax would lead to an additional 200,000 jobs around Australia.

The Government, if it were truly concerned about reforming the taxation area, would listen to the concerns of industry and junk the wholesale sales tax mess. But of course, on the big issues of micro-economic reform, the Government inevitably shows a remarkable lack of concern for Australia's real national interests and tends to highlight what it sees as the narrow, short term interests of its own Party, the Labor Party. The Minister in the tabling statement and in the report concedes that insufficient time has elapsed to be completely definitive about the impact of the resources rent tax on the petroleum exploration and production industry. Surprisingly, he then goes on to argue that early indications are that the RRT is meeting its objectives. He further advises in the tabling statement that the Government will give further consideration to some changes in relation to associated taxation aspects of the resources rent tax.

Happily, I believe time is running out for this Government and for this Minister. The coalition believes that the problems which have been highlighted in relation to Victoria remain, despite the Minister's whitewash. The problems have been highlighted in the many submissions in relation to pricing, market distortions and investor confidence which have flowed from the imposition of the resources rent tax without proper consultation with people in the industry. The Kennett Government in Victoria also has concerns, naturally, about the effect of the resources rent tax in relation to the private sector cogeneration industry and its impediment to interstate trade.

The industry itself has highlighted a number of problems relating to the resources rent tax. First, it argues that it is a barrier to interstate trade in gas; second, that it will lead to higher gas prices in Victoria; third, that there will be less incentive to explore and develop gas, and fourth, it warns that some gas reserves will be left in the ground.

I believe that none of these issues has been adequately addressed in the report tabled today. The Minister has shown that he will not listen to industry. He may like to re-read—or perhaps read for the first time—the submission that was lodged by the former Labor Government in Victoria. In regard to the competitiveness of major Victorian gas users, the former Victorian Government argued in its submission:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst many factors contribute towards private sector investment decisions, a number of proposals have been deferred indefinitely and others face uncertainty as a major consequence of the potential impact of RRT on Victoria's national and international competitiveness. This applies not only to the general manufacturing sector but also to the petrochemical industry which, as a major consumer of ethane as well as natural gas, will be placed in an untenable national and (notably) international competitive position.
These substantial difficulties will not be resolved until the immediate threat of RRT pass-on under existing contracts is overcome—
and, as the Minister at the table knows, that is a very big issue in Victoria which is causing major concern amongst the gas producers—
. . . but more particularly, not until the longer term threat of the now higher tax regime on gas is eliminated.

It is economically dispiriting for Victorian manufacturing industry to realise that a number of its international competitors are purchasing natural gas from the North West Shelf project, where a significantly lower tax regime is applied compared to that for Bass Strait.

Further harm will be done to Victorian industry as a consequence of its interstate competitors acquiring gas supplies from onshore petroleum projects, where significantly lower tax regimes also apply.

While perhaps one would not agree with every word put in that submission by the former Victorian Government, one would have to say that it highlighted major concerns which are certainly felt in our home State, Madam Acting Deputy President.

PARA.TAB: In order to illustrate the consequences of this legislation for investment and employment in Victoria, let me cite a number of specifics which the Minister might care to investigate. The Pratt group planned to invest in co-generation facilities for its paper recycling plant at Coolaroo. But a significant factor affecting the viability was the additional RRT payable on gas. However, similar plants operate in New South Wales, and Victoria is missing out on investment in this relatively new, environmentally friendly technology. I think that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, will be concerned to learn that.

Another case that has been brought to my attention relates to the Geelong based cement factory. As you know, Madam Acting Deputy President, Geelong is an area in Victoria which is particularly depressed and which suffered greatly as a result of a number of disasters which afflicted the former Government in Victoria. Pioneer holds a 50 per cent share in this factory, which is a major Victorian gas user. Gas is cheaper in New South Wales, South Australia and Japan, and this means that the cement produced in, say,

SPEECH.PARA: South Australia can be produced at a lower marginal cost than it can in Victoria. The cost of producing cement at the Victorian plant is already four times that of the same company's Kandos plant in New South Wales, which uses brown coal, a less environmentally friendly fuel.

PARA.TAB: I would like to have a number of further comments recorded in this chamber. The report fails to distinguish between two very different products of the industry—oil and gas. The report focused largely on oil and often missed the point about the needs and concerns of the gas industry. I believe the report also contains a logical fallacy. It wrongly links the proposed Bass Strait development with the recent introduction of the RRT. In reality, other options were available that would not have had the severe negative consequences for Victorian gas and ethane.

I believe that the report is largely a whitewash. Very worryingly, it ignores the big impact that the application of the RRT to gas users can have on the future of Victorian industry. One of the big issues which appeared before the Committee related to the compensation arrangements which the Government decided to make to compensate Victorian gas users and producers for any possible flow-on effects in order to help moderate those effects. Sixty million dollars was provided to the Victorian Government for this compensation package. Senator Loosley will be interested to know that that money was paid into Consolidated Revenue—paid to the Kirner Government. None of it, as far as I am aware, has been paid out as compensation. In fact, it has been pointed out that that may well have to wait until a number of court cases are decided.

Of course, as honourable senators know, that Victorian Government, as a result of the mismanagement of the Cain and Kirner years, was running a very substantial deficit. I suggest that the $60m has been spent. Naturally the liability involved will be incorporated in the Forward Estimates. Presumably, when the time comes, further money will have to be raised. In any case, I look forward to receiving any comments that the Victorian Government, or the relevant Minister, Mr Jim Plowman, may have on that issue.

What we saw in Victoria was a vast black hole which swallowed money up from all areas. Sixty million dollars was paid into the Consolidated Revenue account and I believe that it has, in a practical sense as distinct from a technical and legal sense, already been used.

Many of us were waiting anxiously for the report that the Minister was required to produce in assessing the impact of the legislation. Certainly given the time period involved one accepts that not all definitive judgments can be made. But it is clear from the very extensive submissions that have been provided to the Department—which I have had a brief chance to skim through—that there are very widespread concerns in Victoria about aspects of the resource rent tax. As a person who is particularly concerned to make sure that Victoria gets back on its feet and that we recover rapidly from the disaster of the Cain and Kirner years, I say that I would have liked to see the Minister more effectively addressing in this report the concerns which many producers and consumers of natural gas and ethane have brought to his attention.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT DOCUMENTSAustralia and the World Bank

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Operations of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: These two documents give the Senate some indication of the relationship between Australia and the World Bank and the operations of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank over very recent times. Membership of the IMF is open to every country that conducts its own foreign policy and will adhere to the fund's charter. In that respect, Australia joined the IMF in August 1947.

PARA.TAB: Since joining the Fund, Australia has been the largest quota holder in its IMF constituency. That constituency currently includes the Republic of Korea, New Zealand, the Philippines, Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu, Western Samoa, the Solomons, the Seychelles and Kiribati. Australia nominates the executive director who can speak within the executive board on behalf of each constituent separately.

It is of interest to note that Mongolia joined the IMF on 14 February 1991 and has asked our constituency's executive director to take charge of its interests in the period leading up to the next election to be held in September of 1992 when it is anticipated that Mongolia will formally join our IMF constituency. Our relationship with the International Monetary Fund is reflected in the consultations which occurred in 1988 and again last year by way of review of Australian trade and industry policies, with a particular focus on Australia's position on the various Uruguay Round issues. It is now a matter of history that Australian leadership, through the Cairns Group of countries and our relentless efforts to liberalise world trade, will almost certainly meet with success in a conclusion to the Uruguay Round in 1993, following the breakthrough in GATT between the United States and the Europeans.

It is also of consequence to note that in September last year Australia formally moved from the European Department to the South East Asian and Pacific Department of the International Monetary Fund. Australia's trade and economic priorities lie increasingly with the Asia-Pacific region and Australia should and, in my view, will benefit from a greater understanding in the IMF of Australian economic links with the Asia-Pacific region.

It is fair to say that the IMF has become an influential agent for promoting and cementing international economic change. However, it should also be stressed that it must be of increasing importance to the International Monetary Fund that it take note in its deliberations of the social agenda which is involved in making evaluations; that it take note of the different cultural values in each country within our constituency and beyond and display a sensitivity to those values, to the political climate and to the history of the member nations involved. That has not always been the case, though in our region the performance, for example, has been much better than it was a decade or so ago in Latin America.

There is no question that a significant feature of IMF operations is the consultation process which accompanies its lending activities. It is of real consequence to make certain that negotiations between the Fund and the recipient country are on the basis of common objectives and equal responsibilities in the relationship. There is no doubt that, for example, in the view of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, IMF programs are generally effective in encouraging countries to adopt policies which will maximise potential for long term, stable economic growth. We really need to see a great deal more of that in the future, especially in our region.

In terms of the World Bank, Australia has given a high priority to active policy discussion between donor and recipient, both bilaterally and multilaterally, through international forums. Through its projects and programs, the World Bank has demonstrated an increasing emphasis on policy dialogue and conditionality. The Bank has made a contribution to global growth and development. That contribution has been positive.

In performing its economic policy leverage function, the Bank has been able to persuade borrowing countries to adopt economic policies which will improve prospects for growth. In conclusion, I stress the need for sensitivity and discretion and the need to take into consideration the cultural values, the political histories, the traditions, the social agendas of the individual recipient countries, and the need for equal rights and equal and common purpose between donor countries and recipients.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Office of Film and Literature Classification and Film and Literature Board of Review

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many issues which this report raises which have become of more importance and immediate concern to parents throughout Australia. Indeed, the recent furore over the screening of violent films and material on television before 8.30 at night, which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) raised as an issue only last month, has been of concern to many in the community for a number of years. This report says on page 21:

The primary responsibility for protecting children and young people from harmful material rests with their parents or guardians. In discharging that responsibility they have a right to expect assistance from the State, especially as films and videos are so readily accessible. They must be confident that material to which children may be exposed has been carefully examined and appropriately classified.
On page 20 the report notes:

Our right to see what we please cannot be allowed to infringe the rights of others. Children and young people, in particular, must be adequately protected from material likely to harm or disturb them, and people who may be offended by certain material have a right to expect that it will not be thrust upon them against their will or without warning.
The report goes on to say:
Equally, the community has the right to ban material considered likely to endanger public health or safety, or to offend accepted standards of public decency.

The problem which has developed over recent years in Australian society is that these accepted standards of public decency seem to be constantly changing—not as a result of growing agitation by the parents and families of middle Australia, nor as a result of a general referendum of middle Australia. They are changing because of the growing pressure provided by the ever-increasing number of special interest lobby groups—groups which have money to make and spend in the promotion of the burgeoning pornography, sex and erotica industries. This is in contrast to parents who are struggling to provide their families with a decent standard of living and decent expectations.

PARA.TAB: Only last month we heard of the organisation of the purveyors of X-rated and R-rated videos, films and printed matter, together with the sex industry workers, gay and lesbian lobby groups rallying in Sydney so that they could form their own lobby group. I ask honourable senators: where is the lobby group for families?What will happen is that governments and the bureaucracies will increasingly give in to these lobby groups as they have the money and the time to be vocal whereas families are just forgotten. As a mother and grandmother, I feel that any issues which affect women and families rate the highest priority. The growth of these industries should be of the highest concern to all women and families throughout Australia.

This Government has made a sham of looking after families. It gives in to yet another minority—the pedlars of pornography, an industry which makes money out of exploiting women and which caters to the more perverse elements in society. Honourable senators opposite talk about civil liberties, the rights of people to do what they wish and to pursue a normal, successful life to the best of their ability. I ask honourable senators: what could be a greater infringement on the rights of the majority of average Australians than the sort of dangerous material we are talking about today? What could be more harmful to the pursuit of those aims?

Decent families, church groups, women's groups and many other organisations have been crying out for firm action to be taken to stamp out this smut. Indeed, it was only last month that I made a speech on the adjournment debate on this very issue. The speech was the result of representations made to me as a matter of urgency by a number of parents in the Toowoomba region. They were concerned about the increasing use of pornography in our electronic media. I will quote a small part from the letter they wrote, which is a direct plea to politicians to act now to stop what those parents see as the decay of moral standards in our society. The letter reads:
We are writing to express our disgust, horror and sadness at the endorsement of promiscuity that continues to decay our society.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on:

PARA.TAB: The electronic media has an enormous power over the public, especially the young and impressionable. The escalating problem of unemployment of our young people leaves them very little self respect and decency. In these days when there is a lot of unemployment perhaps young people might have too much time to sit at home and watch a lot of television.

SPEECH.PARA: It continues:

PARA.TAB: When they see that the Australian media paint a picture of an immoral society it is seen by our young to be the accepted standard—
