SPEECH.PARA: and I regret that very much indeed. Time does not permit me to say as much as I would like to, but I am pleased to be able to put these remarks on record.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The mission of NBEET is to promote discussion of the issues and provide independent advice to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) on national policy matters on employment, education, training and research. It is the area of training which I particularly wish to address today and the role of the Employment and Skills Formation Council within the NBEET structure.

PARA.TAB: This Labor Government has been in power now for 10 years. In that time it has completely neglected the training sector. While teenage participation in schooling and higher education has increased by 10 per cent over the decade as a result of a number of factors to 67 per cent, participation in TAFE since 1983 has stayed constant at 11 per cent. The Employment and Skills Formation Council has brought down a report, commonly known as the Carmichael report, detailing these deficiencies in the current system and making far-reaching recommendations towards improving vocational training in education in Australia.

Unfortunately, this Government sees a solution to the problems of training in setting up yet another bureaucracy—the Australian National Training Authority, ANTA. This begs the question: why has the Government so little confidence in its current advisory structure; why is ANTA not under the purview of NBEET's Skill Formation Council? While Labor has undertaken some belated initiatives within the last year, over its 10 years of government it has never adopted a comprehensive strategy to raise the level of skills in Australia to international levels.

Successful countries in this field, such as Germany and Japan, have long surpassed Australia in the provision of training skills for their young people. In a culture which rewards and admires achievement in the attainment of excellence, such as that in Germany, there is clear well resourced, well funded and industry recognised training schemes and a great diversity of training opportunities. In Germany almost 80 per cent of teenagers, virtually all those not attending universities or colleges, are undertaking some form of training course. This does not compare particularly favourably with Australia which has a national average of only 21 per cent of young Australians receiving vocational education. The OECD average is 50 per cent. Clearly, the plight of this neglected sector of education has in fact deteriorated under this Labor Government.

Fortunately, however, the coalition recognises the importance of this sector. We believe it is essential to move towards national reporting of standards of attainment based on assessment of key competencies required for success in the workplace. Vocational training should be provided in a wide variety of ways appropriate to the range of needs of those seeking training, including the needs of those at different stages of their career. As far as possible, funding should be directed to the people rather than the courses and the institutions. Under the coalition's Fightback policy, over the next three years we will spend $945m on the expansion of vocational education, thus providing over 225,000 new training places. This funding commitment is an increase of $225m over the Keating commitment for TAFE.

Of course, the present Government has failed in what it has done in this area and has now moved to try to be seen as doing something by setting up yet another bureaucracy called ANTA. The Government, in the way it is establishing the Australian National Training Authority, looks like it is going to repeat the mistakes that it made with the universities when it established the national unified system and insisted at that stage on intrusive measures, such as course profiles. We note that with the setting up of ANTA it is going to do exactly the same thing again. It is time for this Government to act effectively and reverse these centralist policies so that Australian youth do not continue to fall further behind in the international race.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The report on research funding programs for 1992 comes up every year, and each year the Australian Research Council makes available grants for scientific and academic research which is conducted by our tertiary institutions. Such research often plays a very valuable role in developing our understanding of humanitarian issues or in providing answers to life threatening diseases. I believe that it is fair to say that over the years Australian institutions have held their heads high internationally with the standard of their research.

PARA.TAB: This year the Australian Research Council has allocated $77m in total. Whilst I have no concern whatsoever with the value of the research, I must take this occasion today to question the priorities which the Australian Research Council places on its funding allocations. I have on previous occasions in this place, as Senator Sowada would know, pointed out grants made by the Research Council which I believe would provide little benefit to the people of Australia. Reading through the grants allocated by the Council this year, I am once again forced to draw the conclusion that a great deal of money given by the Council for research could have been better spent.

We should remember that we are in a nation where one million people are out of work, where hundreds of Australians tonight will be forced to sleep on the streets, and where many young children tonight will go to bed without a meal. In that situation I find it totally unacceptable for the Australian Research Council to allocate $20,000 for a study of the history of tourism in fascist Italy. I find it similarly amazing that the Council should see fit to allocate $31,000 for an analysis of the visual representations of witchcraft in early modern Europe. The Council also allocated $35,000 for a study of the rise and fall of German communism. No doubt someone will be interested in that, but I have great difficulty in resolving how our nation's pending school leavers, who will find themselves looking for a job, will derive any benefit whatsoever from a $16,500 study on the structure of the British Raj in India from 1937 to 1947.

The list of grants which surely are open to question is endless but includes a study, for instance, of nineteenth century French romantic song, an analysis of family, work and class in middle class Malaysia, and it is probably the third study that I can remember relating to the eighteenth century Irish Parliament. If we want to throw in another bizarre area of research, we are to spend $15,500 of taxpayers' money on a study of the culture of the Stawell Gift. I suppose next year we will see a study into the Adelaide Grand Prix and perhaps there might even be a study of the culture of the Melbourne Cup. But we are talking about hundreds of thousands of taxpayers' dollars—indeed, millions of dollars—which should be put to better use in benefiting all Australians.

I note with interest that in an Australian article on 16 September, the Chairman of the Council, Professor Max Brennan, indicated that some of the Council's critical fellowship programs were likely to close if there were not more Government support. I would argue very strongly that Professor Brennan should consider exactly where the Council is placing its funds, because money which is simply being wasted on schemes such as I have outlined here today could be diverted to areas of the fellowship program which will be of real benefit to all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the annual report of the Australian Research Council, which I have to say is one of my favourite reports in that it displays to the Parliament and the Australian public the tremendous variety of research currently in progress in universities around Australia. It never ceases to amaze me what that variety consists of and Senator Calvert has expressed to the Parliament this afternoon some of the very specific research projects that have been funded in this report.

PARA.TAB: However, there are a number of points that need to be made about the Australian Research Council and I will take this opportunity to do so. The 1992 research budget has increased to $255.5m from $230.9m in 1991. This certainly represents an increase and we commend the Government for it, but closer examination of the report will clearly illustrate the enormous and unprecedented stress upon our research institutions.

I put on the record here that nowhere in this report was I able to find any comparison of research grants from last year to this year, which certainly hindered my appreciation of the work done by the ARC and the nature and scope of research work in Australia at the moment. A quick comparison of the grants from 1991 to 1992 showed that there has been an unprecedented increase in the amount of money and the demands placed upon the Australian Research Council. For example, applications and requests for grants in the social sciences jumped from 383 applications, both new and continuing, in 1991, to 462 new and continuing applications for funding, which represents more than a 20 per cent increase in the applications for grants in social sciences alone. In humanities the number went up from 273 in 1991 to 306.

One can go through the report fairly quickly and see that there really has been tremendous stress placed on the available funds. This stress has been generated by the fact that many of the newer universities created under the Dawkins amalgamations feel the need to engage in very broad and wide-ranging research projects in order for them to somehow be seen as a legitimate university engaging not only in undergraduate teaching, but a broad postgraduate program as well.

This increased demand on the total pool of funds for research has placed enormous stress especially on the older research institutions such as Melbourne University, Sydney University and those which have a very large research base. It has meant that everybody has been squeezed for funding and enormous stress has been placed on those institutions.

However, it is always exciting to examine the broad range of research. I notice that archaeological research has received a handsome slice of money. I would point out that Australia is very active in the eastern Mediterranean in many countries which have ancient remains. For example, the remains of Jebel Khalid in Syria have been the subject of research by the ANU for some years and that research has received a very nice grant of $65,000. I commend Professor Graeme Clarke to the Senate who, of course, is an internationally renowned scholar and whom we are very fortunate to have here in Australia at this time.

The work done by Monash University at Ismant El-Gharab in the Dakhleh Oasis is again very important work on a very little understood site in what is a very poorly understood period of Egyptian history. I recall visiting that site in 1991 to escape the Gulf war in the Middle East and being absolutely astonished by the size of the remains existing in the desert oasis of El Dakhleh, and actually witnessing the inscribed papyrus being excavated by the archaeologists who were literally finding papyrus in the sand by the bagful. Believe me, that is a very unusual, rare and special experience for anyone who has worked in the field.

I would like to suggest to Senator Calvert that, whilst many research grants might seem somewhat obscure, they are given by the Australian Research Council for a very good purpose. These grants are scrutinised very carefully and it is certainly not for this Parliament to call into question the quality of the work being done by Australian scholars. I am sure that the Research Council has given all these grants the very best scrutiny and the scholars who have received them well deserve them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances on the scrutiny by the Committee of Public Service determinations 1992/27 and 1992/46.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report deals with scrutiny in action by the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in respect of two Public Service determinations which prejudice the rights of Commonwealth employees. In this context I note that the year 1992 was the bicentenary of the publication of Tom Paine's The Rights of Man, one of the most important and influential works on personal liberties, and a work which incidentally influenced me greatly in my youth. Therefore, it is particularly appropriate that the Committee has taken the action that it has and upon which I now report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: These determinations made by a departmental official removed an injustice for one category of employees, but entrenched a similar injustice for some 30,000 other former employees. The position of these employees was described by the Merit Protection and Review Agency as anomalous, unfair and inequitable. In the course of its inquiries the Committee found that the administering authorities had known about this unjust situation for almost 20 years. Eventually the Committee accepted an undertaking to provide express one-line Budget appropriations totalling $4.1m to recompense the disadvantaged employees.

A notable feature of the Committee's scrutiny was the support it received from the three Ministers who became involved. The Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, immediately instructed his Department to cooperate fully with the Committee to solve the problem. Later, I am pleased to advise the Senate, both the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, agreed within a short timeframe to include appropriations in the 1992 Budget—the Prime Minister expressly mentioning the Committee's deliberations. This is really routine in terms of the kind of cooperation which the Committee receives from Ministers. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1992TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 6) 1992MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992INCOME TAX (DIVIDENDS AND INTEREST WITHHOLDING TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second major cognate debate on taxation matters today. It is great to see the Senate getting on with business. The Bills in this package cover very diverse areas such as the Medicare levy, income tax and dividend and interest withholding tax.

PARA.TAB: I deal first with the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2). This is quite an historic piece of legislation. It is one of the first deliberate moves by this Labor Government in years to consciously and proudly increase a progressive income tax measure so as to finance the provision of better public health facilities and service.

I think it is interesting to take an international perspective or at least to take a comparison, because we have the incredible situation of President-elect Clinton winning an historic victory on a platform of introducing a national health system in the United States. Most people would be aware that in the United States if one does not have health insurance, one does not get health care. It is a classic market model which accepts that tens of millions of people will be totally disadvantaged.

It is unclear to me why the Opposition wishes to go back to the private insurance model which will simultaneously increase the total cost of national health care and—perhaps this is the reason—increase the profits of the private health insurers. It will increase the income of specialists and others with scarce skills, which have been provided by the public education system, and ensure that many people will become uninsured and hence will be vulnerable to financial ruin if a tragedy befalls their family.

We have a huge problem in Australia with the efficient allocation of resources in our economy. We have a permanent shortage of development capital which continues to force many entrepreneurs to give up or to go overseas with their inventions. This shortage of capital must be exacerbated if we divert more of our total resources into health costs. We spend about 8 per cent of GDP on health costs. The United States, with its Fightback style health system, spends over 11 per cent.

So why is the Opposition proposing these kinds of changes? The United States has one of the highest infant mortality rates in the West and it has lower life expectancy than in Australia. The simple fact is that a national health system is more successful, more economically efficient and much more equitable. Health is a special case; I think it needs to be recognised as such. The Democrats support this measure as, I believe, so do most Australians.

There are also two omnibus taxation Bills, Nos 5 and 6 for the year, which cover the usual diverse range of matters. Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1992 is not contentious. The legislation proposes, among other things, to simplify the administration of the prescribed payments system which will allow many businesses to go on to an annual system of reporting rather than the current monthly system. The legislation also proposes to provide a tax exemption to the new family payment advance. From 1 January, recipients will be able to elect to receive half of their family payments in a lump sum in advance. These payments are exempt from tax when received periodically and this amendment will ensure that lump sums are also exempt.

I think the Government should be commended on this initiative. It is good social policy to allow families the flexibility of deciding whether they need all of their entitlements on a regular basis, or whether they might like to effectively commute some of their future benefits into a larger amount to enable them to afford important purchases such as school uniforms, to enable them to pay overdue bills, to top up the family holiday or to buy Christmas or birthday presents. It is fair, but it is also politically astute, especially its timing, and I think it will prove to be popular in the community.

The major revenue measure, possibly the most controversial, especially if one takes the view of Senator Campbell, concerns the proposal to treat limited partnerships as companies for taxation purposes. Currently, partnerships and limited partnerships are not taxed as separate entities, but the individual partners are taxed on their particular proportionate entitlement. This also means that partners can claim a proportionate share of a partnership loss. On the other hand, companies and certain public unit trusts are separately taxed and shareholders cannot claim a proportion of corporate losses. Instead, these are available to be carried forward to be offset against future profits.

Limited partnerships are different from ordinary partnerships in that they are created under specific State legislation. Most partners can limit their liability in much the same way as shareholders, but still obtain the benefits of an entitlement to tax losses. Hence, they are a perfect tax planning vehicle. This legislation proposes to tax new partnerships as companies from the Budget date and for those existing at that time from 1995-96.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a major decision.

—It is a major decision, as I acknowledge, and the Finance and Public Administration Committee will examine it. Whilst it will probably be argued that this is an anti-avoidance provision, there are significant questions to be answered as apparently this is a commonly-used vehicle for major private infrastructure projects where there are significant initial losses before the projects become profitable. I acknowledge that private infrastructure projects are assuming greater importance in an age of smaller government.

PARA.TAB: The coalition initially opposed the decision, but I understand from media reports that shadow Cabinet will not oppose this because these are Budget Bills which Mr Keating has helped rocket to some sort of prominence in public understanding. There are many and varied options. For example, we might be able to support the proposal, but put in a mechanism whereby the Federal Government could declare that some limited partnerships were exempt from the tax. This would mean, for example, that the Federal Government could assist a particular project like a harbour tunnel, but this would be at the discretion of the Federal Treasurer, who would presumably weigh up the tax cost against the other benefits of the particular development. Indeed, this could be an important industry policy instrument.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dinner, I started to make some remarks on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill, which we are discussing this evening. This Bill also contains some important taxation proposals. The major provision concerns the allowance of some environmental expenditure as an immediate tax deduction and the allowance of depreciation on other environmental capital expenditure which is not currently allowed. This is a major sustainable development initiative. It is similar, although more restricted, than the measures that the Australian Democrats recommended in our alternative Budget this year entitled Getting to work. I will discuss this measure in greater detail a little later.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the gift provisions concerning donations to environmental organisations are being redrafted and broadened. There will be a register of groups for which a tax deduction will be allowed. Entry onto or removal from the register will be by agreement between the Treasurer and the environment Minister through an executive order which is not reviewable by the Parliament. This system follows the model established for arts bodies, which was also introduced to stop the practice of funnelling money through bodies that qualified for deductions to bodies not entitled to deductions on direct contributions.

Tax deductibility for interest on money borrowed to finance superannuation contributions will be terminated. The timing of this decision suggests that it is a reaction to a ruling issued earlier this year which granted deductibility for the interest incurred by taxpayers in borrowing money to contribute to a superannuation fund. Clearly, it is absurd for the tax system to favour borrowing funds to invest in a savings vehicle. The point of granting tax concessions for superannuation is to increase the level of savings. Borrowing to fund superannuation is clearly unproductive.

Royalties paid to non-residents will be subjected to a final withholding tax. This is subject to the various double tax treaties to which Australia is a signatory. This is not the time for a full debate on the standard treaty model. However, it is clear that it is designed to assist capital exporting countries relative to capital importing ones.

Australia suffers from a perpetual shortage of capital, and we are disadvantaged by the structure of these treaties. This issue needs to be taken up at the international level. The structure of the standard international treaty penalises capital importing countries and needs to be reformed. This measure will raise $50m.

I know that nobody has a monopoly on good ideas—I also know that this is a bit nitpicky, but I want to get it on the record anyway—but today it was asserted that the 25 per cent increase in the zone rebate provision was discovered by the coalition. We have sponsored this initiative for years in our alternative Budgets.

The capital gains tax provisions have been rewritten in order to clarify them. As previously announced, the provisional tax uplift factor is being reduced from 10 per cent to 8 per cent. This is a welcome move. Given the very weak growth currently occurring in Australia, we think that the Government could have been even more generous.

The second area of amendment in the provisional tax regime is the relaxation of the penalty provision section 221YDB. This provision is hated by taxpayers as it imposes a liability on people who vary their provisional tax and get their estimated income wrong by more than 10 per cent. This Bill relaxes that 10 per cent test to 15 per cent. The Democrats support it.

Technical amendments are made to the tax treatment of the disposal of securities. The very generous horse breeding concessions are reduced, but I think they still remain very generous. The research and development concession is maintained at 150 per cent, thereby abandoning the planned future cut to 125 per cent. Other technical amendments to the R&D provisions are made.

There are technical amendments in respect of the depreciation and development allowance and there is further rollover relief for capital gains tax purposes as well as some technical amendments concerning foreign source income. There are also some highly technical amendments to the petroleum resource rent tax and to the Taxation Administration Act, including allowing the electronic payment of child support obligations.

In the few minutes left, I will return to the environmental protection expenditure proposal. Environment protection expenditure is expenditure incurred for the sole or dominant purpose of preventing, combating or rectifying pollution of the environment or treating, cleaning up, removing or storing waste. The deduction is constructed in a very complex manner, but basically it is designed to grant a deduction to directly environmentally related expenditure which does not currently qualify for any taxation relief, either by way of an immediate deduction or by way of depreciation over a number of years. Therefore, expenditure not now deductible, such as the costs of removing contaminated soil from an industrial site, will become fully deductible. Similarly, certain earthworks which are not deductible or depreciable will now become depreciable.

However, the installation of, for example, pollution control plant or equipment will not obtain immediate deductibility but will continue to be depreciable over a number of years. As a consequence, this new measure will not stimulate new sustainable development investment, as this type of investment will continue to be treated like any other investment. By that, I mean that it will be subject to the ordinary accelerated depreciation rules.

The Democrats believe that we need to advantage specific expenditure so as to stimulate the introduction of pollution and waste control equipment and the introduction of renewable energy and energy efficient equipment and the retro-fitting of existing structures—for example, by installing insulation. This will create the market for these vital future industries. This market is still not mature at the moment.

The Senate has before it legislation which proposes to deliberately advantage the offshore banking industry in this country. There is no dispute from either the Government or the Opposition that tax policies should not be used in that case. Why should a proposal to foster a productive and innovative high technology sector in Australia be opposed? The level playing field is discredited, even with the most recent promising signs in world agricultural trade. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1992. As the coalition representative on science and technology in this chamber, I will be restricting myself simply to that part of the Bill which addresses the research and development taxation concession. By way of background, the Bill contains a number of important elements in this regard. First, it provides the indefinite extension of the taxation concession for business expenditures on research and development at a rate of 150 per cent. Secondly, it removes the limit of $10m that currently applies to pilot plant used in research and development activities.

PARA.TAB: The full cost of pilot plant acquired or commenced to be constructed on or after 19 August 1992 will be able to be claimed over three years as research and development expenditure. Third, the Bill denies the research and development concession to companies involved in syndicates or other financial schemes where investors are guaranteed a return on their investment. This includes government bodies such as universities and the CSIRO. Finally, the Bill strengthens the Industry Research and Development Board with respect to the actions that it can take when finance schemes do not meet research and development tax deductibility guidelines.

I should say at the outset that the coalition supports the intentions of the Bill with respect to the research and development taxation concession. It would be well known to honourable senators that the Government had intended to reduce the concession to 125 per cent from June 1993. At the last minute, just before the Budget was announced, the Government had a change of heart and determined that the existing 150 per cent concession should remain for an indefinite period.

The coalition supports the continuation of the concession at the 150 per cent rate. However, unlike the Government, the coalition understands that encouragement of investment in research and development cannot be left to the taxation concession alone. If one takes the trouble to look at Australia's position in the world with respect to research and development, the consequences of this one-track policy are clear.

Our total gross expenditure on research and development as a percentage of GDP is 1.23 per cent. The OECD average is 1.87 per cent. The large public research and development makes even this sad comparison look better than it is. Business spending on research and development, one of the crucial indicators of industrial performance and competitiveness, looks worse still. Australia ranks sixteenth out of 19 OECD countries which have measurable levels of private sector research and development expenditures. Australia's rate of business expenditure in business enterprises on research and development is 0.51 per cent of GDP; compare that with the OECD where the average is 1.18 per cent of GDP—about double.

It should be clear that the level of private sector expenditure on research and development in this country is woeful, and the current Government has done very little to address this situation, for all its talk. The taxation concession at 150 per cent is important but it is not enough by itself. What more is the Government prepared to do? The answer, sadly, is nothing. The Government has no new policies and no agenda for change—yet another area where we have a tired Government bereft of ideas.

A Keating Government only promises more of the same. For a private sector starved of incentive, this means a level of investment in research and expenditure which falls far short of the world's best standards. The private sector has to be provided with greater incentive to invest in research and development. The coalition is responsive to that need. We will be providing this incentive through the reform of the business tax regime and through reform of the labour market.

The Government simply is not doing enough and it is not prepared to tackle the major reforms that are necessary to encourage a self-supporting private sector research and development effort. The taxation concession is only one step in that direction. It is one part of a broad economic assessment carried out by companies when they are reflecting on their capacity to invest in the developmental and commercialisation phases of a new product or a new production process. The cost of capital, labour productivity, business input costs and the efficiency and structure of supply networks are all crucial factors. On every one of these we find that the coalition's Fightback plan has a positive impact. By extension, this means a positive impact on research and development investment by the private sector. By contrast, the Labor Government seems to think that the taxation concession is all that is required.

I remind you, Mr Deputy President, of the Government's failure to implement one of the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee—of which you were the Chairman and I was a member—inquiring into the education of gifted and talented children which are needed in this country. If ever a country needed its gifted and talented, Australia does now. These are the very people who will benefit from any increase in research and development in this country and who will benefit Australia by that research and development. Mr Deputy President, you must feel as sad as I do at the failure of your Government to take any action on the education of the gifted and the talented children.

In the context of a government lacking imagination and failing to forward ideas or inspire confidence, it should not surprise us that the Government's science White Paper, Developing Australian ideas, has sunk almost without trace, rather like our Committee's report into gifted and talented children. In opinions which have been widely reported in the media, the White Paper has been described as underwhelming and has been criticised for failing to tackle the real problems in the science portfolio. We have been told that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) has been living down to his nickname of `Agenda Free'. It has even been said that the only good thing to come from the White Paper was the Government's decision to retain the 150 per cent tax concession on business research and development. As I have said, we have adopted the 150 per cent rate.

We also support the other provisions contained in this Bill in relation to the taxation concession. For instance, the Government has drastically reduced the likelihood of any future abuse of the concession. The Bill ensures that the concession is available only to those businesses which are engaging in genuinely high risk investments. As my colleague Peter McGauran, the shadow Minister for science, has pointed out in the other place, this has always been a concern to the coalition parties over the years. We have raised the issue publicly on a number of occasions. It is pleasing that, after defending its failure to act for so long, the Government has at last accepted the arguments of the coalition on the need for a tightening of the applicability of the research and development concession. It is yet another example of the agenda free Labor Party being led by the coalition with a very busy, active and innovative agenda.

In conclusion, I repeat the coalition's support for the research and development taxation concession initiatives contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1992, but it is clear that much more needs to be done. If we can allow companies to operate in an internationally competitive low cost environment—an environment which allows them the basic right to exact internationally competitive rates of return on capital and labour—increased levels of expenditure on research and development will follow. In the long term, that is the only effective strategy. In simple terms, it is clear that this tired, policy-bereft Government cannot do this, but the coalition will.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be following Senator Newman because the package of Bills we are debating includes, amongst others, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. I thought I should continue the discussion I was having with Senator Newman this afternoon about the health legislation of this country and the benefits of Medicare—the simple, fair and affordable universal coverage of Medicare. That is what we support, that is what we have supported and that is what many people, on any polling, like. The Opposition, suggesting that somehow people would be sick if they were not forced to have private health insurance—
—It is like war time rationing.
—Order! It is only 20 past eight; we have a long night ahead of us.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President, I am appreciative of your assistance. The Opposition was arguing that we should have an urgency motion, essentially criticising its own policy, but that is a clear measure of the capacity of the Opposition to understand health at all. I was interested to note that Opposition senators, particularly Senator Knowles, wanted to argue that the waiting lists are out of control and going up and are very high.
—Especially in South Australia. Ha, ha!

—Is there a hyena in the House, Mr Deputy President? I was able to tell Senator Knowles that she clearly does not know—and certainly will not hear, if I tell her; that is all right, she will still remain ignorant—that through Mr Peter Shack the Opposition claimed that there were 100,000 people on the waiting lists of this country, and in its Fightback document, which is a mere 12 months old, it assesses that figure at 60,000 people.

PARA.TAB: Either the Labor Government has been dramatically effective in the last couple of years in terms of the waiting lists dropping by 40,000 or the Opposition knows that the figures on waiting lists are very rubbery and concedes that its previous figures were too high. The Government has put money into reducing waiting lists. Over three years the Commonwealth has allocated $50m which was matched by $50m from the States. As a result, the waiting lists fell. It is quite clear that if one targets expenditure one can reduce the waiting lists. Indeed, that is why in the recent Budget the Government has put up $70m over the next two years to deal with the size of the waiting lists which, quite clearly, is not acceptable.

It is also true that under the Medicare agreements it has been possible to contract public beds in the private hospitals. I was saying this afternoon that that is something which has been done very successfully in my own State as well as in New South Wales. The private hospitals were very pleased to cooperate with the public system. They have been able to use their spare capacity beds to help reduce the waiting lists. This particularly applies to pensioner patients waiting for eye surgery and orthopaedic surgery. Reliable data indicates that these specialty needs have been a problem in terms of waiting lists since the late 1960s. They still are the principal cause of the waiting list problems. However, the time taken to treat such patients has much more to do with the supply of the necessary specialists than public or private hospital funding.

This afternoon I also reminded the Senate that in my own State the private hospitals were very pleased to proceed. However, those private hospitals, the public system and the State Government were obstructed in that exercise by the specialists refusing to come to the party. Public patients on waiting lists in South Australia were held to ransom by greedy doctors and by greedy specialists. That is a fact. It is also one of the facts that ought to be part of this complex arrangement. Quite clearly, it is beyond the ability of my Opposition colleagues to deal honourably and honestly with the waiting list challenge in this country.

I asked Minister Tate not too long ago a question about waiting lists and the allocation of public funding to public hospitals. This matter concerns the very graceless brawl that is going on between the New South Wales and Victorian governments and the Commonwealth over whether to sign the Medicare agreements. It is no more than political posturing. The Minister, in answer to a supplementary question, was able to deal with the quite clear question I put to him. He certainly made it clear to honourable senators opposite, who certainly were not minded to listen to him, that if we want to extend waiting lists then we reduce funding to public hospitals.

The whole Fightback package is devoted to shifting money from the public sector to the private sector in the hope that that will run down waiting lists. This is no way to deal with public funding of public hospitals. We certainly cannot reduce public waiting lists by reducing public funding to public hospitals.

This matter is apparently quite beyond the ability of the Opposition to grasp. That is what the Medicare agreements are about. That is what the negotiations between the federal Minister, Mr Howe, and the State Ministers of health are about. I think that is very well understood but is not accepted because the Opposition wants to play peculiar politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —In order to quieten the cacophony from the other side of the Senate, I am perfectly prepared to say that State politics are played not only on party political lines but sometimes on State versus Commonwealth lines.
—What about Keith Wilson?
—Mr Wilson had his own reasons for behaving in a very unproductive way if we were looking at the best care for the people in the public hospital system in Western Australia.
—Just because he tells the truth.
—Ignore the interjections, Senator Crowley.
—I am certainly trying to, Mr Deputy President. It is just proving to be remarkably difficult.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the complexity of waiting lists must take into account the cost to the nation of health. I heard Senator Lees say in her contribution this afternoon that the real tragedy about health in this country is that, to a great extent, the political debate is not fought on the basis of preventive health, morbidity and disease, ways in which we can reduce ill health in our workplaces or in our community, and how we can look at clearly establishing environmental guidelines for clean water and unpolluted land, but on the basis of whether we have private or public insurance. This is a big distraction. But it is where the political fight has taken place. Unfortunately, with Fightback, this will continue to be the case. This is what will happen as the Opposition tries to drag us back to the 1950s and the Government proceeds apace with the equity, accessibility and affordability of Medicare.

In particular, the Opposition has not put a cap on the cost to this nation under Fightback. One of the distinct achievements of the Labor Government in the health area has been holding the cost at about 8 per cent of GDP. The cost under the American system, which the Opposition is planning to adopt, is now about 13 per cent. It is growing out of control to such an extent that Mr Clinton has won an election on the second most important issue that the American people wanted to vote on—that is, to change their health system.

Health care in America is unfair. It is outrageously expensive for individual citizens. Something like 100 million people in America have limited or no access to health insurance. The people of America have said, `That is enough. We cannot go on managing. We are sick, we cannot get to hospital and we cannot afford treatment. We cannot afford to meet our individual costs'. At last it has been recognised that the nation cannot afford those costs. In Australia we have actually managed to hold at a very reasonable and manageable 8 per cent the percentage of the money that the country is spending on health.

Senator Newman, in a piece of high dudgeon this afternoon, suggested that this Government was evil and wicked and was into rationing. I am terribly pleased that Senator Newman can now spell that. I am pleased that she knows that this is occurring in the health area. Indeed it has. This is precisely why this Government has said that under the new Medicare agreements we will require and arrange for people to get into the public hospital system as public or private patients according to clinical needs. That is what this country will move to. It is what has been largely happening anyhow. Most people get into public hospitals as a result of accidents or emergencies. Anyone in this country who is ill as a result of an accident or an emergency is dealt with straight away in public hospitals.

I simply remind the Opposition about where Mr Packer went after he had had a massive heart attack and was at death's door. According to some descriptions, he went to one of the humbler public hospitals in Sydney. He went to a public hospital which treated him in the same way as every other patient. Public hospitals treat such patients regardless of their insurance status, capacity to pay, social status and socio-economic background. The public hospital system treats them according to need and it treats them equally. That is what our public system is about. It does not distinguish between patients in terms of their insurance status. Indeed, it is an absolute matter of principle that this Government says that we want to establish that as a right. We want to give a strong guarantee that people get into the public hospital system on the basis of clinical need.

We have to appreciate that the waiting list figures are rubbery at best. We do not really know how many people in this country are on hospital waiting lists. I can assure Opposition senators that we have very little access to hard data from the private sector. The public sector properly goes some way to accounting in public for how it expends its money. It is clear from the Budget statements and the further development of Medicare that it is not good enough—I do not believe so and neither does this Government—that the States are not providing adequate data to the Commonwealth about how they are allocating their health dollars, particularly in regard to their hospitals.

That is one of the new thrusts in this Budget for Medicare. We would like to require harder data so that we can make more reasonable decisions about access to services and what services we will properly put in place. I presume that honourable senators opposite would not argue if I suggested that a patient with gallstones had a larger claim on the public dollar than a person who wished to have their tattoos removed. We could then proceed to trawl through the various medical conditions or illnesses that people might front the hospital system with. Everybody would agree that there is some kind of rank ordering and that it is reasonable that a person who is in an acute state of illness be treated ahead of a person who has a chronic illness or an elective condition.

We already set lists, if you like, allocating priorities within our system. We already know that we ration services. Would the Opposition argue that we should be expending as much effort to save the life of a person who is 85 and has kidney failure or cancer as we might with somebody who is 35 and has a young family? We can come up with any number of examples to justify making a choice between who has a priority claim on those spare, scarce and hard-won dollars. It is a nonsense for the Opposition to accuse the Government of rationing. What matters is that we begin to ration in a proper, thoughtful and deliberative way.

When I was chairing the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, that is why we actually went to an opening chapter that stressed the importance of asking for a large public debate so as to make the rationing of resources a matter of considerable community and ethical regard so that people would know, for example, how much it costs to keep a premature baby in a humidicrib alive—at last count, it was about $75,000. The community might have to decide how many humidicribs it wants. It might actually learn not to suck in its breath and gasp every time Derryn Hinch says, `Tiny, underweight baby flown across state'. I say to Mr Hinch, `Of course that is an entirely proper thing to do with restricted resources in order to save the life of a little person'.

That is the sort of debate we cannot have about this whole issue because the members of the Opposition are ignorant and unprincipled in the sorts of debate they will try to lead on these emotional issues. They are like the Derryn Hinch of the Parliament: bleeding on any issue to make a cheap point and not seriously prepared to deliberate on the complexities of this issue, on the very important differences between the Government and the Opposition on Medicare.

I am interested to note the silence from the Opposition when it is challenged by me on what Medicare levy it will include, should it win, with Fightback. Is it going to take the levy of 1.4 per cent which those opposite have come in here and abused us about for proposing to introduce in July next year? Is it going to take money or is it going to settle for 1.25 per cent? Like many areas of policy from those opposite, one can note the thunderous silence. I do not know if they even know. As I said this afternoon, they are in a log jam. They are keeping Medicare so that it is very difficult for them to go out and argue against it. They are keeping Medicare because they want the goodwill that goes with the name, the money that goes with the levy and the guarantee of universal insurance.

That is what Medicare has given the people of Australia. That is what the people of Australia know, that is what they want and that is what they say every time they are asked in a news poll. Those opposite are actually left only to fight on, `We prefer private insurance because we are supporting our lobby interest groups called the private hospitals, the private specialists and the private insurance industries'. That is what their specious little motion this afternoon was about and that is why they have a terrible problem when they go out into the community to argue about health.

Under Fightback, health will cost every individual more, it will cost the nation more, it will be permanently inflationary and it will set the health policy of this nation back 30 to 40 years. In no way could I possibly endorse it. I am happy to support the increase in the Medicare levy. It goes to the principles of Medicare—fairness, affordability and universality. Medicare is what the people want. The Opposition is keeping it. Why does it not come clean?

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let such absolute, arrant nonsense from Senator Crowley go unanswered. She has come back into the chamber, re-run her speech from this afternoon—because she has had nothing further to say—and has trotted out the same fallacious little diatribe that we copped this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: Is it not interesting that Senator Crowley is supposed to be a doctor, and I emphasise `suppose'? I have actually spoken to some people who have had experience in that area; fortunately, I have not. Senator Crowley mentions that the way in which—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very wicked, Senator, and you know it.
—I am just wondering, Madam Acting Deputy President, whether you are going to allow Senator Crowley to continue to rabbit on while she is standing up.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—She is in her seat, but if she is going to interject, she should be sitting down.
Senator Crowley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have a hell of a long way to go; that is all I can say. Senator Crowley is not even prepared to stay here and have the questions that she has raised answered.
—Certainly not.
—Senator Crowley says, `Certainly not'. That just demonstrates the gross ignorance of this person—absolute ignorance.
—Wind it up, Sue. Come on—louder.
—She is nuts. She has gone off her brain.
—Order!

—This supposed professional person has come in here tonight and said that something miraculous is going to happen—that people are going to get into hospitals on clinical need. This is exactly the point that Senator—surgeon, doctor—Herron stated this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: We believe that people should get into hospitals on the basis of clinical need, and that clinical need should be decided purely and simply by doctors. The problem that this Government has is that the decision of who gets into hospital is made by bureaucrats. Madam Acting Deputy President, you can frown all you like because you know that it is fact. The bureaucrats now have the responsibility to ration waiting lists; to decide what case is urgent and what case is not. That has been clearly demonstrated by files and files of cases that we have in our offices. If you do not get the complaints, Madam Acting Deputy President, we sure do. Senator Herron gave example after example this afternoon of where this is leading.

Senator Crowley had the audacity tonight to say that the Opposition was ignorant and unprincipled. We have had our health policy on the table for 12 months and we are called ignorant and unprincipled, and yet this lousy, rotten Government will not even release its policy now—a matter of months out from an election. Senator Crowley comes in here, professing to know all about health, and she still cannot tell us what the policy is. I ask again: when will the policy be announced? The Government cannot say that what it is currently legislating for, and has legislated for in the past, is the policy because it is not working. The figures have blown out; they have gone to the extreme, and that is where we are at today.

Waiting lists have grown. Anyone but anyone, if they are out there in the real world, which Senator Crowley quite clearly is not, can tell the Government that waiting lists have grown. People know that they cannot get into hospitals for various surgery, whether it be surgery as important as thoracic or cardiovascular surgery. Once again, Senator Herron gave examples this afternoon of how long the waiting list could be for an urgent cardiovascular operation. He said that an urgent case might get into hospital in a month.

But Senator Crowley is so rude in this chamber that she only breezes in, abuses, and then breezes out again. She would not stay here long enough to hear Senator Herron. She would not stay here long enough to understand that people are dying waiting for bypass surgery. The problem is that she does not care, and nor does this Government. If they cared, they would release the policy.

Senator Crowley also asked, but she is not interested in sticking around to find out the answer: what are we doing about the Medicare levy? Our policy has quite clearly stated that we will retain the Medicare levy. But the Medicare levy, as far as we are concerned, is only a part of general taxation anyway.

This Government is still pretending that the Medicare levy somehow funds the total cost of health. As I said this afternoon, the levy covers 17 per cent of the forecast total health cost. Senator Crowley would not know what I said this afternoon because she did not have the decency to come in and listen. She just comes in and abuses. She even thought that this afternoon we were debating a motion. We were not debating a motion this afternoon; we were debating a matter of public importance. It is absolutely outrageous to try to make anyone believe that the total cost of health is somehow being funded by this stupid levy. One could say to people, `Just take an extra 1.4 per cent of your income tax and you can categorise that as the levy', or just make it the whole issue and up income tax by 1.4 per cent.

But, as I say, Senator Crowley has no wish or desire to know the truth. She treats this chamber and the Opposition with such absurd rudeness that one ceases to be amazed. One day she will have the courtesy to come in here and listen to a full debate and then respond to it accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The old adage that empty vessels make the most sound has never been more eloquently established. With regard to the principal Bills that we are dealing with tonight, the committee stage will be held subsequently. There are a number of matters of detail raised by honourable senators that will most appropriately be dealt with there. So, as with the last set of Bills that we dealt with, I will not duplicate that exercise, although I will refer in passing to some.

PARA.TAB: I do need to indicate formally—although the chamber is aware of it, because I think these amendments have all been circulated; they have certainly been provided—that there are some amendments to the Bills that will be dealt with in the committee stage. Before I deal with those, just as a matter of advice—although the chamber is aware of it—I should mention that in the area of corporate wardrobes there were amendments made in the House which I think have significantly enhanced that legislation. I will deal with that in a moment. There will be amendments with regard to the taxation of limited partnership companies to ensure that all limited partnerships are corporate limited partnerships in the 1995-96 year of income and subsequent years.

There will be amendments relating to R&D to allow for the gazettal of guidelines for determining when government bodies operate on a fully commercial basis and so will not be denied R&D deductions even if some guarantees are offered. There will be an amendment to the royalty withholding tax clarifying that the tax will not apply to permanent establishments in Australia of non-residents of a country with which Australia has a double tax agreement. I can formally advise that the Government is considering representations that the transitional arrangements for companies whose R&D proposals were approved after 30 March and before 10 June 1992 may adversely affect some companies. These representations are currently under consideration.

So, having put those formal matters behind me, there has been some broad support for the thrust of the major measures in this complex array of tax legislation, not so much that it makes complex legislation but that there is an array of measures in these Bills with which we are dealing that cover a large number of issues. That is caused by two things: it is a product of the cognate debate of several Bills at the same time and in the nature of taxation laws amendment Bills that they tend to range, of necessity, over a diversity of issues. Broadly, there seems to be support for the register of environmental gifts. I was disappointed to hear it referred to as a political sop. It does not provide greater benefit; it only provides benefits in a much more regularised, organised way, capable of more effective scrutiny.

I was amused to find that everybody is claiming credit for the zone rebate initiative. Success has a thousand fathers or, in this instance, several parents, seeking to play different roles in the birth of this child. Nevertheless, it is recognised by the people of Australia, particularly by the people affected and by everybody in the chamber, that it is a worthwhile initiative to be enhancing the zone rebates. It has been welcomed here, as it has been welcomed around Australia and as it should be, as were the changes with regard to the prescribed payments system and dividend streaming. So given that support, there is no virtue in taking the time of the chamber in heated agreement. The second reading speeches outlined the changes and I welcome the support for them.

I always hesitate to say that my good friend Senator Panizza might in any way have misunderstood a piece of legislation because our offices are in the same corridor and every time I do he comes in and says, `No, I did not. I really understood it.' I did not hear what he said; I have only been able to get a report of what he said. He did seem to be concerned—far be it from me to say that he misunderstood—about what the Government was doing with TFN credits as they relate to provisional tax. I want to make clear—without going into it too technically—that what we are effectively doing is giving these credits the same status as other credits that taxpayers might have to set off against their provisional tax liability, for example, PAYE or others.

The provisional tax changes generally have been welcomed. Some people would always like to see bigger changes—the variation potential greater, the uplift factor lower—but I think it is generally regarded as putting these rates in a better perspective. I welcome the support for the capital gains simplification.

I turn to some of the issues in contention, first of all to the limited partnership question. It is never a welcome measure when legislation seeks to tighten up the operation of legislation where people have been seeking to use a particular form of structure which they regard as being tax-effective for them. But the Government is concerned that we should not allow to continue a process by which those not exposed to losses can utilise the tax benefit of those losses. It will continue to be the case that people exposed to genuine risk of loss in other forms of corporate vehicle will, if they incur the loss, have no diminution of their access to the tax benefit of that loss.

There was reference in the debate to the international trends with regard to this matter. My advice is that comparable countries have in many instances felt the need to restrict access to losses through limited partnership, not necessarily in the way we have done, but recognising the same problem that we recognise and moving to resolve it. No-one expected it to be a popular measure, but I think it is a correct measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not for research and development for an infrastructure.

—I am a great friend of enhanced funding of infrastructure, but that is not to say that any tax proposal that will lead people to provide more funds to infrastructure is, of itself, justified. It depends on the nature of the tax measure, the likely cost and the likely implication, including its economic impact in terms of where it may divert investment that should otherwise be made elsewhere.

PARA.TAB: The occupational clothing proposals as amended in the House now have broad support. I note that Senator Watson raised a couple of questions of detail. I think they are better dealt with in the Committee, and I will happily respond to him at that time. I just acknowledge that he raised them.

The R&D changes are important. I think people generally recognise the virtue of the changes that have been made. With regard to questions of environmental expenditure, I understood people—at least Senator Kernot—to be raising concern that perhaps we should be even more generous. We have not here given a tax break to environmental expenditure. We have essentially recognised the contemporary responsibility of the corporate citizen—that an obligation of corporations in a modern society is to engage in such expenditure in the normal course of running their business, and that therefore that expenditure should be so recognised.

My next point will be the last that I refer to before concluding. In summing up a second reading debate, there are always more points to raise than there is time in which to raise them, but others have sought to be brief in their contributions to expedite the proceedings, so I will seek to cooperate in the same way. There has been concern that residents of non-treaty countries with permanent establishments in Australia should not be treated differently from residents of treaty countries with permanent establishments. It is a complex issue. We could debate it for a long time. But the nature of the treaties is such that they protect Australia's position internationally and they protect the revenue. Residents of non-treaty countries may well not be residents of countries with comparable tax systems, and we know that in some instances they are not. If they are residents of a low tax country, there would be an incentive to enter into arrangements to enable them to pay most of their tax offshore, and that is not a loophole which we wish to leave. To the contrary, we would prefer that they were all being taxed under the withholding tax system, but we do not have that option, pursuant to our treaties, and that is proper, I think.

Concern has also been expressed about 30 per cent being too high a rate. The Government decided that Australia should impose withholding tax on all gross royalty payments to non-residents at a flat rate of 30 per cent in the absence of treaty limitations. The same rate applies to unfranked dividends paid to residents of non-treaty countries. By way of comparison, the non-treaty rates of royalty withholding tax of some of our trading partners are, for example: the United States, 30 per cent; the United Kingdom, Canada and Germany, 25 per cent; and Japan, 20 per cent.
So I do not think we are out of step with others. As a matter of interest, though, I note that on 3 November in the debate in the House of Representatives, Mr Wilson, the member for Sturt, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . where we use withholding taxes we should set a much higher rate . . . Then we should reduce it . . . according to whether we are dealing with a treaty country or a country that has a tax system somewhat similar to our own . . . The lower rates of withholding tax should, therefore, be made available only when we are sure that we are getting a fair share of the tax cake.

I have not quoted every word of his speech. I do not wish to be accused of taking him out of context. I think I have got the sense of it accurately. I do not wish in any way to have anybody express concern because I did not use every word of his quote. I think if honourable senators read the full Hansard text they will see that I have not taken him out of context. That is not to say that because one member of the House of Representatives from the Opposition generally shares my view rather than Senator Watson's that I am right and he is wrong. Nevertheless, it is an interesting addition to the debate.

PARA.TAB: I thank honourable senators for their contribution to this debate. All but the Medicare legislation will now go to a committee. I hope that that legislation gets relatively speedy passage when it returns—and may we deal with the Medicare legislation in the committee stage somewhat more smoothly and harmoniously than we did at the second reading stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of brief questions for the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan). The first is in respect of the cost of Medicare. Is the total amount received from the Medicare levy sufficient to meet the costs of Medicare? If not, by what margin is it insufficient?

—I cannot give Senator Harradine a detailed answer to that. I understand that it is an important issue, but it is not an issue directly related to this Bill. This is a Bill, I accept, about raising the levy. It was never the intention of the Government that the levy would cover all the costs of the health system in Australia; nor have we ever pretended that it will. The expenditure side of Medicare is something that Senator Harradine will have to pursue with others, but, on the revenue side, this Bill merely proposes to raise the levy from 1.25 per cent to 1.4 per cent. So, as a matter of logic, it will cover the costs more than it otherwise would, but it is not designed to be a 100 per cent coverage. If, rather than Senator Harradine pursuing it elsewhere, he wants me to get some more detail for him, I will happily do so. It is a matter of public record.

—I am sure the Chairman will rule me out of order if it is not relevant, but I would have thought that this was fundamentally relevant to the question of whether the Parliament should vote for an increase in the Medicare levy. I accept the Parliamentary Secretary's offer to provide further and more detailed figures. I would also like to know: what was the cost of Medicare in the last relevant 12 months and what was the income received for that same period from the Medicare levy?

—That is all a matter of public record in the Budget documents. But I am not trying to obfuscate; I will happily get it extracted and provide it. On the revenue side I can do that quite readily. On the expenditure side, I will get what the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) provides and forward it to Senator Harradine.

—I now go to the question of Australians who have been paying their way and are not eligible to receive Medicare benefits. I refer to the matter that was raised in this chamber by Senator Herron relating to a missionary couple in Papua New Guinea by the name of James and Ruth Mollenhauer. They had recently returned to Australia for the birth of their baby after doing three years missionary work in Papua New Guinea and their applications for new Medicare cards were refused by the HIC on the grounds that they were not Australian citizens. Because I am interested in this question as to whether the Medicare levy should be raised, I want to know why, if this levy is to be raised and if this levy is being paid, are people not entitled to Medicare benefits?

PARA.TAB: I have a more glaring example where the person was a freelance journalist, had been employed, had paid her taxes and had been overseas for a fairly short time. She is now back in Australia paying taxes and paying the Medicare levy, and will be giving birth to a baby in March. She has been denied a Medicare card. Frankly, this is appalling. She is an Australian citizen. She has worked as a journalist since 1983 and has paid her taxes. In 1990 she married and, with a Christian organisation, took part in voluntary aid projects in South East Asia. To help support herself and her husband, she undertook freelance journalism.

She returned to Australia in July this year and subsequently was appointed to a temporary position of press officer. She has been duly paying taxation and the Medicare levy. Last month she went to the Medicare office in Canberra to apply for a new Medicare card in her married name. She explained that she had been out of the country and was informed that this would not affect her entitlement, as the time for which she had been absent was acceptable.

She returned to the office with the relevant information and was told that a new card had already been issued in her maiden name. She indicated that she wanted the card to be issued in her married name. After checking with the Medicare office in Sydney, the staff member told her that she no longer qualified because she had been out of the country. She explained her involvement in volunteer aid overseas. She also explained that she could possibly be going to China for similar volunteer aid for one or two years at the end of this year or next year. This has caused her great anxiety. She has been refused a Medicare card. Her baby is due in March and without Medicare coverage she will be faced with some financial hardship.

I feel that this type of case is relevant to whether we in this chamber agree to an increase in the Medicare levy. If we agree to the increase in the Medicare levy and people, such as this person, who have been paying their taxes and their Medicare levy are not entitled to receive benefits, the system is unjust. I know it appears that the message has not got through to the Parliamentary Secretary who is at the table. I warned the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Senator Tate) that I would be raising these issues, but apparently the message has not got through; the communications have broken down. But this is an urgent case and I would be very grateful if the Parliamentary Secretary were to take this on board and, hopefully, pursue it so that justice can be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine is very skilled in the art of utilising this chamber to make his point. He has effectively established, fairly circuitously but nevertheless sufficiently, that this matter is properly before us. I was not previously attempting to argue that it was not relevant, simply that, given that I am here in the capacity of dealing with it as a revenue measure and Senator Harradine is dealing with the expenditure side of the equation, I will need to refer this information elsewhere to get more information. I understand Senator Harradine wants to get this matter on the record and this is a very effective mechanism for so doing.

PARA.TAB: I know about the first instance only because I heard it raised in the chamber in Senator Tate's response. So I know the Government is aware of those details. If Senator Harradine would like to give me any further details on the second case—which sounds very important to me because, on the face of it, it sounds as though he is referring to a constituent of mine—I will happily pursue it with the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services with as much expedition as possible. I can send the information that is contained in the Hansard; if Senator Harradine wants to give me anything more, I will happily take that and send it as well.
Bill agreed to.
