TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation flows directly from the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority entitled Who is to guard the guards? That report was an evaluation of the National Crime Authority. The primary matter considered by the Committee was the level of accountability of the National Crime Authority to the Intergovernmental Committee and, in particular, to the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority.

PARA.TAB: The decisions of the National Crime Authority are subject to review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act of 1977. They are subject to the most cursory scrutiny of the IGC and, to the extent that the Authority has thus far been prepared to interpret the relevant sections—55 and 51—subject to some sort of scrutiny by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. They are also subject to the Freedom of Information Act.

However, presently that scrutiny is far from adequate. The Authority has argued that section 51(3) is the normal standard secrecy provision which refers to the disclosure by members of the Authority staff, members of the Authority and past members of the Authority, of certain information, including information to tribunals, courts and so on. The National Crime Authority has thus far interpreted that section to include, by way of disqualification from exemption, the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. There has been very considerable debate on the relevance of that section by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. The Solicitor-General, if I remember correctly, originally gave an opinion buttressing the notion of the Authority members that they were bound by the secrecy provisions when they appeared before the Committee.

The Clerk of the Senate, in a very eloquent and persuasive opinion, took the opposite view. By a process which one could politely describe as evolution, or perhaps more of attrition, we have found that the Solicitor-General, as a result of opinions he has given in respect of that and other matters, has come to the conclusion that his original opinion was wrong and that section 51(3) does not apply in the way in which it has been used by the Committee. However, having said that, the Opposition has an amendment which we propose to persevere with to ensure that in terms of debate that is beyond reach.

There are restrictions as to the information which can be given to the IGC and they are contained under section 59(5). However, I do not think that is any barrier to the IGC's scrutiny and monitoring of the National Crime Authority because, frankly, it just has not bothered. During the period of imbroglio, turmoil and confusion in the National Crime Authority, which for the first part of its life was the hallmark of its operation, the IGC without exception fastidiously ignored those difficulties. I think during the much more difficult periods, the IGC met but once and, to my knowledge, there was nothing on the agenda of that meeting which indicated that it was showing any concern for the difficulties that the National Crime Authority was having. The IGC, of course, is made up of the various State police Ministers—I think South Australia is the exception; that State has its Attorney-General on it—and also the Federal Attorney-General.

In view of the restrictions which the Joint Committee found itself suffering from, it has recommended changes to the method of accountability. The primary proposal was that the Joint Committee be given unfettered access to information with subsequent and sensible controls in terms of the disclosure of information of a sensitive nature which is given to the Joint Committee in camera.

I have always thought it somewhat obscene that a committee or a creature of the institution which set up the National Crime Authority is denied sensible and reasonable access to, and the opportunity of monitoring, the Authority's conduct. As we all know, one of the conditions of setting up the National Crime Authority in the first place was that it be subject to stringent accountability and supervision by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. As I say, thus far it has not been possible.

The task of the members of the Committee has not been much helped by the IGC's rather impertinent view that the Joint Committee ought to be abolished. Senator Tate is nodding. I assume he would not be nodding in approval but just acknowledging the absurdity and obscenity of that proposition. Clearly, the IGC has not done its job, and that has been eloquently demonstrated. To suggest that a committee of this Parliament is not responsible enough to receive from the NCA information as to its functioning, I find ludicrous.

The second option, and the fall-back position that the Committee took so as to give the Government two matters to contemplate, was that the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority receive information other than that which may be classified by definition as `sensitive'. This Bill opts for the second. I do not know, but I think it is more substantial than speculation to imagine that that is the preferred option of the IGC. The Federal Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) seems to very much reflect the view of the IGC. My experience of but two meetings of that body is that it has some fear of the Joint Committee exercising its functions properly and some concern that we might have the capacity to properly monitor it, and its view is that we ought not to be receiving information other than that which is `sensitive' as defined.

Under the proposed Bill, if the chairman of the Authority declines to provide information, the matter can be referred to the Attorney-General who himself is capable of making a decision. But I never forget that he is a political animal and part of the political institution. He may refer the matter to the Inspector-General, a new position being created, who will investigate the matter and report back to the Attorney-General, and the Attorney-General may publish that finding in so far as it does not disclose the sensitive information.

The Joint Committee will be able to examine the annual report of the Inspector-General. That is not to say that it is intended to have a supervisory role or to second guess, but certainly to at least examine the annual report. The Inspector-General has some flexibility in terms of his responsibility. He is not required to investigate matters which he judges to be frivolous or vexatious. He will be required to notify the chairman of the NCA and the Attorney-General of any inquiries. The Inspector-General's hearings shall be conducted in private and he may compel the provision of documents and information.

Complaints in respect of the NCA may be made through the IGC or the PJC and then on to the Inspector-General. The Inspector-General will be required to advise the complainant and the IGC or the PJC if they are, in fact, the initiating complainants, of his findings. The chairman of the NCA will be required to advise the Inspector-General of his action in response to a finding of the Inspector-General. If the Inspector-General is dissatisfied with the resolution of the chairman of the NCA, he may report to the Minister.

There are just one or two other minor amendments. One minor amendment includes the prohibiting of the disclosure of the serving of a process by the NCA which is issued under the recently amended sections 28 and 29. The current credit reporting provisions of the Privacy Act require the agencies to record any disclosures on an individual's credit information file and to ensure that an individual can obtain access to his or her file while, under the amendment to disclose, it will be prohibited until the notification of the prohibition expires.

The Opposition has a number of amendments. The essence of our primary amendment is that the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority ought to have unfettered access to all information that it requires of the National Crime Authority. There then will be a mechanism to ensure that that information is disclosed only in a proper way. Perhaps what is not understood is that the disclosure of any sensitive information flowing to any committee by any member of that committee improperly will ultimately reflect on members of parliament.

It ought not to be overlooked that, as to the conduct of members of parliament in disclosing in camera evidence—as at the present time in respect of almost all other committees, save for the ASIO committee—the real and final sanction is that of our peers and of the wider community. I believe that it is inherent in the position of members of parliament and incumbent on them to conduct themselves in a proper and responsible way.

To suggest that members of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority are sufficiently irresponsible to have a sanction placed on them as to what information they can receive, does a gross disservice to the functioning of the Parliament and to the Committee. I will be moving the Opposition's amendments in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate today is debating the Government's National Crime Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. This Bill seeks to respond in large measure to some of the recommendations made by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority in its report, Who is to guard the guards? Unfortunately, I feel the response is not adequate and certainly not within the spirit of the recommendations made by that Committee.

PARA.TAB: I will address some of the major amendments made by the Government's Bill. I welcome the first amendment, which omits section 55(2) of the National Crime Authority Act. That section states:

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing in this Part authorizes the Committee—
(a) to investigate a matter relating to a relevant criminal activity; or
(b) to reconsider the findings of the Authority in relation to a particular investigation.

That is a welcome amendment. During the existence of the Committee, which was established to assess—in a sense, supervise—the workings of the National Crime Authority, these provisions have caused difficulties. To say that the Committee may not investigate a matter relating to a relevant criminal activity raises considerable doubt as to whether the Committee may investigate anything. As to whether it should be prevented from reconsidering the findings of the Authority, similarly, this makes one wonder what task the Committee is left with, seeing it was asked to `monitor and review the performance by the Authority of its functions'.

PARA.TAB: In the report Who is to guard the guards? various suggestions were made, one of which was to drop the words `matter relating to' so that the Committee was simply prevented from investigating criminal activity as such. That would have been acceptable. It was also suggested that findings should not be interpreted as being conclusive findings. However, the Government has gone one better and omitted the whole section. I certainly welcome that.

It is unfortunate that the other provisions the Government has sought to put in place through this Bill virtually have the effect of preventing the Committee from exercising its function to supervise and monitor the work of the Authority.

I turn to some of those provisions. The central question is what information the Committee may obtain from the National Crime Authority. If we turn to the interpretation section of the Bill, we find that `sensitive information' is categorised as information which might prejudice:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the safety or reputation of a person; or
(b) the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence; or
(c)the effectiveness of an investigation by the Authority; or
(d)the operations of law enforcement agencies.

These definitions largely mirror definitions which I offered in my private member's Bill that was seeking to solve this problem, but one wonders about the inclusion of the term `reputation'. If nothing may be said or disclosed which could conceivably prejudice the reputation of a person, it is far too wide and the first hurdle in the provision of information to the Committee.

PARA.TAB: The second hurdle is in clause 9 where the Committee may request the chairperson of the NCA to disclose certain information, but only in the performance of its duties. At first glance, that seems quite reasonable. However, if the chairperson of the NCA decides that the request made by the Committee is outside the performance of its duties, the Committee has no recourse, avenue of appeal or reconsideration of that judgment. This places a barrier in the way of the Committee receiving information from the NCA which could in certain circumstances be insurmountable.

The third hurdle is that, if a dispute or a difference of opinion arises, the decision is ultimately to be made by the Minister. I find that totally unacceptable, because it does leave the decision of whether a parliamentary committee should have access to information which would enable it to exercise its duties in political hands. We have all had examples—I mention the former New South Wales Police Minister, Mr Pickering—where political considerations have intervened with proper processes in the area of crime detection, particularly in any large scale attempts to combat organised crime.

Therefore, I find the concept that the Government is putting forward of the Committee only receiving information that is not sensitive as defined in the Act totally unacceptable on the three grounds that I have foreshadowed: firstly, that the definition is somewhat faulty; secondly, that it is not possible to appeal if the chairperson decides that the information sought is not within the performance of the Committee's duties; and, thirdly, that the final arbiter is left in the political arena.

The Government's intention in putting forward this legislation is well illustrated by the fact that absolutely no restriction is placed on disclosure of information received by the Committee once that information has been judged to be not sensitive. That to me seems to indicate that the Committee will receive only information that is generally available or can be made available to the public. It seems to me that that characterisation of the work of the Committee reduces its effectiveness considerably. It is quite clear that the work of the NCA deals in many areas with information that in normal circumstances would not and should not be made public, but withholding it from the Committee would make the work of the Committee absolutely impossible.

It is quite clear when we consider its duties, the Committee must have access to all information that is in the hands of the National Crime Authority. As I have mentioned before, the central task is to `monitor and to review the performance by the Authority of its functions'. It also has a duty to report to both Houses of Parliament; to examine each annual report; to examine trends and changes in criminal activities, practices and methods and report to both Houses of Parliament any change which the Committee thinks desirable to the functions, structure, powers and procedures of the Authority; and, finally, to inquire into any question in connection with its duties which is referred to it by either House of the Parliament, and to report to that House upon that question. It is quite beyond me how the Committee could fulfil those functions unless it had access to the information that the National Crime Authority has in its possession.

I believe that the principle I have put forward in my private member's Bill—and I thank shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peter Costello, for his courteous acknowledgment—which principle is reflected in amendments by both the Opposition and the Democrats, is the correct one: the Committee must have unlimited access to all information within the purview of the ambit of activities of the NCA, except, of course, operational matters. In turn, members of the Committee and the Committee as a whole should be restricted in the disclosure they are able to make of the material that comes into their possession.

The amendments I will be moving will be putting that view forward and will advance provisions which will enable the National Crime Authority to advise the Committee that certain information may not be disclosed. If there is a difference of opinion, between either the Committee or a member of the Committee and the National Crime Authority, then that matter needs to be resolved by a judge of the Federal Court. I emphasise again that in introducing a judge of the Federal Court as an arbiter at this point, I believe strongly that such a decision must be taken out of the political arena.

It is quite clear that there may be many matters under investigation by the National Crime Authority which could, if made public, cause considerable embarrassment to the government of the day. It is beyond me how the Government can then expect, and in this case also the Opposition, that that particular decision can safely be left in the hands of the political representative of the Government, the Minister. I believe it is absolutely essential that this decision be taken out of the political arena.

I foreshadow another two amendments that I will be moving in this area. Those amendments address the question that, if certain material has been judged by the Federal Court judge as sensitive and therefore may not be disclosed either in the Parliament or generally in public, it may leave the Committee as a whole or members of the Committee in a difficult position if they feel they have come into possession of information which would suggest that certain remedial action needs to be taken related to the work of the National Crime Authority.

To simply sweep it under the carpet by saying that it is sensitive information, that it may not be disclosed and therefore no effective political action may be taken, seems to me once again to defeat the task of the parliamentary committee. To cater for that, the amendments concerned suggest that that information may be provided by the Committee or an individual member of the Committee to the Minister, and to the Minister only. But to ensure that some political pressure is on the Minister to take responsible and responsive action, the Committee will report to the two Houses of Parliament that such a report has been made to the Minister—without, of course, disclosing its contents.

There is another range of amendments, amendments 5 to 11, which I shall move, which address some of the provisions connected to the establishment of the new office of Inspector-General. In principle, I welcome the establishment of that office. It is one of the recommendations that was made by the Committee in its report Who is to guard the guards? The Committee has come to the conclusion that there are a lot of complaints which are made about the work or related to the work of the National Crime Authority which the Committee cannot cope with. It has neither the resources nor the expertise in many cases to deal with complaints, and yet very many of them are worthy of further examination and, if possible, resolution and remedial action.

The new office of Inspector-General is to be charged with that task. However, there are two areas which I believe require amendment. One of them is that, in a number of sections, the Bill provides that the Committee must hand on to the Inspector-General without any further involvement by the Committee any complaints it receives. I believe that that, once again, diminishes the potential for a substantive contribution that the Committee may make. I believe that it should be up to the Committee to determine how many of the complaints it receives should be passed on to the Inspector-General, and when.

Finally, there are a number of sections which deal with the provision of reports by the Inspector-General. In many of these provisions, the Committee once again is conspicuous by its absence. Even where the complaint has been received by the Committee, the Committee has decided to hand it on to the Inspector-General and the Inspector-General has dealt with it, it is apparently considered by the Government that the Committee, in discharging its duties to supervise the National Crime Authority, should not be given a copy of the report at various stages of that process. That is ludicrous. Therefore, I have endeavoured to provide in a number of amendments the provision that when the Chairperson of the NCA and the Minister are given a copy of the report, the parliamentary Joint Committee also receives a copy of the report.

That raises a concern that where the Committee receives a report it could contain sensitive information. There is no provision at the moment in the amendments that are to be moved by the Opposition or by the Democrats which would cover that particular eventuality. I accept that the protection against disclosure of such sensitive information contained in a report must be in the Bill. Therefore, I will move an amendment to the amendments to be moved by the Opposition which will fill this gap.

This brings me to the conclusion of the overall assessment of the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2). I express my disappointment that the Government has not seen fit to enable the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority to carry out its work effectively and efficiently, but rather—I echo some of the words used by Senator Crichton-Browne—in spirit, if not in words, has followed the attitude expressed by the IGC that the Committee might just as well shut up shop. If the Bill were to be passed as the Government intended, the Committee might as well do so. With these comments, I recommend strongly to the Minister that he consider seriously the amendments put forward by the Australian Democrats and by the Opposition to enable the Committee to continue to carry out its work, which I believe is essential and valuable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is discussing the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. Primarily, the Bill attempts to deal with the continuing friction that has occurred between the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority and the National Crime Authority on the one hand, and the National Crime Authority, the parliamentary Joint Committee and the Inter-Governmental Committee of Ministers on the other.

PARA.TAB: To start with, this indicates the complexity of the relationship between the various bodies which the Parliament first established. Naturally, the National Crime Authority, being the prime object of the original legislation, is an extraordinary body vested with powers of a quite different nature from those normally possessed by law enforcement agencies throughout Australia. More particularly, by way of obtaining references from various jurisdictions, it is able to overcome a lot of the hostility, jealousy and petty demarcations which allowed organised crime in Australia to get a hold, taking advantage as it did of the differences between jurisdictions and the lack of a body which could effectively investigate serious criminal offences occurring across the borders of the States and Territories.

In addition to the National Crime Authority, the Inter-Governmental Committee on the National Crime Authority was established, as it had to be. It is natural in a democracy that, where a law enforcement body is vested with such extraordinary powers, there must be a body which takes political responsibility in the various parliaments for the operations and general conduct of that authority. Naturally, in our political system that is the elected members of the parliaments who attain the status of Ministers and who are responsible to the Parliament and, through the Parliament, to the electorate. The parliamentary Joint Committee also has an important role.

When one is discussing the question—which boils down to whether sensitive information ought to be passed from the National Crime Authority to bodies other than other law enforcement bodies—the history of the creation of the National Crime Authority and the various supervisory bodies argues very strongly that there should be no transfer of such sensitive information.

Let us recall the definition of `sensitive information', which is provided for in the Bill and has universal agreement as a fair definition of what should count as sensitive information. Sensitive information means:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any information the disclosure of which might prejudice:

PARA.TAB: (a) the safety or reputation of a person; or
(b) the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence; or
(c) the effectiveness of an investigation by the Authority; or
(d) the operations of law enforcement agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: A good starting point for deciding how such sensitive information ought to be dealt with is to look at the way in which the Act intended that such information should be dealt with by the Inter-Governmental Committee. This body of Ministers, who participated in setting up the Authority and sustaining it, in granting references to it and in taking responsibility for it in their own parliaments, is under a very considerable constraint.

PARA.TAB: Section 59(5) of the National Crime Authority Act provides that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Authority shall not furnish to the Inter-Governmental Committee any matter the disclosure of which to members of the public could prejudice the safety or reputation of persons or the operations of law enforcement agencies and, if the findings of the Authority in an investigation include any such matter, the Authority shall prepare a separate report in relation to the matter and furnish that report to the Commonwealth Minister or Minister of the Crown of the State by whom the relevant reference was made.
In other words, the Intergovernmental Committee, as a body, is not to have access to that sort of information.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't work that way, Senator Tate. How do you think they get the references in the first place?
—As a body. That constraint in the statute, which is observed, is an important indication of the right line to take.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that what is proposed by the Opposition and by the Democrats, though by a slightly different surrounding structure, is that all that information which I have described as sensitive should be made available—Senator Spindler used the words `in an unlimited way'—in an unfettered and unhindered way to the parliamentary Joint Committee and that that information should be transferred holus-bolus. There are then constraints on its further dissemination.

Senator Spindler, in the latest version of his particular way of tackling this matter, says that a Federal Court judge could decide that, if it were sensitive information, it should not be transferred. Am I correct, Senator? It is only if he decides that it is not sensitive that it can be transferred.

TALK.START.PARA: —That it should not be disclosed by the Committee.
—Only simply not disclosed? In that case, the Democrats and the Opposition both share the point of view that all the information should be made available to the Committee.
—But on request—not holus-bolus.

—Nevertheless, there is no hindrance on sensitive information being transferred to the Committee. The Federal Government and other participating governments take an absolutely adamant view that that should not occur. We believe that that represents a totally unjustified expansion of the role of the parliamentary Joint Committee. It certainly has attendant risks.

PARA.TAB: I am not speaking of improprieties on the part of Committee members. I am simply talking about continuing to disseminate material dealing with the safety or reputation of a person; the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence; material the disclosure of which might prejudice the effectiveness of an investigation by the Authority; or information the disclosure of which might prejudice the operations of law enforcement agencies. In terms of distributing that sort of sensitive information into even more hands, irrespective of whatever precautions people take in their parliamentary or electorate offices with the handling of information and the safety of office procedures and so on, every dissemination of such material must have further attendant risks as to its disclosure. This is unfortunate for those whose reputation or safety might be unduly affected or where the operations of an investigation or a law enforcement operation might be jeopardised.

As I say, that is the adamant view of the Intergovernmental Committee. It needs to be emphasised because this Bill is not simply the attitude or the expression of a point of view of the Federal Government and the Federal Attorney-General; it is the point of view of all the governments of all the States and Territories of Australia in relation to this matter.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I am sure that you would like me to indicate those who attended the meeting of the Intergovernmental Committee of the National Crime Authority last Friday in Melbourne. The meeting was chaired by the Hon. Michael Duffy. The Hon. Chris Sumner attended from South Australia; the Hon. Terry Griffiths from New South Wales; the Hon. Paul Braddy from Queensland; the Hon. Frank Madill from Tasmania; the Hon. Graham Edwards from Western Australia; the Hon. Terry Connolly from the ACT; the Hon. Pat McNamara from Victoria; and the Hon. Marshall Perron from the Northern Territory.
That is a wide range of political allegiances. In no way did they discuss this matter in any partisan manner, but they all agreed to a resolution, which was as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Inter-Governmental Committee:

(a) supports the provisions of the Government's Bill which would prevent access by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority to sensitive information, and would ensure that disputes as to whether particular information is `sensitive' are resolvable by inquiry by the Inspector-General of the National Crime Authority and determination by the Minister, and
(b) opposes any amendment to the Bill which would have the effect of granting the parliamentary Joint Committee unfettered access to National Crime Authority sensitive information.

That is the resolution of the Intergovernmental Committee that was brought down last Friday, 20 November, in Melbourne after a full discussion of the matter and having had the pros and cons of the Opposition's amendments explained to it. That was its conclusion. It wanted to give encouragement and support to the Government persevering with its Bill which, it needs to be emphasised, has the following safeguards so that what occurs is not likely to result in a simple political act of bastardry by a Federal Attorney-General who was minded to frustrate the workings of the parliamentary Joint Committee.

PARA.TAB: The Government proposes—as honourable senators will know—that if a chairperson of the National Crime Authority forms the view that the information which should otherwise be transferred to the parliamentary Joint Committee is sensitive, as described, the chairperson of the National Crime Authority does not make a final determination but the matter is referred to the Federal Attorney-General and he makes the determination. But, in doing so, the Bill indicates that he will seek the guidance of the Inspector-General of the National Crime Authority—an office created by this Bill—who will provide advice on the question of sensitivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —He may.

—As Senator Crichton-Browne knows, it is expressed in that formal way. Senator Crichton-Browne knows very well that he will provide advice and it would be a very imprudent Attorney-General—in the face of an Inspector-General of the National Crime Authority saying that material was not sensitive and should be disclosed, could be disclosed, ought to be disclosed and under the statute would have to be disclosed—who would say, `Thanks very much for your opinion but I regard it as sensitive'. That will not occur. Whilst the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth will take political responsibility for the decision in the Parliament, quite clearly he will be guided to the nth degree by the advice he receives from the Inspector-General.

PARA.TAB: Is that a preposterous, outlandish and frustrating position for the Parliament to find itself in? I do not think it is. The report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority entitled Who is to guard the guards?, which was published in November 1991—in respect of that very structure which I have just outlined as being incorporated in the Bill—stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In paragraph 7.37 the Committee recommended that it be given unrestricted access to Authority information.
That is the position of the Opposition and the Democrats. It went on:

The Committee recognises that this recommendation may not be fully acceptable to the Government and may not be fully implemented. Accordingly, the Committee proposes the following, which it regards as a second best, but still acceptable, solution. In proposing this solution, the Committee has taken into account its recommendation in paragraph 6.77 that there be an Inspector-General with unrestricted access to Authority information who will be able to deal with individual complaints.
The report went on:

The Committee understands that the main concern of the Government and the IGC is over the Committee's access to information that is variously described as `sensitive' or `operational'. The Committee considers that the NCA Act should be amended to define this category of information.

7.59The Committee regards the formula in the Spindler Bill . . . as an appropriate definition of `sensitive information'. If the Committee's primary recommendation for amendment of section 51 is unacceptable to Government, the Committee recommends that this formula be inserted into section 51 to define the information which the Authority is not obliged to provide to the Committee.

7.60As noted in paragraph 7.47 above, a dispute may arise between the Committee and the Authority over whether a piece of information fits within this definition. The Committee endorses the use of a third party to arbitrate these disputes.
It is precisely what we provide for in this Bill—the Inspector-General to give the guidance in that matter. It continues:
For the reasons given in paragraph 7.55 above, the Committee considers that the Commonwealth Minister with portfolio responsibility for the Authority should be the arbiter.

We distinguish between guidance, which should be given by the Inspector-General, and the final determiner, who will be the Commonwealth Minister with portfolio responsibility for the Authority—namely, the Commonwealth Attorney-General. I believe that we have a situation where what is embodied in this Bill is described by the Committee itself, admittedly as second best, as an acceptable solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not interested in what is acceptable; we want first best.

—I am afraid that it is not simply a matter for the parliamentary Committee to come to this Parliament and assert what it wants. There is a responsibility vested in the Intergovernmental Committee to ensure that this Authority is a creature sustained by the support of all governments and jurisdictions throughout Australia. The view of the IGC is important. It has adamantly expressed that view. The Federal Government has a coincident view that information of the sort that is described as sensitive should not be put in the hands of the parliamentary Committee. That is the position of the Government to which we adhere. Therefore, I indicate that when it comes to the committee stage the Government will not be accepting the amendments that will be put forward.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 8, page 4, paragraph (c), after proposed subsection 51(3A), add the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "(3B) For the avoidance of doubt, and without prejudice to the effect of any other law, it is declared that this section does not affect:

TAB.TAB: (a)the presentation or submission of a document, or the giving of evidence, to the Parliamentary Joint Committee; or
(b)the operation of a lawful order of the Parliamentary Joint Committee.".

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 9, page 4, paragraph (c), proposed subsection 55(2), line 23, omit "request", substitute "require".

3.Clause 9, page 4, paragraph (c), proposed subsection 55(2), line 27, omit "except to the extent that it contains, or is, sensitive information", substitute "and the Chairperson must comply with the requirement".

In many respects the first amendment is a declaratory amendment. It clarifies the position which has been in some dispute between the National Crime Authority, the Attorney-General, the Solicitor-General and, on the side of the angels, the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority and the Clerk of the Senate. I might refer to the thirty-sixth report of the Senate Committee of Privileges. The report says:
More generally in relation to secrecy provisions, the exchanges of advice on this subject, referred to at paragraph 3.22—
which I will come to shortly—

which were conducted between August 1990 and August 1991, are reproduced in the explanatory memorandum accompanying the Parliamentary Privileges Amendment (Effect of Other Laws) Bill 1991 introduced by Senator Crichton-Browne. The purpose of this bill is to declare, for the avoidance of doubt, that the powers, privileges and immunities of each House of Parliament, and of the members and committees of each House, are not affected by a provision of a law other than the Parliamentary Privileges Act except to the extent that the provision expressly provides that those powers, privileges and immunities are affected. Parliament should give urgent and serious priority to considering legislation of this kind.
In many respects, that is the effect of this amendment. It has been an absolute nonsense up until this point to argue differently.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to refer to recommendation 5 of this same report, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Parliament should give urgent and serious priority to considering legislation such as the Parliamentary Privileges Amendment (Effect of Other Laws) Bill 1991.
While I am on my feet I would like to read a further paragraph of the report. The report states:

The PJC itself, having grappled with the narrow interpretation of sections 51 and 55 of the National Crime Authority Act, has recommended that the situation be clarified, and Senators Crichton-Browne and Spindler—both members of the PJC—have separately introduced bills to amend the NCA Act in an effort to deal with the problem. The Committee also notes that the Government proposes to introduce legislation to clarify the relationship between the NCA and the PJC, based on recommendations of the Inter-Governmental Committee rather than those of the PJC. The Government has indicated, however, that it intends to formulate amendments to the Act "in a manner acceptable to the Government, the States and Territories, the Parliamentary Joint Committee, and the Parliament as a whole", to address the problem. The Committee of Privileges looks forward to the legislative resolution of the difficulties which have arisen.
I trust that these amendments now clarify that position. The Committee will now be in a position to receive all information, including information of a sensitive nature.

PARA.TAB: If these amendments were in place now the Committee would not be capable and competent to deal with the motion given to it by the Senate in respect of its present reference—that is, the reference relating to the relationship between the National Crime Authority and James McCartney Anderson. It would be in this position for a number of reasons, not to mention the definition of `reputation'. When one is dealing with personalities and characters such as James McCartney Anderson, Abraham Saffron and a number of other people, if this proposed Bill were in place there would be no flexibility and we would not be able to receive the sort of information that we are receiving now and, therefore, we would not be capable of in any way monitoring the National Crime Authority.

One of the problems that we have had thus far is that until the last two chairmen, members of the Authority have refused to disclose what they describe as operational matters. I might give an example. A previous chairman of the Authority resigned in circumstances which led the Committee to make some tentative and superficial inquiries. The Committee simply wanted to know what were the circumstances surrounding the resignation of the Chairman of the National Crime Authority. We were told that we could not have access to that information because to do so would be to disclose whether or not it was an operation, and to do that would breach the secrecy provisions of the Act. That is the level of the nonsense that has been taking place with the National Crime Authority using the present provisions in a way that I am sure were never intended.

I refer Senator Tate to the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority entitled Who is to Guard the Guards?. If he reads the report carefully he will discover that the IGC's role was considered. It is not without significance to note that the Victorian Council for Civil Liberties commented that it saw the Committee, not the IGC or the Minister, as the body to which the Authority was accountable. The report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Assistant Commissioner Graham Sinclair of the Victoria Police made a similar point:

PARA.TAB: I think the National Crime Authority needs to be seen to be accountable, and not just accountable to the IGC. In my view, the IGC is a body that has a greater vested interest in the National Crime Authority. I do not mean that disrespectfully. You are talking about relevant Ministers and so forth, some of whose staff are employed with the Authority from time to time. To me, this Committee stands much further away from any taint of vested interest in the Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at the way the IGC had conducted itself, we observed the following:
This claim by the IGC—
when it says that it has a better line of responsibility—
is difficult to reconcile with the limited activities of the IGC. In the period July 1984 to October 1991, the IGC met on only 16 occasions.
The report went on to say:

For example, in 1989-90 financial year the IGC met only once. Yet during this period the Authority was embroiled in major controversies, including those relating to the operation of its Adelaide office and the abrupt resignation of its Chairman. The Committee is alarmed at the infrequent meetings of the body claiming to provide `effective oversight' over the Authority. More adequate supervision by the IGC would have prevented the controversies arising in the first place.
The report continues:

As indicated in chapter 3, the Authority's history has not been problem-free. The IGC appears to have done little if anything to address the problems. As far as the Committee can determine, the IGC made no contribution to giving the Authority strategic direction. Future Directions seems to have originated quite independently of the IGC. No management reviews have been initiated by the IGC. No formal assessments have been made by the IGC of the Authority's performance.

That is the contribution that the IGC has made. I remind the Minister, I hope without malice, that the police Ministers in the various States have their own problems in terms of managing the affairs of their own police departments. The history of the police department in Queensland is well known. The Commissioner of Police is now in gaol. The history of the New South Wales police force is well known and well documented. If the evidence being disclosed through ICAC is only partially true, it gives an indication of the incompetence of various police Ministers in managing and supervising their police forces.

PARA.TAB: As for the Western Australian police force, I need say no more than that the Commissioner of Police recently had the office of the Deputy Commissioner of Police bugged so as to monitor his conversations. That makes me wonder what capacity the various police Ministers have for the management of their own affairs, never mind their supervision of the NCA. It would be an absolute nonsense for the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority not to have access to all information.

I was very interested to hear Senator Tate's vigorous defence of the IGC. I well remember—and I must go back to the Hansard some time—his absolute outrage and indignation, when he was Chairman of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, that the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General had announced by press statement that amendments were going to be made to the National Companies and Securities Commission legislation. He promptly stood up and gave notice of an intention for a reference to the Legal and Constitutional Committee. Who did this lot think they were, telling the Federal Parliament what the legislation was going to be! At that stage, Senator Tate was on the side of the angels.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm a Minister now.

—Senator Tate is a Minister now. If that explains the difference, that explains the quantum leap in his logic. The truth is that the IGC is not the appropriate body to perform the supervision, the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority is. It is quite impossible for the Committee to function if the information provided to it is filtered to the point of definition, as is being offered in this legislation. As I say, to have `reputation' as a definition makes it almost impossible to deal with any reference. Yet the Government would have it that the Committee has some sort of capacity to monitor the National Crime Authority without information. I think that makes an absolute nonsense of the proposition. Therefore, we move these amendments requiring the National Crime Authority to provide the Committee with the relevant information.

PARA.TAB: I will not repeat what I said before about the responsibility of members of parliament and their accountability, the consequences of misconduct and the inappropriate releasing of in camera evidence—or evidence of any nature. I say this to Senator Tate: the sanctions are the Parliament and the wider community. From a public point of view, it is not important what information is acquired by members of the Committee. What is material and of consequence is what it does with that information. There is no evidence that the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority has disclosed any information of a nature which would even embarrass witnesses—except for two members of the Authority who told lies to the Committee. For their sins, they were found out, as was disclosed in the Privileges Committee.

If Senator Tate is serious about having proper supervision and monitoring—a proper watchdog—of the Authority, which he himself has observed has extraordinary and most unusual powers of the type that, a decade ago, would never have been thought to be given to any such body by the Parliament, then it has to be a body that understands how the Authority functions. The IGC does not do it. It is a nonsense to suggest that section 59, for instance, is complied with. The only way that the NCA can get its references is through the police Ministers. To obtain those references, it discloses very detailed and confidential information so as to be able to make sensible judgments. I ask Senator Tate to allow these amendments to prevail.
Progress reported.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That standing order 64 be suspended to allow new business to be commenced after the question for the adjournment of the Senate is first put this day.
Consideration resumed.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3 moved by Senator Crichton-Browne on behalf of the Opposition are virtually identical to amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3 that the Democrats have circulated. The Democrats will therefore support the amendments moved by Senator Crichton-Browne on behalf of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that all honourable senators will be relieved to hear that I do not intend to repeat the very comprehensive and acute analysis of the situation that was provided to the chamber by Senator Crichton-Browne. I simply add that I find it somewhat astounding and deplorable that a Minister who is a member of this House is prepared to be a party to legislation which hobbles the work of a parliamentary committee that has been charged with the duty to supervise, monitor and critically assess the work of a body that has been established by this Parliament. Let me emphasise that the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority has been established by this Parliament for that express purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Otherwise there would have been no Authority.

—Indeed. It seems to me that the Government is saying, `We want that Authority to go its own way, to do essentially what it pleases, and we do not want any supervision by a parliamentary committee that has been charged by this Parliament with that duty'. The Australian Democrats support amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3 as moved by Senator Crichton-Browne.

—Whilst Senator Crichton-Browne might have put a very acute and well argued case, it was not ultimately persuasive as far as the Government is concerned. We still believe that the very wide range of material which the Opposition and the Democrats wish to flow to the parliamentary Committee is unwarranted.

PARA.TAB: It is quite evident from Senator Crichton-Browne's contribution that this arises from a series of incidents, perhaps the most dramatic episode being the inquiry which the parliamentary Committee wished to undertake into the resignation of Mr Faris as chairperson of the National Crime Authority. It seems to me that, in that situation, a legitimate question arose as to who should determine the sort of information that might flow to the Committee.

That is why we believe that this Bill—embodying, as it does, what is called, even by the parliamentary Committee, a second best but, nevertheless, acceptable provision for the Federal Minister responsible to this Parliament to determine whether information is sensitive or not on the advice of the Inspector-General—is a way to deal with this sort of situation. Had it been in place, I believe it would have aided the Committee in its investigation into the circumstances surrounding the resignation, which led to that terrible friction and souring of the relationship between the National Crime Authority and the parliamentary Committee with which we are all familiar.

I believe that this series of amendments put by the Opposition is, in a sense, consequential on amendment No. 4. That is the core of the matter. Whilst for convenience we are dealing with them in this particular way, the Government believes that the interlinking of all these amendments is such that, in accordance with all my previous statements, we will oppose this particular series of amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not wish to labour this point past that which is necessary, but just for the record let me make it clear that these amendments do not spring from frustration arising from anything to do with Mr Faris and his resignation. I might add that when we were taking evidence for the report Who is to guard the guards? I was very tempted to withdraw from receiving further evidence because it was a total waste of time trying to get sufficient sensible, intelligent, detailed information about the functioning of the National Crime Authority. It was almost impossible. In fact, the only evidence we got that was material, in my view, was evidence from people outside the National Crime Authority. We got very little information from the National Crime Authority which was comprehensible, intelligent and of some assistance.

PARA.TAB: While I would not wish to again have the Minister assume that because I am raising the matter of the current reference that that is again a reason, I just give it by way of example. We are dealing with the matter of James McCartney Anderson's relationship with the National Crime Authority. He was a protected witness—a very expensive one—and a primary witness in reference No. 1, which was inquiring into the activities of one Abraham Saffron. McCartney Anderson is a well-known criminal in New South Wales crime circles. Mr Saffron's reputation seems to precede him in most places.

I ask the Minister, with respect: how does he possibly imagine that we can inquire, as the Senate has unanimously resolved that we should, into the relationship between Anderson and the National Crime Authority—a very complicated and detailed relationship—if we are to be fettered by the definition that he is proffering as the division between us and the information? It would be totally impossible. I have to say with respect to Senator Tate that if the Government does not want supervision of the National Crime Authority, vote against our amendments. But if it wants decent, reasonable, mature, considered deliberation and examination of the National Crime Authority by the Parliament that created it in the first place, it will support our amendments.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Clause 9, pages 4 and 5, paragraph (c), lines 28 (page 4) to line 7 (page 5), proposed subsections 55(3), (4), (5) and (6), omit the subsections, substitute the following subsections:

PARA.TAB: "(3)If the Committee, or a member of the Committee, considers that it is necessary, in a report to the Parliament or otherwise, to disclose:

TAB.TAB: (a)oral evidence taken by the Committee in camera, from persons who, at the time they gave evidence, were officers of the Authority or to provide a report of such oral evidence; or

(b)a document which has been submitted to the Committee by an officer of the Authority and which has been requested by the officer of the Authority or ordered by the Committee to be treated as evidence taken in camera,

SPEECH.PARA: the Committee or the member of the Committee, as the case may be, must inform the Chairperson in writing of the evidence or the document proposed to be disclosed or provided.

PARA.TAB: "(4)The Chairperson may, within 14 days after a proposal under subsection (3) has been provided to the Chairperson by the Committee, certify, by writing signed by the Chairperson and provided to the Committee, that the evidence or a document proposed to be disclosed contains or is sensitive information.

"(5)If a certificate has been provided by the Chairperson to the Committee in accordance with subsection (4), the Committee or a member of the Committee must not, in a report to Parliament or otherwise, except in accordance with subsection (9), (10) or (11), publish or disclose any evidence or document which is the subject of that certificate.

TAB.TAB: (a)the Committee makes a decision that evidence or a document of the kind described in subsection (3) should not be disclosed in a report to Parliament; or
(b)the Chairperson provides a certificate under subsection (4) in relation to evidence or a document,

SPEECH.PARA: then, if a member of the Committee so requests, the Committee must refer the evidence or document to which the decision or certificate relates to a Judge of the Federal Court.

PARA.TAB: "(7)Within 30 days after evidence or a document has been referred to a Judge under subsection (6), the Judge must determine, in writing, whether the evidence or document contains or is sensitive information.

"(8)For the purpose of making a determination under subsection (7), a Judge may hear submissions by members of the Committee and by the Chairperson, and may otherwise obtain information in any manner the Judge considers appropriate, but must not make public any document or information obtained for that purpose.

"(9)Where a Judge determines under subsection (7) that the evidence or document does not contain, or is not sensitive information, that evidence or document may be disclosed in a report to Parliament by the Committee or in a special report to Parliament by a member of the Committee or published generally.

"(10)A special report by a member of the Committee under subsection (9) may be attached to a report by the Committee or may be presented to each House of the Parliament in the absence of a report by the Committee.

TAB.TAB: If the Committee, or a member of the Committee, considers that a matter relating to the Authority requires remedial action, the Committee may make a report, which may include sensitive information, to the Minister.

If the Committee, or a member of the Committee, makes a report to the Minister under subsection (11), the Committee must report to each House of the Parliament the fact that the Committee has made that report.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is based in large measure—as, indeed, amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3 were—on my private member's Bill, which was received by the Committee and acknowledged as such with approval in its report Who is to guard the guards?. The amendment essentially deals with the capacity of the Committee to disclose information that it has received at its request from the NCA. It acknowledges that some of the information received may be potentially sensitive material within the definition specified in the Bill. It acknowledges that the National Crime Authority chairperson should be given the right to certify information that is requested by the Committee as sensitive. If the Committee then wishes to pursue its case, believing that the information—notwithstanding that it is sensitive—is required for the proper discharge of its duties, then this dispute shall be adjudicated by a judge of the Federal Court.

PARA.TAB: The amendment requires that the judge must determine in writing within 30 days after this evidence or a document has been referred to him or her, and that the judge may, in the course of his or her deliberations, hear submissions from the members of the Committee or the chairperson of the NCA. Where the judge determines that the evidence does not contain, or is not, sensitive information, then the document or evidence may be disclosed in Parliament by the Committee, by a member of the Committee or published generally.

I believe that this provision deals very adequately with the dangers that the Minister has outlined could be inherent in the Committee obtaining this information. It acknowledges that the Committee has a responsibility not to disclose outside its sphere of activity information that it has received. But as I have said before, it is important that the decision not be made within the political arena for political reasons. The examples where this has been done and where the matter has been treated as a political football are legion. I believe, therefore, that the provision for a judge of the Federal Court to make this decision is soundly based.

I would also ask the Committee to note that special provision is made in this amendment for an individual member of the Committee to be able to make such disclosures or to provide such reports. It is quite clear that, even within a committee, the tyranny of the majority may prevent a particular matter being brought forward which an individual member of the Committee believes is extremely important to be dealt with by Parliament or by the Minister.

I have referred previously—and I briefly repeat it—to the fact that there are also two provisions which would enable the Committee or individual members of the Committee, even if the judge has decided that the material is sensitive and may not be disclosed, to transmit this material to the Minister with a request that some remedial action be taken. I believe that satisfies the public policy requirement that sensitive material, once it is classified as such, could not or should not be simply buried but should be transmitted to the Minister properly in the political sphere to take appropriate remedial action. I commend this amendment to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will oppose this amendment, basically for the extensive and so far not persuasive reasons that I have advanced to the Committee in relation to the basic thrust of these amendments, which is to require sensitive information to be disclosed to the Parliamentary Joint Committee.

PARA.TAB: In so far as there is a role for a Federal Court judge to deal with the question of further publication beyond the Committee, I think it would be of great interest to know the views of the Federal Court judges as to the imposition of this particular role upon them. Whilst it has some character of weighing up arguments as to whether information is properly described as sensitive or not, and therefore has some of the trappings of a judicial exercise—an exercise of judicial power—it really seems to be the sort of exercise which is properly, in our view, undertaken by a responsible Minister, such as the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth of Australia, who would be answerable to the Parliament and thence to the electorate for any determination to be made in relation to this matter. We believe it is more a matter for which a person ought to take political responsibility as a responsible Minister in an elected government than a decision to be made by a non-elected member of the Federal Court Bench. For those reasons, basically, we will oppose this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will oppose this amendment also. In saying that, I foreshadow our amendment No. 4, which is not dissimilar in principle, thrust and purpose.

PARA.TAB: Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments are not dissimilar. The glaring distinction between the two is that our amendment proposes that the Attorney-General make the primary judgment in respect of this matter.

PARA.TAB: It is not improperly disclosing any committee deliberations to say that Senator Spindler put the very persuasive point that the arbitrator, if I may describe it as that, not be a politician but rather be an independent person above the political system. I was rather attracted to that proposition, but the Committee ultimately took the view that the responsibility ought properly to rest with the Attorney-General and, as Senator Tate says, be accountable to the Parliament, whatever sanction that might entail in the event that he makes these decisions, and ultimately to the electorate. We will oppose the amendment for that reason.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Clause 9, pages 4 and 5, paragraph (c), proposed subsections 55(3), (4), (5) and (6), page 4 (line 28) to page 5 (line 7), omit the proposed subsections, substitute the following subsections:

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Clause 10, page 6, proposed paragraph 55AD(1)(b), line 31, omit "55(5)", substitute "55(8)".
6.Clause 10, page 10, proposed section 55AL, line 26, omit "55(5)", substitute "55(8)".

The proposed subsection in my amendment No. 4 sets out the steps that are to be taken when the Committee or members of the Committee wish to disclose in camera evidence, presumably by way of a report. I will not go on at length other than to quickly recap the processes proposed in that amendment. Firstly, there is the informing of the chairperson of the evidence or documents that are proposed to be disclosed under subsection 55(3). The chairperson may then, within 14 days, certify to the Committee that the information required is of a sensitive nature within the definition of subsection 55(4), and the Committee is then prevented from disclosing the evidence or documents except as permitted by subsections (10) or (12).

PARA.TAB: If a member of the Committee so requests, the evidence or document must be referred to the Minister under proposed subsection 55(6). The Minister then has 14 days to determine whether the document or the evidence contains sensitive information. The Minister, before making that determination, may require the Inspector-General to make inquiries as to whether the information is sensitive. If the Minister determines that the information is not sensitive, it may be disclosed by the Committee in a report to the Parliament or a special report to the Parliament by a member of the Committee—that is, contemplating a minority report in most cases.

If the Committee considers that a matter relating to the NCA requires remedial action, it may make a report to the Minister which can include sensitive information. But, when such a report is made, the fact that it has been made must be reported to both Houses of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment to Opposition amendment No. 4, clause 9, proposed subsection 55(3), after paragraph (b), add the following word and paragraph:
"or (c) any information in a report of the Inspector-General under paragraph 55AT(1)(d);".

This amendment to the Opposition's amendment is intended simply to ensure that subsequent amendments I will be moving on behalf of the Democrats do not create a gap in as much as a report of the Inspector-General that is transmitted to the Committee should not be able to be disclosed by the Committee unless consideration is given to whether or not the information contained therein is sensitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even with the amendment moved by Senator Spindler we do not find the basic tenor of the Opposition's amendment improved. I repeat: the Opposition's amendment has the consequence that sensitive information could be passed to the Committee; that is, information the disclosure of which might prejudice the safety or reputation of a person, the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence, the effectiveness of an investigation by the Authority, or the operations of law enforcement agencies.

PARA.TAB: I believe I have said sufficient in this debate to indicate that the Government does not support the disclosure of such information to the Parliamentary Joint Committee. Therefore we do not support the Opposition's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just indicate that we support the very sensible amendment proposed by Senator Spindler.
—The question is that Senator Spindler's amendment to the Opposition's proposed amendment No. 4 be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express regret that the Opposition has seen fit not to support the referral to a Federal Court judge who is above the political hurly-burly. It remains for the Democrats to support the basic thrust of the Opposition's amendment No. 4.
—The question is that the three amendments, one of which has been amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Clause 10, page 7, proposed subsection 55AE(3), line 17, omit "must", substitute "may".
6.Clause 10, page 7, proposed paragraph 55AE(4)(c), line 26, omit the paragraph.
7.Clause 10, page 8, proposed paragraph 55AG(2)(a), line 13, after "made", insert ", other than complaints made before the enactment of this section".
8.Clause 10, page 9, proposed section 55AH, line 18, omit "and the Chairperson", substitute ", the Chairperson and the Parliamentary Joint Committee".
9.Clause 10, page 10, proposed section 55AL, lines 26 and 27, omit "and Chairperson", substitute ", the Chairperson and the Parliamentary Joint Committee".
10.Clause 10, page 14, proposed paragraph 55AT(1)(d), line 33, omit "and the Chairperson", substitute ", the Chairperson and the Parliamentary Joint Committee".
11.Clause 10, page 15, proposed paragraph 55AV(2)(c), line 25, omit "and Chairperson", substitute ", the Chairperson and the Parliamentary Joint Committee".

These amendments address the question of what happens to the reports of the Inspector-General, the office that is established by the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. The amendments seek to address two matters. In a number of clauses of the Bill, it is provided that the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority must convey complaints directly to the Inspector-General. That includes complaints that the Committee has received from constituents.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats feel that the Committee should be in a position to examine those complaints and, if it decides that it is beyond its capacity—and in most cases it will be—to examine those complaints and to deal with them exhaustively, then hand them on to the Inspector-General. When a constituent makes a complaint about the National Crime Authority to the parliamentary Committee, which has been charged with a duty by Parliament to supervise, examine and monitor the work of the Authority, then the Committee should not be simply placed in the position of being a letterbox and a `hander-on'. It must be enabled to exercise its discretion as to what needs to be done about the complaint. Amendment Nos 5, 6 and 7 address that matter.

The remainder of the amendments deal with the question of reports being submitted by the Inspector-General to the chairperson of the NCA—in some cases to the Minister. Almost pointedly, the parliamentary Committee is omitted from those bodies that receive copies of reports of the Inspector-General. My remaining amendments seek to remedy that. I believe it is essential, if the Committee is to continue to fulfil its functions, that it be given reports of complaints about the Authority, about the body that it has been charged to supervise, when the report is made by the office of the Inspector-General which has been established to deal with such complaints.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the amendments. Senator Spindler has articulated with persuasion the fact that the amendments strengthen the role of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. That is quite right. Save for this amendment, it may well have developed into a process where the Committee—to use Senator Spindler's expression—would become a letterbox, and there may be certain matters in the form of a complaint that the Committee may wish to deal with as a reference. This ensures that the Committee has a capacity to make judgments about how it deals with the various complaints.

PARA.TAB: The reason we support the proposition in the first place is that we are not competent by and large to deal with very many of the complaints that come before us. But there will be occasions where we may wish to look at the matter further. Senator Spindler is also right when he touches upon the starkly obvious point that the Joint Committee was left off the mailing list of the Inspector-General. In many ways, it reflects the rather vain and antagonistic view of the IGC towards the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority.

I do in part resent the attitude of the various State Ministers who make up the IGC with their arrogance and supercilious approach to our Committee. As I said at the beginning, it just shows what a nonsense their concern is for proper scrutiny when they have the audacity to argue that the Joint Committee ought to be abolished when, of course, the Committee is a body of this Parliament which created the National Crime Authority in the first place.

I conclude by reminding Senator Tate that the reason the IGC was formed was not only as a watching brief for the National Crime Authority but also as a form of placating the various antagonistic and parochial State Ministers who were concerned not to lose any of their powers. However, having said that, let it be recorded that I was the only member of the Federal Parliament from any party who voted against the National Crime Authority legislation when it was introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point made by Senator Spindler has some force in relation to the question of whether a complaint that is received by a body or person must be transferred to the Inspector-General. Whilst the Government will not accept the amendment, we will not be dividing on it.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
