PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Collins) proposed:
That the amendments made by the House of Representatives be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek your guidance. Are we speaking about the amendments to Senator Harradine's amendment to the Bill?
—That is correct.

—The Democrats will not be supporting those amendments. We will be sticking with what we believe is Senator Harradine's better amendment. Senator Harradine's amendment, we think, achieved a couple of things. In fact, what it did achieve was significant and very useful for the Parliament. It achieved having codes of standard which are usually self-regulatory and do not come normally before the Parliament. That will remain, as I understand, in the Government's amendments. It achieved having those codes of practice and standards amendable by the Parliament. That would still be retained, as I understand it, in the Government's amendments.

PARA.TAB: What the Government's amendments would do, though, is to take away from the Parliament the automatic amendment of a code or standard if a motion were put up to amend it and it was not dealt with by both Houses. What that would do, of course, would be to force both Houses to deal with any motion amending a code or standard. So, even though the Government's amendments maintain a lot of the good things about Senator Harradine's amendment—and we are very pleased to see that—we would still rather stick with Senator Harradine's amendments. So we will not be supporting the Government's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the concern of the Democrats on this matter, but I honestly do not think that they have sufficiently considered the horrendous implications of Senator Harradine's amendment—and I am not talking about pay TV. In fact, I hope that Senator Bourne has Senator Harradine's amendment in front of her while I go through the problems with it.

PARA.TAB: The problems with Senator Harradine's amendment go far beyond pay television; they go to the heart of proper democratic process. The reason I make that comment is that Senator Bourne said that Senator Harradine's amendment had the virtue, the value, of forcing the Houses to deal with an issue. The difficulty is that not only does it not do anything of the sort but it also has the horrendous implication that law will be made by both Houses literally doing nothing at all. Simply by Senator Harradine or any other senator in the Senate or indeed—and perhaps even Senator Harradine should consider this—a member of the House of Representatives giving a notice of motion will law be made, because neither House does anything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why I said it.

—I said last night that it was unprecedented. Mr Smith, the shadow Minister, sought his own independent advice from the parliamentary research service. He tabled that advice an hour ago in the House of Representatives, and the last paragraph of that advice says it all.

PARA.TAB: I hope the Committee understands that we are not talking here about disallowing regulations. Senator Harradine's amendment has changed that. The original section 128—and this is why I would like to return to that, but in sweet reasonableness to Senator Harradine we are not doing that—made these codes of practice disallowable instruments subjected to the normal procedures of this Parliament. Senator Harradine's amendment removes the original section 128 and replaces it with a power to make law; to actually draft these codes of practice here in the Senate or in the House of Representatives and make them law. This is the problem. Part (2) of Senator Harradine's amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: If notice of a motion for an amendment to a standard or code of practice is given in a House—
a House; either House—
and within 15 sitting days of that House after the notice has been given:
(a) the notice has not been withdrawn—
and, of course, the notice would not be withdrawn—
and the motion has not been called on . . .
In other words, nothing has happened. Part (2) continues:
. . . the amendment specified in the motion shall then be taken to have been agreed to by that House.
It passes the Senate without a single word of debate. The problem then is that it goes to the House of Representatives, or the other way around. Part (3) of the amendment states:
If a House agrees to an amendment—
and we have agreed to it by doing nothing under part (2), because nothing has happened; all that has happened is that the Senate has a notice of motion—
in accordance with subsection (1), or is taken to have agreed to an amendment pursuant to subsection (2) . . .

In other words, it is simply deemed to have been agreed because nothing has happened—no debate; nothing. If 15 sitting days go by in the other House and nothing happens, the amendment is taken to have been agreed to. I said last night that this was an horrendous amendment and I was taken to task for describing it as such. It is, and the horror of it has nothing to do with pay TV or anything else. This is law of a breathtaking kind.

PARA.TAB: This is the scenario under the Harradine amendment. If Senator Harradine or anyone else comes into this House, and it can be done on a daily basis, jumps to his feet at 10 o'clock in the morning with a cast of thousands present, as we have every morning in here, and gives a notice of motion that says, `I move that Neighbours shall be banned from television'—it is on the Notice Paper under this amendment and nothing else may happen for 15 sitting days—if there is no debate, no motion actually moved, under Senator Harradine's amendment, it becomes deemed to have passed the Senate.

It then goes to the House of Representatives and under the next part of the amendment, part (3), if nothing happens in the House of Representatives, it becomes law of Australia. Vigilance would be required. This is an horrendous amendment. I said this last night and it is accurately described.

Despite the soft words of Senator Harradine saying that people will only come in once a year or just at the end of the year as a clean-up exercise, I draw the attention of the Committee again to the amendment. There is nothing to stop a senator, or indeed a member, coming into the House every single sitting day of the Parliament and giving notice of motion to amend this, that or something else that is a code of practice. In fact, by amendment they can totally rewrite it.

In other words, we are not disallowing regulations; we are making law in this amendment. After notice of motion is given in the Senate or in the House of Representatives, by the simple fact that nothing else happens after 15 sitting days have elapsed in both Houses, it becomes law. How can anybody reasonably describe that as being democratic?

The last thing I wanted was to have this Bill amended at all in the House of Representatives. We were prepared to make great concessions in terms of what was amended in this Bill. The last thing I wanted was for this to have to come back to this chamber. I am sick of it; everybody is sick of it.

The implications for democracy and the democratic process are so profound in this amendment that it simply cannot be allowed to happen. We will not allow it to happen. We will not proceed with this legislation if this is carried. We cannot allow that to happen. I ask honourable senators to read Senator Harradine's amendment again.

I say honestly: how can the Australian Democrats with their philosophy of democratic government support this? How could they support any proposition which says that, by simply giving notice of motion—we do it 20 times every morning in here—it becomes the law of Australia without another word of debate by virtue of the fact that nothing else happens? That is an extraordinary proposition for the Committee to carry.

I really do plead with the Committee to consider the implications of parts (2) and (3) of the amendment. Technically, this does not even have to go to the other House. If that House does not get notice of it, it has to be put on the Notice Paper by a member of the other place. It is a profoundly undemocratic amendment. We cannot allow a member or senator in this Parliament to stand in his or her place and give a notice of motion which then, by simple virtue of the fact that nothing else happens, becomes a law of Australia. That is the effect of Senator Harradine's amendment.

I apologise to the Committee for going on at some length about this, as I did last night. I have not used the word `fundamental' once, but I do want to get across to the Committee the real horror of the total destruction of the democratic process which is wrought by this amendment.

I accept Senator Bourne at her word. I know her well enough to know that. She has said that this amendment has to be supported because it forces the Parliament to take some action. The Government amendment does that, and that is why we have amended the Bill. The profound problem with Senator Harradine's amendment is that it does exactly the reverse: it removes the obligation from either House to do anything. By the simple fact that nothing is done, a law is made by one member of this Parliament in either House simply giving notice of motion that a law be made.

I would like any honourable senator to deny that this is true, but, as I said last night, even though Senator Walters may not be with us after the next election, I predict now that these notices of motion will be given in the Senate on a regular basis. The only way that we can stop this from becoming law is by absolute vigilance and by depending on every occasion on nothing slipping through with all of the horrendous amount of business that these Houses carry. If we are not absolutely vigilant and do not scrupulously examine the notices of motion given every day either here or in the House of Representatives, and the 15 days elapses in both Houses with nothing else happening, this Parliament will have made a law which has profound implications for the broadcasting industry and the people who watch television in this country without a single word of debate having occurred in either House of Parliament.

I really am asking the Democrats to reconsider what they have in front of them and to have a look at parts (2) and (3). I listened to every word the shadow Minister, Mr Smith, said in the House of Representatives. He sought his own independent advice from the parliamentary legislative research department. He tabled it in the House of Representatives. I have it here and I am happy to table it in the chamber. It confirms precisely what I have said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we have a copy now?

—Certainly. I am happy to table it. This is the advice the shadow Minister sought and received. Honourable senators do not have to read all of it; they only have to read the final paragraph. It confirms the advice. They have only to read clauses (2) and (3) of Senator Harradine's amendment. If nothing happens, we make law. It is a democratic nonsense to even suggest that we should pass law which has that effect.

PARA.TAB: I commend the Government's amendment, which retains the model. I would like to go back to section 128 as it stood from the Government, of course, but we have retained the model Senator Harradine has put up except that, in order to make law, we require positive action, taken in both the House of Representatives and the Senate, so that we do not make law by default.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins has gone right over the top tonight. He has stated that my amendment strikes at the heart of proper democratic process. He has stated that there are horrendous implications in my amendment. He has stated that this amendment will mean `the total destruction of the democratic process'. Hyperbole indeed!

PARA.TAB: Let me just deal with what Senator Collins says is the total destruction of the democratic process. He says the total destruction of the democratic process is the provisions of subparagraphs (2) and (3) of my amendment, which are designed to require the Parliament to deal with an amendment which is proposed to the codes of practice and the standards. What is the difference between that and what is currently in the Acts Interpretation Act which deals with the disallowance of regulations?

TALK.START.PARA: —Read Warwick Smith's advice.

—I have read Warwick Smith's advice and I have read it quite clearly. I am saying to the Committee that, in respect of regulations, if a motion for the disallowance of the regulations is not determined within 15 sitting days of that notice being given, that motion is deemed to have been adopted. Thus, by only one chamber doing nothing, we are making laws. One chamber is making laws.
—No, we are making regulations.

—What is a regulation? The Minister knows that a regulation is a law. If somebody breaches a regulation, he is bunged inside if the regulation has a penalty of imprisonment, and he is fined if the regulation has such a penalty. That is a law, is it not? That law is enacted by the Parliament, by the Parliament doing nothing.
—It is not subject to the Senate's Regulations and Ordinances Committee.
—Wait a minute. The Minister is shifting ground now.
—You are not talking about regulations; you are talking about law.

—The Minister makes the point about regulations not being law. They are law, all right. We then get to the situation where, if a regulation is made, a law is made by the bureaucracy and that is tabled in this Parliament. By virtue of the Senate doing nothing about it, it retains its legal status. Is that the total destruction of the democratic process? Of course it is not. That is precisely what I have suggested in this amendment.

PARA.TAB: We come then to the question of whether or not, just by an individual member of the Senate getting up here and moving an amendment to a code of practice or a standard, that code of practice or standard will have been amended. Senator Collins is suggesting that people may not know that there has been an amendment moved and, therefore, it may slip past. What is the bureaucracy doing? There are armies of people within the bureaucracy looking at the notices of motion and what goes into this particular chamber and of course they will know what has been passed here.

The Minister and the Government are striking at the heart of the democratic process. The Minister and the Government clearly do not want the Parliament to deal with a matter which might be of great public importance. A matter which indeed is of great public importance at the present moment is violence on television. It is an area of extreme public importance. The Minister does not want the Parliament to have the ability to deal with that matter. He does not want it at all.

What the Minister says is false. He says that my amendment will prevent the television industry from consulting with the community. That is false and the Minister knows it is false because the industry is required, under the Broadcasting Services Act, to undertake those consultations. The Minister knows that so why did he say it? Is he suggesting that the television industry is going to breach the law simply because of this amendment? Is he suggesting that the Australian Broadcasting Authority—Brian Johns—is going to break the law just because of this amendment? Is he implying that? Is he saying that? That is what he has just said. I have more respect for both the industry and Mr Johns than to agree with that suggestion.

I come back to the suggestion the Minister has made about Warwick Smith's advice. The first part of Warwick Smith's advice from the Legislative Research Service is irrelevant because the Government is agreeing to the Parliament doing something on codes of practice and program standards. The Minister points to the last part of the advice which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed new section 128 follows a similar method, but there are significant differences. Firstly, the period in which regulations can be disallowed under the Acts Interpretation Act is limited to a short period after they are made. The proposed new section 128 does not provide for the standards or codes to be laid before the Houses shortly after they are made, and a motion for amendment can be made at any time.

One of the very valid reasons for not having them laid before the Parliament automatically is the very reason that I advanced when I proposed this amendment; that is, I do not envisage, nor do I expect in the amendment, that automatically these matters should come before the Parliament as do regulations. I do not envisage that at all, and that was quite a deliberate instruction of mine. The final paragraph says:

Secondly, disallowance is a negative act, and it is reasonable for a disallowance to take place unless there is positive support for the regulation expressed by the House. An amendment is a positive act, which makes a positive change, and it is arguable that amendments should only be made upon a positive vote of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—The Minister says `Hear, hear!', but what about regulations? Regulations are amended by the bureaucracy.
—And disallowed by this chamber.

—No. By the House doing nothing, they continue with legal effect. The Minister is saying that the bureaucracy can amend laws but the Parliament, because it does nothing about them, is acting contrary to the proper democratic process. That is extraordinary.

PARA.TAB: If there is an amendment to a regulation it is tabled here, and a motion can be moved for the disallowance of that amended regulation. Indeed, a motion can be moved to excise a discrete part of that regulation and, if that motion is not attended to or disposed of within 15 sitting days, it is adopted. Therefore, the regulation is amended by the Senate doing nothing. That gives the lie to the Minister's whole proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid not.
—It does. Can the Minister tell me how it does not?
—I will in a minute.
—I would like to hear it. The Minister should address that point and tell me the number of occasions that this chamber has seen disallowance procedures.
—I chaired Regs and Ordinances so I know a bit about it.

—I know. The Minister knows that motions have been moved in this chamber in respect of disallowance and the Government has chosen not to bring it on and thus defeat the regulation in a quiet manner. The Government has done that on a number of occasions. So the Minister should tell me the difference. Is that striking at the heart of proper democratic process? Does it have horrendous implications? Of course it does not. My amendment is doing the same thing as the Acts Interpretation Act does for regulations—that is, putting in the 15 days so that the matter will be dealt with—and the Minister says that that means the total destruction of the democratic process. That is absurd.

—I will directly address Senator Harradine's point. We are not talking about disallowing regulations with Senator Harradine's amendment—not even Senator Harradine pretends that—we are talking about making law. Senator Harradine wanted me to address this point and he is not listening. The difference between Acts of parliament and regulations is that the whole disallowance procedure is a method of scrutiny which works very effectively and which is administered by a committee of this Senate that has no peer, that is, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. But the disallowance act is a negative act. It is a means of scrutinising the Executive's delegated powers. If the regulation is disallowed, the status quo is restored—that is the point that Senator Harradine is just totally ignoring—and that is the worst thing that happens.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about passing law with this amendment, not the negative act. Acts of parliament are called Acts of parliament because they take a positive act of the Parliament to create them. The disallowance of regulations that Senator Harradine tries to equate this proposal with is totally non-comparable. The disallowance procedure is an effective scrutiny of Executive delegated decision making.

I might add—and I do not make much secret about where my sympathies lie on this—that the question of our making too much delegated regulation and subordinate legislation is a separate debate. In fact, I would like to debate it one day in the Senate. But that is a separate issue. We are talking about passing Acts of parliament by not a single word of debate being used in either House. I will explain to Senator Harradine how even more absurd his amendment is in terms of its effect—and this advice has just been confirmed.

Under Senator Harradine's amendment, a motion would not even have to go on the Notice Paper in the House of Representatives; it would not even have to go that far. What would happen is this: a senator rises at the giving of notices of motion in the morning, under clause (2) of Senator Harradine's proposal, and gives a notice of motion. It could be about anything. For example, `I give notice that, on the next sitting day, I will move that Neighbours not be allowed to be screened on television'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not do that.
—Senator Harradine says that he will not do that. That is fine. It might not be him; it might be anybody.
—It is a code of practice; it is not an individual item.

—This allows an unfettered discretion to amend that code of practice. As Senator Alston well knows, an amendment can remove every single word from what one is amending and replace it with whatever one likes. We do it every day in second reading amendments in this chamber. We delete all the words and replace them. That is exactly what one can do, and Senator Alston knows that. For example, Senator Harradine's notice of motion could be that he will move that code of practice number so and so be amended to remove—let us take a realistic one—the prohibition on R being broadcast on free to air and replaced with a prohibition on R and M. Let us take a real world example that could be moved in here.

PARA.TAB: Fine. Nothing else happens. The notice of motion is not brought on, and there is not a single word of debate on it. Fifteen sitting days pass and, under Senator Harradine's proposal, that motion is deemed to have passed the Senate, simply because someone has got up and given a notice of motion—without a single word of debate. What then happens is that it becomes a motion of the Senate.

That motion of the Senate—and I refer to part (3) of Senator Harradine's amendment—is then sent to the House of Representatives as a message from the Senate. It does not even go on the Notice Paper; it does not have to under Senator Harradine's amendment. It simply says, `If, after 15 sitting days, the other House does not agree or disagree with it . . . '. So it does not even have to go on the Notice Paper of the House of Representatives to become law. That is absurd.I have just been given that advice and it has been confirmed. That is the effect of this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are living in cuckoo-land. Do you reckon that would really happen in practice?
—Now we are talking—
—It would force them to do something.

—With respect, it does not force anybody to do anything; that is the problem with it. Senator Chapman should read it. It would be a case of vigilance. We and the television industry—it would probably employ a fleet of people just to do it for us in case we missed out—would have to watch the notices of motion given in either House of Parliament every single day in case one of these motions was moved and no further action was taken by the Parliament, and it became law.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine's only defence—and it is a nonsense—is to say that in the real world people would not move motions like that. I tell him what: it gets a bit unreal at times in here, and Senator Harradine cannot guarantee the composition of this Senate or the House of Representatives for the next 12 months—I was going to say 12 years; it could change completely at the next election. How can Senator Harradine guarantee that?

We have an obligation to pass good law in here, not bad law. This is atrocious law. I will put the proposition to Senator Harradine again. His only defence is, `Oh, it wouldn't happen; people wouldn't do that'. I will outline what could happen under Senator Harradine's amendment. We should turn the situation on its head and imagine what would happen if someone wanted to play ducks and drakes with this in the House of Representatives and it got through. Senator Harradine might not like that very much if the Government in the House of Representatives was not of his persuasion.

But let us stick with the Senate under Senator Harradine's amendment. Senator Alston has conceded that this scenario could reasonably happen. A code of practice comes in which says that R is banned from free to air. Senator Harradine comes in and gives notice of motion to the effect that he is amending that to ban M, as well as R, from free to air. Nothing happens in the Senate for 15 days under his amendment—not a word of debate. The motion is not brought on and it becomes deemed to have passed the Senate with no debate. It then goes to the House of Representatives as a message. Unless somebody actively puts it on the Notice Paper in the House of Representatives, it does not even have to go on that House's Notice Paper. After 15 sitting days of its being received as a message by the House of Representatives, without even going on the Notice Paper, it becomes a law of Australia. That is a nonsensical proposition.

I do not want to go on at length about this. I simply want to indicate to Senator Harradine that, as far as the Government is concerned, we cannot allow legislation like this to get past the Senate—and it has nothing to do with pay television. To put up a proposition that we can make law for Australia with not a single word of debate having been uttered other than the notice of motion being given by one senator or member of the House of Representatives is a nonsensical proposition that nobody interested in democracy should support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add something in support of what Senator Collins has said. It seems to me that one of the problems—and I have not had a good look at this; I have just listened to the debate in my room—is that this amendment may have some troubles with the Constitution because it seems to deny the ability of the Governor-General to look at it. Chapter 1, section 1, of the Constitution says:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislative power of the Commonwealth shall be vested in a Federal Parliament, which shall consist of the Queen, a Senate, and a House of Representatives, and which is herein-after called "The Parliament," or "The Parliament of the Commonwealth.
Section 58 of the Constitution says:

When a proposed law passed by both Houses of the Parliament is presented to the Governor-General for the Queen's assent, he shall declare, according to his discretion, but subject to this Constitution, that he assents in the Queen's name, or that he withholds assent, or that he reserves the law for the Queen's pleasure.

PARA.TAB: The Governor-General may return to the house in which it originated any proposed law so presented to him, and may transmit therewith any amendments which he may recommend, and the Houses may deal with the recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposed amendment purports to have primary legislation—Senator Collins mentioned this; it is not delegated legislation but primary legislation—passed by a method which seems to exclude any ability on the part of the Governor-General to look at individual laws as distinct from overall law. It would seem that the Constitution contemplates that any motion to change the primary law would be dealt with by a particular debate in the House. It would then be passed in a formal fashion by both Houses and then sent to the Queen or to her representatives.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to add to what Senator Collins has already said, but we ought to look at this amendment very carefully before we pass it because it might be quite unconstitutional.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with the remarks made by Senator Cooney. It was a brave effort. He spoke about enacting primary legislation by a negative means. Senator Cooney says that this is not delegated legislation. It is less than delegated legislation. We are talking about codes of practice developed by the industry. We are talking about standards developed by the ABA. They are less than delegated legislation. My amendment provides the Parliament with the ability to amend those codes of practice. I think Senator Cooney misunderstood that.
—Warwick Smith supported this in the Reps. Are you going to roll your shadow Minister?
—The Minister should listen to what I am going to say now. He carried on for 10 minutes a while ago.
—You took your full time on both clauses.
—I hope that I am not carrying on. The Minister carried on for 10 minutes, saying—
—You went for 15.

—The Minister carried on for 10 minutes, saying how horrendous it was that we could have a situation where a senator gets up in here and moves an amendment to the code of practice. He gave the example of the code of practice saying, `No R, but M'. He said that a senator could move a motion that that code of practice be amended so that both R and M were restricted before 9.30 p.m., or whenever.

PARA.TAB: The Minister is suggesting that a senator can sneak into the chamber of a morning and move that proposition. Let us say that he does. Let us say that everybody is asleep, including the armies of bureaucracy in his Department. Let us say that they are all asleep.

TALK.START.PARA: —It happens.

—Okay, let us say they are all asleep. After 15 sitting days—they are asleep for these 15 sitting days—under my amendment the proposal is deemed to be carried. We should bear in mind that my amendment enables the Parliament to deal with the matter so that the Government does not put it on the bottom of the Notice Paper. That is what it is for. I might move that motion at the end of next week. Fifteen sitting days takes us to the beginning of March next year. So everybody is not asleep for 15 sitting days; they are asleep for three months.
—What does this have to do with the principle of this mechanism?

—This is what the Minister has said. During that time nobody wakes up to the fact that somebody has stood up in here and moved an amendment to a code of practice so it goes back 15 sitting days in the House of Representatives. A message goes down to the House of Representatives and the Speaker gets up and reads the message. They are all asleep; they do not hear him. Fifteen sitting days pass and we are now up to June of next year. So everyone is asleep for six months. If the House of Representatives does not deal with it, it passes into—as Senator Collins said—a law of the Commonwealth. So what happens? Suddenly, after six months the industry sees that it cannot screen M rated movies before 9.30 p.m. Suddenly it wakes up. What do honourable senators reckon happens then? The Government immediately turns around and on one day moves a motion to reverse that situation, gets it through the next day, puts it up to the Senate and in four days it is reversed.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister to listen to this.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not listening.
—No, he is not listening.
—Don't get too tired and emotional.

—I am not tired and emotional. The Minister has accused my amendment of being `the total destruction of the democratic process'. What happens after 15 sitting days has passed in the Senate? The Department is automatically advised of that before the matter goes down to the House of Representatives. So the Department knows about it. What Senator Collins is proposing to the Committee is an absolute furphy. He should hang his head in shame for what he has said.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I refer to the reason paragraphs (2) and (3) are in the amendment. They are in the amendment to require and enable the chamber to deal with the matter and so prevent the Government from putting it to the bottom of the Notice Paper. I point out to Senator Cooney that that is precisely the reason that in 1936 such an amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act was adopted by the House of Representatives.

It will be of interest to the Opposition to know why this happened. Does Senator Hill know who accepted the amendment in those days? It was accepted by Sir Robert Menzies. This is what Sir Robert Menzies said in 1936 about that aspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our amendment was drawn up in consultation with the shadow Minister.
—The Minister is getting frightened now. I will read what was said in 1936. Mr Blackburn, who I understand was an Independent, moved the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: If within fifteen sitting days after the day on which notice of a disallowing resolution has been given in either House of the Parliament in accordance with sub-section (4.) of this section, such resolution has not been withdrawn or otherwise—
this is in precisely the same terms as my amendment—
with or without amendment, disposed of, the regulation named in such resolution shall cease to have effect in all respects as if it had been disallowed.
What did Sir Robert Menzies say about that? Sir Robert Menzies, the then honourable member for Kooyong and the Attorney-General, said:

I accept the amendment; in fact, I am indebted to the honourable member for having drawn my attention to this point. It seems absurd, that with one hand a House should be given the right to disallow a regulation, and with the other hand the Government should be given power to overcome that by keeping the motion at the bottom of the notice-paper. The effect of the amendment is that, unless the motion is debated and decided within fifteen days of its appearance on the notice-paper, the regulation being challenged shall automatically lapse. In other words, the House must be given the right within a reasonable period to express its views on the regulation.

That is precisely what I am doing with paragraphs (2) and (3). The Minister can put up his straw men all night if he wants to. But those straw men will be cut down on each occasion. They are straw men and they ought to be regarded as such. I believe that the proposal that has been moved by the Minister should not proceed. I foreshadow, however, that there is one aspect of this amendment which possibly deserves consideration, though I do not think it is necessary. I refer to point (2) of the schedule of amendments made by the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: Point (2) of the schedule of the amendment in effect requires that the provisions operate 28 days after my amendment, which was carried by this Parliament, has taken effect. I suppose that is not necessary because we do not do that when it comes to standards determined by the ABA; we do not say that they will operate 28 days after those standards are determined. But what I am foreshadowing is that perhaps the motion ought to be amended so as to only retain point (2) of the schedule of amendment made by the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of this puts this whole process in a very difficult position. As I said before—and I would like to go through this process—the Government amendment that is before the Committee tonight was drawn up in consultation with the shadow Minister for communications, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith). This amendment did not just spring out of left field; we have not dragged this off the top of our heads in the last half-hour. We saw the problems with creating law by negative action rather than positive action. I discussed it last night. We have been discussing this matter for most of the afternoon, on and off, and this evening with the shadow Minister. It is in the Hansard of the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: The shadow Minister advised me that the Government amendment was satisfactory and that it solved the problem. In fact, the honourable member for Bass enunciated, when he tabled his legal advice—the final paragraph of which says,`Yes, this is a positive action and it should only happen by positive action'—that he supported the Government amendments in the House of Representatives. I point out the difficulties that we are now facing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard his speech.
—I will tell the Committee what he said precisely, word for word. The honourable member for Bass said that he supported the amendment of the Government.
—`At this stage'.

—If Senator Harradine would let me finish, I can say it myself. It is in the Hansard. Obviously Senator Harradine only saw the first part of what he said. The honourable member for Bass made two statements on this amendment. Senator Harradine should go and have a look at the Hansard proofs. When he concluded the debate in the House of Representatives, the honourable member for Bass stated the reasons why he supported the Government's amendment. He then said—and it was curious wording, I confess—that nobody knew what would happen in the Senate, but that he hoped that his support for the amendment in the House of Representatives would provide some guidance, presumably to his colleagues in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I know the reason why he said that, and it had nothing to do with any deficiencies in the Government's amendment; it had to do with what I have been witnessing going on on the other side of the chamber for the last hour. I stated this at the beginning of the debate: the fact is that if the Government wanted to adopt a position, we would want to go back to the original section 128 which made all of these standards and codes disallowable instruments—in other words, subject to full parliamentary review like delegated legislation, and disallowable by the Senate.

We knew that was not acceptable to the Senate; that is why we negotiated this with Warwick Smith. We did not do that, even though we knew we could not support this amendment, and the honourable member for Bass indicated that, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have gutted it.

—That is nonsense. What we did was maintain the structure that Senator Harradine brought in of allowing both Houses of parliament to actually carry amendments that will create new standards and codes of practice for the television industry, but only by a positive action, not by waiting 15 days and doing nothing and it just becoming law.

PARA.TAB: The only reason I make this point is that at this point in the debate, Senator Alston surely having consulted fully with his shadow Minister on this and receiving his assent to the Government amendments, are we in the absurd position of having the Government amendments supported by the shadow Minister in the House of Representatives and opposed by his own colleagues in the Senate? The only reason I ask that is that if we do not get that resolved—and we might as well know it now—this debate will go on for the rest of the evening.

The problem is this: if the Government amendments that have been agreed to in the House of Representatives are further amended here, there will be no pay TV legislation yet again. Frankly, I am not going to cut my wrists or cry about that, but there are a lot of people in the industry that will, because they are sick and tired of waiting for a resolution to this.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have waited 12 years.
—Fine, if that is Senator Alston's attitude, so be it. I am making a reasonable point. What I am saying is that if the resolution—
—Send it back to the Reps.

—That is what will happen if we keep playing this ridiculous game of ping-pong with this industry. If the House of Representatives has not adjourned by now, it is about to do so. That means that if we further amend in the Senate an amendment that has already been agreed to by the shadow Minister for communications in the House of Representatives, this legislation will have to go back to the House of Representatives again and we will wait another month until the House of Representatives resumes—on 17 December or something like that—before the people that actually want to get going in this industry can start moving, start creating employment and start providing people with the pay TV that they want. They will have to wait another month before they see any legislation. With the greatest respect, I do not think any of us—and I have to say that I am sure that would include Senator Alston—want that result.

—Perhaps I may make our position clear. What we have tended to lose sight of in this debate this evening is that when we supported Senator Harradine's amendment the other night, we made a very significant move in the direction of parliamentary democracy; over the Government's dead body, but nonetheless we did it. What we succeeded in doing—and I think Senator Bourne said this at an earlier stage—was to allow the Parliament to have a say as to the amendment of standards and codes of practice. But it was also abundantly clear, from what Senator Harradine said, that he would not expect any amendment to take place without a positive vote of both Houses.

PARA.TAB: In those circumstances it seems anomalous that one can have a double default mechanism that would allow a change to be brought about without any positive vote. It seems to me that when one analyses the differing points of concern that have been expressed tonight, it really comes down to whether, in the normal circumstance, if the Senate is the place where notice of motion is most likely to be given, the House of Representatives, in due course, ought to be forced to conduct a debate. I have no doubt that Senator Walters will want to contribute to the debate on this point.

The fact is that, if the House of Representatives is minded to support the amendment, it will bring the matter on for debate. By choosing not to do that, the House of Representatives—or the majority party—is making it plain that it will not be supporting the amendment. In those circumstances, Senator Harradine's conditions have not been fulfilled and he would not expect them to be fulfilled. In other words, he does not expect that an amendment ought to be achieved by the vote of one House only; it has to be by vote of both Houses.

Knowing that that is the position in the House of Representatives, what the original amendment did was to force that debate to occur, even though, for practical purposes, there was a pre-determined outcome. One would know, because one would see from the vote here how each party lined up on the issue, what was going to happen in the House of Representatives. Of course, the majority party, if it chose not to bring it on, would make it abundantly clear that it was not minded to support it.

It seems to me to simply come down to whether we ought to allow those default mechanisms to occur. I have a great deal of sympathy for Senator Harradine and that is why we supported the amendment in the first instance and I think we have achieved an overwhelming result. We have achieved a situation where, by vote of both Houses of parliament, the ABA can be overridden.

Senator Harradine should not be churlish about this. He should not think that somehow the Opposition has suddenly ratted on a deal or that we do not really have any sympathy. The fact is that we have overwhelmingly supported a proposition that turns what the Government wants to do on its head. The Government has not been at all keen on it. We have seen the merits in this from the outset, as have the Democrats. We still adhere to the view that if the Parliament, meaning both Houses, wants to change those standards or codes or practice, it ought to be able to do it. That is Senator Harradine's view. So it simply comes down to the issue of whether we ought to be allowing things to happen simply by default.

It seems to me that that would then involve a great degree of vigilance. It is possible that things could slip through. It does not have to be a fundamental amendment, which, of course, would attract national attention and then ensure that everyone was very anxious to move the necessary amendments or to bring the motion on for debate; one could actually have something that looked innocuous but was not picked up. We had an instance of that not so long ago with the superannuation guarantee charge legislation where, because the debate was still proceeding well after midnight, something slipped through, the records were not accurate and the House of Representatives found itself voting on something which had not occurred in this House.

We cannot pretend that somehow the system is infallible. Therefore, if we are to amend standards and codes of practice, we ought to do so consciously, deliberately and on the basis of a notice of motion given in each House. If we reach that position, then we have achieved what Senator Harradine's amendment would appear to be arguing for; that is, that this Parliament, by separate majority vote in each chamber, ought to be able to override the ABA. That is what we have supported, and we still support it.

What we are saying tonight is that it does not seem right that one could bring about that result by default. Therefore, I do not see that we have in any way stepped back from our commitment to what I think is a very worthwhile and progressive amendment and one which will enable notices of motion not only to be given but to be brought on for debate—for votes to be taken and for people to have to show their hand. If there is sufficient community support for it to be brought on in the other place, then that will occur as well.

If the matter is taken to a vote and the view is the same, then we will have achieved what we set out to achieve. In those circumstances, I think what we are looking at tonight is not any sort of fundamental change to what was originally proposed, but simply a refinement to ensure that we require a positive vote in both the chambers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apropos of what Senator Harradine said before, I agree with what Senator Alston has said. He shows his great legal ability in this case. Mr Chairman, it is a constitutional point. If we are to pass legislation in this House it has to be passed in accordance with the Constitution. That does require, as Senator Alston says, a positive vote in both Houses. A system which attempts to get legislation through by default is not in accordance with the Constitution.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine said, `The legislation, as originally made, is subordinate legislation, and surely we can alter that'. As Senator Alston said, `Of course we can, but in altering it we have to go through a process that is set out in the Constitution and that requires a positive vote in both Houses'. The default mechanism, as Senator Collins has said and Senator Alston has inferred, is a system that is not available to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just deal with the matter raised by Senator Alston. I would be grateful if he would consider carefully my response to him. I ask him to give me the courtesy of listening to my response to what he said. I acknowledge Senator Alston's sincerity in this matter. What he actually indicated was that we should not have a situation whereby legislation is virtually passed by double default. He indicated to the chamber that if a motion to amend a standard or code of practice was adopted by one chamber—that is to say, by a vote of this chamber—and then that message was sent to the House of Representatives and the government of the day did not bring that matter on for debate in the other chamber, that would be an indication that the Government was not supporting the amendment to the code of practice.

PARA.TAB: That is not necessarily the case. There has been a situation in regard to regulations where the 15 sitting days has been allowed to expire by the Government because it did not want the regulation. So the main point that Senator Alston has made out against my proposition does not really hold water. I refer to the Blewett instance, which is a classic example. He just allowed the 15 sitting days to expire and blew the regulation. He did not want to get up and debate it; he just knocked it off by that means.

TALK.START.PARA: —He clearly did not support it.

—That is the point that I am making. It does not indicate that he does not support the motion to disallow. In fact, in that particular instance he actually supported the motion to disallow but chose to let the 15 sitting days run and, in effect, supported by a negative action the disallowance of that motion. So what is the difference between that and this?

PARA.TAB: All of this nonsense that Senator Collins has been talking about that somehow these measures can be snuck through is a load of tripe. I have never heard so much tripe in my life. As I said to him, people have to be asleep for six months before suddenly they realise that M cannot be shown on television. That is a nonsense because if, for example, a period of 15 sitting days has expired in this chamber, a message has to go back to the other chamber. As I am advised, that message also goes to the Department. What would the Department do at that stage?

So what the Minister has been on about is just ludicrous. It is crazy. It is a furphy. It is the use of hyperbole to deny, effectively, to this chamber and to the House of Representatives—the elected representatives of the people—the right to deal with questions of great public moment. I have been accused of proposing a motion which represents the total destruction of the democratic process. I am doing the reverse. What I am doing is trying to ensure that the Parliament deals with these questions of great public moment—not in an automatic way as per regulations, but only in a manner that will ultimately have the support of both Houses of parliament.

As I said, let us say that everybody is asleep for six months, including the Department. What will happen the day after people realise that there has been a change in the code of practice? The government of the day would get up the next day and move that it be reversed, and that takes four days before the matter is actually determined.

I remind the Opposition that my amendment is intended to ensure that the Government cannot just put it on the bottom of the Notice Paper; it has to deal with it. I refer to what was said on 2 December 1936 when this particular measure was decided upon in respect of regulations. Mr Blackburn, who moved the amendment, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of my amendment will be, that a member gives notice of a motion to disallow a regulation, that motion is either disposed of by the House in which it is moved, within fifteen sitting days, or the regulation ceases to operate. In this House or in any House in which the Government has complete control over the time-table, the Government can render illusory the rights of the House to amend regulations simply by postponing a motion for disallowance.
Do honourable senators follow that? What did Sir Robert Menzies say? He said:
. . . I am indebted to the honourable member for having drawn my attention to this point. It seems absurd, that with one hand a House should be given
the right to disallow a regulation, and with the other hand the Government should be given power to overcome that by keeping the motion at the bottom of the notice-paper.

That is precisely what the Government is doing in these amendments. It says that it is providing to the Parliament the power to amend codes of practice and standards. It is providing that, but what it is doing is making illusory the rights of the Parliament by amending my amendment so that it can, simply by postponing the motion for disallowance, make that provision illusory. As Sir Robert Menzies said, that is absurd. It is absurd to give the right to disallow a regulation—and in this case a code of practice or a standard—with one hand and, with the other hand, give the Government the power to overcome that by keeping the motion at the bottom of the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a question of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins). Under the Minister's proposal, what would occur if in this area, which, as the Minister himself has said, is very prone to high emotional feelings, the Senate decides to have a conscience vote and the decision is to support the person who brought the notice of motion?

PARA.TAB: The vote in the Senate would not reflect the vote in the lower House at all. There would be no indication at all as to what the conscience vote in the lower House would be. If the Prime Minister of the day decided not to bring it on because it was too hot a political potato to handle, there is no way that a vote could be forced to know what the outcome would have been. A conscience vote would have been taken in this place so there would have been no Government decision, and we would have no idea what would happen in the lower House.

Under Senator Harradine's amendment, if a conscience vote were taken in this chamber and the motion passed, then the lower House must consider it, otherwise it is automatically passed. It is simply not enough to say that a government decision has been taken up in this chamber and, therefore, it is clear which way the Government is going to vote—not at all, not if it is a conscience vote. There would be no clear indication at all. I would like the Minister to explain how the Government would cope with that situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston answered Senator Walters's question probably a lot more succinctly than I would have, and I am sorry that Senator Walters was not here to listen to that answer. I concur with everything that was just said by Senator Alston. It might be useful for people to know what the drafting instructions were that I gave for this amendment. I am very keen to see this legislation, in whatever form, finally get through this Parliament. The reason for that quite simply is that this Parliament has some obligation to a lot of people who want to see this industry get started. That is the reason for the drafting instructions I gave.

PARA.TAB: When the double default, as Senator Alston referred to it, was pointed out to me last night, I said to the draftsman, `We are not going to get the support of the Senate for the original position that the Government adopted. The Senate has clearly said that the Parliament is going to have a role in amending or even creating—as it can by amendment—brand new codes of conduct and standards. So if we want to get this through the Senate we are going to have to maintain that structure'. Senator Harradine has had a win out of this. That is why I cannot understand Senator Harradine's attitude. He has had a win, and I am happy to acknowledge it. I said to the draftsman, `Give me an amendment that maintains the structure for which Senator Harradine got the support of the Senate but which requires the positive action of both Houses of Parliament to achieve it instead of a double default by both Houses of Parliament'. They were the drafting instructions that were given.

So this is not some kind of three-card trick that has been produced by the Government at the last moment because, not being a complete idiot, I know that would not get this legislation through the Senate. So I said, `We have been done on this. Senator Harradine has got the support of the Senate for the Parliament to have a direct role in amending these Acts of parliament'. This is the answer to Senator Walters's question. My instructions were to draft an amendment that maintains that structure but which provides that it must be by a positive act in both Houses instead of being achieved by a double default in both Houses.

As Senator Alston pointed out—and Senator Colston by body language, if not by interjection, recalled—there was an evening when we did something by mistake in this chamber which resulted in the House of Representatives voting on something that did not exist. Mistakes do happen. I support what Senator Alston said. Let us maintain the Parliament's role, as Senator Harradine wants it, but let us do it at least by positive actions of both Houses. I will answer Senator Walters's question. She said, `Let us say a conscience vote occurs so that the Senate takes a vote which is different from the vote in the House of Representatives'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.
—That is what Senator Walters said. I do not want to argue; I will agree that she said anything she wants me to agree she said—I promise.
—How can you answer if you don't know the question?
—I am trying to answer Senator Walters's question. Forget the conscience vote.
—I can't forget the conscience vote—that is my question.

—Senator Alston answered Senator Walters's question. The Senate and the House of Representatives are constituted differently. The Senate does not have a Government majority. I thought Senator Alston handled it very succinctly. If the House of Representatives, however constituted and whichever government is in power, receives a message from the Senate that a motion has been carried in the Senate, the government of the day, whichever it is and whether or not it is a conscience vote in the Senate, will make a decision on whether to bring the matter on and deal with it.
—That is the problem.

—Senator Walters had better argue with Senator Alston about that because he does not see it as being a problem and neither do I. It is called democracy. I understand what Senator Walters is saying. The kind of situation she wants to bring about is not the situation that Senator Alston correctly quoted Senator Harradine as saying last night. The kind of situation Senator Walters wants to bring about is that where a vote in the Senate will determine what happens.
—No, it is not.
—With the greatest respect, the Senate cannot force the House of Representatives to consider a matter that it does not want to consider.
—Yes, you can—by Senator Harradine's amendment.

—At the end of the day the House of Representatives will reject it if it is minded to do so. I point out to Senator Walters the absurdity of this argument: Senator Harradine keeps on asserting that his amendment forces the Senate and the House of Representatives to do something. That is not right. The problem—as Senator Alston has seen—is that Senator Harradine's amendment does not force the Senate or the House of Representatives to do anything at all. Senator Harradine can get up in the Senate under this proposal, give a notice of motion that an amendment be carried and read out the detail of that amendment, as we do every day with notices of motion. That does not force the Senate to do anything. If the Senate then does not do anything for 15 days, it is deemed to have passed the Senate without a word of debate.
—By regulation.

—Once again, I will point out to Senator Harradine the difference between an Act of parliament and a regulation. I hate to tell Senator Harradine this, but an amendment that becomes law is an Act of parliament, as I explained before, because it is a positive act of the Parliament to create it. Delegated legislation, rightly, as Senator Harradine said, is made by bureaucrats, not by parliament, and is subject to disallowance by parliament. It is a negative action. It is a scrutiny on the Executive power to achieve. Senator Harradine is talking about the positive action of amending something that then becomes law. I point out that his amendment does not cover only codes of practice; it also covers standards. It covers things such as Australian content and children standards.

PARA.TAB: I would like some guidance at this point as to how long we will continue to run around the same track, because the fact is, whether or not he likes to admit it, Senator Harradine has had a win out of this. The structure that he has asked for, in which the Parliament is positively involved in amending standards and codes of practice of the ABA, has been retained. But it has been retained, as Senator Alston said correctly, by amending the proposal so that that act is a positive act and not a double default.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to prolong this debate. I will keep it going only as long as the ludicrous statements continue to fall from the lips of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins). What he is saying is a complete nonsense. He is saying that I can get up here and move a notice of motion hoping that it will sneak through by the expiration of 15 days and that nobody in the chamber will know about it. Will I not start lobbying around the place for support for my motion, or will I sit back and secretly hope that it will go through by default? How stupid to do it secretly!
—You are not the only one who can give notices of motion.

—Anybody in this chamber can get up and give a notice of motion and then, because of the operation of my amendment, if 15 days elapses, that motion is deemed to have been carried and is sent as a message to the House of Representatives. Let us see how ludicrous this is. Who in this chamber in his or her right mind gets up and moves such a motion, then sits back in his or her room secretly hoping that after 15 sitting days it will pass? Would that person not go around lobbying people to try to get the thing passed?

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister to be sensible. It is a nonsense and he knows it is. The Minister knows that what he is doing is attempting to make illusory what he says is my victory. That is what he is doing. You should not deny it because that is precisely what you are doing. You know as well as I do that all I have done—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, `through the Chair' might be better.

—I am sorry, Mr Chairman. The Minister knows as well as I do that all I am doing is following the precedent for regulations. He says, `Oh, but regulations are made by the bureaucracy; they are not law'. Of course they are law. Mr Chairman, you try to breach them and see how far you go—you go in the slammer in some cases. They are law all right. The Minister says, `Oh, you can only disallow them'. Senator Collins ought to know from the Borthwick case that we can amend a regulation by excising a discrete part of it. Mr Chairman, what is the difference between that and what I am proposing?

PARA.TAB: I will finish on this. Senator Collins really went over the top by saying that my amendment was horrendous. It is rooted in the words of the Hon. Mr Justice Blackburn and the Hon. Sir Robert Menzies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Right Honourable.

—Rt. Hon. Sir Robert Menzies. So my amendment has horrendous implications; it means the total destruction of the democratic process—indeed! What the Minister is trying to do is to so amend it as to deny the true democratic process unless it is approved of by the Government. That is what he is trying to do. What he is trying to do is give the power to the Government to keep the notice of motion at the bottom of the Notice Paper unless the Government decides to bring it on. I am trying to avoid that because I am trying to ensure that the Government cannot render illusory the rights that it now agrees should be given to both Houses of parliament. I appeal to the chamber to support my original amendment.

—Senator Collins did not answer my question on the conscience vote. I would like him to answer that specific question. Senator Alston certainly did not answer it, as Senator Collins claimed. What I am saying to him is: if a conscience vote occurs in the Senate, it does not reflect the conscience vote in the House of Representatives because it is impossible to do so. How then do we know the Government's attitude on that particular motion?
—With the greatest respect, I did answer the question. Senator Walters may not have liked the answer, but it was answered, and I cannot really add anything else to it.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Collins's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.
Motion (by Senator Collins) proposed:

TAB.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I pay tribute to a great Queenslander, and indeed a great Australian, the late Sir Leslie Thiess, who died in Brisbane on Wednesday night. My early memories of Sir Leslie are of when he was working on main roads projects and I was working for the Main Roads Department typing estimates in the drafting section, many of which were jobs carried out by Thiess Bros during the war years. Over the years that I have been living at Kingaroy, I have gone up and down the roads from Brisbane to Kingaroy by car so many times that I have lost count. Joh has told me of all the cuttings on that road that were built by Thiess Bros and also of the many sections of bitumen that were laid by Sir Leslie's firm. During those war years Thiess Bros also ended up building dams, airstrips and ports.

PARA.TAB: In 1958, 25 per cent of the Snowy Mountains hydro-electric work was constructed by Thiess Bros. Thiess Holdings became the first Australian company to win a contract for tunnelling works in competition with international construction companies. Is it any wonder that I say he was a great Australian?

Another area of his work was the pioneering of the open-cut coalmining in central Queensland in the 1950s. He went to Japan and organised the first sales of coal to Japan from the Kianga open-cut mine. Look at how that industry has grown and what it has meant to the economy of Queensland. I was in Gladstone on Monday this week, and the vast expansion of open-cut mining is obvious from the tremendous stockpile of coal at the port ready for transport to Japan, and no doubt also these days to Korea and other South East Asian countries. It is obvious that he was a great Queenslander who did much for the economy of our State.

It grieves me very much when I read in the media of the $1m bribe he was supposed to have given to Joh. That was all based on a story told to Channel 9 by Mr Woodham, who had been sacked by the Thiess family for dishonest practices. He was paid $50,000 for the story, which was untrue and was meant to hurt Sir Leslie. He threw in Joh for good measure, to make a good story and to get his $50,000.It is interesting to note that, after thorough investigation, the CJC wrote to Joh's solicitors and told them that there was nothing on which to base any legal action. It examined that before the case went to court. After Sir Leslie defended it and it had been finalised, the CJC carried out some months of investigation based on what was said in the court and came to the same conclusion that there was absolutely nothing on which to base any charges. Woodham and Channel 9 did not even come to Sir Leslie and Joh and ask their side of the story because, they said, it would have spoilt a good yarn. In other words, they knew it was a trumped-up story to build up the ratings of Channel 9. There is no doubt that it was completely untrue.

The Queensland Government, when Joh was Premier, awarded contracts on the basis of the lowest conforming tender. Indeed, in all contracts let in his almost 20 years as Premier, they did not find any based on other than the lowest conforming tender. Any work given to Thiess Bros was won by it on merit. The stories Channel 9 came up with in this regard were completely without credence. When we think of what this wonderful Australian has done for the nation, there is a dark, black cloud lying over the Channel 9 people who were involved in that exercise: Jana Wendt, Peter Wilkinson, and, of course, Ron Woodham, the man who told them the snake yarn in the first place. It was one of the most despicable actions that could possibly have been taken against a man like Sir Leslie Thiess.

I am happy to stand in the Senate tonight and pay a sincere tribute to Sir Leslie Thiess, a great Queenslander and a great Australian, who, as Joh said in the paper yesterday, had contributed more to the State of Queensland's growth and development than anyone he has known. I would also like to express to his family my sincere sympathy in the loss of their father, brother and friend.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleague Senator Bjelke-Petersen in her tribute to a great Australian and a great Queenslander, Sir Leslie Thiess. Sir Leslie Thiess was well known in Queensland. He left his mark right across the face of Queensland in many ways: in his contribution to the coal industry; in the fact that he was one of the first importers of Toyotas into Australia; and in his great engineering works right across Queensland.

PARA.TAB: I was never fortunate enough to know Sir Leslie well, as obviously the ex-Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, and his wife, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, were, but I understand that he came from very humble beginnings. In fact, he had a farm, I believe, just outside Toowoomba. He grew up on that farm with his family and then diverted into industry and commerce. He provided a great many jobs and he is one of the men who changed the face of Queensland and brought it from a small State that was basically primary industry to a State that went in and built up great mining and engineering works. Sir Leslie Thiess played his role in Queensland, and I add my sympathies to those of Lady Bjelke-Petersen to his remaining family and pass on my condolences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to pay tribute to Sir Leslie Thiess. I wish to speak of another aspect of Sir Les Thiess. He was an extraordinary individual, the likes of whom will not be seen again, I think, in our lifetimes. He had the opportunity after the Second World War arose and he did so much for Queensland that will be a monument to him that will last long after all of us have passed through this world.

PARA.TAB: I want to speak about Les Thiess as a family man. I first met him in my professional capacity as a surgeon. He was an extraordinarily strong individual. He came from a large family, he had a large family and, above all else, he was a strong family man. He was a man of great generosity and he distributed that generosity in many ways. I am sure that much of the maligning of Les Thiess came about because of this generosity and because of his friendship and his ability to give to his friends the help or assistance that at times they might need.

I, too, am in sympathy with the family he leaves behind, in particular Thelma Driscoll and Kevin Driscoll, both very close friends of mine who are also great Queenslanders. I extend the sympathy of the Senate to the remaining members of that family as well. I want to join with Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Boswell in their tribute to Sir Leslie and the condolences we all extend to the family.

Another matter I wish to refer to is the casino development on the Gold Coast and the letting of the casino contract in Brisbane. The Courier-Mail, by any stretch of the imagination, could not be said to be a supporter of the coalition Opposition in Queensland. In fact, I do not think I have ever seen anything supportive since the Labor Party came into power. To my amazement, almost to my great delight, I saw in the editorial in the Courier-Mail today the heading `Casino contract rates a look'. The article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It is unresolved—in the public mind, where it matters most—whether former Jupiters stockholder Daikyo relinquished its shareholding at the Government's insistence or on its own judgment.

PARA.TAB: The distinction is crucial. When the Brisbane tenderer was announced on May 26 this year, Mr De Lacy said it was a condition that Daikyo sell its 24 percent stake. The Premier, Mr Goss, subsequently said that the sale decision had been made by Daikyo on a corporate basis, without duress. This dichotomy alone is a proper subject for parliamentary inquiry. Queenslanders are entitled to know every detail, not just those which the Government or other interested parties decide to divulge.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an important matter. I seek leave to have a document, which was incorporated in the Queensland Parliament this morning, incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: SUMMARY

During the last four to five years the Queensland media have reported large financial investments, by the Japanese, in this State mainly in the areas of property development and tourist associated ventures.
These investments have been confirmed, particularly on the Gold Coast and Cairns—North Queensland area.

With the consolidation of these financial investments intelligence obtained by members of the Task Force (Bureau of Criminal Intelligence) indicates an alarming increase in the movement of the Japanese organised criminal group `the Boryokudan'. This criminal group have preferred to be known as the Yakuza as this suggests an element of mystique.
The activities of this organised criminal group has been identified as intimidating legitimate tourist industry businesses and the laundering of vast sums of money.

Currently members of the Task Force (BCI) are working in concert with members of the C.J.C. (Intelligence Division) and preparing profiles on members of the Boryokudan that have been identified in this State, their associates, and monitoring the possible criminal activities of companies controlled by Japanese interests.
INTRODUCTION
The Boryokudan

1.The Boryokudan are groups involved with organised crime throughout Japan and abroad but more recently their tentacles have extended to Australia in particular Queensland. Concern has been shown by authorities in Australia and rightly so as this country relies heavily on foreign investment and the tourist dollar a majority of which comes form the Japanese.
2.In Japan the Boryokudan make their money from trading in illegal stimulants and cocaine, bookmaking, prostitution, firearms, intimidation of tourism traders and corporations.

3.With an annual turnover well above $10 billion, the 2200 gangs in Japan are organised in a tight structure dating back 300 years, which allows their overlords to muster all the resources they need for foreign activities.
The Hawaii Comparison

1.Law Enforcement agencies throughout Australia have compared the Japanese influence in Queensland to that of Hawaii in the 1970's when the Japanese purchased considerable legitimate businesses worth hundreds of millions of dollars. This was followed closely by a criminal invasion by the Boryokudan.

2.United Sates law officials now estimate that the yearly take from Boryokudan operations in Hawaii to be as high as $8 billion, in particular they targeted crimes such as drugs, prostitution, pornography, gambling, gun running and extortion.
QUEENSLAND BORYOKUDAN INFILTRATION
Tourism
1.Japanese are flying to Australia on Japanese airlines, staying at Japanese owned motels, being guided by Japanese tourist guides and shopping at Japanese owned businesses.
2.The Gold Coast Visitors and Convention Bureau's figures state that in 1989 60,000 Japanese tourists visited the Gold Coast alone. They estimate a similar figure for the 1990 period.
From the Japanese Consul—Permanent residency statistics of Japanese in Queensland are as follows:
Inquiries with the Australian Securities Commission have reached an impasse as they will not release any figures on Japanese owned property.
3.In general Japanese travel to the Gold Coast because of the closeness, the low crime rate (compared to other countries), the golf courses, acceptance by the tourist industry and the Casino.

4.Intelligence investigations reveal there is presently business practices of coercion amongst local Japanese businessmen involved in the tourist industry. For example tour operators conveying Japanese tourists to particular Japanese souvenir shops and in turn receiving commission.
