SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I asked Minister Cook a multi-part question about the Tasmanian oyster industry, in which I am sure you are greatly interested, Mr Acting Deputy President. The question was motivated by my knowledge that many Tasmanian oyster growers are concerned about the recent actions of the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries. Their concern has been provoked because the Department has recently declared the bonamia disease as endemic to all Tasmanian waters. I quote from a letter sent from Coal River Oysters to the State Minister, the Hon. Robin Gray. In part, that letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The declaration causes us great concern as we have received no advice nor any consultation that provides assurances that this move is in the future best interests of our shellfish farming industry.
I, too, am concerned about the future best interests of Tasmania's shellfish farming industry. That is why I asked the Minister in Question Time today:
What effects has the Tasmanian action had on the oyster industry within Australia and what effect will it have on Australia's export earnings?
I was astounded to hear the Minister, advised by AQIS, answer:
. . . the impact on Australian production and exports of oysters should be minimal.

This is in direct conflict with the advice which is readily obtained from within and without the industry itself. A Miss Joanne Wilson was quite recently employed by the Department of Primary Industry as a scientific officer on the Tasmanian Shellfish Health Survey. This is a project which was jointly funded by the industry—that is, the growers—to the tune of $35,000 and the Federal Government to the tune of $50,000. It took place over two years. Ms Wilson recently communicated with Tasmanian oyster growers to say:
Protozoan diseases such as MSX, QX, Bonamia and Perkinsus have been recorded from Pacific and flat oysters in other parts of the world where they have caused heavy economic losses.
The Tasmanian Aquaculture Cooperative Society wrote to its members in May this year to say:

Further to concerns received from growers relating to the possible spread of Bonamia through the transference of shellfish from infected areas, implications for our future status internationally could well extend to Pacific Oysters as well as Angasis.
That is native oysters. Further, I quote from the same communication:

At present we are awaiting the outcome of Molluscan disease control measures for Tasmania and Victoria from the OIE Annual General Session in Paris. New European Common Policy Regulations will come into effect on January 1 1993 directly relating to movements of shellfish and the placing on the market for theirs and other countries of live oysters.
From this information, world wide standards are being set now and areas with disease free status will be held at a premium on the international market.
I suggest that this premium is obvious when we consider the requirements of the South Australian Department of Primary Industries for the translocation of oysters into South Australia.

PARA.TAB: I quote in summary from a communication by Mr Steven Clarke, Senior Research Officer, Aquaculture, of that department in South Australia. On 18 November, under the heading `Additional requirements due to the discovery of Bonamia' there is listed in his communication the following:

SPEECH.PARA: *Prohibition of the translocation of native oysters from states where Bonamia has been recorded.
*Prohibition of the translocation of pacific oysters greater than 7 mm in size from areas (bays) in which Bonamia has been confirmed.

*Prohibition of the translocation of Pacific oysters less than or equal to 7 mm in size from areas (bays) in which Bonamia has been confirmed unless they have been held in sterile seawater for 24 hours before shipment to South Australia.

Obviously, this readily demonstrates that there is direct, almost measurable, commercial advantage from the retention of disease-free status. Consequently, the diseased status incurs a commercial penalty which should be obvious to all, irrespective of whether they are interested in oysters.

PARA.TAB: It is hard, if not almost impossible, to understand why AQIS would advise the Minister just today, and I quote again from the answer that AQIS provided the Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the impact of this Tasmanian Government decision on Australian production and export of oysters would be minimal.

Another part of the Minister's answer today is that he was advised that discussions were held at officer level between AQIS and the Tasmanian Department on the matter. If AQIS is incapable of appreciating the international and interstate trade ramifications of bonamia, then its advice is next to useless. The Minister obviously needs better advice.

PARA.TAB: Another part of the Minister's answer today indicated that he was aware of internationally recognised methods of containing the spread of bonamia, including restriction notices on affected areas, movement restrictions and bonamia free zone classifications. These are precisely the methods recommended by the British Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food in an article entitled `Impact and spread of bonamiosis in the UK' contained in a 1991 publication called Aquaculture 93 from Elsevier Science Publications, Amsterdam. In that article we are told that bonamiosis was first recognised in Europe in Brittany in 1979, that it spread quickly, and that the losses sustained soon threatened the viability of the French flat oyster industry.

Further in that publication we are told that in France, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and the United States of America it is considered a matter of national importance. National authorities accept the responsibility of monitoring and managing the definition of affected zones and controlling the movement of stock around the growing areas.

I suggest that it is not acceptable that our Minister should be aware of these international methods and yet allow the Tasmanian Government to follow this lazy, sloppily administered and economically irresponsible strategy. This Federal Government contributed funds to the survey of the health of Tasmanian shellfish. I previously quoted the scientific officer who conducted that survey when she warned of the seriousness of this matter. But she also predicted:

SPEECH.PARA: Nor is it expected that any serious disease problem will be encountered during the course of the study.

This was confirmed by a subsequent study, known as the May 1992 bonamia survey of Tasmanian wild flat oysters. The results of the study, prepared by J. Handlinger of the Animal Health Laboratory of the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industries and Fisheries, which were published in September 1992, read:
Conclusions

The May 1992 Bonamia survey of Tasmanian wild flat oysters confirmed moderately high levels of infection (30-60% infected) in Georges Bay and Triabunna, with characteristic focal lesions in most infected oysters. Similar small lesions were more widespread around the East and South East coasts, and low numbers of Bonamia organisms were confirmed in three other locations.

As Bonamia infection in other known infected countries progresses throughout summer, declining during autumn to disappear during winter, these findings could indicate that May sampling was too late in the Bonamia cycle to detect many infected oysters. Alternatively there could be other widespread causes of focal lesions—
in other words, not bonamia—

of this type. Another possible explanation is that most Tasmanian flat oysters succeed in destroying most Bonamia, even in summer, so that infection is not established. It is possible that all three of these mechanisms are occurring.
Further survey samples collected during the summer could clarify the distribution.
Under the heading of `Comments', it states:

The focal nature of most of the lesions, the low levels of mortality shown in the heavily infected populations at Georges Bay and Triabunna, and the very small lesions and low level of infections seen in some other areas, all indicate that Bonamia is not at this stage having the devastating effect on Tasmanian flat oysters which has been seen in flat oysters of most other countries to which Bonamia has been introduced.

The high mortalities seen in Victoria, and the apparent difference in severity between Georges Bay, Triabunna, and other infected areas of Tasmania indicates that the severity of infection is not uniform in Australian populations.

Yet this comment was apparently ignored, because a uniform declaration was applied by the Tasmanian State Government to the whole of the Tasmanian State waters. This is amazing. It is incompetent; it is irresponsible; it is ignorant. It defies commonsense, even considering a few basic facts, such as that earlier in the survey we are told that no flat oysters, and therefore no bonamia, were detected in the north-west and west coast areas of Tasmania. You would be aware, Mr Acting Deputy, that that is two-thirds of the State. In fact, the affected regions probably occupy an area of less than 100 hundred kilometres out of a coastline of a total of 3,200 kilometres.

PARA.TAB: To put into perspective the amount of prime Australian oyster growing area which has been compromised by this idiotic Tasmanian Government decision, I point out that the total length of Victoria's coastline is 1,800 kilometres and New South Wales has just 1,900 kilometres of coastline. In other words, between the two of them they do not total the sort of area that has been wiped out of production by this stupid Tasmanian decision.

I suggest that the Federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has a responsibility to safeguard this Australian export. The federally funded shellfish health survey should be followed up by a Federal assessment of the national effects and the suitability of the decisions made by the Tasmanian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise some major concerns that have come to my notice about the security of data held by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. There have been some recent news reports that the ABS has been slow to implement recommendations on security arrangements for foreign trade data, which is a concern not only for privacy reasons but also because of its commercial sensitivities. In addition, it would appear that the person who brought these security problems to the attention of the Bureau may have been subject to victimisation. I will come back to that staff problem later. I first wish to address the security matter.

PARA.TAB: It was reported in the Sunday Telegraph of 18 October 1992 that security was upgraded on the ADABAS files used in the foreign trade section of the Bureau of Statistics in July this year. However, I understand that security of this data was a matter of review and concern much earlier and recommendations were made that security should have been upgraded as early as January 1991—18 months earlier than the upgrading that apparently occurred.

There has been no explanation at all of the reason for the delay in making the security improvements. A delay of 18 months seems highly unsatisfactory given the sensitivity of this data. That is particularly so given that an internal ABS paper stated that password controls were `looser than they need have been and if circumvented would have contravened the need to know principle' before the July 1992 upgrade. That is all the more reason to question the very long delay. It raises questions about whether the upgrade that has now been made will ensure the full security of all foreign trade data and whether similar security can be guaranteed for all ABS data.

There has also been speculation reported in the press about security breaches in 1987-88 when there were large currency transactions before the release of balance of payments data. The foreign trade data plays a major part in the compilation of the balance of payments publications. These suspected breaches were investigated by the Australian Federal Police. However, the person or persons responsible for those breaches were not identified.

It is of major concern that security procedures are not put in place which allow for an ineffective audit trail to allow for detection of breaches so that the perpetrators of such crimes can be brought to justice. The new security procedures must be sufficiently sophisticated to allow for such an audit trail, at least for the most highly sensitive data.

It would appear that the whole episode with the foreign trade data has been handled very badly. That comes as a considerable surprise to me because until now I have had every confidence in the integrity of the ABS and its officers. They perform a very important role in the policy making environment and most Australians are touched in one way or another by the work the ABS does. That is why any security breach is all the more disturbing. Millions of people supply data to the ABS, frequently at large personal cost because of the time and effort involved. The time and effort is one thing; giving up confidential information and having it plundered is quite another and should not be allowed to continue for a minute longer if any possible security loopholes are discovered.

I would emphasise very strongly my view that security of data should be of paramount importance to the ABS. I am sure the Senate would be gravely concerned if lapses in security meant that respondents to data requests felt apprehensive about providing information. That would be a major threat to the personal privacy of those people and it could also badly compromise the quality of the data collected which, in turn, could lead to inappropriate policy responses which impact on us all.

Given those serious concerns, I have today put some questions on notice to the Bureau. I hope that the Department will answer them expeditiously in view of their significance. Very briefly, those questions are: what measures has the ABS taken to ensure that all holdings of data within the Bureau are secure? Can people be confident that the information they provide to the ABS will remain confidential? Can the Bureau provide an indication of the sorts of security measures that it uses for its data holdings? In particular, are the computer systems passwords protected? Are physical records of data—whether that data be written or on a disk or tape—kept in secure storage? How easy is it for non-ABS officers to enter Bureau premises and access data records? Are the allegations in the Sunday Telegraph of 18 October 1992 accurate? In particular, were there long delays in implementing the recommendations made about improving the security of foreign trade data? If so, why was there such a long delay in implementing those recommendations?

My other serious concern is that it appears the security problems were identified by an officer who, as a result, has now been the subject of victimisation. It was reported in Public Eye of 19 November 1992—just a week ago—that the Bureau has been criticised by the Merit Protection and Review Agency, and by a Canberra magistrate, for improper and unfair treatment of the officer involved in exposing the security problems. If that is correct, as it appears to be, in my view that is both reprehensible and unacceptable. Such actions by officers should be encouraged at every opportunity. It is outrageous that instead of reward it seems that this action to maintain the integrity of the ABS has led to an officer being castigated and victimised.

I understand that the Bureau has admitted that its management was wrong on a number of issues put before the Merit Protection and Review Agency. I have therefore also placed on notice today various questions relating to this issue. They include: do personnel practices in the Bureau encourage staff to ensure the security of data accessed? Can staff who advise management of possible security breaches or security loopholes be assured that such action will not be detrimental to their employment prospects in the Bureau or the Public Service generally? Have there been any changes to the management and personnel practices within the Bureau since receipt of the criticisms by the Merit Protection and Review Agency? If so, what is the nature of those changes?

I look forward to getting a full and early response to those questions because they go to the whole issue of the public's need to have confidence in the integrity of our premier statistical agency: the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why was the claim by the NFAW approved when the claim for similar deductibility by the National Council of Women of Victoria has been consistently refused and is it because the NFAW was included in the legislation.
(2) On what basis was the NFAW included in the legislation.
(3) Was the National Council for Women of Victoria advised to apply for inclusion in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) On 15 December 1989, the then Treasurer, the Hon P. J. Keating, MP announced that the Government had decided to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to allow tax deductions for gifts, to the value of $2 or more, made on or after 10 November 1989 to the National Foundation for Australian Women (NFAW). The Government's decision was made in response to a request from the NFAW for separate listing in the gift provisions of the income tax law.

The Government has agreed to the separate listing of organisations in the gift provisions only in exceptional circumstances and proposals for separate listing therefore require consideration by the Treasurer. A check of the records has not revealed that any request for separate listing in the gift provisions has been received by the Treasurer from the National Council of Women of Victoria.

(2) The Government's decision to list separately the NFAW in the gift provisions was made in recognition of the Foundation's objectives of undertaking research and education regarding a wide range of issues affecting women, with particular emphasis on disadvantaged groups in the community, and because the Foundation planned to establish a publicly accessible archive of women's documents and artefacts, serving the function of both museum and library.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 14 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the revised arrangements for the provision of stoma therapy supplies to veterans:
(1) What were the practical and legal issues involved in the decision to revise the arrangements.
(2) Is it possible that veterans who are members of committees of unincorporated Stoma Associations may be personally liable for the association's debts.

(3) In correspondence with veterans, has the Minister suggested that `The Commonwealth would have provided cover to any veteran being placed in that situation (ie, facing personal liability) unfairly'; if so: (a) is this an ongoing commitment; (b) how does the Minister define an `unfair situation'; and (c) what would the `cover' encompass.

(4) Has the Department of Veterans' Affairs received any complaints from veterans who are facing personal liability for Stoma Association debts as a result of their involvement with a Stoma Association since the introduction of the revised arrangements.
(5) Why was the veteran community not fully informed of the legal issues associated with membership of Stoma Associations before the revised arrangements were introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Stoma Associations are established in each State and Territory to provide patients with pre and post operative counselling, advice on daily living, with drugs and stoma therapy preparations and stoma appliances. They are staffed by volunteers, who generally also have stomas, and provide a network of sympathetic and knowledgeable support and advice.

Before the introduction of the new arrangement with the Stoma Associations concern had been expressed that some patients in country areas were having difficulty in receiving their stoma therapy supplies from the Repatriation General Hospitals (RGHs). It was for this reason the Department examined the feasibility of these items being supplied from an alternative source.

The decision to revise the stoma arrangements was consistent with one of the main themes which emerged from the Health Review, which was the need to encourage veteran independence in the local setting, using community support networks.

A major consideration was also that there are twenty Stoma Associations in Australia available to supply stoma therapy items as opposed to the then six RGHs. In addition the revised arrangements constituted part of the overall plan of preparing the RGHs for integration in their respective hospital system whilst ensuring that entitled persons retained access to quality services.
Also many DVA beneficiaries had already chosen to become members of Associations prior to the proposal being put forward.

The Department carried out a comprehensive costing of the proposal, as well as an examination of the Stoma Appliance List to ensure its comprehensiveness for veterans' needs. It was also established that clients of the Department of Health Housing and Community Services had been successfully receiving their stoma therapy items through Stoma Associations for some time.

Regarding the legal issues involved, my Department acknowledged that when dealing with unincorporated associations a risk of contractual or tortious liability does exist, but analysed that risk as extremely slight. It also recognised that another Commonwealth Department was already dealing with these associations and recognised that this Department should encourage all associations to become incorporated. Any risk was also minimised by the presence of relevant insurances, since insurance companies do generally issue policies to unincorporated associations.

The reason the risk of liability attaching to a veteran personally is low, is that it could only arise where the veteran was part of the governing committee of the association, and had become integrally involved in contracting for the association or, regarding negligence, had actually been negligent while working for the association.
(2) It is possible.

(3) Yes. (a) Yes, until remaining associations become incorporated; (b) each case would be considered on its merits. My Department would indemnify veterans except in cases where the insurance of the Association eg public risk, covers the situation and in those cases that involve fraud on the part of the veteran; and (c) the amount of cover would depend on the circumstances and merits of the individual case.

(4) One veteran has written on several occasions about his concerns about unincorporated associations. My Department does not know of any veteran facing personal liability for Stoma Association debts.

(5) As I have already explained, another Commonwealth Department was using the same arrangements successfully and my Department decided that any risk was very small. There are twenty associations in Australia, fifteen of which are incorporated. Of the remaining five, one is in the process of being incorporated, one is seeing a solicitor about being incorporated, one is well insured, and another has Public Risk Insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did any Australian citizens flying helicopters for the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) breach any laws of Australia, Papua New Guinea (PNG) or the Solomon islands in flying kidnapped Solomon Islander, Francis Beiaruru, against his will to a location within Bougainville.
(2) If Australian citizens working for the PNGDF have breached any such laws, what action will the Australian Government take in response.

(3) What activities did Australian citizens or government employees, including defence force personnel, perform in connection with, including in a supporting role, the illegal raid by PNG security forces on a village in the Solomon Islands in September 1992 and the subsequent transportation and interrogation of Mr Beiaruru.

(4) What tasks does the Royal Australian Air Force Wing Commander, Michael Fanderlinden, as head of air operations for the PNGDF, perform in regard to monitoring and modifying use of the Australian-supplied Iroquois helicopters or other aircraft involved in operations in or around Bougainville.
(5) What information does the Australian Government possess about the reported massacre in the Aita village area in May 1992.

(6) What are the occasions of ministerial approval given for Australian citizens assisting overseas defence and security forces since the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978 was amended in 1987.
(7) What was the nature and extent of training provided by the Australian defence forces to the PNG personnel involved in the September border crossing into the Solomon Islands.
(8) What is, and has been, the nature and extent of training provided to the PNGDF and other PNG security forces by the Special Air Service Squadron.
(9) Does the Australian Government have any information about the nature and extent of any training provided to the PNGDF and other PNG security forces by the Malaysian and Indonesian Governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) We do not know how the Solomon Islands citizen to whom you refer was transported to a location within Bougainville.
(2) See answer to (1) above.

(3) No Australian Government employees or Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel performed any roles in connection with the events to which you refer. I am not aware of any action by other Australian citizens in connection with this matter.

(4) The RAAF officer to whom you refer performed the duties of Director of Air Operations in Headquarters PNGDF from 1989 to 1991. During his posting he was the staff officer responsible for the development, overall operation and efficiency of the air element of the PNGDF. He left PNG at the end of his posting in December 1991 and was replaced as Director of Air Operations by a PNG officer.

(5) The situation on Bougainville is unsettled and confused. There have been a number of allegations and counter-allegations of abuses of the civil population by various parties to the conflict. We have seen reports of the incident to which you refer, but because of the situation on Bougainville, we are unable to determine for ourselves the truth of these stories. Nevertheless, our commitment to upholding human rights is universal in its application and Australian Ministers have taken every opportunity to raise reports of abuses on Bougainville with the PNG Government, and made clear our abhorrence of abuses by the BRA.
(6) The question is more appropriately directed to my colleague the Attorney General; his portfolio is responsible for this matter.

(7) Australia has provided training to a significant number of PNGDF personnel since Independence. At the completion of their training, they have returned to the service of the PNG Government and we can have no influence on their future posting and employment.

(8) Two Special Air Service personnel, assisted by another ADF exchange officer already in PNG, provided a limited amount of training to a PNGDF special reaction team in August-November 1991. The team was formed by the PNGDF in case of possible security threats arising during the South Pacific Games. After the Games, it was disbanded.

(9) As an independent and sovereign country, PNG has bilateral relationships with many countries. The PNGDF has accordingly developed defence relations with a number of countries other than Australia, including Malaysia and Indonesia. What training they provide to PNG is properly a matter between PNG and the countries concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 3 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Senate Question on Notice No. 2373:

(1) Has the company which was awarded the Commonwealth contract for the supply of operator chairs, adjustable chairs, sequential lounges and operator seating (tender no. RT 5211 358 C1) recently been sold; if so to whom.
(2) What provisions of the contractual arrangement between the Commonwealth and the company awarded the tender allowed for the sale to proceed and why was the tender not readvertised.
(3) Was Ministerial approval either sought or given to the sale.

(4) Was the critical tooling associated with the provision of items to the Commonwealth under tender included in the sale; if so, on what basis can the Government expect the new owner of the company to adequately meet the tender criteria.
(5) Did the new purchaser of the company unsuccessfully lodge an application for the original tender.
(6) What are the guarantees to the Commonwealth that the new owner of the company will be able to comply with the tender requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) PC52/11358C-1 was the common use contract number allocated to Program 21 Pty Ltd. Program 21 Pty Ltd was one of six suppliers to the Commonwealth of adjustable chairs. This common use contract was recently transferred to Sturdy Components Pty Ltd.

(2) The General Conditions of Contract between Program 21 Pty Ltd and the Commonwealth required that the contractor shall not (whether under power of attorney coupled with an interest or otherwise) directly or indirectly transfer or assign the contract without the previous written consent of the Commonwealth.

Program 21 Pty Ltd was not able to continue to supply under common use contract and approval was requested to transfer the contract (to supply Program 21 chairs) to Sturdy Components Pty Ltd. As part of the transfer Sturdy Components Pty Ltd undertook to accept the existing obligations of Program 21 Pty Ltd under this contract. As the common use contract expires on 31 October 1993 and as the obligations of Program 21 Pty Ltd had been accepted by Sturdy Components Pty Ltd it was decided not to readvertise.

(3) Ministerial approval was not sought as it was not required. The appropriate Delegate within Purchasing Australia approved the common use contract transfer after gaining appropriate assurances that there were no legal impediments and that the previous contractual terms and conditions would be honoured.

(4) My Department has been assured by Sturdy Components Pty Ltd that it had made arrangements to ensure the supply of components and also has first option to purchase the tooling if it becomes available.

(5) Sturdy Components Pty Ltd was unsuccessful in its tender for adjustable chairs but was successful for fixed height chairs. Under the terms of the transfer approved by my Department, Sturdy Components Pty Ltd will supply the originally approved Program 21 Chairs.
(6) Before the request to transfer the common use contract was considered the Commonwealth required Sturdy Components Pty Ltd to:
demonstrate appropriate skills and financial backing to fill Commonwealth orders;
demonstrate ability to produce the current items under contract at the common use contract price;
agree to all the common use contract terms and conditions;
demonstrate ability to market and service the products approved for sale to the Commonwealth under the common use contract;
demonstrate ability to acquire components from approved Sub-Contractors;
honour the warranty on all items previously purchased by the Commonwealth under the common use contract;
supply only the items currently approved for supply on the common use contract with no substitutes to product or approved components being accepted without prior written approval of the Commonwealth.
Sturdy Components Pty Ltd gave these undertakings.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to investigations conducted by the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) into possible insider trading in Jupiters shares before that company was awarded preferred applicant status for the Brisbane Casino:

(1) Did the ASC also investigate the purchase of 1.6 million shares on 9 April 1991, the day after the Queensland State Labor Cabinet had considered suitable Brisbane Casino sites, and three days before the Cabinet decision on the three possible sites was announced.
(2) Did the Queensland Labor Party, through its company Labor Holdings, hold shares in Jupiters at that time.

(3) Were the purchasers of these shares linked in any way with the members of the Queensland Inter-Departmental Committee on Additional Casino Licenses, with members of the State Labor Cabinet or with individual directors of Labor Holdings Pty Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The question set out in the Notice Paper on 4 November 1992 referred to the date 9 April 1991. It is my belief that this was not the honourable senator's intention and that she intended to refer to 9 April 1992. The answer is accordingly given in reference to 9 April 1992. I am advised that:

(1) Despite preliminary inquiries, the ASC is not in possession of sufficient evidence or information which would afford a reason to suspect a contravention of a national scheme law or a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory, as is required by Section 13(1) of the Australian Securities Commission Law in order to initiate a formal investigation into share trading relating to Jupiters Limited. Therefore, the ASC has not formally investigated the purchase of shares of Jupiters Ltd shares on 9 April 1992 as the purchase of shares at that time did not represent an extraordinary trading pattern when viewed against Jupiters Limited's issued share capital of 192.4 million shares. However, if Senator Chamarette has any evidence or information relevant to this matter, I would be pleased to pass it on to the ASC.
(2) The ASC has not investigated this matter.
(3) The ASC has not investigated this matter.
